The main restaurant, The Tavern, serves cuisine far beyond my expectations in quality, as does the small, almost hidden sushi bar. I would happily return for any future business trip.
user_name:
JJacobs2015
New York City, New York

review_body: I had an absolutely wonderful stay at andaz. The breakfast was a great surprise even though it's a tad too pricey to eat every morning. I would absolutely stay here again, and would suggest anyone reading this do the same.

Our first stay at Andaz property and it was outstanding. We were traveling with our 10 and 11 year old and worried that hotel would be too posh and not child friendly. The opposite was true. A gift awaited them in the room and staff was very courteous and helpful. Pool was amazing and quite of hotel was second to none.

Andaz Tokyo is a very beautiful hotel with beautiful people.Breakfast at the tarven was very good. Burger at Beubeu was very good.Housekeeping team did a great job cleaning the room and performing night turn down.Thanks Fumi-san for the upgrade.Alistair, E Chef Shaun and Thomas were great at their guest service.Highly recommend to any tourist going to Tokyo.

The Andaz is a fairly new hotel in Tokyo. Rooms are very well designed with a beautiful view of Tokyo Tower especially in the evening. Service is good. Being on top of the Toronomon Hills Building has its plus and minuses. The plus is definitely the view but it is such a long way to go up (top floor) to the lobby and my ears popped every time! Then you need to take another set of lift to go to your room level. The lovely thing about the hotel is the complimentary coffee, tea and biscuits all day as well as wine and cheese during the early evening at the cavernous lobby area.I also liked the spa and the very clean pool area.However I did find the location to be slightly out of the way. Ginza and the Aoyama is a 30 minute walk away so most often we had to take taxis. Upon check out, there was a discrepancy between the room quote online and the actual amount I was charged. I complained about this to Mr Kiwame Kageyama, Assistant Front Office Manager and he immediately honoured my online rate by reversing the charges immediately. I would like to commend him for making me happy and satisfied client of the Hyatt group!

This is the BEST hotel - you won't want to leave it. I didn't want to, and I had Tokyo to see for the first time! The happy hour in the lobby is perfect after sight seeing. The food is amazing in the lobby bar, restaurant, room service (same as lobby bar), and the burger place downstairs. The gym, pool and spa are also modern and clean. The rooms are spacious and comfortable. The only minor drawbacks are: you need 2 elevators to get to your room because the lobby isn't on the ground floor, the pool had children when we went (it's a lap pool and not really conducive to swimmies), and there's usually a wait to speak with a concierge - it would be helpful if they had more on staff. But these are minor compared to everything else. We also loved the location - very close to the Ginza shopping district and the subway to other areas is near by. They even have a bus / shuttle service to the airport on your way back (DON'T take a cab - it's $300USD). There's no way you'll regret staying here - true luxury and affordable if you to do the pre-purchase pay-in-full option.
user_name:
DJLuciaLove
New York City, New York

review_body: Very nicely located Andaz Tokyo is one of the top hotels in the city. The hotel is located in 47-51 floor of Toranomon Hills building. If you are lucky, you can have a Tokyo Tower view from your room. Staffs are nice. Daily free snacks, softdrinks and wine at the lobby reception area. Softdrinks and snacks in the room are also free of charge. Of course it comes with a price tag probably not for everyone (US$~400 per night). But I do enjoy the hotel. Sleeping very well in the room. Hope I can stay here again in the future.

I would highly recommend this hotel. The rooms are fabulous and the entire property is well maintained and in the Japanese decor - clean lines; minimalistic; immaculate. The food at the restaurant is very good as was the music and instrumental artists. The service was excellent. Great location.

Andaz does a great job of providing consistancy of experiences on its properties around the world. However Andaz Tokyo is at the top of its experiences. The hotel is immaculate and staff is very very friendly. You can tell that everything has been very well thought out in its planning, down to the really cool light switches. The view of Tokyo tower is the best. Definitely will be returning on my next trip to Tokyo!

We spent three nights here, and the staff could not have been more helpful. The concierge team was able to assist us with securing reservations even before arrival, and the facilities are beautiful and well maintained. Easy access to the subway lines was important to us, and the Andaz gave us a chance to make the most of our time in Tokyo.

Clean room, very spacious, amazing views, comfortable bed, love the toilets. Food was also very good - loved happy hour in the lobby... always different treats! Staff was very accommodating and friendly - overall was a great experience that I loved coming 'home' to every night.

The Andaz Tokyo is simply not a top tier Tokyo hotel. The location is inconvenient, the service is lacking, and the room service was subpar. I just returned from a week in Tokyo, where I split my nights between the Peninsula (4) and the Andaz (3). The Andaz is simply not on the same level as the Peninsula, and here’s why. Upon arriving at the Andaz by taxi, our bags were unloaded to the curb, and the attendant disappeared before we could pay and exit the cab. We waited several minutes before someone returned to assist. After a very slow check-in, we waited in our room for a good 10 minutes before our bags arrived, which the attendant simply placed inside the door in the foyer, instead of the closet. At the Peninsula, you’re made to feel like Royalty. Everything is so smooth and efficient, our bags beat us to our room and were waiting in the exceptionally large closet. The Andaz lacks a front desk. When we arrived, we looked around an empty lobby for a couple of minutes before getting the attention of an attendant who ultimately checked us in. Multiple times during the process, she got up and left without any expectation setting of how long she’d be away, or what she was doing. At the Peninsula, we were escorted across the lobby to the front desk, for a quick and efficient check-in. We were then escorted to our room and given a brief tour of the many amenities. The room at the Andaz is new, and features a nice view. The amenities were lacking for such a new hotel. There were no USB ports next to the bed. There is no mood lighting or dimming, and many of the lights are connected in a way that limits control. In the closet/foyer, it’s basically all or nothing with lighting. The Peninsula is older, but the room and ambience is vastly superior. Each nightstand features multiple USB ports and plugs. The entire room can be controlled by panels on either side of the bed. Each light switch features “mood” settings, which dim the lights to a soft golden glow. The Andaz layout is strange where the foyer is oversized, the closet is small, and the actual room is also quite small. This is made worse with a couch that cuts across the entire window, blocking some of the view you’d otherwise see. The room service at the Andaz was significantly more affordable than the Peninsula, but the quality was terrible. When we asked for an ice bucket to chill a bottle of wine, it took about 20 minutes to receive a tiny ice bowl with tongs. I again asked for a bucket, which would fit the bottle of wine. Again, a 20 minute wait. The pool and spa is extremely nice at the Andaz, but the service is totally lacking. I mean that literally, there’s virtually no service when you go to the pool. The Peninsula has a beautiful pool and staff is always on hand to assist with anything you need. The location of the Andaz is inconvenient if you’re planning to adventure and return to the hotel at all during the day. The subway is a far enough walk that it’s not convenient, and taxis rarely know where the hotel is. When we did get taxis downstairs, the staff failed to help in giving the driver instructions. Instead we had to pull out our phones each time and wait for the driver to figure out where we were going. I know much of what I’m pointing out is a luxury, and of course I don’t expect these things at every hotel I visit. However, Tokyo 5 Star Hotel experiences can truly be something special, and I think it’s notable that the Andaz is not. It’s just a nice Hyatt. If you’re used to other Hyatt’s, you’ll probably think this is fine. If you have the chance to stay at the Peninsula, I wouldn’t even bother wasting a night at the Andaz. At least four our visit, the two hotels were the same price. We felt like we got a great value at the Peninsula, and we were ripped off at the Andaz.

New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel is pretty new so the hardward and facilities are nice with no doubt. But the service is very bad, we got bad attitude from the staff of check-in and breakfast restaurant many times. We waited for our luggages to rooms almost an hour, and when the staff sent them she just wanted to drop outside the door. For the breakfast, the staff was quite impatient to wait us checking the main menu, she showed an unpleasant face and suddently left without a word. Before Andaz, we stayed at Conard Tokyo for one night, everything was fine, there were welcomed tea and snack for my family when checking in. The staffs were all very warmhearted to us especially to the kids. We had stayed Andaz in other country before, this one was the worst. It is not suitable for family trip, it is not suitable for anyone who wants to have a pleasant travel in Tokyo, Japan.

It was not the least like last time we visited a few years back, hardware remains as good, but very unpleasant service attitude, service efficiency and effectiveness have dropped so much. We will not come back again

Great view if don't mind no Tower view.Staffs are great and room service is good.Staffs treat guests like VIPs .Though there is no direct access to the reception, the lifts are within walking distance.

everything is walking disatance including palace, tower and ginza so easy to go-around major distination for capital sightseeing with family but especially night seen bit difficult to find out jaspanese typical dining around accommodation

My family experienced the most humiliating and insulting check-in ever, because of my Globalist status.I had informed the hotel through my Hyatt Concierge that my wife would be checking in with her parents, and yet the hotel made all the effort to treat her as if she was lying and somehow unfairly take advantage of a third person’s account and Globalist status.My wife had merely inquired if free breakfast was provided, given my Hyatt Globalist status, at which point the hotel Associate started asking a series of questions such as “are you really married?” “where is your husband?” “where is your father going?” this after making my family wait >10 minutes. and oh... they did not even apologize when my wife asked why they were asking these questions, and instead started irrationally justifying their questions with “we are worried about your father’s safety” type of excuses.I had been extremely pleased with Singapore Andaz, so had asked my wife to give Tokyo Andaz a try, instead of Park Hyatt Tokyo which was her first choice. wow, do I truly regret assuming that all Andaz provide the same level of courtesy and welcoming experience.Based on other reviews, Andaz Tokyo seems to have a habit of NOT recognizing many of Globalist benefits. Should have checked first, before booking. Beware if you’re thinking about this property!!!

Pros:Beautiful room views, well appointed in-room amenitiesCons:Inflexible & thoughtless service staff (staff refused to change our reservation dates despite more than 48 hours notice; promised a room upgrade upon check-in but we never got it)We love Hyatt hotels (see my glowing review of the Park Hyatt Ho Chi Minh City), but we will never stay at an Andaz hotel again. Apparently premium pricing doesn't always guarantee premium service.

I normally stay for business but this time we had a four day holiday in Tokyo and it was superb. We had a lovely Tokyo Tower view room with all the usual great amenities. The pool is first class and as is the bar with its big Tokyo view and also complementary drinks for guests of an evening. The staff again were great especially Thomas Le Bretton. He was so so good at his job and looked after us wonderfully. Breakfast is terrific and decent value. Our only complaint was the complimentary strawberry chocolate boxes at reception as we ate too many! Thanks Andaz for a great trip.

We stayed here for two nights with our boys who are 8 and 10. We booked two adjacent rooms, and they were able to accommodate us easily. Pros:All staff professional and courteous. All non-alcoholic minibar contents are free. Unlimited complimentary milk available 24/7 for the kids in the hotel lobby. Nespresso makers in-room make for easy caffeine injection in the morning. Modern clean beautiful pool with towels, swim caps, goggles, robes, and slippers all provided. Great bay view from our room. Convenient store in the same building on the 3rd floor. Optional paid shuttle bus to Narita airport was comfortable and had a bathroom in the bus. Cons:Not so close to the nearest subway/train station. The cab to Tokyo Station is about $12 USD.

There are other hotels that are more centrally located for tourists like us, but we wanted to try the Andaz since it looked beautiful in pictures and the majority of the reviews were positive, bordering on gushing. We stayed a week, and a lovely week at that. It felt like home, even though our actual home looks nothing like the hotel. The attitude and the personable manner of the service staff was very welcoming - as if they understood how the place and the design could feel intimidating to some people so they amp up the personal touch. There's a small spread for guests in the lobby (aka living room?) in the morning and evening. It wasn't a huge buffet, but we started looking forward to it after a few days, if only to sit or grab a soda. Also nice that they have cappuccinos in to-go cups anytime of the day. I was even able to take an entire gallon (liter?) of orange juice to the room when I wasn't feeling well.Our room was design-y without being impractical (ok, a bathroom door did get in the way of the dresser or the fridge, but that's nitpicking. Also the hotel was quite generous with wood panelling. It was everywhere. Someone must really like wood).The bed was comfortable, next to it were light and window controls. We had a desk, a bench, a coffee table and still lots of room to stretch out and walk around. The large bathroom had a shower and a soaking tub (it was mirrored, we didn't use it). Coffee, snacks, and some drinks were complimentary from the mini-fridge, and there was also a free 'handy' phone for us to use during our stay. Tip: you can use it as hotspot if you'd rather use your own cell phone.The amenity set was beautifully presented. Yukatas (for two) and slippers were in the closet. They had a number of toiletries that they can send to room or purchase for you.Outside, the lobby, the hallways, the restaurant, and lobby furniture contributed to a modern yet cozy feeling. It felt Japanese yet international. The spa/pool floor was a wonderful place to spend some free time. Lots of baths with jets and at various temperatures, with shower amenities and an attendant present.There was one subway stop next to the hotel, and others a few minutes away. It may be less accessible by public transport than others, but the trade-offs are worth the walk or cab ride. A walk to Ginza or the Imperial Palace was only 15-20 minutes, bordering some parks and greenery, too.

ezraulo
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed there for new year holidays and it was an excellent choice. The rooms were spacious and had good closet space. Concierge was very helpful in organising day trips and providing detailed instructions to navigate through sites. Restaurant had some good selection of beef and finally the bar on TOP of hotel was simply spectacular with some great cocktails.

Overall my experience at the Andaz has been wonderful. I believe they pride what they do there. Really enjoy my experience in Tokyo. It was quite hard to find a hotel that allow two adults and two children. We upgraded with a really nice room.It had an amazing view.

Perched high above Tokyo, the hotel offers impeccable views of the city with equally attentive service. The hotel is new or feels it. The rooms are large and very comfortable with beautiful bathrooms and massive soaking tubs. Great pool and spa. The breakfasts were delicious with lots of choice of flavors and cuisine. We really enjoyed our stay and would be very happy to stay here again.

We stayed here for 4 nights during the Christmas holidays. We have always had wonderful stays at Hyatt properties throughout SE Asia and this one did not disappoint. The staff and the concierge were very helpful during our stay. The breakfast buffet had a wide variety of food and was delicious. The hotel had views of the city are spectacular and the pool and spa facilities are top notch. Within walking distance to the train station and lots of restaurants nearby. Definitely would recommend for a luxury stay in the city.

Don’t be fooled by the hardware of this hotel. The software in terms of customer service needs to be improved fast! Our check in took 30minutes, room was not cleaned after our first night, room service order for my children’s dinner was wrong & the staff at the restaurant struggled to communicate with us.

My stay at the Andaz hotel was top notch. Definitely one of the most memorable hotel stays of my life. The view of Tokyo from my room was beyond gorgeous especially at night with all the city lights and then of course in the am when I could see Mt Fuji!!

Andaz Tokyo is true to its promise by offering local taste and flavour in a luxury setting. It's use of wood and minimalistic decor with a sizeable room makes our trip very comfortable. The location is convenient and we can go everywhere we wanted to visit within a 20 mins cab ride radius. The view is spectacular as promised and the staff is flawless. One caveat is the vicinity has a lot of construction going on but detected no noise and no obstruction to view.

From the amazing customer service skills, to the amazing views, the overall vibe you get is that this is more than just a place to stay the night. Personally I enjoyed the rooftop bar for great cocktails and food. The fitness center is also a great place to be with great equipment and overlooking Tokyo.

Stayed at the Andaz Toranomon in Tokyo. It is a great hotel with amazing rooms which is fairly large for Tokyo hotels. As the rooms start from level 47 to 50, all room comes with sweeping views of Tokyo. The complimentary drinks in the evening is a nice touch. Swimming pool is also awesome.

We left our cases with the door staff and were taken to the 51st floor to check in, where we sat at a lounge table with a cup of tea. We booked a corner room and it was on the 47th floor with views over the Tokyo Tower. Gorgeous room, green, white and wood decor and five huge floor to ceiling windows. Bed, large table and sofa, chair, tv in front of the window. Large, wood panelled bathroom with a huge circular bath, separate shower and Toto. Lots of Argan toiletries. WiFi was free and quite quick. Lots of sockets, both sides of bed. Fridge-type minibar with free soft drinks replenished daily including water, coke, orange juice, green iced tea and chocolate and a kettle with small china mugs. The free wine and canapes happy hour in the lounge is a nice touch and there are also doughnuts / bagels and juices supplied for breakfast.

Lovely hotel with a upmarket ambience. Room had a good view of Tokyo tower. Service is good. We only ate breakfast at hotel which frankly I will rate so-so, nothing special. Would be great to have more local specialties. The evening lounge snacks is a nice touch.

We stayed five days in November, and would gladly have stayed five months.To have a drink in the lounge while the jazz trio played felt like being on a movie set. The food was good, too. The concierges were also very helpful, obtain concert tickets for us. I would never stay anywhere else in Tokyo

The property was beautiful with amazing views from the room overlooking the city. Staff was very personable from the moment of arrival until our departure. Only problem we had was at the Rooftop Bar where the server very rudely refused to split our group's bill. Despite the bar (which I would not recommend due to their poor service), the hotel was splendid and I would recommend staying here if you are visiting Tokyo either for business or leisure.

My partner and I stayed here for almost a week during our visit to Tokyo from the 28th September to the 4th October. The hotel was exceptional and the breakfast of the best quality - There was a constant attention to detail and going above and beyond expectations. The person who cleaned our room during our stay honestly needs commending and I personally wrote her a note which I left in the room as acknowledgement of her efforts. I visibly saw the presence of the Head Chef during the morning buffet multiple times and also had cocktails on the roof a few consecutive nights and the view was amazing. I will be staying here again in future when I visit Tokyo and have already recommended you to other friends and colleagues for their holidays too.

I enjoyed my stay. Grwat views from my room 5019. Could see the tower, Mt Fuji and the Bay. Great breakfast buffet. The closet area/space is a bit tight for teo, but we managed. Lication was good for walking, subway and cab travel.

Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: My family and I stayed at Andaz Tokyo Toranomon Hills for two nights on the last part of a family holiday, traveling Japan. While we enjoyed traveling through Japan and seeing all this magical country had to offer, this hotel took the prize as one of the highlights of our trip! From check-in with extremely personal service to the fine details of the hotel room itself, we were completely blown away and really wish we had more time to spend there! This was, by far, the best hotel experience we have ever had. In closing, I travel A LOT. Saying this was the best hotel experience I have ever had says A LOT. We have been home from our vacation for less than a week now and are still raving about this single experience, which says a lot. Really looking forward to a return visit, if we are ever able to get back!

The Andaz Toranomon Hills is one of my favorite hotels in the world because of its interior design. The use of warm wood in simple, elegant ways in the room -- and especially the bathroom -- is nothing less than gorgeous. The clean and interesting decor in the common areas speaks to many Japanese traditions in a most sophisticated way. The spa floor is equally appealing. The interior architect for this hotel should be very proud. The room rate is very high, and the cost for breakfast is prohibitive for most except business travelers. I think that's a shame because offering a reasonably-priced breakfast to guests paying over $400/night would go a long way. But I can't deduct a star because frankly I would love to live in this hotel...that's how much I like the design.

First the positives: the room I had - a King Deluxe with a view of the Tokyo Tower - was very comfortable and cocooning, with the sort of nice touches you'd expect at this price point, e.g. free non-alcoholic drinks from the minibar, climate control that maintains exactly the correct temperature silently, a very comfortable bed, impressive and spacious bathroom and walk in wardrobe. What was less than perfect was the overworked and slightly disorganized front desk/concierge. Small hiccups like not getting a call back from the concierge's desk when I asked for help confirming my onward flight; when I called back 15 minutes later the operator said that the concierges were still helping other guests, which is possible but honestly it seemed more likely that they don't have a way of according guests who call the same priority as guests who show up in person at the concierge desk. When I called back the operator at least took my flight details but after a further 10 minutes elapsed with I ended up calling the airline myself; while I was on the line with the airline, the concierge called back to say he had contacted the airline. Similarly, checkout left a bit to be desired: I found myself standing with 3 other people waiting for the single reception clerk, until a second one showed up - this was at checkout time, so it is hard to understand why only one receptionist would be there. There were other small signs that staff, while unfailingly pleasant and evidently eager to please, were simply overworked; indeed, a couple of employees confirmed this to me in separate informal conversations. None of the very minor glitches I encountered during my brief stay left me in tears or indeed seriously detracted in any way from my time at the hotel, but they ought to be addressed by management.

We chose to stay here primarily because of the design. We had heard that it was popular for its design. The other 2 hotels we were considering were the Parky Hyatt and the Aman, so take that into consideration when reading this review. There is not a surface that is not touched in this hotel--even the ceiling panels in the restaurant are lacquered. The public areas are interestingly designed, but it seems like value engineering resulted in cheaper materials being used. i would have preferred better materials used more sparingly. The result, to me, is a bit theme park-ish. The rooms are very comfortable. I love the long built in sofa along the window wall, which allows for both desk and living room seating. There are old school flip switches for the lights and blinds, which give it a retro feel. There is a nod to Nakashima in much of the furniture (sofa, chairs, tables with butterfly details). The bathroom has a huge tub and shower, and the dressing room is nicely appointed with yukatas and japanese slippers. However, the entry area is cluttered with too much furniture and too many shiny surfaces, which results in a bit of an obstacle course.Service: the desk-less reception experience is meant to provide a speedy check in for guests. This is not the case in Japan. Both our check-in and check-out were much longer than was necessary. I think we got the manager for both, and perhaps he is a temporary staff person? Service in the restaurant was just ok, and service in the spa was also slow.

r7k
New York City, New York

review_body: Hotel design:One of our primary reasons for staying here was the design. We had heard that it epitomized the best in new hotel design, and had surpassed the Park Hyatt as the new 'it' hotel. I liked the design overall, but the materials felt a bit cheap. I think the design could have been edited more, so that more $ could have been spent on the areas that mattered. The rooms were very comfortable. I liked the wall to wall sofa at the window wall, that allowed for both desk and living room seating. I liked the wall panelling, which recalls rice paper screens. The entry way and bathroom together take up a lot of square footage. I think there is wasted space in the entry--the number of components that are there make it feel a bit like an obstacle course. The bathroom is well appointed, but could use a second sink. The wet room is very nice, with its oversized round tub. Also a nice touch is being able to access the walk in closet from both the bathroom and the entry hall--but this is not a necessity. Again, I would rather have a second sink than this feature.Service:The service at this hotel makes it feel like a 3 star hotel. In the US, the lack of a reception desk is supposed to make the Andaz feel less stuffy, and be a more efficient way of checking in. In our experience, checking in and checking out at the Andaz Toranomon Hills took much longer than was necessary.

We loved this property! Rooms were very large, the views outstanding, and the service impeccable. The pool and fitness area were amazing. Highly recommend. It's close to the metro so easy to get around the city.

Being a new city hotel, we were not sure if the service would be good as some of the more traditional hotels we've stayed in Tokyo previously. We were welcomed as a Hyatt World member and given a cold drink as we checked in. After a long 8 hour plane ride and a drive from Narita, this was a very thoughtful way to check us in.

Yes, it lives up to its reputation and then some!When asking friends where to stay in Tokyo, the most common answer is “if you can get in...the Andaz”. In the heart of the most intense city in the world, on the fifty-first floor is an oasis. Stepping out of the cab, my bags were taken by a welcoming team, and I was escorted to a pair of automatic doors leading to a richly paneled elevator lobby that wisked me to the hotel lobby. This is not your father’s Hyatt. When you step out of the elevator, you will likely be greeted by a team member inviting you to a drink in the lounge. I had the great fortune of arriving during happy hour, where there was an array of wines an appetizers in a very comfortable lounge area. There is no registration desk or check in counter. Team members bring registration to you while you sit comfortably. After this easy checkin, I was shown to my fiftieth floor room. It was night when I arrived and the room had an amazing view of the Tokyo skyline. But that was nothing compared to the next morning, awaking to a crystal clear view of Mt. Fuji.The room itself was not big, but I am sure there is a great variety of rooms. The bathroom, however...well phenomenal!!!Andaz takes service to a high level. They don’t ‘nickel and dime’. The lounge has complimentary snacks and beverages all day. Mini-bars include snacks and non-alcoholic beverages complimentary, and a few alcoholic drinks if you like.room controls for drapes, lights etc are advanced. But the essence of the room cannot be conveyed in a post. The room itself, like the rest of the public areas of the hotel, is a showcase of carved wood art; yet warm and welcoming.Food in the restaurant was very good, and no detail overlooked in service. Special call out to team member Thomas who took great joy in meeting and talking to as many guests as possible, and ensuring that every need was met, every desire exceeded.Location is convenient. I’ll warn you, this hotel is not inexpensive. It is a five star hotel in the heart of an expensive city. I’ve stayed at other hotels in the area, but from now on, I will only be staying at the Andaz.Thank you Andaz team for a fantastic stay.

Fantastic place. My #1 selection, #2 being the Grand Hyatt.Great staff, food, room and facilities. Excellent gym.One of the staff even helped me photocopy and cut up business cards as I'd ran out during my trip....

An experience that pampers guest and envelopes them in Japanese hospitality and culture. Honest and sincere staff go the extra mile to make our stay memorable and relaxing. Rooms and views amazing! Just stay here!

This was our first experience with the Andaz Hotel Brand but will not be the last. This very comfortable and luxurious hotel makes for a great home away from home. The staff are friendly, the amenities are fantastic and the homely feel of the hotel is a rare find.The hotel lobby on the 51st floor is a focal point for the hotel, a gathering area, a community lounge, a comfortable zone for a coffee, wine or sparkling sake (all on the house) and the most amazing live music in the early evenings.Our room was located on the 49th floor and had the most extraordinary view of the Tokyo skyline. The room itself is divided into two key areas, the main sleeping area and separate dressing, robe and three way bathroom. A very generous sized room for Tokyo. All rooms also come with their own Nespresso machine and free mini bar (excluding alcoholic beverages).A great hotel, very comfortable, the best bathrooms and overall an extremely comfortable and homely hotel.

Second post for Andaz Toranomon, which continues to impress us with each visit. Overall, for the price, this is easily the best hotel in the world. Such impressive facilities and staff. I wrote a longer review below and upon each visit, the hotel simply gets better. The highlights are the breakfasts, the views, the spa/gym/pool area, and the location (controversial). The only downsides would be the beds (we find them slightly too firm) and the pool area when busy. The PH does have a better spa but is otherwise below Andaz in all regards. I found the front desk extremely helpful with reservations, and easily changed, added and cancelled for us without issueWe have only experienced excellent service here.

I had been traveling for 3 weeks for business. This was the best hotel on my journey. It is beautiful, comfortable, and well staffed. A perfect stay except that it took forever to get coffee in the morning. I hope to return.

I was excited to stay at the Andaz; the reviews and photos of the hotel made it sound amazing. The location is convenient, the room is spacious with a large bathroom area. They provide complimentary amenities in the room and in the lounge area. I did not find the staff to be helpful or overly friendly.

Only reason I am not giving it a 1 star is because the rooms are clean, the bathroom is nice, and the bed is comfortable. Unfortunately what could have been a nice stay, resulted in the worse service ever received in Japan, and I’ve been to Tokyo well over 30 times. The staff at the restaurant was deceiving and condescending. Upon bringing the bad experience to the manager on duty, he patronized me with an insincere and well rehearsed “ I am so sorry, I am so sorry”. No action taken to correct the fault. Less sophisticated establishments in Tokyo have far better service and manners.

It's an understatement to say that this hotel is amazing. You are celiac and need gluten free? This hotel has you covered. The hotel staff went above and beyond to make us feel like at home. My husband is celiac and every morning, they made gluten free pancakes for him. We booked the twin bedroom and while beds are smaller than full beds but a little big bigger than twin beds, we slept in one bed and were cozy. The bedrooms are ample and super clean. I loved the long table where I could put stuff everywhere. The rainfall shower? amazing. I would stay in any Andaz in the world. This place is worth every penny.

Stayed at the Hyatt Regency, Grand Hyatt and Andaz in our most recent trip. Andaz, by far, was the best in terms of location, amenities and comfort. Location: although you’ll need to take two different sets of elevators to get to your room, walking through the Toranomon Hills building that transforms into the ultra-modern area part of the Andaz was delightful. There are 2 nearby subway station that takes ~10mins walking (including time to get through hotel).Amenities: there are always drinks and snacks set out in the lobby area, such as fresh fruit and chocolate croissants in the morning, hairabo gummies and sweets in the afternoon. Globalists get breakfast at the Tavern. Canapes are set out for 2 hours with a bartender shaking up a signature drink with wine and a Kyoto beer in the evening. Two refrigerators as well as a full coffee/tea set is tucked in the back for access anytime. Lap pool is gorgeous along with full access to separate steam and whirlpools at the spa. Comfort: we were in the Large Tower King and although not considered a suite, the square footage was just as big as our suite at the Hyatt Regency. Rooms and amenities were far better. Will pick the Andaz over the Grand Hyatt for future stays!

Without doubt this is an excellent hotel. It covers the top 7/8 floors of a 52 story building with the most spectacular views over Tokyo. I was there on holiday and found the location a bit distant from the areas that a tourist might want to visit but if I had been there for business I would have rated it 5 stars. Breakfast was a fantastic assortment covering both local and European tastes. The roof bar was expensive but worth having a drink there for the terrific night view. The room was spacious and very well laid out with a both desk and separate sitting area. The bed and linen were extremely high quality as were the towels. The closet was walk-in and provided drawers and hangers to spare. The bathroom had both a circular bath and a separate shower. The toilet also was in its own space and was the modern heated automatic type that Japan is known for. The seat comes down and flushes as you walk away. Everything about this hotel spells luxury and I would recommend it especially for a business location.

Unique hotel in the 50th floor with breathtaking view Beautiful decor Amazing rooms with all amenities including Bose speakers mini bar with free snack and non alcoholic drinks and specious tub Wonderful breakfast Go check the roof top bar Complimentary evening drink and snacks

Our room had a particularly amazing view of the bay, but I can easily imagine that all rooms come with pretty nice views with such location/height. What I loved the most was the impeccable modern design that's functional and aesthetic throughout the hotel (not only the room but all the common areas including the library and the reception. Excellent and attentive service, complimentary non-alcoholic beverages all day and (once again highly aesthetic) complimentary cocktail hours were extra perks.

The hotel is modern contemporary oasis,the style with wood paneling and large single wood panel table represent the modern Japanese style . The layout of the room is large with well stock bar with snacks which is all free except for the alcohol. The bath tube is hug round which i found useful soaking. The gym and pool are close after 10pm which strange if you want to cater to business people. Shops in area the does not really cater to foreigner outside of convenience stores maybe 1 or coffee shop. If you want to visit and try the local cuisine is better you look else where. Outside of house keeping made my room late, strange gym hours and very few foreign cater business . This could of been a 5.

Hotel is located in a quieter area, but generally convenient to various metro stops. Hotel is modern, and lobby and rooms are situated on high floors with rooms offering a good view of the city. Rooms are clean, modern and generally spacious (particularly for Asia). Hotel offers a nice complimentary happy hour with drinks and small snacks. The complimentary non alcoholic drinks and snacks in the room were a nice bonus. Service at hotel was nice and concierge service was very prompt and helpful.

great central location, beautiful and refined design where modern Japan meets the best of contemporary architecture, friendly staff, delicious restaurant, breathtaking views over the city. The breakfast is phenomenal. Not to be missed, it is part of a great Japanese journey!

Excellent environment with poor customer service experience at front desk. No doubts for its spacious room equipped with a round tub bath. Comfortable bed with nice view from the room. However, poor customer service experience at front desk would drive me away to stay again.

We had a lovely time at Andaz Tokyo. The lobby sits on the top floor of 51st. The view up here is AMAZING!We were lucky to be given a room suite on level 50 with the Tokyo Tower view (be mindful the hotel shares the same building as the residential, there’s lifts taking you from ground floor straight to level 51). I have never seen Tokyo from this vantage point of view. And I loved it! To me, it looks like a super cute version of LEGO city :) everything is awesome!Andaz rooms are sophisticated, immaculate and minimal. Stylish with bespoke furnishing, bringing the traditional Ryokan interior into the 21st century. My favourite has got to be the round bathtub. Andaz provides beautiful rice scented bath salts (and I mix it up with body wash for a bubbly effect).There’s Nespresso for coffee lovers, with a variety of pods to choose from. Loving the tea as well.Soft sheets for our King size bed. It’s spacious, and the toilet lid has a sensor that opens up automatically. That was a surprise and delight for me :) Japanese toilets always excites me hehe. And not forgetting the automatic shades and blinds, just one switch!Staff are very kind and helpful. It was a wonderful time. Thank you guys Tokyo Andaz! I share images of my travels on Instagram. You can find me on @hellomissmay. Happy travels everyone! Tokyo is always a good idea.XMay@hellomissmay

This was our first visit to this Andaz. We have been to three in the US. This was the best one! Although we have been home for two weeks now, this hotel and our room is still top of mind everyday. We hated to leave. Our room was a corner large king and it was on the 50th floor. We felt as though we were living on top of the world, or at least on top of Tokyo! Service here is just the best Bathroom had two shower headsand a deep soaking bathtub. The cherry on top of the icing was the Bose Bluetooth speaker. Everywhere you go, there is beautiful artwork all around. Even the hotel room had some sculptured lamps and ceramic pieces. Views are of the Skytree, Tokyo Tower, Hibiya Park and the Imperial Palace. Of course it all looks very small form the 50th floor!

This hotel is awesome! The rooms have amazing views, the pool is extraordinary and the staff are genuinely caring and polite. We spent 5 nights and could have stayed much longer. The free drinks and finger food during happy hour (it actually goes for 2 hours) were a nice bonus.

Spend 5 nights in Andaz Tokyo. Excellent services when checkin. Very detail explanation on hotel facilities and services. Room is very clean and tidy. Able to see Tokyo tower everyday. Around 5 mins walk to Toranomon station. Breakfast is good but would be bored when you tried more than 3 times. Within business area so lack of entertainments around. The facilities, rooftop bars and restaurants in the building would be enough if you don’t want to go far.Staff is very friendly and helpful. We lost a small bag in express bus when going to day tour on the other day. The staff able to check and call for us using our limited information provided. At the end, we are able to get the bag back. It is great when we cannot speak Japanese. Checkout is the same person did checkin for us. Not sure if it was organised but it’s better experience as customer perspective.

I recently spent ten nights at this excellent hotel situated in a business district in central Tokyo. The metro station Toranomon is a pleasant short walk (a few hundred metres) away. A short ride takes you to all the famous areas of the vast city with Ginza being ”next door”. In the immediate proximity to the hotel there are also residential properties, lots of restaurants (if you explore the side streets) and the ever present fabulous convenience stores which really live up to their name. Visiting them are an important part of the travel experience and is highly recommended!The hotel occupies level 37 (spa, pool and gym) and levels 47-51 (rooms, suites, lobby and restaurants) in the 52-storey Mori Tower in the mixed-used development Toranomon Hills. The hotel offers terrific views over Tokyo and gives you a real sense of the size of this metropolitan area which stretches as far as you can see. I stayed in a room facing the Imperial Garden and (in the far distance) the Tokyo Skytree and it was one of the most impressing views I have ever seen! Since the tower is considerably taller than the surrounding buildings the view from all the public areas are equally jaw-dropping.The interior design is restrained, elegant, minimalist, has a cool modern vibe and incorporates Japanese design elements. The room was very well appointed with a huge round bathtub, amenitys with seasonal fragrances (went from summer to fall during my stay), a very comfortable bed, complimentary minibar (excluding items with alcohol) and house-keeping was impressively metoculous. In the lounge area adjacent to the lobby complimentary beverages and snacks are available throughout the day with a choice of wine and canapés in the evening. The main restaurant serves a beautiful and delicious breakfast buffet with Japanese and Western food. Try the Japanese breakfast items with grilled fish, rice, miso soup and pickles! The gym is large, has great views and is better equipped than most hotel gyms. The lap pool is equally wonderful.The staff throughout the hotel offers attentive thoughtful service and really makes you feel welcome. The breakfast staff, lounge hosts and spa/pool/gym staff deserve a special mention but in fact everyone you meet is delightful.In summary, if you have the opportunity to stay here I highly recommend it! As with all luxury hotels you need to spend an extravagant amount of money. Here you get very good value for your spending.Swimming in the pool high above the city after a day of exploring fantastic Tokyo, followed by a glas of wine in the lounge, is a luxurious vacation memory I am very fortunate to have!

The Andaz was fabulous. We had a great stay and wished we could have stayed longer. Very welcoming for children, too. The staff provided excellent assistance with dinner reservations, etc. The breakfast buffet was delicious. Free water, juice, and soft drinks along with happy hour was a nice addition.

Andaz is located in the new tower - second highest building in Tokyo, on purpose. The developer did not want to race for the highest but rather focuses on offering g the glimpse of the future of Tokyo. And what a job they’ve done. You can enjoy the nice art, restaurants and shops in the building with excellent views of the iconic Tokyo Tower. Conveniently located within 5 minutes walk from a couple of metro stations.The hotel offers spacious and luxury rooms, top notch service. Enjoy the welcome drink and happy hour at the reception everyday. Concierge was so helpful in making reservations for us. Wonderful swimming pool and gym. We throughly enjoyed our stay and didn’t want to leave!

We chose Andaz because of the cool design. Hotel is located in a business district with no connection to the metro. The nearest subway station, which is the Toranomon station, was just a few minutes away by walk.Some reviewers mentioned about the poor service they experienced upon arrival but it was totally not the case for us. The moment our car arrived, bell staff came to help with luggages. We were greeted and escorted to the lobby on 51F. Coffee was served while we were waiting for the friendly lady to do the paperwork. Check in was done swiftly and we were shown to our room. Staff at the front desk were particularly helpful in making dining reservation as well as giving direction. Everyone spoke fluent English and personable.We had the Tower View Room for 4 nights. Room was nice in size and it was stylishly decorated. We love the working table in front of the floor to ceiling window with a postcard view of the iconic Tokyo Tower. We only wish there were two sinks in the bathroom. Non alcoholic beverages and snacks at the mini bar were free. They even provided a phone for the guests to use outside of the hotel. We did not need the phone but it was a very thoughtful idea.We tried several dining venues including BeBu for happy hour, the Lounge for a light dinner, the Grill for lunch as well as the Sushi for dinner. I gave separate reviews for our visits. The experiences were fine except the Sushi dinner which was disappointing. What we looked forward to was the breakfast every morning. A satisfying buffet spread with menu of items cooked to order. Food was very good in quality, service was attentive. We also enjoyed visiting the common area at the lobby where they served free coffee and snacks throughout the day. From 6-8pm, canapés and alcoholic beverages were also available.We enjoyed our first stay at Andaz and the service level truly exceeded our expectation. Unfortunately, our dinner at the sushi restaurant as well as our treatments at the spa were underwhelming.

I travel a lot for work and for vacation trips, and Hyatt is my go to brand. This is my fourth Hyatt stay, with previous visits to Amsterdam, Singapore and Scottsdale. All four Andaz stays have been excellent, and I'm looking to try additional properties in the future.Our time at Andaz Tokyo was the result of a family vacation. When booking the trip, I noticed the Andaz was really the only Hyatt property in Japan that allowed guestroom occupancy for three. Knowing the strict enforcement of the occupancy limits in Japanese hotels, this was a huge benefit. The hotel is part of a much larger complex, but I didn't find the entrances difficult to manage at all. Yes, you do need to travel up to the 51st floor lobby, and transfer to an elevator down to your room. However, having the hotel at the very top of one of Tokyo's highest building, with spectacular views the guestrooms, is absolutely worth that minor inconvenience. We found the staff to be very helpful. Any requests, including an evening room refresh, were met promptly. The décor and finishes are really well done. We found the entire experience very impressive. The location is 10 minutes from several subway lines, which we didn't find difficult. It's also within walking distance of the Imperial Palace area. There are a number of convenience stores in the immediate neighborhood, and the tower contains numerous restaurants and a great convenience store in the lower floors.Thank you Tokyo Andaz for a really fine experience.

This has to be one of my best hotel experiences. The hotel is in a great, though sleepy, part of town. The rooms are upwards of 47 floors so the views are great. The decor, styling and ambience make it a great place to stay in. I loved the play of wood in the rooms. Being Tokyo I was expecting smaller rooms l, but they specious and well appointed. Everything in the minibar is free, except the alcohol and I think more hotels should go their route. The breakfast buffet was great too. The only issue is getting to the rooms. You have to go up to 51st and come down again in another lift. But that’s a small pain for this great hotel.

from the high ceilings in the public areas to the relaxed check in and the swimming pool, breakfast and staff, everything about this hotel is first class. The rooms ooze understated class - well designed but not fussy at all. And the views are breathtaking as the hotel is higher than everything else around. Would return to this or try another Andaz without any hesitation. Hyatt have struck a great formula here!

I loved the tavern, a perfect place for a cocktail and late night foods. It has the perfect view. I had sashimi and a steak, both were delicious. Reservation isnt necessary. There are also lots of good spots for taking pics.

Andaz Tokyo is the best overall I rated in terms of location, decoration of rooms, service, breakfast and view.Lobby is situated high up in the building. Most people may not spend time there after got off the lift but you can actually see views very far away.The staff at check in counter is always friendly and efficient.Breakfast on the top of the building where they have nice view and good quality food.Of course, service always good.Room is good size in Tokyo. I had suit a few times. Some junior suites are very nice. Don’t forget to search those books and decorations inside the rooms. They are so good.Of course, when we recommend a hotel, it’s easy for someone to say it’s excellent or good but I’m a very demanding person and had stayed over 400 hotels worldwide. In order to rate Andaz Tokyo the best, so from lobby to room, breakfast everything has to be excellent.Shower is strong, good shampoo, toothbrush. Various pillows regardless you want hard or soft, they got in the room. Mattress is good, you don’t feel tired afterwards. Great views from the room. Extra large bed. The lighting in the room is also comfortable. Bluetooth speaker in the room and plugs for various countries. Everything is so thoughtful.I’m a very demanding person but I’m happy to stay there a few times. There are shops at lower floors too. So you can grab some drinks or stationary. Don’t forget to search the Doraemon within the building and outside of building, there are a few hiding somewhere. Doraemon may not means anything to some of you but it was a character from a popular Japanese cartoon. I grew up with this cat.

The hotel is beautiful but the staff were quite rude at times. I found this incredibly surprising considering we were in Japan; a country known for it's good manners and attentiveness. Besides our problems with the front desk staff, we saw on 2 separate occasions when other guests were furious with the front desk staff. The area is quite far away from everything so be prepared to travel a lot to get to where you are going. For the amount of money Andaz Tokyo charges, you can find many other options all over Tokyo. The only good thing here that separated Andaz from other hotels were the free drinks and snacks in the lobby.

My family stayed in Andaz Tokyo in May. For me, everything the hotel offered met Hyatt quality. One thing quite special was that the guest room had a smart phone that included unlimited data usage. We carried the smart phone during our self-guided Ginza tour, comfortably searching on line for all destinations and directions.

One can only dream of the perfect hotel. Great service with a luxury lobby, amazing food and outstanding facilities. How about a comfortable room with maybe a view?Two words. Andaz Tokyo.Never have i ever felt so fascinated with a hotel. Truly a remarkable experience and i recommend this hotel to anyone who wishes to experience an escape from the real world. The eye catcher throughout my stay was the art represented within the building itself by Shigemitsu Kotaka, Tetsuya Nagata and Charlie Whinney. Each with their own distinctive art work.All in all, it was an amazing experience to me.

My friends and I have been trying to stay at all the 5 star hotels in Tokyo. Andaz, based on the reviews we saw, appeared to be something special so we were quite excited to stay there. Surprisingly, we were not impressed. The check-in experience was impersonal - we were sat in a waiting area with no windows. Every other hotel we’ve stayed in had an impressive lobby with a view so this was odd. To be fair the Park Hyatt check-in was in a room with no windows but the one-on-one service and the walk through the lobby made a difference. The room itself was quite nice and the bathroom was the best I’ve experienced. Some weird design elements in the room brought it down. A giant wooden table in front of the window made the room seem small (even though it wasn’t) and blocked the view. Additionally, the walls folded in to cover a foot of the window on either side, also making the room seem smaller.

I still use a lot of review sites including TA, Google, Yelp - however not all of them are that trust worthy unless you have something always highly rated - 4.3/5+ for food, and for staying at a place I would only look at 4.5+/5. Well I can say that this place is fantastic considering how many hotels I stay at for work and mostly for leisure. I do believe of the Hyatt hotels this is one of the gems and should be considered above the Park and Grand here also in Tokyo. There are arguably better hotels in Tokyo and Japan, many with excellent service and location, however the view here is unparalleled. Thank you. Pluses: Blackout shades, killer views, pool and gym, free minibar (non-alcoholic), free smartphone to use (only dialed once to try and it works as US calls are free). Will highly consider here again on repeat trip.

Unfortunately we ended up at Andaz on a rather stormy and rainy evening but we had a blast nevertheless. This is the highest rooftop bar in Tokyo, so the view (especially at night when the whole city lights up like some crazy, colorful festival of blinking dots) is amazing. The terrace is very nice, but due to the weather we snuggled up inside at the bar. The bartender did a great job explaining us all we wanted to know about the gin tonics on the menu (some great GT's available here!). I ended up drinking the cherry blossom GT, which tasted delicious. The place is not cheap, but totally ok taking into account what you are getting for it (view, excellent service).

There isn’t a word in the vocabulary to describe how good this hotel is!I will recommend to anyone who wishes to come to Tokyo to book in Tokyo Andaz.My children and I were treated like the most welcome guests,staff attended to small details,best breakfast ever!!

The hotel was disappointing, NOT because it is bad, but it is not what it advertises. I am a business traveler that likes to enjoy spa after a long day, well, I am not sure these is the “French themed spa” you would expect...especially in Japan....The room was nice, but very simple for a Hyatt, that sells same price as the Grand! Staff is young and not helpful or knowledgable at all. No helpWith suitcase saying you must change elevator twice to get to your room. No service as business center or hair salon offered, BUT If you want a free croissant with coffee in the morning and snack at night to save and you don’t care the rest this hotel is for you.

Great location. Beautiful hotel. Extremely good customer service. I I I. Would come back for the luxurious comfort and quiet. Loved the happy hour with live jazz,good wines and nibbles. . The view from 48 th floor room was incredible

From the front desk staff who is very attentive to every other detail, this hotel shines bright. Always willing to help and lend a helping hand in a suggestion to a problem.Granted on the 1st day after a long flight we decided to splurge for breakfast and had read it $33 a person, but now $36, plus gratuity which I thought there is none in Japan except in large hotels, it was about $90 for 2.Nice to have complementary water and soda when it is 95F out everyday, and a happy hour for wine and apps.The health club and pool were really nice even though we only use them twice of 5 days.

This was our 4th stay in Andaz Tokyo in 3 years, and we were not disappointed. The entire design, look and feel, and service at Andaz is amazing. You would think all of it would get old after our 4th time, but my wife, baby and I were happily satisfied. The complimentary lobby refreshments that change every few hours was an improvement from the last visit as well. One thing that was disappointing was that we didn’t receive a nicer upgrade to our room (my Discoverist status had already given us a room with a park view). I had wanted a larger room as I have been a loyal customer for the past few years. Regardless, this continues to be one of the best hotels in the world!

I have reviewed this hotel several times in the past as I consider it my home in Tokyo.This review is for two stays back in October 2017 and two stays in January of this year.I continue to stay at Andaz Tokyo for my visits to this wonderful city because of the outstanding level of service I continue to experience. It is rare to be so loyal to a hotel but I cannot even look at any other when I come to this city.I was sad to learn from Andrea Lobo that she was departing to work in another location with Hyatt. She took care of me on every single stay and she will be missed! Nonetheless, when I stayed here and she wasn't available, the team succeeded in offering the same level of service Andaz Tokyo is known for. It was nice visiting so often and I can't wait to be back I wish I knew everybody's name to include in this review but sadly my memory fails me. Here are some names I do remember: Miwa, Rie, Kasumi, Alice and Chery from Andaz Tavern breakfast service. I am sorry to those whose names escape me now but I can assure you that if you choose Andaz Tokyo you will not be disappointed by a single interaction you may have with staff.Toranomon as a neighborhood keeps evolving and I have seen it become more welcoming to guests over the years. I love how secluded and local you when exploring the little streets. It is also a very short walk to Ginza. Even after so many years and so many stays at this property the hotel still feels fresh and new. All in all, Andaz Tokyo is my favorite city hotel in the world!
user_name:
Sebastian P
New York City, New York

review_body: Located not far from Ginza area, but it's quiet area. Transportation is convenient, about 8 minutes walk to the subway station. I choose here since my friend highly recommended and I'm glad that I didn't miss it. It is one of the most highly-rated Andaz properties, that worth everyone has nothing but good to say. Got a Tower view king room, I really love this room since the natural materials based design. And the view of Tokyo Tower, impressive!

A truly beautiful hotel with breathtaking views of the city, Tokyo Bay and Tokyo Tower. Luxurious rooms with wall to wall windows (with electric shades), thoughtful amenities (including a phone with data to use during your stay!) and a great shower and deep tub (We were in the Large Tower King, a very spacious corner room with amazing views, especially at night). Unique wood decor throughout the hotel. Excellent and genuinely warm service throughout. Our room was ready on arrival even though it was well before check in time. A special thanks to the amazing chef Shaun, and the entire dining staff, who were especially accommodating of our dietary restrictions and made us feel at home. Our honeymoon arrangement in the rooftop bar was also really nice and thoughtful. Only slight negative is location but the train was not too inconvenient, and well worth it. We hope to be back one day!
user_name:
Jason S
New York City, New York

review_body: Our family of four (parents plus kids age 11 and 13) stayed one night in early August 2018 on a long layover returning home from Europe to Hawaii. We chose the hotel because it was one of the few available hotels with rooms that sleep four. We were jet lagged, and Japan was experiencing a historic heat wave, so we spent the middle of the day bathing and relaxing in our air-conditioned hotel room, 5014. The room was spacious, spotlessly clean, and cleverly designed to take advantage of the panoramic view of Tokyo Bay and the Rainbow Bridge to Odaiba. Unlike many hotel rooms, the main space is bright and well lit. The walk-in closet and bathing area are large enough so our clutter didn't spill into the main room, where a long natural wood table and chairs sat in front of the huge window. Andaz provides Internet, snacks and non-alcoholic drinks for free in the room, so we made green tea and relaxed, watching the Yamanote and Shinkansen trains leaving Tokyo Station. The following morning, we ordered a delicious room service breakfast that featured large tasty portions. Although the location was a bit far from the tourist trail, we were able to walk to Zojoji Temple (増上寺), where several of the Tokugawa Shogun mausoleums are located. It was the perfect location to sleep and recharge for the flight back to Honolulu. We would gladly stay at Andaz Tokyo Toranomon Hills again.

My husband and I stayed here for 3 nights in the beginning and 1 night at the end of our Japan honeymoon and had the best experience. It is hands down the most beautiful hotel we've ever visited, and the service is incredible - so warm and helpful. For our first stay we were upgraded to a beautiful room with a view of Tokyo tower. The gym, especially the pool, is absolutely gorgeous. The rooms themselves are beautiful, especially the bathrooms - we made great use of the giant soaking tub. I also want to compliment Minjoo in particular. She was such a huge help while we were there and made a reservation for us at Kyubey (also highly recommended!). We will absolutely come back when we are in Tokyo!
user_name:
juliakat312
New York City, New York

review_body: This is definitely one of the best hotel in town, with a great location and personnel really responsive to try and help having the best experience ever in Tokyo.This is a brand new hotel, with large rooms, great viee and wonderful breakfast ! Mini bar and lobby orders are complimentary and people are really dedicated to improve customer experience...

I have stayed at the Andaz on a number of visits to Tokyo and it is definitely my favorite spot in the capital. The hotel offers majestic views over the whole city, including the royal palace and the port. The hotel is five star and offers all the amenities you would expect from one of the leading brands. The pool is a must visit where can relax and exercise whilst looking over the city. The rooftop bar is worth a visit in the evening, again to take in the cityscape over a cocktail.

A very pleasent stay, excellent and fast room service, food quality and presentation, design hotel, quiet but the same time fun with activities inside the hotel. AMAZING VIEW!!AMAZING SERVICE!Definitely I will comeback

For a modern minimalist feel but with a traditional Japanese twist, this hotel cannot be beaten. The interior designers must have been given a free reign. Serenity throughout, a total enjoyable experience.Amazing views from 47th to 52 floors, easy access to transport. Great breakfasts, but also good local cafes and restaurants in the same building or across the road.Spoiled, couldn't stay anywhere else in Tokyo now.

My family of four stayed for one week at the Andaz Tokyo Toranomon Hills. We were thoroughly impressed with every part of our stay. Our room, overlooking the Tokyo Tower, was large by Tokyo standards, with a huge shower/bath and floor to ceiling windows on the 48th floor. There's no need to pay to visit any tall towers in Tokyo, as you have a marvelous view, and if you're lucky (as we were) you'll even see Mount Fuji in the distance if the air is clear! The staff of the hotel were attentive and helpful in answering our questions about public transport and tourist highlights. The breakfast buffet was pricey, but in our opinion worth the money. Fresh fruit/berries, eggs cooked to order, pastries, with variety on a daily basis. The dinner menu was somewhat limited and also expensive, but quite typical for Tokyo standards. Pool facilities were large and importantly, allow children (many do not). Location is a bit out of the way, but it's an easy 5-10 minute walk on a quiet street to the nearest metro stop. Also nice is that it's not in an overly touristy neighborhood, so you're a bit away from the hustle and bustle of areas like Ginza or Shinjuku. We will most definitely stay here again if we ever visit Tokyo!! Thank you, Andaz, for the lovely stay!

First, checkin to the hotel is not done through the typical counter but instead they sit you in a table style and go over the stay and reservation. The room layout, though very nice, seems smaller and less of 5-star quality compared to other high-end hotels we stayed. The carpet doesn’t appear to be clean especially for a Japanese hotel where they pride on cleanliness. When I pointed out the room appears smaller than our previous hotel, the staff emphasized that the bathroom is larger than most. For me i prefer to have a larger sleeping room than a large bathroom.I really like the gym and pool. Equipments are new and room is good size for workout. The pool has a jacuzzi, hot bubble and cold pool to invigorate and jump start your body.

My family just spent five nights in Tokyo at this hotel and it was wonderful. The four of us stayed in one room (not always easy to find in Tokyo) and there was plenty of space of two adults and two kids (13 and 11) in a double twin with one rollaway bed. The bathroom was huge and has a large closet area with shelves and drawers. We did not take the subway, but all our cab rides were fairly reasonable and we were in lots of different neighborhoods in Tokyo. The best part of our stay was the amazing customer service- the front desk helped with making dining reservations, directions to various points of interest, etc. The only nit I would say is that the pool area is very hot and humid. My kids went swimming every day, and the pool is lovely, so it would be nice to have a portion of the seating area with some fans or AC. Otherwise, it was a perfect stay and I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo.

Perched above Tokyo with a perfect view of the Tokyo tower, my young family were stunned by every aspect of the magnificent hotel. From the arrival to the departure it was one unique experience after the other. My only concern being that I didn’t want to leave the hotel to explore. My kids will have this memory forever

We loved this hotel and found it a great value compared to the other options we were considering (Ritz, Aman and Park Hyatt). Hotel ended up being one of our favorites! Concierge service was fantastic and helped us find a fantastic private guide for 1.5 days. We booked two deluxe rooms with the Tokyo tower and rooms are new (2014) with very nice bathrooms. Very functional. We loved the sofa which was more like a window seat. Service was great and there is a fantastic workout area with views. The location is off the beaten path a bit but we loved it as we learned to navigate the subway system and used car service to get to the train station with bags etc. The bar is fantastic with great views and a nice casual menu. We did the fine dining one night and it was delicious but of course expensive but again we thought appropriate to the value of the quality, view, and service. Rooftop bar is nice but the view from our rooms and the lobby bar was just as nice. Since the hotel is at the top of the building it feels like a hidden gem from street level. Thank you Andaz! We hope to be back!

Gorgeous room on the 50th floor with a full frontal view of the Tokyo tower. You are so high up, there is no need to pay to go up the tower. Views of Tokyo bay and rainbow bridge. Has to be the best view room we have stayed at in Japan. Room itself is beautiful with wood accents, and traditional Japanese wet room tub/rain shower. Food is expensive but very good. Roof top bar also very expensive, but good experience. The spa was very good too as were the workout facilities. All in all an excellent hotel with amazing service.

Being the 3rd time I've stayed at Andaz Toranomon, service and quality have become quite a norm for me here. So this time my review would be more focused on things the traveller can/should do to better enjoy their time at the hotel.Take note that you're staying at a boutique hotel in Tokyo, so it definitely isn't one meant for you to stay at if your pure intentions are to explore all of Tokyo, and find a place to return to after a whole day of exploration. Although the location of the hotel is comfortably well within walking distance of both JR, and Tokyo Metro, if not there are always taxis you can take downstairs. In my image, the purpose of the hotel is for you to enjoy a lazy morning, followed by a brief outing, then returning by sunset to enjoy the breathtaking view from either your room or the rooftop bar (you should definitely take advantage of the free cover charge as a staying guest).For mornings there, take advantage of gym (although it would be best to avoid it from 8-10AM, from my experience people go there specifically to take pictures and not work out), the swimming pool, and the hot tub in the locker rooms.For those who are there to seek the amazing view of Tokyo, as with most Andaz hotels around the world, they offer room upgrades (via email) a few days prior to your check-in. Generally I pass on these offers as I don't really care what view I get now, but if you want a view of Tokyo Towers, go ahead and take the offer for a great view at night.While I admit the bathtub orientation is a bit odd (a round bathtub doesn't quite make sense without jet streams), the seasonal bath salts that they provide definitely make it worth while to bathe in the tub at least once during your stay (currently its summer bamboo). The silver lining of the bathtub situation could be that there is no emergency drain at the top of the bathtub, so feel free to will it to the brim and be completely submerged in it (don't waste too much water though).All in all, Andaz Tokyo Toranomon maintains its excellent service despite the recent influx of tourists entering Tokyo. My suggestion to the hotel would be to increase the employee amount during check-in/out hours, while to those that are considering staying at this hotel...to arrive before check-in time, drop off your luggage, and go out and explore Tokyo for your first day before...and then returning around 4-5pm (that way you avoid the 3pm check-in rush) with hopes that your room will be ready and suitcases have already been delivered to your room.

Booked with AMEX Fine Hotels & Resorts so I got a room upgrade to Tower view king and free breakfast at the Tavern. A great room with dark wood accents, nice seating area next to the bed, with magnificent view of Tokyo. Nice welcome amenity of tasty eclairs from the Pastry Shop. And free minibar and snacks plus Nespresso, except for alcohol.Bathroom was very nice also with seasonal amenities in a Japanese bento box styled layout. Huge circular soaking tub next to rain shower, and a nice Toto washlet.Weird to have dark wood for the sink surface, but it’s beautiful although one crack has already soaked up some water and started to buckle - so may need to be resealed soon.Lovely breakfast buffet at the Tavern, with great fruit selection and small but decent offerings from western and Asian cuisine. You can also 2 items from the a la Carte menu. I’ve never had eggs Benedict on croissant before - interesting! Again, heat view and great service, but could be a bit of a wait for the excellent espresso drinks.Had drinks and snacks at the Rooftop Bar. Nice space, good music, some cool spaces to hang out, diverse and hip crowd of young professionals. Had some sushi in the small bar that maybe seats 8 at most, and karaage and sake outside in the breezeway lounge overlooking the night time lights of Tokyo.Great infinity pool at the AO spa with great city views. The locker room wet areas are nothing special - so chose to use the hot tub at the pool area instead.The only negative is the location. Toranomon Hills is a new development still under construction area the neighborhood, and the nearest metro station is still a good 3+ blocks away walking thru a narrow alley with lots of people on tight sidewalks — I had to walk on the street most days. And the walk to the taxi area is crazy long — you can see the taxi stand thru the glass wall. but you have all the way down long hallway to get there. The porters could at least see you coming, and offer to help you a few minutes later.Also the floor logistics is crazy: from the closest entrance from Metro at 2F, you have to first take the escalator down a floor to 1F, and then take elevator to 51F, in order to check in and then have to take another elevator to your room and the AO spa.Summary: great view from nice rooms, good service esp at the Tavern. But not the best location to easily get around town.

wonderful views over tokyo from the 51st floor reception & rooms just a few floors below. the service was excellent, and the rooms large, well appointed, and stylish. all round wouldn't hesitate to come back. if i had to force a more cautious comment, i think the room service menu could be more varied.

A beautiful hotel. We had stunning views of the city, and the staff were highly attentive and pleasant. Had not stayed in an Andaz before but would look for one again. Only negative is that the location is slightly away the middle of things, but this was really not a problem. Great experience.

We arrived at the property around 5 pm local time. We were welcomed in the small first-floor lobby and escorted to the main lobby which was on the 50th floor if I recall correctly. We were warmly greeted by an associate who offered us a beverage and asked us to have a seat while he processed our check-in. About 5 minutes later we had our keys in hand and were escorted once again to our King room on the floor below.The room was modern, large and comfortable with a fantastic view of Tokyo Tower. The bathroom was large with a soaking tub and shower segregated from the sink area. As with other Andaz properties, the non-alcoholic beverages and snacks in the minibar were complimentary and included local options in addition to the typical Coca-Cola products. The internet in the room was complimentary, fast and reliable.The location of the hotel was easily accessible via a short cab ride from Tokyo Station (about 1000 yen). We only had one night at the property so did not explore the area much. We did walk from the hotel to the Tsukiji fish market and back. I wouldn’t describe it as an easy walk, but it was a nice morning and with comfortable shoes, was doable.The property always offered complimentary water or juice in the lobby as well as fresh fruit. We didn’t have a meal during our short stay at this property but we did have a drink at the rooftop bar on the 52nd floor. The bar is enclosed so you are sheltered from the elements and offers fantastic views of Tokyo. The only negative about this property was the need to use multiple elevators r to get from one place to another. It was really only a minor inconvenience and wouldn’t prevent me from choosing to stay at this property again.

We really liked our room and service was great. We had a great view of the city. The pool, spa area was amazing so we made sure to find time to soak in the hot tub after walking 10 miles a day throughout the city. Location was ok and only a short 10 min walk to the train but u are not near tourist areas.
user_location: Simpson Bay, St Martin / St Maarten
user_name:
TootsieM
Simpson Bay, St Martin / St Maarten

review_body: This place was awesome. Let’s start with cleanliness, everywhere from lobby to room was well cleaned. Like properly cleaned. Even my drawers seem were dust free Lor. Most other hotel staff very lazy - always skip all their drawers lah, books and crannies , but this one power, everything was properly cleaned. My army sergeant won’t be able to find any issue with this place lolThe room also has free mini bar for all drinks except alcoholic, no I don’t bluff u wan - free mini bar, juice , water , vegetable juice (must be healthy mah) and even water and sparkling water. Yes - sparkling water leh! I learnt that day that I actually like sparkling water.If not enough - just go to the lobby. The lobby has 24 hour free drinks. Yes - also neber bluff u, coffee , tea, milk (if that’s ur thing) etc.. if only that had Milo I would be a happy man. What’s better? Between 6-8pm got free Wine , Sake and canepés. make me so happy I almost cry sia : finally a hotel that gives all guests abit of that “club floor” treatment.Service was as good as you’d expect from Japanese service.
