Location was great, a lot of things to makan. Quite near train station also. It’s only a short walk to Ichiran which is open 24 hours so that’s also good. Car park there is 3000 Yen a day, not cheap ... but ok lah, central business district leh. Some more near to Ginza.Overall I’d recommend this place if you have the budget for it. It greatly improved our Tokyo experience.

Usually stay at Park Hyatt or Grand Hyatt under the group but wanted to try there new addition - Andaz Tokyo. I stayed at the corner suite with panoramic view of the city featuring Tokyo Tower and the palace. Very modern design with a glimpse of the traditional japanese wooden furniture. Love the high ceiling. The view of the city from the hotel is amazing. Staffs are welcoming but some of them don't understand english much although they are helpful.

Stayed here for work, and was very pleased with how everything turned out. Location wise, Toranomon hill is not exactly tourist friendly, but taxi can get you places easily, metro station is about 10 minutes walking. A very peaceful sanctuary, luxurious and conteporary. Room was very big (for Tokyo standard), and love the design (very Andaz), the free non-alcoholic mini bar (yet another Andaz touch), and the daily aperitif at the lobby from 6-8pm.As expected from any Hyatt properties in Tokyo, an excellent service. They really know how to make you feel special. Good breakfast (tried room service), the rooftop sushi restaurant, and the restaurant on the lobby floor. Would definitely come back.

Hands down one of the best hotel experiences I’ve had anywhere. On a family vacation with our teenager. Location is a little away from the tourist districts such as Shibuya, but this was not a problem at all. Extremely safe business district with stores, restaurants, and foot traffic at all times of day and and night. Many restaurant options in the building or nearby. Subway is a 5 minute walk thru nice neighborhood. Subway in Tokyo is great and what most people will use to get around and perfect for hitting all of the sightseeing spots. Hotel felt intimate- the staff all know your name and there was never once a wait to be able to get assistance w restaurant booking, directions, or any other questions. Wonder perks such as complimentary espresso machine, soft drinks, juices in lobby 24/7. Pastries in the morning in the lobby and wine and snacks in the evening. Room is also stocked with complimentary drinks and snacks. Full complimentary gym and infinity pool use with a view of the city on the 37th floor. Spa looked nice thou did not try it. Rooms are good size for a Tokyo hotel and all with a view. Bathroom is huge and luxurious. The wonderful front desk staff really made our stay in Tokyo enjoyable and easy with their attentiveness. Would not hesitate to stay here again.

Andaz Tokyo has magnificent view in the middle of Tokyo. There are a number of constructions going on nearby but currently the building which Andaz Tokyo is in is the tallest building and thus the view is fantastic.

My wife and I stayed here for four nights. We arrived very late, around midnight, so quickly checked in and shown to our room.We had been upgraded to a king room with a great view of the Tokyo Tower. The room was large and beautifully finished. Large bathroom with shower and bath and a fridge with plenty of water and soft drinks as well as snacks.Very comfortable and quiet room and the blackout blinds ensured a good nights sleep.The hotel is in a great location for exploring the city within walking distance of the Imperial Palace and many other sights. Five minutes from the subway so easy to get to Ginza if shopping is your thing.Every evening between 6-8 there is wine available in the lounge and some small snacks. The food in the hotel restaurants was excellent and there are also beautiful pastries available from the shop on the ground floor.Everyone we met from the hotel was friendly and helpful and nothing was too much trouble.Highlight was meeting the Geisha and Maiko on the Friday evening. We will definitely stay here again on our next visit to Tokyo.

Excellent choice of hotel and most friendliest throughout in Tokyo. English spoken by all staff. Some great little local estaurants nearby. Toronamon Koffee witin the complex served great coffee and alternative breakfast choice

The Andaz Tokyo has some of the best views of Tokyo and the best designed hotel rooms I have ever seen. It is luxurious without being ostentatious. From Narita Airport, the arrival is seamless: take the Narita Express to Tokyo Station, and then take a 10 min cab directly into the building's porte-cochere from where you and your bags will be whisked to the 51st floor lobby for a no-line check-in and then without delay to your room.While traveling throughout Japan, I managed to accumulate more souvenirs than I could fit in my airline luggage, but the staff came to my room to help me ship the excess home – even though it was 2am when I was packing! Absolutely fantastic service. A couple nights at the Andaz was the perfect way to end my trip across Japan.
user_name:
wm250
New York City, New York

review_body: My girlfriend and I stayed at the Andaz at the very end of our trip to Japan. We extended our trip by a few days and decided to give the Andaz a try since we were a bit underwhelmed by the hotel we were staying in up until then.The Andaz did not disappoint, it is very stylish and in a nice location. Rooms start from the 41st floor up I believe, so you cannot really have a bad view. Our view was towards the Tokyo Tower which was very nice. The room was very spacious and we both agree that the bathtub was the highlight of this hotel. It was extremely large for a tub and reminded us more of a hot tub than a standard bathtub. We also really liked the design of the lobby and elevators. In fact, we took pictures of the pretty designs in the elevators. The staff was friendly and made us reservations at two very nice restaurants. However, the food in the hotel was mediocre. We ordered room service one night and found it very average.I think this hotel was a nice way to end our trip and I would definitely recommend it to people traveling in Tokyo.
user_name:
taylexvhors
New York City, New York

review_body: The Andaz is a great brand, and this new hotel definitely holds up. The hotel is beautiful, fairly conveniently located (Tokyo is huge), the rooms are fantastic (definitely recommend a room with a view of the Tokyo Tower). My only 'gripe' would be the concierge services. Tokyo travel REQUIRES great concierges, as almost no restaurant takes online reservations, and most 'bespoke' experiences require local booking. The Andaz does not have concierges, as apparently they consider all their employees to be 'hosts,' and any of them can help. While this is a novel concept, a true 5 star concierge is a local EXPERT - has amazing contacts, and can truly listen to a guests requests/desires, and make specific recommendations. We had a lot of interaction with the hotel in setting up restaurant reservations (they did a great job, as we had a very specific list), but beyond that, it was very obvious that they were just recommending from a list of 'approved' recommendations. That being said, I would definitely recommend this hotel, and would likely come back.

I asked some questions when booking, but no response, also no upgrade room for the globalist.room and location is good, of course the cost is high.if you ask me whether I will recommend this hotel, frankly I didn't know.

Nothing to fault - five star plus experience in a (much appreciated) quieter region of Tokyo - but still walking distance to major transportation hubs (Shimbashi station and just a little further Tokyo station). Our room, overlooking Tokyo tower, was stunning and spacious.The room included aa nespresso coffee machine (with water filled every morning, details!), Bose surround sound speaker, plenty of storage space and huge walk-in rainfall shower with large round soaking tub. Everyone we encountered was gracious and helpful. The gym, spa and pool are excellent. There is a roof top bar with amazing views. Our rate included the breakfast buffet which had excellent Japanese and western options. A daily evening "happy hour" in the lobby lounge (51st floor) with free wine, sake and canape was appreciated after a long day of walking and sightseeing. We previously stayed at the Andaz Maui and had high expectations - this urban property exceeded them all. Looking forward to making this our home base upon return.

I stayed at the Andaz multiple times for an extended period during my project in Tokyo. I was very impressed by the refined and elegant design of the hotel, spacious rooms and the quality of the service. Centrally located and close to Ginza and Shibuya, the hotel sits at the 51st floor of the Toranomon Hills tower. The rooms are very spacious with a walk-in closet and stunning view of the city. The breakfast buffet was impressive with a large variety of food and rooftop bar offers one of the best views in the city. The staff also makes every effort to make your stay as pleasant as possible. The amenities are also best in class. The hotel offers a beautiful pool with city views, the gym is nicely equipped with state of the art machines and the spa is super relaxing. Highly recommend!
user_name:
simonyc2015
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel really is a treat...everything is 5 star. The service levels are amazing, nothing is too much trouble. The food is excellent. The breakfast was an absolute treat. My room was beautiful, very clean and stylish. Really couldn’t fault anything. Will certainly be back again.

Having visited several Andaz properties in the US, I was expecting a pleasant stay but boy was I far from the truth. This property is in a completely different league, and I was absolutely blown away! The hotel is stunningly gorgeous. I had the most basic room type, which was huge and extremely well appointed. The bathroom and shower were fantastic. The bed was one of the most comfortable bed I slept on. There is this enormous table facing the windows that are great to work or have in room delivery. All the rooms start on the 47th floor so you will never have a bad view :). All Andaz offer free mini bar snacks and soft drinks in room, but in the US you'll usually have a bottle of water and a cereal bar, at best. Here, you have 5 or 6 different drinks, and several very high quality snacks available and a Nespresso.The service was exceptional, although very formal which is the norm in Japan. Everybody was uber courteous and pleasant. And when your room is serviced, they even refill the water tank of the Nespresso! It's the little things...The breakfast, whether in room or in the restaurant, is phenomenal. The buffet is amazing and the food is actually delicious (and not as expensive as I would have expected). Just skip the sushi restaurant on the top floor, it's not worth it and there are far better options in the city.The one negative of this hotel is location, especially if you're coming for leisure: it is a business area so there is nothing to do around and the subway is several blocks away, so keep in mind that it's not Shinjuku.All in all, it was absolutely phenomenal and I would look forward to staying there again.
user_name:
clem92
New York City, New York

review_body: Spacious and stylish room in a brand new building, with stunning view on Tokyo. Facilities, staff, amenities: everything is made to ensure you'll have a wonderful stay. Once you have experienced staying here, there is no turning back.

The bedding is not very comfortable needs improvement as a 5 star hotel.The staff can speak gpod english. Hotel room is a good size for two people. The location is quiet but a fair walk to the station.

My fiancée and I for our first Japan trip, wanted to experience all the different perspectives of the Japan culture. Of course, one of those perspectives we wanted to see was an experience of luxury, premium and comfort. As a side note, we needed a good home base to get prepared for our engagement shoot (we needed space to get makeup and hair prepared). First of all, the location of the Andaz epitomizes the idea of how success and luxury go hand-in-hand. I am only mentioning this because for our first impression walking in was entering amongst an atmosphere of many driven, business dressed individuals. The Andaz is in the same building of other companie(s) where we regularly saw people in business attire whenever venturing out during our stay. Of course, the Andaz itself exceeded our expectations on every level and I can summarize it with three main parts: 1. Staff Interaction, 2. Room amenities, 3. Food & Beverage. 1. Staff Interaction at Tokyo Andaz was inviting, welcoming and responsive. We really felt like they cared about us. From a welcome drink during check-in to a thorough explanation of all the room features (there were plenty!), we definitely felt very welcome. They even made it seamless for us by booking our airport shuttles at check-out! Oh and I almost forgot, complimentary happy-hour where our cups were never empty! Nice one, Andaz family!2. Room amenities were among the best we've seen. In-room Japanese snacks and beverages were a nice touch. Of course, our favorite things about the room were the rainfall shower, spacious tub, Bose Soundlink speaker and premium Toilet bidet. The room was also perfect for my fiancée to get ready for our photoshoot. It was spacious enough for her to get her makeup and hair done and also included various mirrors (vanity, full-length, close-up) Also, as an amateur photographer myself, the view of Tokyo Tower was a bonus!3. Food & Beverage could be found in the same building and in surrounding area. We loved the Toranamon Koffee shop to start off our adventures and the in-building Family Mart for our convenience needs. There were also in-building restaurant options that we regret our never-ending adventures didn’t give us enough time to try. We did however try some local ramen easily found in the surrounding area and it was delicious! All transportation options were easily available, from taxi to nearby subway. We humbly opted for the latter for our adventures with no problem.Lastly, we’ve be fortunate to have stayed at Andaz Maui and now Andaz Tokyo. To compare the two would be like comparing Excellent with Excellent. I will say that the top-notch experience was consistent through both, although I may have to give the overall to Andaz Tokyo a very slight edge. Like comparing an Lamborghini to a Ferrari, it really stems from personal preference. Still would love to go back to either.Overall recommend for the best hotel experience that hands-down sets the bar for other hotel experiences and is worth the splurge. We hope we are fortunate to be able to stay again!

We were speechless when we got into our room at the Andaz Tokyo. The huge room was BEAUTIFUL, the nicest bathroom EVER, and the view was like nothing I had ever seen before. It was breathtaking! The hotel's pool was also exceptional, with those same amazing views. We ended up having dinner at the Andaz because honestly the hotel was so beautiful and the views so amazing we didn't want to leave. And that turned out to be an excellent experience as well.The staff was also extremely accommodating and helpful with all questions--top notch.We have travelled pretty extensively and I can honestly say this is the most luxurious and beautiful property we have ever stayed at. Totally worth the splurge.

I would highly recommend the Andaz. It was one of the best hotel experiences I have had in years of constant business travel. The service was excellent, the room was spacious with outstanding floor to ceiling views/windows, the room service was top notch, and bed/pillows as well as the shower/bathroom were all 5-stars. In addition, the gym had excellent cardio equipment with phenomenal views.

We loved this hotel. From the epic and cleverly designed rooms, with floor to ceiling windows that make you feel like a visiting master of all you survey, to the effortlessly multi-lingual staff and the small touches like complimentary mini-bar and amenities, size perfect bath robes and slippers for everyone in the family - this is a hotel that instantly creates happy memories. Do make time to visit the breathtaking pool area (swimming in the clouds anyone?) and do plan to come down early before going to dinner to enjoy the very generous lounge snacks and complimentary wine and cocktails every evening. The multi-lingual staff were fantastic from check-in to check-out and we were only disappointed once - when our request for a dinner suggestion led to a restaurant that was in the same building - we were hoping for something a little more local, a little more insider-y... but perhaps we are being a touch too fussy.Do stay here. You'll be glad you did.

The view of Tokyo Tower is spectacular! Room feels light and airy with all of that glass. Finding the rug needs to be updated/changed. All else was wonderful. Breakfast buffet is extensive. Martinis at night time are perfectly made. Easy checkin and check out.

We stayed here for the first time earlier this month and had a great time. We were put in an Andaz Large room and it had an absolutely beautiful view. Our daughters loved to look outside and see all the blinking lights! We also have a perfect view of Tokyo tower and the stroller we were able to borrow from the Andaz was super convenient. The concierge was very helpful but it did not alway seem like they were as familiar with the area as we would have expected. However, they always made sure to find the correct information if they did not know it themselves. We enjoyed breakfast each morning at the Tavern. There was a reopening going on so we got to have a bit of variety with the breakfast being served in a different location each morning which was fun for our girls. I will never forget the delicious Iced cafe latte I had daily! The room was great with adorable little kimono and bath sets for our daughters and they loved taking a bath in the large round tub. The Argan toiletries by Cote Bastide are my new favorite! Everything was pretty convenient but I will say that that elevators left much to be desired as I dreaded going in every morning and having my ears pop. My daughters hated it and I'm not sure why it was so much pressure! Regardless, we loved our stay!

This hotel was one of the best hotels we've stayed at. Everything from the room, to the staff, to the inclusive amenities were flawless and on par if not better than other five-star resorts. The lobby is very spacious with lots of tables and seating for guests to relax. The hotel hosts a daily happy hour with wine, sake, and a few light hor d'oeuvres. There is also mini pastries and juice every morning. There is also coffee bar and refrigerator stocked with juice, sodas, and water 24/7 for guests, which we thoroughly appreciated after a long day of sightseeing and exploring the city.The room was excellent and had a great configuration where we never felt cramped. The guest rooms are located on floors 47 - 50 of the building with great views. There are also free non-alcoholic beverages and snacks from the mini bar, which was a pleasant surprise. The only minor consideration is the location. As others have mentioned, the hotel is located in the financial district, so the weekends do quiet down substantially. If you plan on taking public transportation, it's about a six minute walk from the subway line and a 10 minute walk to the closest JR rail (Shimbashi) station. This didn't bother us a bit, but is something to consider if you have young kids or grandparents traveling with you. And lastly the staff were wonderful, friendly, and go out of their way to make you feel welcome and accommodate your needs. I would recommend this hotel in a heartbeat!

First time ever in an andaz and must say it's a very hip place that knows how to cater to business guests. Service was very efficient and friendly, truly Japanese. The design is great, very minimalist. I really enjoyed dining in their restaurant on the ground floor which had a cool vibe and amazing drinks too. Location is near Tokyo tower and convenient.
user_name:
elninotoro
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Andaz Tokyo is a modern, hip, casual hotel. Our room had a very nice clear view of Tokyo Tower. Younger clientele would enjoy this hotel more - it is 'casual' and 'hip' and unstuffy. ///Breakfast I remember last year when I came to Andaz, I really enjoyed the selection of items they had at the buffet. This time around the food was very limited and the selection seemed to have little or no rotation (food sat there for a while), which shows that other guests weren't pleased with the selection either. Last year they had premium grilled fish like miso glazed black cod but this time around it was more standard salmon or mackerel.///The RoomLast year our suite faced the Tower and there was a reflection of the sun from one of the buildings that glared directly into our suite making it extremely bright. It was uncomfortable during the day. We had to keep the blinds drawn most of the time.The room had a modern circular bathtub in the shower. I enjoyed the waterfall rain head and dorn bracht faucets. The layout was a little awkward with the mirrored folding doors but I appreciated the design risk they took. They were skimpy on the products (only left one shampoo, didn't refill for turndown) and the bath products were not a well known brand like The Peninsula (Oscar de la Renta) or Shangri La (Bulgari Green Tea). The room did not have enough table space for two people to comfortably eat together. ///The LobbyThe lobby area was nice and airy with high ceilings. They had cocktail hour where there would be live music playing at the bar and some wine and little chips that you could enjoy at the lobby.  ///The Lobby RestaurantWe rarely got service with a smile at the Andaz. I had some business contacts come over for drinks and dinner at the lobby restaurant and the server was rude. He was very unhappy serving us. The food was just OK, it was nothing special but the price would seem it should be. ///The LocationThere was a lot of construction around the Andaz last year and now it seems like there is even more construction. Taxi drivers in Tokyo rarely knew where the Andaz hotel was so we had to ask for 'Toranomon Hills' but they wouldn't know how to get into the building so we kept being dropped off on the side across from the 'car entry'. We would have to cross the road and then the guards at the car entry wouldn't allow pedestrians to enter through the 'car entry' but you could literally see the door to the hotel 3m away. We would have to walk around the block to the street entry and walk down the hallway back to the hotel entry (a giant U). I'm all for safety and rules but this was a bit nonsensical. The car entry area is shared by the Toranomon Hills building so the Taxi Stand is shared too. At other five star hotels the valet would ask us where we were going and translate it to the driver for accuracy, which we appreciate very much. At the Andaz we asked the valet if he could translate this address for us and he just pointed to the taxi driver saying we should do it ourselves. I did not like this at all and we ended up being dropped off at a completely random location across the bridge from our 3 michelin star sushi restaurant, and had to walk 10 blocks in the rain (and we were dressed to dine at a 3-michelin star restaurant). We were wet from the rain, and late (a big no-no). There isn't much food to eat around the restaurant and it is very quiet around the hotel. It is a 10 minute walk to the subway through residential/side streets.///The SpaThe pool, gym and spa is beautiful and views from there are awesome. I loved going for a dip in the pool and whirlpool and my husband enjoyed the gym. ///CheckoutOn the day of our checkout, we asked for the bellboys to come to get our luggage. We waited 15 minutes and no one came so we called again. They said they were coming and waited another 15 minutes. We called down again and they said they were coming and waited another 15. At the 45 minute mark we got up and took our luggage on our own and bumped into the bellboy in the hallway.///ConclusionPricing is great so I would come back here again if I'm on business.

Room Type: Andaz Large (55sqm)The Good: - The amazing view from its floor to ceiling windows is possibly among the best in Tokyo - Room itself is tastefully designed - Professional and helpful staffThe Bad: - NoneThe Noteworthy: - The nearest subway station is about 800m away, so expect a bit of a walk. If you're hauling a lot of luggages, consider a taxi/uber.The Verdict: Highly recommended if price is not an issue.

Andaz sharp design - Very friendly welcome early in the morning the team made us confortable to wait for the room. Elegant and relaxing ambiance. Clean and very tidy room. Breakfast just normal without anything particular other than a very bright atmosphere. I like the high ceiling and large space.

The view inside the room (50/F) and breakfast place (51/F) are wonderful.The lift for going up fr ground fl to concierge is fast.The pillows are all not my types but the toiletries are good and bath tub is nice.For ppl who has meetings within 1-3 days around Ginza area, Andaz is definitely a good place to live and shorten your traffic time.

What can you say that hasn’t been said about how amazing this hotel is. The service is great without being as overt as it is at other luxury brands (e.g. Park Hyatt). So if you are looking for a little more laid back vibe, this is an excellent choice. Pros: incredible design, sublime decor, coolest spa facilities, spacious rooms, perfect service, location is great (quiet but close to subways). Cons: I have only one complaint. It will seem weird that this is the longest part of the review. I want to be clear that I LOVED this hotel, and in the grand scheme, my complaint did not deter from a great stay. I just do not understand why this choice was made by the designer. Every other detail in this hotel is made with intention. This must have been too. I just do not understand why. One of the coolest attributes of this hotel is that it is on the ~50th floor. Soaring views of one of the greatest cities in the world. Floor to ceiling windows are so dramatic when you are up this high. The problem is that in the regular/view rooms, the beautiful and elegant wall panels turn in about a half meter as they meet the windows. Instead of having windows that go the full width of the room, the panels shrink that by about a meter. Why???? On top of that, there is a couch facing inward, backing up to the windows that is the full width of the room. For two people in the room, a couch this long is not needed at all. And what it does is act as another obstruction of the view, and even worse, a barrier. What’s the best thing about floor to ceiling windows on the 50th floor? Walking right up to them! Can’t do that in these rooms. You can jump over the back of the couch, but I just can’t figure out why there needs to be a full width couch in this room. Tip: to remedy this problem, upgrade to the “Large” king rooms. No obstructions. Just huge windows and soaring views.

This property is now right at the top of my favorite hotels I've ever stayed it. It's probably tied with the Andaz in Costa Rica. The property is gorgeous, the staff was excellent, and the room was unbelievable. The view of Tokyo can't be beat. Would definitely stay again and recommend to anyone thinking of visiting Tokyo. The only drawback is being ~12-15 minutes walk from the trains...but honestly not a big deal.

Loved our recent one night stay at the Andaz in Tokyo. Warm & welcoming service; spacious, well thought out and luxurious rooms; fun rooftop bar with amazing city views; and love the Andaz approach of free snacks & drinks throughout the day. Loved the circular deep bath - super relaxing. Location wise - it’s an easy ten min taxi from Tokyo station (but ensure you have the address in local language as the hotel wasn’t known to our taxi drivers). Highly recommended.

It was my first time in Andaz Tokyo and I was amazed by how well this hotel combines the traditional and modern Japanese culture from architecture to interior design. The hotel reception breaks down the barrier of hotel staff and residents, we could talk to each other side by side. The sitting area is more like a higher end co-working space so hotel residents can really blend in. One thing I should mention is that they do offer flip-flop style slippers if you are a fan :)

Wonderfully luxurious and all its service staff are immaculately trained. All speak excellent English. The hotel is near the subway lines and is within walking distance to the imperial palace and Shiodome. The eateries at the Shimbashi station areas are about a 10 minutes walk away.

Sadly we were only able to stay here for one night but I absolutely loved every second here. We arrived in Tokyo at Haneda airport and took the Keisei line to Shimbashi station. We could have taken a cab from Shimbashi but decided to walk since it was a beautiful Thursday evening and the walk only took 10-15 minutes. Checkin was quick and we were offered a drink while we relaxed in the elegant "living room" area just off reception. Since we were only staying one night and we checked in after 10 PM we were upgraded from our standard room (I had used Hyatt points for the stay) to the Andaz room View on the 48th floor which had a lovely view of the Imperial Palace park area. The room had a huge bathroom and large soaking tub which we took advantage along with one of the best beds I've encountered in a hotel. As you'd expect from all Andaz hotels this one offered free nonalcoholic drinks and snacks for free and the mini fridge was well stocked with sodas, juices, and water. The best part was the free yummy rice snacks and chocolates. We also took advantage of the pool on the 37th floor which offers great views of the city. The spa area has a large lap pool and several smaller hot pools along with a carbonated water pool which was so relaxing. The locker rooms were really nice and offered a hot room and additional relaxation hot pools along with showers and multiple amenities (spray deodorant, hair products, toothbrush and mouthwash, etc). The hotel is within walking distance to Shimbashi station which has several restaurants that stay open late and several convenient stores where you can stock up on snacks or alcohol so you can return to your room and relax in the soaking tub. Checkout was also efficient and we were offered yummy caramel candies as a goodbye gift which were delicious.I'll be looking forward to my next Tokyo vacation so I can stay here again.
user_name:
NNBTravel
New York City, New York

review_body: Would stay here every single time. Rooms in pristine condition and greatest view in Tokyo. The first with a view to Fuji Mountain and the second with the Tokyo Tower. The guest service is like shadow, you don't see it but feel it. Very comfortable with a touch of luxury. Located in walking distance from Ginza, Emperial Palace, etc.

Second visit in 18 months. Decided to return as I needed a hotel in the area, and Andaz offered decent value. As you'd expect, not much changed from the previous review https://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/ShowUserReviews-g1066451-d6485175-r426051139-Andaz_Tokyo_Toranomon_Hills-Minato_Tokyo_Tokyo_Prefecture_Kanto.html The gym / spa is the winner. Best I have seen in Tokyo. Breakfast buffet was nice. Word of caution on taxis, the hotel shares the taxi stand with the building. If it is raining at rush hour, expect a long wait as it does not seem to a natural stop for taxis. You'll be better off grabbing an umbrella and walking few hundred meters.

Great hotel with superior service. Was there for 3 nights. And they wow me all it’s every single time except for one not so pleasant experience.Check in was excellent. Eespecially if you checked in online.1. I left my winter coat in one of the rooms in the lobby. Was there for a drink, minutes after I returned to my room,I received a call saying I left my coat in the lobby! I don’t know how they knew it’s me?!2. We wanted to go to Kamakura on Sunday, I was tasked to check with conceige on how to get there. This guy, Jowen, is extremely helpful and detailed in giving directions on how to get there. This helps when you haven’t been there. He even goes to details such as paying the bus fare after alighting! I had to go back to look for him as I wanted to ask some other questions but he wasn’t around. A. Indian lady was there, she was ok but condescending. Saw her the next day and so clearly felt her service was insincere. Every other staff there was excellent with their service and sincerity.Breakfast was not cheap but was extremely good, worth paying for it!

Second time staying at the hotel, it's got a nice feel to it. The design is modern and slick in the public areas with a nice nod to the Japanese Ryokan in the rooms. The all important bathroom is well done with a nice big tub. Good breakfast. Some nice little touches that the kids loved such as free local sweets and snacks each day at the reception area. The only very small downside for me is that it's not in a slightly busier area but with the taxi service and availability in Tokyo you barely notice.

We really enjoyed staying at this hotel, we found the staff and amenities to be top class. It is fairly convenient to different train lines, about a 10 - 15 min walk depending on which line you want.There was a small hiccup at check-in, we arrived at our room to find a another couple already settling in. Although quite embarrassing, the staff were so fantastic, discreet and professional and had it fixed within a few minutes. They then went out of their way to make sure the rest of our stay was perfect (including complimentary drinks) and it was! The atmosphere is sophisticated but relaxed and the view is probably one of the best in Tokyo, so worth staying just for this. The rooftop bar is fabulous and we ate at the Sushi Restaurant which was spectacular. We will definitely be back.

This is a WOW view from the roof-top bar. All aspects of this hotel are 5 star. There is also a spa which is beautiful, treatments are wonderful but do come with a hefty price tag, if you can justify it I can highly recommend it

We stayed a total of 8 nights at the Andaz Tokyo Toranomon Hills: our first two nights after flying into Narita form the U.S. for a chance to get acclimated to the time change and get our bearings as this was our first trip to Japan. Then after returning from 3 nights in Kyoto, we stayed another 6 nights. Both arrivals were smooth with quick and efficient check in. I had ordered a pocket wifi and it was already placed in our room prior to check-in upon our first stay. We checked two large suitcases with the hotel while we were away in Kyoto and those were also placed in our room prior to our second check-in, along with a nice welcome back note and tasty macarons. Both stays I had reserved a King Tower view room and the views were stunning! Seeing the Tokyo Tower lit up every night was breathtaking and the vast bird’s eye view of Tokyo was mesmerizing! The hotel is beautifully designed, with lots of natural wood and clean lines. We dined at the Tavern bar and the Tavern restaurant a few times and were happy with service and food. Our experience with hotel staff was excellent. We were almost always greeted by name and we used many of their restaurant recommendations. They were happy to make reservations for us, and never hesitated at any of our requests. The hotel is located in a quiet, business part of Tokyo, with a short walk to the subway station. We appreciated being able to get away from the hectic city in our quiet room. My only complaint would be the bed…I found the mattress to be overly firm. I prefer a more plush hotel bed experience. The room was gorgeous, smartly designed and spacious for Tokyo. Nespresso machines in the room were fantastic and non-alcoholic drinks and snacks were free. We ordered the room service set breakfast almost daily and found it a good value for expensive Tokyo…and my husband especially enjoyed the hot chocolate!

Andaz Tokyo has perhaps the most mesmerizing view of Tokyo due to its height and central location. Looking at different directions you can see the Sky Tree, the Royal Palace, Shinjuku (and on a clear day, Mountain Fuji) and of course Tokyo bay and Tokyo Tower. It was such an amazing experience to close all the lights in our room and immerse ourselves in the glittering night of Tokyo. And to wake up in the morning with Tokyo Tower and Mountain Fuji in front of your eyes. That experience alone is worth the splurge.On top of that, the Andaz has a charming, modern yet very Japanese style and the pool and spa is such a retreat -- so far, so good. The people at the Andaz are generally very professional and warm, and speak very good English. They explained everything in great detail and were very attentive to detail.But then here comes the negatives (it's only my personal feeling): first,I'm not a fan of the lounge concept -- especially during CI -- the lounge area barely offers limited selection of drinks and little snacks (not replenished very often) and is not close to any windows, and the seat is not really very comfortable -- I mean, for God's sake this is Tokyo and if I can't get to my room immediately, I know a million of choices that are more comfortable than the lounge. And the 'lounge' concept also means we need to wait on 52F with our luggages by our side, instead of leaving our luggages to the concierge on the ground floor. Sure, we can 'help ourselves' but it's more like a youth hotel than an upscale property. Not to mention that the lounge is so much inferior to any club lounge of the 'ordinary' luxury hotels -- alright, we know this is not a club lounge so that's fine.The dining options are not particularly strong as well. Honestly the bar, the Tavern and the sushi bar are not very tempting for us because the view of our room was much better and the food they offer were nothing outstanding for Tokyo. (especially when you compare them to the excellent restaurants of Ritz Hong Kong) I really appreciate the free mini bar, but we only ended up using the bottled water -- we didn't need the coke and diet coke; the free snacks are great, but were, again, nothing outstanding for Tokyo. (I know, the feeling of having a free mini bar in an expensive hotel is so much more important than having the mini bar itself)All in all, the Andaz is exquisitely designed (kudos to the designer) and some of the most stunning views you can have in Tokyo, but on the other side, feels like a help-your-self private sight-viewing room (with a luxury pool and sauna). For sight-viewing, this is the best so I still recommend this hotel but after a few days the dazzling view becomes a little boring and for prolonged stay I will consider staying at the Prince Gallery just a few blocks away. This is not to say that the Andaz is not good -- we are grateful we were there -- but there are more comfortable options out there.

This hotel is centrally located and within reach to major shopping areas.The hotel is well kept and is very new.I would like to thank Fumi-san for making my stay a great one and also Andrea for looking after us.Our first encounter at the Andaz Tavern for breakfast wasn’t great but subsequent visits were better. Our encounters with Andaz hosts were below expectations. They are better than receptionist at GH Tokyo but way below Concierge and Grand Club Team at GH Tokyo. (1) got my restaurant reservation wrong, no private room reserved. (2) when I ask a host to send 2 bucket of ice during night turn down at 5plus in the evening and he was so confident and tell me just call and the ice bucket will be delivered. I told him your customer required 2 bucket of ice to be delivered during night turn down. When I return to hotel at 7.15pm, neither the room was turned down, no ice buckets too. I told him off. I was waiting at the lounge for Housekeeping to turn down, no one come to apologise and no on come to tell me that the room was turned down. (3) when I told them to book a taxi to Haneda for me tomorrow leaving hotel at 1pm, they asked for my flight information. Isn’t leaving hotel at 1pm enough ? They went further to ask me for reservation confirmation number. I think they may ask me for my back account number next, just to book a taxi. No explanation on why such details are required. I am really not a fan of this Andaz Host thing. Housekeeping is the second best in Asia, after GH Tokyo. Very very good. One incident which if they have done better, they will be the best. I broke a porcelain glass and cut my feet in the room. The slipper was stained with blood. Both items are placed next to the waste paper basket in the toilet. They were not so sharp to highlight to management. Having said that they are still the second best in all the Hyatt Hotels I stayed in Asia.

We arrived in Tokyo on 19 Feb after a ski trip in Karuizawa and timed ourselves to check-in at 3pm. At check-in, we were told that the rooms were overbooked and our original King tower bedroom is now not available. We needed to stay in Twin generic view bedroom (Room 5033) and change on the second day. Breakfast was offered as ‘compensation’ for the inconvenience (like we cannot afford breakfast, hello? Who cares about hotel breakfast when in Tokyo?). Worse of all, the hotel staff assumed we will be ‘out’ the second day between 12noon and 3pm (since check out time is 12noon and check in time is 3pm) and we needed to pack our luggage and deposit the key at the front desk so that they can move us on the second day to the new room. What a major inconvenience (who likes packing and unpacking)! This is not an inspiring Andaz experience for me. I think Prince Karuizawa did a much better job on all levels! Meh..... for the Hyatt brand. Given that it is Tokyo and not a third world city, major thumbs down. I would have given half a circle if that was available.

This was my first time to Andaz in Tokyo and only my 2nd ever in the past few years…but now I am sold on Andaz! The total stay though short was terrific. The pool is picturesque and very clean and the service people including pool person Tobayashi very helpful! I suggest using the Jacuzzi areas as the warm water and nice seating allow for almost full reclined relaxation. All in all this is a a great hotel!

We made a return visit based on our last time here a few years ago. The area around the hotel has definitely picked up and there are more options for food and activities nearby that make it more appealing to travelers. I wish I could say the service was just as awesome as we remembered it. Unfortunately that was not the case and it left a bad experience for us. We were staying for a few days and had breakfast in the restaurant. Unfortunately, dealing with jetlag we overslept and came near the end of breakfast. Now normally we are not people who take forever to eat and understood that breakfast ended shortly. We acknowledged it but it seemed they were trying to discourage us from eating so they wouldn't have to deal with last minute diners. I guess that should have been the first clue that we might run into issues. We were shown a table and quickly went to the buffet area to pick out our food. Since we knew it would be cleared out soon, we made sure to get what we needed so we wouldn't be holding them back from cleaning all the food out. After we were seated, someone came to let us know that the buffet would be cleaned out soon-we thanked them for the reminder and said we had all that we needed. About 15 minutes later someone came again and let us know that it would soon be lunch and they needed to change out the dining area. Confusion. Apparently they needed us to move so they could get the place settings changed out for lunch. I'm not sure why it would have been a problem to allow us to sit in the same table, considering we were eating food and new lunch diners would also be eating food. Would us eating breakfast items really be an issue? Apparently it was and they told us they needed to move us to the bar area??? So, they picked up our dishes and whatever else on trays and took us to a window area by the bar. Really? I fail to see how this was a better option. Now, we were the only ones eating food while other people at the next table were having a meeting over drinks. The arrangement seemed to make no sense to me but of course I could be missing some cultural issues or procedure issues-whatever the issue it was bizarre and a bit disruptive. Now we needed new silverware and cups for our water since those were quickly whisked away as soon as they moved us. Of course, now that we were in the bar area-it was harded to notice us and when we needed a water refill, there was no one to ask so we just went out to the lounge area and grabbed some bottle water. Last time we stayed here, I distinctly remember staying after breakfast was over while we lingered and enjoyed the view, never once being asked to move to another area for fear of the lunch diners. It made for a bit of sore point for us that for the next breakfasts we were paranoid that we were taking too long so we ate super fast and whenever someone approached our table, we were convinced it was to tell us to move. Sure, we could have ate outside the restaurant some will say. However, we had a mixed group, including a younger child and being all jetlag, it was just easier to stay in the hotel for the first meal of the day.The rest of the staff at check-in were great and the area is easier to get around to and fro. However, this being Japan, there are many other options for lodging and no need to stick to one place if you don't love it. Overall, this definitely made it clear for us that we do not feel the need to stay here again the next time in Tokyo.

Easy to reach all the hot spots in Tokyo. Service quality at reception is also satisfactory including free beverage at the lobby. Non-alcoholic beverage in the mini bar is free as well. Our room on the 49th floor with bay view was very quiet with a fascinating view.

We had cancelled our reservation at Aman Tokyo once we found out the spa and pool area would be closed during our stay and booked our first (and last) stay at Andaz Tokyo.Arrival was perfect: the bellman unloaded our bags from the taxi and whisked us up to the51st Floor for check-in. A young lady offered us a seat at a long, wooden table and coffee next to the reception, a dark and cold area without any windows they call "Andaz Lounge", and proceeded to explain everything in Japanese. I usually can manage standard routines, but when I started to get "lost" and looked at my (Japanese) wife, the lady continued in Japanese and let my wife do the translation... She then offered my wife a small wooden box (Omedeto for your upcoming Birthday, would have been nicer to deliver it to her two days later in the room) and took us down to our room. It did have a great view of Tokyo Tower and beyond, a very nice round bath-tub and large shower next to it, but hardly any space to unpack your clothes unless you could hang them, and not much space around the bed. After unpacking, we went back to "Lounge" which supposedly offers drinks and snacks at Cocktail hours. The choice was wine or soft drinks, not even a beer and forget anything like a G&T, plus a minimalistic offering of a couple of nibbles. Hello???We did meet friends for dinner elsewhere and returned afterwards for drinks at the Rooftop bar. Unfortunately, this was cold like a fridge and windy, so we went for a drink at the "Tavern", which they closed shortly. Our last resort was to raid the mini-bar in the room and huddle in the uncomfortable Lounge. The one very positive experience was the pool and the massages at the Spa. Both you can visit as a day guest so no need to stay for this only luxury experience!Maybe Andaz Management can visit the Club Lounge at the Yokohama Bay Sheraton where we stayed before (at half the price) or the Oval Club at the Kobe Portopia Hotel (at 1/5th of the price) to benchmark the atmosphere and the food/drinks on offer compared to the Andaz Lounge...

This is an upscale Hyatt centrally located. Pricey, but the view for any tea service, late afternoon wine or dinner is spectacular. Even if you do not stay here, worth a visit to the top floor. Easily accessible by train should you wish to meet up with friends.

Beautiful property with commanding views of Tokyo. Staff were excellent and concierge was helpful in securing several dinner reservations. Stylish hotel that represents the Andaz concept well. Tranquil rooms with efficient use of space. Convenient location with easy transit options to greater Tokyo.

Being a Globalist and not getting a room upgrade because the hotel wants to boost revenue by selling it to a higher price to a non loyal customer is a mental meltdown. Hotels that doesnt reward my elite status comes off my list forever. Good bye Andaz Tokyo.

I have nothing but great things to say about the Andaz Tokyo. The decor here is STUNNING and beautiful. The view of the city is unparalleled and you can even see Mt. Fuji from the rooms. The lobby is so sleek and the evening happy hours had some delicious little snacks and drinks to choose from. The room itself is incredible and the shower/bathtub is wonderful. Best of all is the service, it was impeccable. They cleaned everything so well and even arranged all our toiletries we had left around! I couldn't have asked for a better experience. The Andaz has my undying loyalty for any of my trips back to Tokyo.

Stayed a couple of nights in this property recently and very much appreciated the modern design and decor, room style, and professional service. Rooms are quite large for Tokyo, well appointed, and have a nice view of one of the world’s great cities.If you value cool rooms, great views, and being in an upcoming part of town then this a great choice.

My visit at this hotel is now in my top five favorite stays ever! Andaz is adorned with minimalist, yet chic decor and styled Japanese pieces. Everyone working here humbly greets you, nods and continues the Japanese tradition of quiet, respectful and welcoming culture. The room knocked off my socks with the incredible views and beautiful live edge wood tables and sink tops. Nothing here is tacky. You won’t see a drain, rust, dust or any corner overlooked. The room bar is stocked with nespresso, chocolates, gourmet snacks, green tea served in beautifully hand made pottery and even more amenities. Also, it is worth me mentioning the Toto toilet in the room with its heated seat, motion sensing opening and closing lid and self cleaning. Lastly, the hotel breakfast is certainly worth splurging on at least one day of your stay because it is everything AND more.
user_name:
Flyingyogagirl
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed 1 night on 20th Jan at a room with Tokyo tower view. Room was great with huge bath tub and staffs were kind. Non-alcholic drinks are free and lounge bar on top was great for a glass of cocktail.

Great hotel, friendly and very helpful staff, large rooms with excellent amenities. Superb gym and health club. Hotel has great views over the city and convenient for getting around Tokyo.Cant fault it all.

I spent 9 days in Andaz Tokyo Toranomon Hills for business conferences. The reception and lobby is on 51/F which provides complimentary snacks and drinks in the evening. High standard and yummy.My room on the 47/F with a king sized bed can view the Tokyo Tower. It was breathtaking. You can enjoy the beautiful night view of Tokyo with the complimentary non-alcoholic drinks and snacks provided in the room.Breakfast buffet is yummy. I like the Japanese breakfast very much. I had it for the last 8 days during my stay.Meeting room with tea breaks is professional too. High ceiling room and bright with natural sunlight.It is the best hotel in Tokyo I have ever stayed so far.

Andaz Tokyo is one of the best hotels I stayed. This hotel is clean, and the decorations are great. However Andaz impressed me the most is staff, I felt once I entered the hotel, they just couldn’t wait to provide service. Every single time when I’m getting close to the front counter, the employees always come toward me and ask if I need anything, also when I was sitting in the lobby someone always ask if I want anything to drink. Most employees speak English and some with English limitation, when there was a language barrier, they didn’t give up, they will do their best to understand you and still give you professional customer service.

Overall, a good experience. Beautiful rooms and a good view. Was placed on the Mt. Fuji side. Check-in and out are a "lounge" experience, so may take longer than expected (be mindful of this if having plans close to the time of arrival/departure). Great snacks/drink selection in the room and at the lobby area. Good drinks at the Skybar (no Tokyo Tower view). Did not try to the restaurant or happy hour for guests. Quick 5 minute walk to Toranomon metro station on the Ginza Line, which takes you anywhere you want in and around Tokyo. Located in business district so not that many places stay open late, including bars, in the area.

I needed to find a hotel in Tokyo close to the Roppongi district. Since I did not have much time to prepare for this trip and wanted to stay in a relatively new hotel, did a quick search on the American Express fine hotels programme but did not end up booking through them. The Andaz came up and I booked a hotel with a view of the Tokyo tower. It is a fantastic view, especially at night, when the Tower is lit up. On a good day, you can even see Mount Fuji from the room. The location is ok, about a 10 minute walk to the closest subway station, Toranomon station on the Ginza Line. However, if you are looking for busy night life and shopping right at your footsteps, this is not the hotel for you. Another bonus is there is a Limousine Bus that runs straight to the hotel from the 2 airports, Narita and Haneda. It is much more convenient than to take the train from the airport, because you do not have to change into a tax from the train station. The bus is highly recommended. On the facilities, it is commensurate with a 5 star hotel. I did not get a chance to use the swimming pool. The room size is big for Tokyo standards. Another nice touch is the complimentary wine and hors d'oeuvres they offer in the evening hours between 6- 8 pm. The food is surprisingly tasty and with a view of the Tokyo skyline and piano music in the background ( played in the lounge next door), the complimentary experience is really relaxing. I think the Andaz offers great value.

My husband and I stayed at the Andaz a total of 4 nights while traveling in Japan. It’s an easy walk to the Toronomon and Shimbashi (where you can catch the bullet trains) stations, which offer access to most neighborhoods in Tokyo between them. The area itself is definitely more of a business district, but there are still restaurants and 7-11s very nearby.The hotel itself is beautifully decorated, and the rooms are spacious and ours had great views of the city and Mount Fuji. Highlights are definitely the view and the gorgeous bathrooms with their unique round tubs. Th staff here are friendly, helpful, and had very strong English proficiency (not rare for a Tokyo hotels, but still appreciated). Would absolutely recommend to others.

The Andaz never disappoints. Amazing view, beautiful room with wonderful amenities (they even included a phone to use locally!), incredible staff, 52nd floor bar with perfect drinks- wouldn’t stay anywhere else!

Having experienced other luxury properties in Tokyo, the Andaz stands above (not just in room views.) Service is exquisite while remaining friendly and down to earth. No stuffy-ness - it's like a much better version of home. All non-alcoholic items in the minibar are free, the beds are divine and you can watch the sun rise while looking at Fuji without getting out of bed. The bathroom has an amazing shower and hot tub. The spa is not to be missed either.

I was eager to try out the Andaz and finally had the opportunity to split my Tokyo stay between the Andaz and the Park Hyatt. The Andaz brand is more individualistic, meaning you do not expect a traditional hotel in terms of design and functionality. The location is more adhered to businesses instead of leisure, and there is a 10 to 15 minute walk to the nearest subway station. The views aren't bad, while mine wasn't facing the Tokyo Tower which costs a little more. Every room has a free mini-bar for non-alcoholic drinks and snacks. I am not a fan of its bathroom which to me is a little too enclosed and completely lack of views. The décor however is nice and should be quite appealing to young urban professionals looking for something more new and edgy.The Andaz style check-in/check-out process is a deliberate casual yet interactional experience. If you are looking for old fashioned service, this may not be your cup of tea. You will find yourself sitting with all kinds of people wanting different things and engaging in different conversations in the same living room. The daily cocktail hour also resides at the same place. For people who want to see and be seen, and for those who can't stand to be alone, it's perfect. For me, I find it a little bit too noisy and disorienting. It probably has something to do with certain flashy and pretentious guests that I encountered with during my stay, not the fault of the hotel at all. But again, you get an idea of what this property speaks to, in terms of audience. It's instagram-worthy.I wouldn't mind going back to Andaz for a beautifully managed and designed property, but in a city filled with competitive options, it certainly won't be my first choice.

Nice location, nice view, nice stay, nice everything...Will definitely stay with this hotel in my next travels. It was a very short stay this time, but very impressive. The hotel offers free snack and juice.

Majestic and Breathtaking view from my room on the 48th floor! Room was very, very clean. Toto toilet seat. All non-alcoholic drinks + Nespresso Coffee + chocolate and snacks ALL FREE. Happy Hour every day at hotel lobby, they serve red and white wines + french cheese + Japanese Petit fours ALL FREE. Great, Great Staff! Only 5 minutes walk from subway. The room comes with a Mobile phone, you can use it to call all over japan, china and surf the internet FREE. The only thing this hotel needs is to improve the Breakfast at Tavern with more variety, quality and speed when serving tea and coffee. My family and I had a wonderful experience at Andaz Tokyo Toranomon. Thanks a lot to the staff and management team.

Probably one the best properties in the Andaz portfolio. Stylish and sleek from the elevators, decorated with unique paper bas-reliefs, to the high ceiling check-in lobby on the 41st floor.The Tavern restaurant serves perfectly executed Mediterranean inspired dishes, in a grand setting - and you can sometimes spot politicians having power lunches.Meanwhile, the rooftop bar boasts fantastic views of Tokyo with plenty of heated blankets to enjoy the outdoor seating even in the midst of winter. The cocktail and spirit list will do the rest. A favorite hangout in the neighborhood.

I stayed in a King Bed Room JPY 33,500 [AUD 445] per night room rate.The hotel is located above the shop levels many floors up off the ground floor. As usual in Tokyo, service is impeccable from the moment you step foot into the reception to the time you leave.The reception area has a relaxed lounge atmosphere that leads into various event rooms to one side and the restaurant on the other side. There is a bar and spa in addition on other floors. The décor is modern yet 'eco friendly' style. Natural wood is used for tables and natural colour fabrics are used on seating throughout the hotel general and room areas.The room décor is per above and comes with a lounge sofa/work area, beautifully arranged and kitted out bathroom / robe area. The bed comfort gave me the best night sleep in years. I have to mention the awesome shower - big size, massive rain forest shower head.Breakfast is not inexpensive but then the quality of the food is outstanding. Centrally located for the Olympic games and regular tourist areas. About 15 minutes walk away is a nice eating district where you will find food at much lower cost but also good quality. Within the building complex you will also find good food options that are well priced.By far one of the best hotel experiences I have had in a long time - highly recommended for business or leisure stay.

The Best and most complete city hotel we have experienced !Spacious room with impressive view of Tokyo and excellent service.Not much around the hotel but you are just short distance away from Ginza where you will find all the restaurant !

You were not only stunned by the view on 51 floor reception, and the service was equally memorable. The whole check-in process was welcomed by the drinks in the lounge, and the wooden design was special and artistic. Everyone in the reception was helpful and greeted every guest with warm smiles. My wife and I tried the AO spa service and the therapist Chang from Korea was very professional in listening and understanding our stress. We felt very relaxed and had a very good sleep after the treatment. The way she applied the heated herb bag, and the pressure points' handling were just right. Today is my last day in Tokyo, and we will definitely be back. Thank you for the great service.

This is the 2nd time we stay here and it's an amazing hotel! It's now my favorite hotel in Tokyo, better than Grand Hyatt, Conrad and even the Park Hyatt. Beautiful big rooms, nice atmosphere, fantastic service, awesome breakfast and incredible views!!More than Highly recommended!!!

same as Grand hyatt, the entrance is really small~location good, hotel facility is good, brand new, everything looks shinning, the room is relatively large, the hot tub is circle shape, quite sharp!great place to stay! very modern!!

The Andaz is a very nice hotel, with comfortable rooms, interesting architecture, good food, and great views. However, the service can be needlessly awkward (as May from New Orleans well described previously) and sometimes can even verge on being abusive. I both thoroughly enjoyed the Andaz and sometimes resented it.Here's the positive...ACCOMODATIONS: The rooms feature the Japanese aesthetic yet are comfortable, warm, quiet and inviting. The dressing room / bathroom area is made from marble and have very nice fixtures and finishes. I am also impressed that I never heard anybody in the surrounding rooms - the construction seems quite good.CUISINE: The restaurant puts out consistently good food that's well seasoned, well prepared, and well presented. The chef changed the menu regularly - we enjoyed the variety. The wine menu is varied and has depth. The desserts are well crafted and creative. In fact, the Andaz's bakery on the first floor has some excellent desserts we took back to our room and enjoyed while looking at the fantastic view with a glass of wine. Very nice! I am also not much of a breakfast person but thoroughly enjoyed the variety and quality of their daily breakfast buffet. Buffets are almost universally awful, but this one is really nice. Compliments to the chef!AMMENTITIES: I must applaud the hotel for eliminating those annoying and petty charges that seem to plague some hotels. WiFi is fast and free. The gym and pool are very nice and free. They offer a variety of convenient and free snacks / drinks in the room and in the main lobby (on 51). This 'generosity' is quite impressive.PERSONNEL: Everybody is very pleasant, very polite and speak English fairly well. I noted that many guests were from other countries (Poland, India, Germany, Mexico, etc.) and all of them seemed content with the service they received in English. The bell staff on the first floor is really helpful. They promptly greet you, are quick to handle luggage, and gladly assist with getting in/out of your car. And, now the negative...The hotel suffers service problems: (1) Staff seems to love ordering guests around, and (2) they'd rather apologize than fix a problem.Check-in was bureaucratic and time consuming even though I was the only person checking in. The goofy "Apple Store" setup (as explained by a previous guest) for the reception desk makes it overly complicated. While they took far to long to check me in, they repeatedly insisted that I sit down and 'relax' as if I was too stupid to know what what posture is comfortable for me.Tip #1 to Andaz: Check in does not need to be a drawn out process - just swipe my card and give me a key. The restaurant service at the Tavern (the main restaurant) was at times stunningly awkward and at times excellent. The tendency to never return with the tea, coffee, water, etc. was annoying. Other times they'd return to top off the beverage just a minute after they had last done it. It was if nobody quite knew who was supposed to follow through on that simple task. Tip #2 to Andaz: Pouring beverages should not need management coordination.They also had big problems solving simple snafus. I came to the restaurant with the hotel's reservation confirmation, yet the restaurant didn't know about it. They apologized. I was left standing there. After several minutes I had to ask what was happening. They apologized that they didn't have our reservation. I was left standing there. I asked to know their suggested solution. They looked shocked that I expected them to solve their mistake. After a flurry of telephone calls they suggested a table at the nearly empty bar next door. That was fine with us, and they said they'd immediately prepare our table. After waiting nearly 20 minutes, and now quite perturbed, I asked the status. The new clerk informed me that they didn't have our reservation and apologized. I asked about the table in the nearly empty bar. She was clueless and made another of flurry of telephone calls after which she said she'd check on the status of our table. She hurried off. About a minute later I followed to find her trying to set the table. I got more apologies. Tip #3 to Andaz: Apologies are a poor substitute for solutions and follow-through.The useless attendants that guard the entrance are officious and ignorant. I've never met such rude Japanese people. I assume they are nice human beings by nature, so evidently the Andaz management team thought it wise to bully guests.Tip #4 to Andaz: Your staff should helpful and polite, always. Even the useless ones directing the non-existing car traffic should assist not bully.

This is my go to hotel in Tokyo. I love staying here - the rooms are stunning, the views to die for. I've knocked my rating down to four stars though as service does seem to have slipped a bit in recent times. I hope this is something they rectify - and soon - because it's an otherwise exceptional hotel.Oh, and visit the pool during your stay. Just spectacular.

I stayed here a few times already and have always had great things to say to fellow business travelers. This morning though an inexplicably careless screw up changed my view on this property. I had an early flight and asked for a 5:40am delivery for breakfast, one trick I do to assure I am fully awake and can leave on time. Fortunately I did wake from the alarm I set and didn’t hit snooze, 10 minutes past no breakfast arrived, I rang at 5:50 asking for it and they said it’s already en route. At 5:55 I get a knock on my door, they sent it to the wrong room and amazingly the guest took the order anyway (guess they liked the free breakfast), and they asked if they can redo my order for me “quickly”, I had planned to check out by 20 minutes past 6 and of course refused. In over 20 years of business travels I’ve never had this happen, I definitely did not expect this to happen in a Hyatt property and much less in usually impeccably ran hotels of Tokyo. Major fail Andaz, I’ve asked for an explanation and could not wait around for it and miss my flight. So off I went to the airport on an empty stomach and a very foul mood.

At chec-out, the staff asked me to pass my credit card and make a signature on receipt, while I was standing at the middle of the reception hall, where is no table or counter. She didn't care for me that my both hands were full of baggage and I was difficult to write it.

Excellent experience. A cozy and elegant hotel on higher floors of the tallest (or second tallest) building in Tokyo. I had a room with fantastic views of the harbor and skyscrapers of Shiodome. Great service. Walking distance from a subway station.

This hotel is located in a "re-emerging" central Tokyo neighborhood busily being redeveloped. So the immediate precinct is for the moment slightly dull, perhaps, but many delights are a short walk away and there are several subway stations and rail hubs within 10 or 15 minutes walk. Meanwhile the rooms high above the city are marvelously furnished and thoughtfully provisioned, making a great haven from the bustle below. We relished the beautifully presented breakfast buffet every day of the stay. The pool and spa are splendid ways to deal with jet lag.

Waking up with a naming view of Tokyo is what you will get during your stay here. Location of the hotel is great too, with food places and convenient stores all around the hotel' subway station is a few minutes walk away too. Overall, it's an amazing experience during my stay in this hotel.

Definitely more than perfect. Third stay here, whatever is the purpose, family or business, whatever is the room, suite or not ... The crew is more than attentive and provide dedicated and customized services. They will even help you to set up your google map to walk to the right place if no wish of taxi. Just ask for help. Great location with multiple fantastic views, Tokyo tower and Fuji san in the right side and rainbow bridge on the left one, the imperial palace and Ginza, the bay ... Make your choice. Ended my day at the spa ...

I like cleanness of this hotel that adds value of serenity and relaxation while releasing extreme fatigue from hectic long distance business trip.The room seems designed for simplicity and convenience. Everything is reachable but neatly stored.Unlike other hotels in Tokyo, it's not in the midst of people's main traffic area; thus, all the time, the hotel remains serenity, which is awesome for those who really need good rest and quick recovery.Guest rooms are located between 47 and 50th floors, and lobby is on 51st.The bird view of Tokyo skyline from the room is breathtaking and so peaceful. Gym and swimming pool are at lower floor, on 37th. Pool is wide and luxurious, and also very quiet. Therefore, for busy travelers those need to adjust time zone and good rest, this hotel is highly recommended. However, the setback is NOTHING around this hotel. Lots of construction sites. In a way, deserted. Restaurants are located in the same building (lower floors) and by the hotel lobby and 52nd floor - but no shopping mall or attractions nearby. So if you want to have fun at night, take a taxi to go to Ginza and Roppongi areas - it's only 10- 15 min. Subway stations are not located nearby, either.
user_name:
nyay
New York City, New York

review_body: For what we paid.... this is not a value hotel..... it was incredible! We had a room on the 50th floor looking over the City. The Pool on the 48th floor was beautiful with a great gym and the service overall was absolutely perfect. Defintely come here for a special occasion or just to relax in bliss in bustling tokyo.Only downside would be that its a bit father from metro and things to do, but if you can afford to stay here... you can afford a cab....Loved my stay here, staff, environment, food everything was perfect.

Second time staying at Andaz. Love the view from the room and the deco. You would definitely enjoy the bathtub after shopping.Just a few minutes walk to the nearest metro station. some nice coffee shops around. The only downside i could think of is you couldn't get into the hotel from the loading bay if you are not travel by car. One night around 11pm when we walked back from metro station, the entrance to Toranomon Hills building were closed, so the shortest way would be using the entrance at the loading bay, however, the security at the carpark didn't allow us to walk to the entrance, and we had to walk pass the corner of the other street to get into the hotel. it's reli stupid, esp after a long shopping day. overall it's a great hotel, however, if you would like to hv nightlife around, you'd rather stay somewhere else.one advice for the hotel, may consider use another brand for the bath salt...

This hotel has a different style than other Hyatt brands. Everyone wears jean. Their service is dynamic and very quick to help you check-in and check-out. My room does have a good view because I can see the palace from my room. Hotel guest can use the fitness center, swimming pool and sauna. The food and drink for the happy could be better. The choice is not so much. The breakfast is excellent, please try the best fruit options. They also have the marinated fish eggs.

Very cool hotel with a warm and rich vibe. Upon entering the lobby on the 51st floor, you are greeted by stylish staff dressed in sharp polka dot sport jackets and jeans. The wood paneling, tall ceilings in the lobby, and artsy decor are inviting. We only had one meal while staying at Andaz, but it was excellent. The duck breast main dish is awesome!

Wonderful room settings and design with remarkable outlook over the entire city: from the Fuji Mountain, the Royal Palace and to the two famous towers. Gorgeous and elegant view both in and out plus the decent services making our stay here a impeccable one. The breakfast is also very good especially compared with other Japanese hotel which usually doesn’t provide acceptable English breakfast. Note that the gym is not 24 hours which is quite inconvenient.

Perfect place to stay in in central Tokyo . The staff is very friendly and accommodating. They remember your preferences well and if your on a tour they are well informed before hand . The view of Tokyo is mesmerizing. The breakfast is good too but I recommend to eat out for dinner.

The hotel is one of my favorite in Tokyo. Stylish rooms and big too. Compared to many Japanese hotel rooms. Friendly staff and a good restaurant and nice bar and music at night. Definitely worth the visit. I will be back for sure. The Andaz brand of Hyatt is also great. Been to several.

The Andaz Hilton Rooftop Bar is located at the top of the 5-Star hotel located in Toranomon Hills. It’s an upscale bar with drink prices to match. The one catch is that to sit in the seats with the best views of the city you have to pay an additional $20/person cover. We actually preferred the downstairs bar and restaurant, the Tavern. It has a great atmosphere with comfy lounge chairs and wood paneling that adds great warmth to the space. Would suggest at least going upstairs to see the views, but the downstairs was much more enjoyable.

The Andaz is a beautiful hotel with lovely rooms and dramatic decor. Terrific staff, great spa and stunning pool. Food choices are a great mix of Eastern and Western with many restaurants options. The roof top bar and sushi spots are a terrific place to end the evening.

What a great hotel. I stayed in October and then again in November. Great views, walking distance to imperial palace and ginza.Excellent service, beautiful room, great roof bar.We had work conference here too and there was lovely food that catered well for dietary requirement.Very impressed

This hotel and its staff are outstanding. The views from the rooms are like no other, and the staff has absolutely amazing. The rooms were beautiful and the showers are some of the best I’ve ever seen in a hotel room. One of the best hotel stays I’ve had.

Enjoy my staycation at Andaz Tokyo especially the lounge area, a cozy relaxing place to calm the busy Tokyo.The sushi bar create a private environment for guest to chat and spend time at night.Would like to stay with Andy Tokyo again with the room type facing the Tokyo tower, can’t wait to be back

Nice huge clean new hotel . Great location . Nice lobby with bamboo growing in spaces . Comfortable spaces outdoors for lunch and even a quick nap . Nice cafes ...Conference room was spacious and the temperature not too cold . Food served was tasty . Coffee wasOnly served during coffee break .. if you needed an upper when you feelSleepy , there wasn’t coffee around for that. Cultural ? Many events going on .. a beauty contest .. a book event ... I would recommend this hotel on a heartbeat .

Quite literally - take the lift from the reception area right up to floor 51 - and then down the couple of floors to the bedrooms. Of course the views are spectacular, what else would you expect. Easy walking distance to the shopping districts. Superb service in this temple to modernity.

Can't find anything at fault here. The hotel is perfection. In Tokyo, that will cost you. Instead of repeating what others have said, the pro tip is to go eat at Minatoya (one block away) for the best soba I've ever had. It's packkked at lunch so go at odd hours.

My wife and I stayed here only one night at the end of our trip to Japan, and we wish we had been able to stay longer. It's the best hotel by far that we stayed at in Japan and possibly in all of our travels. The room was large, amazingly designed, and luxurious. View was amazing. Lobby was nice, checkin was easy, and the staff was great. Location was ok, short walk to two different subway lines and a slightly longer walk to the Shimbashi station.

This hotel is absolutely stunning and there's nothing else like it! We stayed here for 4 nights with our two kids and had plenty of room! The room was a lot larger than some of the other hotels we've stayed at in Tokyo. We booked one of the rooms with the king sized bed that has the large couch in front of the window. The couch was large enough and comfortable enough for both of our kids (8 & 12) to sleep on. I love the kimonos they have waiting for you in the room too. We had them on the entire time we were in the room! lol I've searched like crazy trying to find some similar to buy and haven't found them. :o( Everything about this hotel is just perfect and I can't find a single thing to even attempt to complain about! Make sure you take a few minutes to go into the locker rooms at the pool and enjoy a little massage in the massaging chairs they have. There's also a little convenience down on the lower floor of the building where you can stock up on snacks for the day. Don't forget to grab the rice triangles from there too!

we spend 2 nights herewhat a pleasure it wasfirst the placelook like so newwith super designthe check in was so professional and fastthe room was spacious with an amanzing viewwe have had a yummy room service...the burger is so yummy like the eclairs !!!the best part is the Pool!!!!!
