Could not fault our 3 night stay at the Andaz - the view is stunning, the breakfast (and breakfast room) is elegant and smart and the room was very upbeat (love the full width banquet). Also the pool has an amazing view - and the roof top bar a great spot for an end of night drink. Thought the location was in a bit of a quitter part of town - but metro only 5-6 minutes away. We will definitely be back.

Large and spacious rooms are high up with beautiful view of Tokyo. Large bathrooms with great toiletries Beds are comfortable. Hotel staff is well trained. So gracious and hospital at every level!Walking distance to train station

one of the best hotels in the world and definitely top in tokyo, new modern but with japanese style design. the art work even started from the lifts to lobby. one of the best Tony Chi's work, try it if you can!

Stayed 3 nights at this gorgeous hotel at Tokyo. Great location - just 10 mins walk to the Tokyo tower and 5mins walk to Toranomon Hills subway station which is just in the middle of the Ginza line. Very well-designed hotel with unbeatable tower view in the lobby and clean and spacious hotel rooms (which also have very nice view depending on which side you facing). Although the hotel entry is a bit mysterious and not easy to find at first. But I do like the privacy style afterall. Very nice and friendly staffs - the check-in experience is smooth and instructive (they even have an extra smartphone in every guestroom for you to use when exploring Tokyo which is a great plus!). Will def recommend and come back again!

Design of hotel: Luxury, stylish, sleek. from lobby to guest room design to bathroom shower / round bath tub.Quality of food: excellent breakfast spreadService: impeccableView: if you get a room with the Tokyo Tower view. it's truly amazing. it's stunning and you can look at it at awe morning and night.

Toranomon Andaz is a truly exceptional hotel, a cut above the usual 5-star lot I've been staying in my business trips. I would say that the sense of good taste and restrained luxury it offers and the consistently outstanding service level offered by its personnel are its main characteristics. Beyond that, rooms are great, even the standard ones, breakfast very good, especially in terms of quality of food, and overall hotel amenities what one would expect at this class. Price is steep, but well worth it. Conclusion: If you have the possibility, don't miss the opportunity to stay in Andaz. Will transform your experience in Tokyo.

We loved our stay at Andaz Hotel and would easily recommend to our family and friends. We stayed for 3 nights, checked out and went to the Aman Hotel across town and then returned for 2 nights given how much we enjoyed it.The Good:- Luxurious and stylish hotel modelled on Aman....at half the price (We stayed in both hotels and thought the Andaz was better)- Everything feels new and not worn out- Great views over Tokyo from all rooms (47-49 floors). Best view is the Tokyo Tower view.- Rooftop bar with sunset views and music vibes. My wife said the cocktails were also excellent- Huge heated pool with spa and soaking tub. A favourite with my son every day- The rooms are relatively large compared to other Tokyo luxury hotels- The coffee downstairs at "Koffee Toranmo" is the best coffee we've had anywhere in the world- Staff service was excellent and attentive- Location & Area: Some reviews suggest the location isn't good, however given it's 2mins walk to Ginza line metro and 10min taxi to most areas/restaurants/stations you want to visit we thought it was convenient. The only downside is the hotel is located in an office building and during the week full of workers. However the upside is there are restaurants in the building/convenience store/coffee/taxis/bars close by. I wouldn't worry about this factorThe Bad:- The only major issue of our 5 day stay was on the last day when the rooftop bar was booked out for a wedding. This really annoyed my wife who loved going up there for a drink to escape the Tokyo craziness. We are paying good money to utilise the entire hotel and don't appreciate being told that we can't access it for guests who aren't even staying in the hotel?. The hotel should either have a separate facility for weddings/events or notify users on website before booking. If we had known, we probably would have stayed else where. One of my pet hates for hotels globally!- Why are the towels half-size and pillows soft and scratchy when you move? Only small issues however can be improved

Exceptional room and service helpful professional management will assure your satisfaction. More of a destination than an accommodation. Impressive views from any floor and rooftop bar and sushi bar offer great food and experience.

As with all Andaz hotels, design trumps all else in this hotel. It was very nice (sleek, clean, new) but I am generally not a fan of hotels with a tiny street entrance then lobby on a high floor. I hate having to take multiple elevators to "commute" to my room! That said, the hotel was very nice....with an EXCELLENT fitness center and pool. I would definitely stay here again.

Rooms are spacious for Tokyo with wonderful views. Staff is very attentive and helpful, although their knowledge of the local restaurants was not as good as we hoped. The area around the hotel is pleasantly quiet on the weekend and busy during the week. Hotel restaurants had excellent food. Ginza subway and JR lines easy walk, a few blocks to the Ginza line a bit longer to Shimbashi (1km). Great experience hope to return.

We stayed at the Park Hyatt, Conrad and Andaz during our stay in Tokyo.The service at the Andaz is good, somewhat casual. That is not necessarily a bad thing. I think by design they are catered to the younger crowds. I like the check in process. When checking in, they welcomed you and have you sit and wait in this big beautifully made wooden communal table. They served you refreshments while they take your passport complete all the check in process for you. It's nice.The design of the hotel is just something else tho. Beautiful, modern, interesting. The entrance to the main elevator, beautiful. The bathroom, walk in closet area, wood paneling, one piece hard wood long table, beautiful. Everywhere you look it's just eye candy. Details after details. The spa and pool are just exquisite. There is a carbonated jacuzzi which I have never been in before. As far as the 'hard' product is concerned, compared to the Conrad Tokyo or Park Hyatt Tokyo, the Andaz is comfortably ahead. And that is to be expected as Andaz is the newest hotel opened in 2014, compared to Conrad or Park Hyatt. I think they are 10 to 20 years old respectively?For the 'soft' product though Andaz is still lagging compared to those 2 hotels. Don't get me wrong, the staffs are professional and very pleasant. The staffs at the spa are excellent even by 'Japanese' high end hospitality standard. One small negative I feel about the staff interactions is that they are not as 'smooth' as they are at Park Hyatt definitely and at the Conrad.But, ultimately I am nit picking. This is an excellent hotel. Another crown jewel for the Hyatt group and Tokyo hospitality.

Our family of four (2 adults and 2 kids) stayed here as an alternative to the Park Hyatt in Shinjuku. The location isn’t fantastic but truthfully the metro station was only two blocks away and could access pretty much anywhere. The imperial gardens where within walking distance. Overall, a luxurious looking and feeling property. Highly recommend it.

While in Tokyo, we stayed at Andaz, Conrad, and Peninsula.Service was impeccable at all three.But the rooms at Andaz won us over. Incredible panoramic view of the city, complimentary mini bar (minus alcohol drinks), complimentary happy hour, awesome gym facilities. The fact that the hotel was built in 2014-2015 also helps. Some have complained about the location of the hotel. We didn't see this as an issue at all as the hotel is very close to the subway station. We will be back!

Great views. My room was on the 47th floor. Check in process is very modern. You sit and enjoy a beverage while they bring the process to you. Brilliant! Staff were very helpful with directions and restaurant reservations outside of the hotel. Nice lobby lounge area with complimentary items including happy hour. Good breakfast buffet of Japanese and western items, but smaller in selection to other places I've been. Felt repetitive after a few days. Good room service selections. Room decor slightly odd for modern hotel (e.g. dingy green carpet). Felt 70s-ish but I would stay here again. Also best idea to offer free non-alcoholic beverages from the minibar!

There is absolutely nothing you could complain about Andaz. Everything is perfectly done - the rooms are immaculate, the staff exemplifies Japanese service standards, the food is amazing. I'm sure there are some that would complain about the location being slightly off the main subway stations, but if you can afford to stay at a swanky hotel like Andaz, I think you can afford to pay for a taxi ride to the likes of Ginza and Shimbashi. And the slightly off-centre location gives you one of the best 360-degree view of Tokyo (if not the best). What's not to like?

This is a review for my stay in May 2017. Had been busy these days and just had time to complete this review. But I think I have to write this review because Andaz Tokyo that stay was really impressive and memorable!Can't remember how many times i have stayed in this hotel. All I can remember is the excellent service I got from Andaz Tokyo on every single stay. This time, I booked Andaz with AMEX fine hotel program.The program comes with 100 USD dining credit and breakfast. Rooms was upgraded to the Tokyo tower view room with great skyline view.Visited Tokyo with my wife this time and her birthday was on the day before check-in. The front desk lady noticed that when we handed in our passports to her for check in (in fact, we haven't mentioned anything about my wife's birthday). After a short while. The front desk lady brought us the room keys and handed my wife a nice wooden box of brownie. We were so surprised how diligent the front desk lady was to spot this little thing.Tokyo is never a strange place to Hong Kong people, However, the Tokyo tower view from the room is always stunning. We just want to stay inside the room whole day.In terms of location, it's close to metro station. A few stops from Ginza, but a bit far away from Shinjuku, The hotel restaurant was great, we had nice breakfast there, especially the Japanese breakfast. We used the credits for room service. Food were fresh, hot and tasty.Had good time at the AO spa as well.In summary, this is an excellent hotel for its flawless service and rooms with stunning tokyo skyline view. Will definitely stay again in near future.

Great location, fantastic rooms and super friendly staff. Everybody extremely helpful. Breakfast of great quality. Rooftop bar magnificent views over tokyo and good drinks. When we go back to Tokyo it will be the andaz again, no doubt.

Our honeymoon and first ever trip to Japan started in the most wonderful way.Before travelling next day to Amonohashidate at a Ryokan (which I will provide a review of) we stayed here at Andaz Tokyo.First class customer service, we were greeted after a long flight with seat and coffee.Our room had amazing views of the Tokyo tower and the city, the room felt like home with the large bath, rainhead shower and a proper walk in closet.Thank Andaz Tokyo.. we recommend you to all our family and friends.

I just completed a two day stay at the Andaz Tokyo and I was simply blown away by my experience. I had been expecting a positive experience based on the reviews, but this stay was far and beyond that. Lets discuss a few areas:1) Service: The service here was way over the top. I came in a day early to drop off my luggage at the hotel. I brought along Kosher food that required refrigeration. The staff took my bags and found room for everything in a number of refrigerators and freezers. They were eager to help me get things in order even though I was not staying at the hotel that night. When I checked in early the next morning, they were eager to get me into my room as quickly as possible. The front desk staff was apologetic that the room was not available for only 15 minutes. I remind you that this was way before the hotel check in time. Yet, I was in a gorgeous room by 10 AM! Throughout my stay, every encounter I had with the staff was friendly, helpful and with a smile. Being that I had brought my food, I required some help with the logistics of having it heated up. The hotel was happy to accommodate my needs and make it feel quite normal.2) The room: Wood all around, amazing views of Tokyo. Great bed. One particular thing I liked was the very separate bathroom and shower / bath area. While I was booked into a regular room, it felt as if it were a suite based on the design. Included mini bar, large sofa...3) Spa, gym, and pool: Again, top notch here as well. The spa was clean and had a nice and hot dry sauna. The only thing missing here was a wet sauna. That would have made this perfect. The pool was clean. Perfect temp, great for a morning swim! Gym had all of the standard hotel gym equip with a full set of dumbbells. The view from the spa area is nice, although not as good as the room IMO.4) Location: I have heard people complain about the location. Sure, its not in the middle of everything. A walk to the subway for me was about 7 minutes (Ginza line). It was not great, but not a big inconvenience. One nice thing about the location was it's proximity to the imperial palace. I was able to go on a nice run around the palace walls without having to take a train there.I can't wait to come and visit this phenomenal hotel in the future.

I absolutely loved this hotel. It was everything I was after. I loved the design and the decor, the rooms are extremely comfortable...arguably the best nights sleep i've ever had in a hotel room! Little touches like having a Bose soundsystem in your room were great. Food is excellent and the views are amazing.

Very nice design and super convenient to our meetings that were in the same building. The only thing I didn't like was taking the super fast elevator from the ground level to 51. My ears always popped and I had slight vertigo for just a minute or two. Spa and pool are also very nice.
user_name:
Christy N
Rio de Janeiro, RJ

review_body: We have lived next to the Andaz for the past two years while on assignment in Tokyo and have visited the Rooftop Bar many many times and the experience was always great, therefore for our last night in Tokyo, we decided to stay at the hotel. It was nice, he bathroom was specious, the view was good, but the room was a bit small, especially with the huge desk right in front the window blocking the view a bit. The service was ok, not as great as I would have expected.

From the moment we checked in, everything was super 5 star and in fact surpassed our expectations!The staff were very attentive, incredibly courteous and helpful and did everything to make us feel pampered and right at home.Our room had incredible views of the Tokyo skyline and we enjoyed all the amazing food in the restaurants in the building. We also had a fabulous experience when we went for our spa treatments - consistently great service!And absolutely loved the daily cocktail hour in the hotel lobby!It was my first time in Tokyo and I loved it so much I'll definitely be back...won't even bother looking for any other hotel to stay in!

From arrival to check-n, you are handed off between very courteous people, and made to feel very comfortable and valued. The service is impeccable. The rooms are extravagant and built for comfort and relaxation.

This would be the second time I've decided to book a night at Andaz for my random staycation. Needless to say, 1 year later, I did not regret it.Service here remains top notch, quick and efficient with minimal effort required on the guest's part. With early check-in's granted to those who provide enough details regarding their arrival (and with rooms permitting of course).I"m typically a hotel snob that prefers to have hotel rooms on high floors that offer better views of city where I stay, but for this hotel's case...it really doesn't matter, given that you start off from the top already.The rooms have remained clean, modern, and scratch free (meaning either guests staying there are very careful with their rooms, or the room is build with very durable material).Hotel amenities change every season (one of the benefits of Japan's 4 season availability), with this time being spring.Overall the room continues to provide me with a calm and serene place to relax away from the chaos down below, but at the same time, offering a great view of this great city.

ProsBeautiful hotel with modern decorBreathtaking viewComfy bedRound bathtub and strong shower Amenities-Argan, quite goodNexpresso machineNice pool and spa-must visitFree refreshments and snacks at day loungeLobby at 51 floorWonderful serviceConsLocation- Business district , 6-10min to subwayNot so happening in the locationA bit expensive

We stayed 2 nights in a King view large room. The plus: amazing bedroom with 5 huge windows. Never seen this before. You have a unique view on the imperial garden and on the Tokyo bay. The hotel and the room style are refined using dark wood materials in combination with white boards. You feel even in a modern place the touch of Japanese style: pure and beautiful. The pool and the fitness areas are very well equipped and brand new. They even have a powerplate machine. The area for the shower has hot and cold bath. The staff was great; friendly and discreet. The breakfast was very decent even though quite expensive. The minus: we went to the bar at the 52nd floor for cocktails. The cocktails were very good (Tokyo mule) but there is a lack of ambiance. Difficult to say why. Maybe the location is not the easiest one to create a warm ambiance. In conclusion certainly our best hotel in Tokyo.

We had a very large room with an impressive view of Tokyo. The bathroom alone was bigger than most rooms. It was tough leaving the room. The service was exceptional. Our favorite part was the Gym and the pool. Out of this world. The neighborhood, however, is not interesting at all. So, if you stay there, be prepared to use taxi or the subway system (a 10 mn. walk)

My wife and I travel extensively for business and pleasure, and short of the Aman this hotel has to be the best in Tokyo... ... Usually Tokyo rooms are so small, the rooms were large, the Japanese soaking tubs and bathroom designs were so clever, it felt even larger... the service was amazing - when our clothes were returned from being cleaned, folded in an almost origami style paper wrap, there was attached a small plastic pouch, with change and receipts we had accidentally left in our pockets... (this happened twice... what honesty!)The 36th floor pool and spa was a welcome relief from our long work days... and what perfection... amazing views to soak in... and created jet therapy in a number of hidden spots... The food at breakfast was perfect... although a buffet style.. it was very high end, with them delivering Eggs Benedict to the table... and a nice assortment of perfect pastries and creative asian food...Last, the Valet staff, especially Max, made us feel as if we were returning to our high end flat rather than a hotel... and their warmth and kindness was a breath of fresh air!Ps.. we also stayed at the Penninsula on this trip, and my review is also on TripAdviosr for that hotel (we checked out of the Penninsula early and returned to the Andaz...)

I love the vibe of this hotel. It's boutique-y with a 5 star luxury hotel service. The room was spacious, big bathroom and I especially enjoyed the round bathtub. The buffet breakfast was the best!!! Truly the Japanese breakfast I wanted with the Japanese rice, egg roe, seaweed and saba (mackerel). The front desk and service crew were attentive and friendly. The only downside is the location, the hotel is far from the "happening" area but at least near enough to a train station. The whole stay would have been perfect except for the last part. We were running late for our flight so we asked the person in charge at the transportation desk at the hotel entrance to get a taxi, we were waiting for 20 minutes and noticed that there was still no taxi. Then when we went to the person to follow up on our ride to the airport, it was then that we realized that he hasn't even called yet! It was very unprofessional especially for a hotel of this caliber! Over all, the stay was still great! The staff who assisted us the whole stay (the one who brought our bags to the room and down the elevator as we were leaving) was so nice, helpful and professional. Kudos to him!!!

The Andaz represents luxury. Having stayed in hundreds of hotels, this is now one of my favorite. The room was impressively large with a modern but functional feel. The shower was also extremely large and the water pressure excellent. There was a lot of room for storage and the room had incredible views. The bed was super comfortable. There was a Nespresso maker as well as a separate device to boil water with excellent tea provided. The wifi signal was strong and there was a nice table in the room which made it easy to work which is helpful if you are staying for business. The staff went out of their way to be helpful and were very friendly. I strongly recommend signing up for breakfast with the room. Although the breakfast buffet isn’t huge, the quality of everything was amazing from the fresh squeezed orange juice to the fresh fruit to the array of Japanese foods available.

Very comfortable room and bed, great amenities in the bathroom, very relaxing spa. Fantastic staff, breathtaking views, amazing service. I particularly enjoyed the friendly staff and the personal touch they gave to each guest, the esthetics of the hotel. This was a perfect stay.

Stayed two nights, and have no negatives to say about this property ... very spacious room (we were on 50th floor, but the lowest floor you can be set up in this hotel is the 47th), top-rate service from any staff member we got in touch with, high-quality spa and a large pool. You'l get a big smile on your face from the time you check it throughout your entire stay ...

Loved staying at the Andaz hotel. The room was gorgeous, complete will a full set of furniture, desk, bed, huge bath tub. The amenities were great, including a wonderful spa and gym that was sparsely used (aka beautiful and not busy). I usually say that I prefer staying away from hotel experiences, but that's because I had never been to the Andaz before. I would happily live at the Andaz forever :)

While there may be better locations, there is no better hotel in Tokyo. The service is amazing, rooms tranquil and welcoming, the gym, spa and pool are world class. If you have the time, get a massage or facial. The AO spa is only matched by its sister spa at the Andaz Muai

My family stayed at Andaz Tokyo couple weeks ago. It was best hotel ever I had stayed! Great facility, Great Service and wonderful food!It's very convenient location as well. I strongly recommend this hotel to everyone!!!

The service was excellent from the moment we arrived at the hotel. The hotel is in a quieter, business district but a close walk to the metro and Tokyo's main attractions. I definitely would stay again.

Having stayed in hotels the world over, I can honestly say there is nowhere I would rather lay my head down than the Andaz Tokyo. Everything is thought out well; the employees are always eager to help without being overbearing; the food and drink are delicious. The hotel is a little removed from the neon of Shibuya and Shinjuku, but the metro takes you there in minutes. Whenever I am in Tokyo, this is where I will stay.

A wonderful stay in a peaceful and beautiful room with all the right details and understated luxuries. Hotel was elegant and service was top notch and extremely helpful! Thanks Andaz for a memorable stay. We will definitely be coming back!

Andaz was the last hotel we stayed on a 15-day trip to Japan. What a perfect ending. The hotel was beautiful, there were snacks throughout the day and the staff was wonderfully accommodating. As the hotel starts on the 45th (or so) floor of the Mori Tower, the view is stupendous everywhere. I appreciated the fact that the third rollaway bed was already in the room and prepared to Andaz's exacting standards before we arrived. While Toranomon Hills isn't right in the middle of the action as in Shinjuku (I have stayed in both the Hyatt regency and the Park Hyatt), it was close to several different metro lines and there were lots of affordable restaurants within a few blocks. The breakfast spread was plentiful and good.

This was the second stay at this amazing hotel for my wife, son and I (our first stay was in June 2015). Other reviewers have said it all - spacious rooms with free in-room snacks and non-alcoholic beverages, beautiful decor, great pool and spa, free wine/sake/snacks during happy hour... These things alone are enough to bring us back and we'll certainly stay here again the next time we visit Tokyo. I'd like to comment on the service we experienced on this recent stay. Just before checkout we learned that our departing flight was delayed. Staff members Ayumi, Kazuhiro and Jowen went out of their way to help keep us informed (by making inquiries to the airline on our behalf) and comfortable during our delay. A mildly stressful event was made much easier thanks to them - smiling, attentive service went a long way on that day! We ended up staying an additional night since our flight delay kept increasing and ultimately stretched out to 19 hours, but if we were going to be stuck somewhere, what better place than at the Andaz!

Great rooms, service and location. Rooms are modern with a fantastic view of Tokyo. I like the touch of wood finishing inside the room fixtures. Highly recommended for business trips to Tokyo. Very close to Ginza and other Tokyo must visit places.

Located most highest part of Mori tower building, the view over Tokyo tower from my room in Andaz Tokyo was amazing. All staffs were very kind and professional. They were very attentive and looks natural and gentle at the same time. Very good location to visit most of the attractions in Tokyo. Round and big bath tub was good to take a rest. Especially my son likes the bath tub. And pool is great in both facility and service. I highly recommend Andaz Tokyo. Great View and Great Service. :-)

The Andaz is described as a concept hotel - and it is a truly wonderful concept.The lobby and public areas are on the 51st floor - and have a triple storey ceiling - giving a feeling of vitality and space. There is an all day lounge with free refreshments, plus wine for a couple of hours in the evening - the lounge has a relaxed and club like atmosphere. Business people meet there in the day and then giggle together at night. The breakfast buffet is served on this floor, with western and Japanese dishes - freshly prepared - the menu varies gently from day to day.Our room was downstairs on the 50th floor. It had a zen like design - white, black and wood enhanced by green carpets - this combination really does work. And the outside wall was completely glass - the views were incredible - especially at night.A good place to stay? YES!!!

Great hotel, with outstanding design and service. Good location and amazing views! My son and I stayed their and it was our preferred hotel in Japan after travelling for a week. Great vibe and delicious food!

I stayed for a week in the Andaz Tokyo and was genuinely sad to leave. The hotel itself is gorgeous with absolutely stunning views of the city. I found it a wonderful island of tranquility during my stay in bustling Tokyo. Every staff member I encountered went of their way to make me feel welcome and taken care of. The breakfasts were a treat and I visited the gym and spa area almost everyday. The hotel is the height of luxury and relaxation and I would wholeheartedly recommend it to any traveler wanted to feel pampered and surround by peace, warmth and beauty.

I stayed at the Andaz for a week. When I checked in, they set us up in a semi-private room to fill out the paperwork and serve us a glass of wine. The room was large and had a few melon filled pastries greeting us.Later, when we tried to make reservations at some nice restaurants, the staff was very helpful finding places that could handle my dietary needs (vegetarian, which is not easy in a place where everything is fish or fish stocks). They found two amazing places for me.The rooftop bar is great and they will try to get hotel guests window seating. The cocktails are expensive, but very well-made and unique.Will definitely come back.

Had to travel to Tokyo for business and it happened to be during Cherey Blossom. All hotels were booked in the area we had to travel but we were able to get in at Andaz. Maybe there were rooms available because it was $600 a night but worth it plus it didn't come out of my pocket. The Andaz is amazing from the unbelievable service to the beautiful rooms to the Gorgeous swimming pool and Jacuzzis. I get to travel all over the world for work and have stayed at hundreds the hotels, the Andaz Tokyo is by far the best I have ever stayed at.

Beautiful architect and interior design. Excellent services offered by everyone we met. We booked the room with Tokyo Tower view - a wonderful view for every night so worth the bit of extra. It is a new hotel thus the functionality (location and design of Concierge, check-in and check-out areas, design of toilet/bath room/basins/walk-in closet makes sense - functionality and aesthetically). We stayed for 4 nights but still missed it. Will be difficult not to go back if travel to Tokyo again

First off wonderful hotel all around. It has everything one could need . Id like to say it all depends on what you are looking for..... whether it be for business or pleasure. My trip was strictly for relaxation and not work. My husband asked me what i thought of the hotel upon my return and the best way to describe it was : it was very masculine.... think dark colors, muted lighting, strong harsh colors in the rooms, dark bathtub area , room had a masculine smell with lots of black and gray. So for female travelers out there looking for a warm St Regis type of place, light colors, inviting lighting , lots of beiges and vanilla tones, this is not the place. Its your typical high rise Tokyo style hotel with lots of steel and glass. I did use all of the facilities to include they gym (great views of the city), the sauna (wet ) area was quite good, female locker room area had all one could need, toiletries, towels, snacks, shampoo, hair dryer, creams etc etc.... at no extra charge! The female area also had a private onsen about 2 feet deep with very warm water. There is also a main pool for lap swimming which was also nice. The one thing that this hotel did absolutely get right was a separate elevator that will take you from your room straight to the gym/spa without having to go through the lobby in your bathrobe or work out gear.... upon return from the spa you take the same elevator straight back to your room! never having to worry about uncomfortable encounters... I did peek at the rooftop 52nd floor bar area but wasn't overly impressed and decided the 51st floor Tavern area with piano was much more relaxing. Overall nice stay . There are just so many hotels in Tokyo to try that i will not be staying at this hotel again . Think i need something a bit more Martha Stewart :)

We stayed here for one night in June. This place is beautiful. Our room had an amazing view and it was extremely nice inside. The bathroom is luxurious. Most of all, the people working there were so friendly and helpful. They spoke English very well and they went above and beyond my expectations. This is the nicest service I have ever had at a regular hotel before. The breakfast buffet had a mix of western and traditional items. It was one of the nicest buffets I have seen. I would definitely stay here again.

I adore this hotel- potentially one of my favourite hotels I have stayed in. The room and other areas of the hotel are all beautifully designed. The pool and spa area are stunning, and the building itself has spectacular views across the city. I would definitely stay here again. The food was also very good. I love the fact they provide free wine and snacks in the afternoon. Be sure to use the bar at the top of the tower during your stay. We also stayed at the Park hyatt during this trip, and despite the better location, I would pick the Andaz over the Park Hyatt any other time I visit Tokyo.

This hotel is amazing! The lobby is on the 51st floor and the rooms are on the 47th - 50th floors. They have floor to ceilng plate glass windows that offer stunnig views of Tokyo (*note - if you have a fear of heights, this may not be a good hotel for you, a low floor is not an option). Within walking distance of multiple subway lines, lots of restaurants, coffee shops and covenience stores in the area, including 7/11 with an international ATM. I traveled with my daughter and we walked from the subway to the hotel late at night and felt completely safe and had no issues. It is about 15 minutes from Tokyo station in a cab. The service is top notch, they have free sodas and snacks and a wine happy hour each night. Because of the lobby being on the 51st floor, it is very private and really the only people in the hotel are guests... not a lot of people popping in/out for food/drinks. While we were there, there was a very high profile/sports person staying there... I am guessing this hotel was chosen for its privacy. I researched a lot of hotels and while it is on the higher end, it is by no means the most expensive hotel in Tokyo... and even if it was, I would probably stay there agin, it is that special!

I'd stayed in the Tokyo Andaz on business and was delighted to have the opportunity to visit with my wife on a few days vacation. It didn't disappoint. the only problem is convincing my wife that not all hotels I go to on business are as wonderful as the Andaz!!

I stay 4 nights with my wife and daughter here. The staffs are so nice, helpful, polite and professional. The room is big, as compared to ANA Intercontinental, 3 full size beds, big bathtub and 6 foot desk by the window.Complementary Mini bar with non alcohol beverage. It's impressive me that 24 hours lounge with tea, or juice.

We stayed at the Andaz for one night at the end of our two week Japan trip and we wished we stayed longer. Here is the good: - if you want to stay at Park Hyatt but can't afford it, this is the next best place. It's still offers you the view and the swimming pool area is beautiful (although not as amazing as Park Hyatt) and is at 200$ cheaper per night- around the hotel has little shops and back alley streets to explore- the hotel itself is on the top of the building and the below floors are full of dining options, plus hair salon, pastry shop etc- we requested inter-connecting rooms as we had our two little children sleeping in the other room- quite spacious compared to the standard hotel room size plus bathrooms are quite large-provided 6-8pm free canapés in the lobby-obviously free wifi-breakfast buffet was good. Not a large selection of options but it was good whatever was provided. I wouldn't say it was the best I've had though-mini bar is free except alcoholic drinks which is a really nice touch when hotels do thatHere is he not so good - room for improvement:- we are Tablet Hotel members and we could have received an upgrade for our room but we didn't. It was disappointing - check in process was ok but we had to wait for our room to be ready. We waited for 2 hours. That wasn't really great as I have two little children and both were tired. This waiting around business in a huge hotel - I just don't get. There are definitely other rooms available, it's just a matter of whether you provide it or not.-Dining at the main restaurant was ok. Expensive-The lady in charge on that morning when we wanted to have our breakfast wasnt professional. I had called earlier to reserve a table next to the windows for the view but also to have ample space for our kids to move around. When I told her we had booked a table in that corner she was a bit funny and weird about it. Then when asked to have a high chair, she reacted in a strange way too- The worst was when we were waiting for our express bus to go to Narita airport! 5 men were trying to sort our suitcases and load them on the bus. All confused and taking so long. Took us 20 mins just for us to get on the bus. It was bizarre. Every other stop the bus stopped, it took literally 5 mins. Not even. The man in charge of the drop off and pick up area of the hotel needs extra training. He wasn't polite either. Only man who was very polite and aware of how long it was taking was the French staff member. He was lovely.  Overall we enjoyed it but will I stay again, not sure. U are spoiled for choice in Tokyo. But the pool spa area is truly amazing. Might come back just cuz of that.

Andaz is one of the finest hotels in Tokyo. Top notch. Rooms are spacious, with lavish offerings. The views are gorgeous and dynamic. It has all the comforts of a 5-star hotel. They have facilities such as gym, swimming pool. The amenities are plentiful and the location is excellent right in the heart of downtown Tokyo.

Incredible view. Staff was polite, friendly and efficient. Room clean and comfortable. Good free wife in all area and free access to the SPA. I really liked the 24h free lounge. Also conveniently located. Check it out

I stayed here for 1 night with my wife and mother to celebrate a special occasion. I stay at Hyatt hotels over 60 nights a year and have Globalist status. It is a very expensive hotel and looked very beautiful from the pictures.I had emailed the hotel prior to arrival to ask if they could make this trip special, but I was informed that they would only adhere to only what was required but nothing more in the WOH program in regards to their Globalist guests. At check-in the lady was friendly, however she was quick to point out that breakfast was only included for 2 adults in the room and since my mother was an adult and not a child she would have to pay for breakfast. Recently Hyatt Gold Passport changed to World of Hyatt, in the old program breakfast was for all registered guests in the room, but now under WOH it is for 2 adults and 2 children per room. Every Hyatt I have stayed at has honored the old terms and invited all 3 of us to breakfast. However this was not the case at the Andaz Tokyo. FYI: At both the Conrad and Hyatt Regency all 3 of us were invited to breakfast and evening canapes in their lounges. (Even though they were not required to do so)The Andaz did adhere to the rules of World of Hyatt. They did NOT go above and beyond in any manner, which is a shame because we were really looking forward to our stay here. I would recommend the GREAT Hyatt Regency a few miles away in Shinjuku or the Conrad nearby if you really want a special stay. I never would have thought that I would be saying that, but it was indeed a much better experience there than I had at the Andaz. We were treated much better at the Conrad and Hyatt Regency than at the Andaz. I must say that the Andaz is a beautiful hotel, however I didn't feel comfortable at all here. The staff was generally nice, but also very standoffish.We also had a few problems with the shower and bathtub in the room which just added to the "not so great" experience. I shared the issues at checkout, although they didn't seem to care very much.

The level of hospitality which staff gave to us is something out of "manual" they have, unlike the one which I usually receive from other high-end brand such as Ritz-Carlton, Four Seasons. I had a issue with early check in for my partners. She was checking in for the reservation under my name, but according to hotel staff, she was scrutinized and treated as if she was bleaching hotel security. She voluntarily gave 2 credit cards and other ID information, yet she was kept at bay for checking in until hotel front reached me by phone. Front desk manager approached me later giving me all the excuses citing "hotel security", but it is for their protection and not mine, and they hurt the feeling of my partner. I did not get the value for the price I paid.
user_name:
貞史 Sada 鈴
Tokyo, Japan

review_body: I stayed in this hotel for three times but this review is based on my most recent stay (April 2017). I will also include photos from my previous stays.This hotel is the most gorgeous city hotel I've stayed in, everything from the public areas to the rooms to the pool are meticulously designed and the view is second to none. Toranomon Hills is the building that houses the hotel, and it has a few eateries within the same complex, including a convenience store and a coffee shop serving amazing coffee - Toranomon Koffee. The vicinity is pretty dead on the weekends but there are no shortage of Japanese restaurants, including chains, offering quick bites (noodles).The service across the board is generally very good, and up to Japanese standards. Special shout out goes to Andrea at the front office who has helped me arrange lots of things and made a few exceptions for me. Kaho at the front office is also very friendly, helpful and genuine, while Abe san at the Andaz lounge makes great cocktails. They are all great assets of the hotel. By the way, I noticed all staff members were very helpful and are willing to go beyond their assigned tasks. For example, the wait staff are the Tavern were very helpful with attraction tips and transportation information, they would patiently spend up to 10 minutes in helping us with recommendations, big thumbs up!The breakfast spread, while not huge, is extremely high quality and tasty, especially the Nutella brioche with vanilla sauce - heavenly. The smoked salmon was also among the best I've tasted, but I am very disappointed with the lack of freshly squeezed juice - unacceptable for a hotel of this caliber. I thought it was a bit absurd and borderline disrespectful to drive me out of the restaurant after breakfast has ended, without allowing me to relax and go through my emails for a bit longer. They did, to their credit, offer me a table at the adjacent bar but I thought it was a bit of a hassle to move.All in all, despite this hotel being generally very pricey, this is one of my favorite hotels in the world, and I would not hesitant a single bit to return to this hotel when I'm visiting Tokyo.

The view from the room is amazing. The hotel is beautifully designed with comfort in mind. We spent our last night in Japan here and wished we had stayed here when we were in Tokyo at the beginning of the trip. Next time, we will make this our base location for Tokyo. It is a short walk to the station, there are things to see within walking distance and restaurants are easy to access. Taxis are waiting at street level so you can get anywhere quickly.

I've been to here before heading to my home sweet home. It's the perfect stays as usual. The bed and duvet are comfortable; it made my sweet dreams when I suffered jet-lag. As you can see the attached pics, the view from a room is stunning. The breakfast is nice balance between Asians and Westerns. The most great thing is the staffs; they are really welcoming the guests and they really want to make happy whom stays at the hotel.

This inspiring hotel offers a unique blend of traditional and modern Japanese style, in a peaceful location that is just close enough to the action in Tokyo. The views from all four directions are absolutely stunning, and the room/common area design is a very refreshing change of pace from stuffy high-end hotels. The staff goes above and beyond to take care of the guests. In addition, this hotel has the most amazing pool/spa complex around, offering a panoramic view of the city from the perfect water of the infinity pool and spa. There are plenty of dining options within the building, and it is a short stroll away from the lively streets around Shimbashi station. There are three subway stations within a 5-10 minute walk.

We arrived at the ground level by cab and the staffs were very friendly as well as efficient to get things delivered up to level 51 (where their checkin, lobby and restaurant is). The lobby staffs were really friendly and they took the initiative to come and say hello - and then to get us to sit at the waiting area as well as give us some food and drink as we waited. Once we have got into the room, the luggages have arrived too - impressive about their coordination. We stayed for a few days and I've tried the breakfast which was reasonable selection and again, service is impeccable and the chair was very comfortable with great ambience. The spa and the swimming pool is very clean and there are etiquette about how shoes are taken off in some areas for hygiene reason and the cap was required for the swimming pool. The rest area is also conveniently equipped with relaxation zone that one can get a drink after a tiring swim and the shampoo/conditioner and the hair products with some skin products are all there for you to use. Very thoroughly thought about the requirements of the guests and the service was so pleasant. It is not a cheap place to stay but the room is very big with a large bath tub in the room and a good sized dressing area. It is great with the views as well. There are only limited rooms as it is part of the office building downstairs. A little walk to the MTR station but certainly not straining at all.

A really enjoyable place to stay - great service at every level - food is great in all the restaurant - bar is very well placed with an amazing view on a park - bartender is awarded for his cocktail skills - a place not to miss either for the food or for the hotel

Awesome venue at the terrace for our office dinner party. The view of the Skytower is great - it is right behind you. On our evening, the weather was just perfect. The service was great - everyone was extremely helpful. I had struggled to get a restaurant to accommodate 50+ people, including ~20 vegetarians, in a private venue. This was the one place where the chef was willing to flex and accommodate a vegetarian cuisine as well. They had the music only for us post 11 PM and the DJ in fact set up the console where we were. He was exceptionally flexible and even had a good Bollywood collection!!! Perfect setting for a memorable dinner

Poor service at the Rooftop Bar. Had to practically beg for a menu. Asked bartender/waiter 3 times for water with no avail. You get much better service at CoCo Ichibanya and in all serious better quality food. If you're looking for great service and view of Tokyo, you're much better off visiting to Ritz-Carlton or Park Hyatt.

Very good stay here. Staff are friendly. Rooms are spacious and clean. The location is good but not perfect. Not much within walking distance, but it is pretty close to Roppogi, Ginza, and Tokyo Station by taxi. The view is spectacular. The view of Tokyo Tower is so great that I did not want to leave my room during my stay. Would return when visit Tokyo again.

A wonderful Hotel. great staff, great food and amazing views overlooking all tokyo. the rooms are very spacious. it is up the top end for rates but good value for money. food and beverages were high quality and the sushi bar is a must.

This hotel was an extremely pleasant surprise. Great views from the room. Great bathrooms. The pool area was very nice and the service was professional and friendly. Much more personable than many Japanese hotels. Would definitely stay again.

Excellent property. Spacious rooms. Very clean, quiet, view. Excellent breakfast buffet. Nice atmosphere- comfortable and not pretentious like some top hotels.Personalized service from the staff. Good location . Highly recommend. I give it 5 stars.

Great, great, hotel. There are a lot of great hotels in Tokyo, and I am lucky to have stayed in some of them, but this one has something more, it is "homy". Not only the rooms ,situated from the 46th floor ( mine was on the 50th fl), have an awesome view, and are very luxurious , but at the reception situated on the 51st fl, you can have a free tea, or juice with nibbles, all day long, and from 6 to 8pm, their happy hour, with wine and sandwiches makes you feel cozy and relaxed after a day voisin ting or working on Tokyo.I went for a swim in their awesome infinite pool, and had a massage with a very experienced therapist.Everyone is so so nice...and helpful. With all these sofas and corners around the fire place, you really feel good.Go for it!
user_name:
Fpny
New York City, New York

review_body: Beautiful, well appointed hotel with Japanese touches, and contemporary rooms. Service oriented and authentic staff who are pleased to help with reservations, directions, luggage forwarding. Breakfast buffet is excellent. Started our trip at the Andaz and couldn't wait to get back at the end of our journey.

By so many standards, this hotel is by far the best in Tokyo.Modern, it gives you this nice feeling of home. Staff will go extra mile to grant all your requests. The food selection and quality is here again best in class

This is my second time stayed in Andaz Tokyo. The service is amazing, room is in top condition and very clean. The best part is the overall experience of being welcomed and at ease every time you are in the hotel. I will stay here every time I come to Japan for business or personal. Highly recommend it!

great ambience, fantastic service, staff extremely helpful, very nice rooms with a great view. the hotel lobby is situated on the 51st floor the rooms are about 10 floors down. beautiful spa. just a great new hotel.

My family and I traveled to Japan for the first time. It was our 10 month old son's first international trip and we wanted to make every experience special for us, but most especially for him. First of all, we wanted a comfortable, modern and flawless designed hotel. The Andaz met our criteria and the service and amenities were above and beyond our expectations. We had such an amazing, relaxing and wonderful time and experience that we plan to check out more Andaz properties in our future travels. We plan to return to Tokyo in a few years when our son is older and there is no doubt will we stay at the Andaz. It's our favorite urban hotel.

It's a very beautiful property at an excellent location. The breakfast buffet is in the top 10 for all the buffets I've eaten at over the years. The staff is very attentive and thoughtful. Very nice stay and we will be back.

We could not find spa menu written in mother language in the room for which we had to call room service. It took about 15minutes to check in the hotel because of the particular individual check in system performed on large dining table in guests lounge. We had to ask some questions for three times because no staff answered our inquiry. Hotel guests can not expect hospitality at all. The view from the room was really great.

Andaz is a part of the Hyatt chain, a lifestyle brand. For once that expression means something more than fancy wallpapers and bad lightning, this hotel is lovely. As all rooms are on floors 47-50, views are great from everywhere. Bathroom made me wish my stay had been longer, a round bathtub, all amenities there, good hairdryer, yukatas and nice slippers, open wardrobe for clothes and, the best hotel bed where I have ever slept ( could one buy these mattresses somewhere?). Restaurant Tavern offered an excellent breakfast with all the oriental / occidental options, and great European style bread. I also had a dinner there, very tasty although not cheap but that is to be expected. There is also a reception lounge with newspapers and coffee/tee served but I did not have time to test it. My new favourite hotel in Tokyo.

Absolutely amazing end to our honeymoon! Brilliant views with phenomal service all round. We had dinner in the tavern and the staff and chefs made me a personal meal as I am vegetarian and it was my favourite meal in Japan!

This hotel is absolutely great but also expensive. The design is modern but also has a lot of the Japanese culture build in. The rooms are big for Tokyo and have everything you need. The view is outstanding! The service level is very high and personalized. The hotel also has access to a spa with a great long pool on the 37th floor. The main bar has a great atmosphere and the sushi bar on the top roof is outstanding and has only 8 seats, it's a kind of private. But be ready to pay a high price for the sushi, its worth every Yen. Overall a great hotel in a great city.

I stayed at this hotel for four nights at the end of a two-week trip to Japan, and what was the most anticipated part of my trip quickly turned into a regrettable disappointment. It all started at check-in, where an error in my booking details (the first night of my reservation was made separately and only reflected one guest instead of two) resulted in the check-in attendant informing me that I would only be given one included breakfast instead of two as the hotel could not alter the reservation file (an explanation that was somewhat mystifying). A later phone conversation with a manager revealed this to be an issue with the accommodation tax, which I was more than happy to pay in order for the issue to be corrected. Nevertheless, at a hotel of this caliber this issue should have been rectified without ever reaching my attention, much less requiring my own intervention with higher-level staff. While the man who did finally rectify the situation was apologetic, precious little was done to try and make up for this service failure beyond being thanked for the 'feedback' I had provided to the staff.This soured my arrival to the hotel and left me feeling as though I was a second-class guest (a perception I suspect relates to the portion of my stay that was on points), as the introduction to the room felt very perfunctory and even a touch condescending, as if I didn't belong in the hotel (my partner later told me that he was asked on multiple occasions whether he was staying in the same room as me, which is more baffling than offensive). I was not informed of the features/services of the hotel—I only discovered the details of the evening wine reception from the small writing on the back of the room key holder—and didn't feel as though the staff cared all that much about me having a memorable experience. Much of the staff around the hotel seemed similarly disinterested/preoccupied, as greetings felt mostly forced and warmth was mostly lacking. When I went to the Rooftop Bar one evening, I was brusquely asked if I had a reservation (the bar was mostly empty) before being shown to a seat after responding that I was a guest of the hotel. That said, encounters with staff at BeBu and the Andaz Lounge, as well as with the housekeeping staff were positive, which kept my stay from being a complete service disaster.The room itself was nice and spacious by Tokyo standards, although perhaps a touch on the austere side to be considered truly luxurious. While it contained all the modern conveniences you would need—the complimentary non-alcoholic minibar and snacks are a nice touch—the room did show signs of wear (marks on the walls, et al.) and was furnished in a relatively spartan style for a so-called luxury hotel (bedroom furnishings consisted of a bed, two night tables, a desk and two chairs). The bed was also quite firm (although this seems to be more of a Japanese thing) but the linens were comfortable and adequate for a hotel of this class. I was also apparently 'upgraded' to a room with a view of the Imperial Palace, which was nice but didn't feel like all that much of an upgrade when compared with the vistas of Tokyo Bay and Tokyo Tower from the other sides of the hotel.The hotel's food and beverage venues were also somewhat disappointing, ranging from an acceptable meal at BeBu to a disappointing breakfast at Andaz Tavern. Having read reviews of the oft-vaunted breakfast, I was disappointed to find that it was distinctly average: the food was mostly lukewarm and not in any way exceptional, and I was served a cafe latte at an undrinkable temperature that somewhat managed to mask the poor quality and presentation. (Save your money and get your food and coffee fix from Toranomon Koffee in the same building, which is of superlative quality and features outstanding service.) Drinks at the Rooftop Bar were of decent quality, but were not at the level one would expect in such a venue (and at such a price point!). The best food experience I had at the hotel came courtesy of the hotel's pastry shop, which produces nice cakes at a seemingly justifiable price point.In the end, I left the hotel not only disappointed, but feeling unable to express this disappointment (I already had to ask to correct an error on the folio presented to me at check-out, the proverbial cherry on top of the service gaffes), as the staff seemed to consistently have little interest in my experience as a guest. Having arrived expecting a hotel that would make my stay in Tokyo the memory of a lifetime, I left feeling grateful that the magnificent city of Tokyo would outshine my memories of this hotel.

If you prefer sitting rather outdoors than indoors this is the perfect location watching people passing by and enjoying an less hectic luncheon. Right on the bottom of Toranomon Hills you can find BeBu cafe/ restaurant. Meals are little more expensive than the usual lunchtime offers but totally worth it.

The staff were very helpful and attentive. The rooms are gorgeous - I liked the local touches in terms of design of the robes and slippers in the room. I recommend taking the time to walk around the Toranomon Hills complex - there are some incredible world-class artworks.

We stayed at the Hyatt Andaz in Tokyo in April, 2017. Coming in by train, we rode into Shimbashi station, which was a very far walk with our luggage. We had shipped in our luggage from previous hotel and they had it ready and waiting in the room. The hotel in Toronamon Hills tower, requires you go up to their lobby floor, then transfer elevator bank to room floor. Unfortunately, we arrived late, and found that we also had to walk very far to find food since most of the restaurants in the tower closed at 11PM. The closest late-night food is at Shimbashi station, which is where Japanese businessmen & women from Ginza swarm bars and izakaya which is not relaxing at a all. Room service was a limited bar menu from their in-house restaurant. It was also very hard to find a convenience store/pharmacy after hours. The only other option is taking a taxi. The room was gorgeous and spacious, with a full wall window overlooking Tokyo Tower. The separate bathroom/closet area was huge with luxe brown wood finishing and a gorgeous large round tub & rain shower head. There is a beautiful raw-edge wood desk facing the window and the Andaz team provided us an extra bed that didn't disturb the room at all. We made a reservation for two days in theSushi restaurant where we had an omakase-style sushi dinner that was awesome, very filling and some of the best fish we've ever had. We also had a round of drinks upstairs in the rooftop bar which was chilly but the staff provides heated blankets as you overlook the city. They had a really good DJ, excellent drinks, and accommodated our requests to transfer seats for a better view. The front desk staff also made arrangements for our taxi to the airport. Overall, a gorgeous hotel with staff intended to do everything they can to make the customer happy and really beautiful amenities. The only hard part is if you are visiting for vacation and require any outside food/pharmacy/access-to-public transporation, the Andaz is out of the way, even by Ginza-standards.

Union City, United States

review_body: The setting for the Andaz Toranomon Hills breakfast has always been stunning - on the 51st floor overlooking the Imperial Palace grounds and Marunochi. But on this visit we noticed that they had taken it up a level. Every morning, there were small, subtle variations in the juices and dishes served. Fresh Orange and Grapefruit, of course, but also peach one day, then mango, then carrot. Exquisitely thinly slices prosciuttos, hams and salami but changing. Fresh avocado and shrimp, then herring. We understood that there was a top grade of care, attention and professional pride that was being applied to this "standard" morning meal. Bravo Andaz!

Staff were very friendly and helpful , enjoyed the room and facilities .Pool and facilities were outstanding , they could improve on the standard of coffee at breakfast . We would come back again . Thankyou

Our extended family stayed four nights, with three 47th floor rooms facing the Imperial Palace. There was construction nearby, but we couldn't hear a peep inside the rooms. WiFi was superb, the spa and workout facility were top notch, daily snacks & drinks were included, and we loved the professionalism and pampering we received from the staff. The pool alone is worth the stay!

I had a very short stay here for work. I enjoyed the modern look of the hotel. I had a great room with a beautiful bathroom and tub. I only ate full breakfast in the restaurant but the restaurant layout and view were fantastic. I really enjoyed it and would stay there again.

staff was great, hotel was well appointed and clean. we'd definitely come back to stay again if we return to tokyo. as with most of japan, more gluten free options would be a nice touch due to my allergy. we ordered grilled salmon from in room dining and they were very gracious in making sure it was gluten free. it tasted great, we ordered this twice during our stay.

We had a great time! Very accommodating staff, modern and clean room furniture. Nice location, just two train stops to Shibuya/Omotesando. Even have a complimentary "happy hour" to all guests where they serve decent wine and finger foods. Good job Andaz!

Awesome stay at the andaz in Tokyo. Enjoyed the great room, location and solid breakfast (as well as free mini bar snacks). No upgrade was available, but luckily normal rooms were still pretty nice. Is in a good running neighborhood close to chiyoda with beautiful cherry blossoms! Definitely recommend!

Staying at Andaz for a business trip I was amazed by the breathtaking view on Tokyo. It can also be enjoyed while swimming in the great indoor pool or sitting in the inviting jacuzzies. My room had a nice bathroom incl dressing otherwise the room was kept quite simple. All in all it was a pleasant stay but the price seems a bit high compared to comparable places in the same sector.

My wife and I had the opportunity to stay at the Andaz Tokyo for the first segment of our honeymoon, and what an experience! We have stayed at several Andaz and Park Hyatt properties before, and this by far was the most beautiful hotel we've stayed at. Service was impeccable, and small details like the welcome gift / card, and wine tasting hours were greatly enjoyed. Recommend a stay here anytime!

Andaz Tokyo is a great luxury hotel for those who want to visit Tokyo in style.The service is impeccable, very attentive to all your needs.The interior design is very refined and is really part of the whole experience.Ideally located in Toranomon hills, you are a walking distance from the Imperial Palace and the Shiodome district. Don't hesitate to walk the neighborhood. You will discover many hidden and charming sites.After an exhausting but marvellous day, you will then relax at the small but nice swimming pool overlooking the city.Ask for a room with view on the Tokyo tower, It's magic at night!

My husband and I love the buzz of city travels but with him being more of an introvert than me, a nice hotel to return to gives him a sense of space that helps in his recuperation. Andaz having its rooms close to the skies, each offering magnificent views of the cosmopolitant city, is definitely up there!Apart from the constant supply of complimentary tit-bits, meiji chocolates and non alchoholic drinks in the room, the round bath tub and sea salt helps one relax in comfort after hitting the roads of this marvelous city. The rooms are beautiful. We also love the gym and pool. One of the highest workout one could get. The service as in most Japanese hotels is impeccable. The thing missing is the fact that Toranomon is a bit out of the way. One does not get the creature comforts of a massive shopping arena and food outlets at its doorstep like Ritz in midtown or Shangri-la at Tokyo Station. Then again it is small price to pay for being in a less crowded area. The range of the evening drinks for guests could also be improved.

Just stayed one night on way to airport return home. This hotel is in a great area, close to main JR station and walking distance to ginza shopping and dining! Beautiful hotel with a fun lively bar! Rooms are quite frankly-- better than park Hyatt!! I'll be back!!

This is a beautiful hotel on around the 50th floor. Rooms are huge and very nice and amazing views. As a Lifetime Globalist you get free breakfast and it's very good!! The area is a little bit different but my wife is from Tokyo and she finds gem restaurants everywhere in Tokyo. I'm looking forward to staying over next New Year with my family. Beautiful!!!

This is a really late review, but I figure since I am reviewing other hotels, I might as well write about this experience as well.I have stayed at several Hyatt hotels, but this Andaz is my favorite. From the service to the room, everything was fantastic. As soon as you enter, you are greeted warmly by reception. A nice touch is that they have delicious traditional rice crackers available at reception when you check-in. Across from reception is the small, open lounge like area. Here, there are small snacks and juices available to eat. It was nice snacking on something here after a long day. As for the aesthetic of the hotel, I thought it was beautiful, minimalist, and modern. It made the hotel feel very upscale and created a quiet atmosphere. I personally didn't really enjoy how minimalist it was because it felt a bit cold to me, but that's just personal preference. However, the room was exactly to my taste. As soon as I entered, there was a giant window that boasted a wonderful view of Tokyo. What a treat to view the sparkling lights of skyscrapers before bed and wake up to a beautiful blue sky. Additionally, the free snacks and drinks were all delicious and high-quality! My favorite part of the Andaz was the breakfast option. The breakfast was a fantastic mixture of Eastern and Western dishes. I really enjoyed having the option of eating a delicious Japanese breakfast each day. Also, the buffet also had the best fresh fruit. I never had actual passion fruit before my stay, but for the three days I was at the Andaz, I had passion fruit every day!The only downside is that the hotel is in a business area, so there isn't very much to do nearby. However, being in Tokyo, this isn't much of a problem as the subway system is available.

After reading many positive reviews, we decided to cancel the Park Hyatt (of the "Lost in Translation" fame) booking and beg-borrow-buy points to book here instead. And it was probably one of the best decisions of our two-week trip through Japan.We stayed at the excellent IC Osaka just before this hotel, so we came in riding on a high! I wouldn't say Andaz took the high to a new level, but it certainly put additional twists on it (in good ways). There were interesting touches throughout to surprise in unexpected ways! The twin room was of decent size and more than pleasant enough. My son and I enjoyed the pool very much. I found the gym to be superbly equipped and operated. Views of Tokyo, especially from the rooftop bar, were simply breathtaking.If I were to nitpick, the only possible downside to this Andaz is the location. The immediate surroundings are not the most interesting, just your usual business district. But several subway stations are within 10 min walking distance, to connect you with pretty much anywhere you would need to go in metro Tokyo.Bottom line, you will not regret your stay at this hotel, and will most likely be very impressed.

Modern, comfortable hotel that is full of amenities. The breakfast was wonderful, room views were spectacular and service was first rate. Although the neighborhood has everything you need this hotel is not near most of Tokyo's main attractions so it might not be ideal for sightseers. However, I would not hesitate to return (and next time I'll leave time to use the spa).
