The Toranomon Hills Mall next to the hotel is more an office building with lots of upmarket restaurants and one small supermarket. I think the Andaz is somewhere right between the Grand Hyatt and the Park Hyatt... It is priced higher than the Grand Hyatt but lower than the Park Hyatt. For people with children, the Grand Hyatt is preferable with the Roppongi Hill Mall nearby etc. The Andaz is more for mature adults and is a more reclusive place where every corner is picture perfect.

Perched atop one of the tallest building in Tokyo, staying at the Andaz feels quite literally like being transported to another world. The rooms are every bit as fantastic as they sound on paper; floor to ceiling windows, designer details, and a bathroom that puts all others to shame. The staff are extremely attentive and friendly- almost to a fault. Every time I left my room (multiple times in a day, regardless of time of day), it was made up by the time I came back. There's also a lovely, if not pricey, rooftop bar with panoramic views of the city. The hotel isn't located in the most happening part of town, but easily accessible to public transportation.
user_name:
whiskycoffee
New York City, New York

review_body: Pros: beautiful lobby and public spaces; high-quality fit, finish and amenities in room; free daily happy hour; friendly staff; great breakfast. The hotel is convenient to 3 subway lines, though each is a 10 minute walk away.Cons: room layout a bit wonky, with a large table that obstructs use of the couch; staff are helpful, but they have no dedicated concierge. The restaurant recommendations we were given came from web searches. We did better ourselves.

Purpose of visit is celebrating my wife's birthday with my family. Service, Food&Beverage and atmosphere are second to none especially our server Ms. Kase's charming service was unforgettable for my family. We will definitely visit there again for such occasion in the future. Thank you Kase san, you have created perfect time for us !

Wonderful hotel in Tokyo with the Andaz touch of a table style checkin and lounge for all guests. Large immaculate rooms with a Japanese touch, faboulus bathroom and amenties. Slightly out of the buzz of central Tokyo but minutes away from Ginza. Great staff and desig.

At the top of a tower in Toranomon, each bedroom offers an incredible view on Tokyo. Each details of bedrooms are of great taste. The team is amazing, the restaurant offers a wide choice (continental or Japanese) for the breakfast and great food for dinner. Last but not least, the spa is fantastic and offers a great view on all the city. Andaz Tokyo is perhaps the most enjoyable hotel I went in my life. It really worths it! For tourism or business purposes, 3 tube stations are within 10 minutes walk and offer nice possibilities to visit in a shirt time the most interesting places in Tokyo.

Very nice hotel, very well located. The personnel is very nice and attentionné. Nice lounge with drinks. A tremendous view over Tokyo. Very beautiful rooftop bar and sushi restaurant (Worth trying even if expensive).

Really beautiful modern hotel with good food at the Andaz Tavern. Particularly the gym and pool areas are gorgeous. The staff seems to remember everything about you. Larger rooms are nice, smaller rooms can be claustrophobic. Nice central location, although nothing interesting within walking distance.

Although the Andaz brand is part of the Hyatt chain, Andaz properties have a very boutique feel - and the Tokyo Andaz is very boutique. It's housed in a skyscraper, but it has only around 150 rooms, so it feels intimate. Our room was beautiful and elegant, with its Japanese-inspired decor, and the space, while not huge, was well organized (a bench along the window, a desk area, a large and comfortable bed, a great bath area, and a huge closet). The public areas are impressive, and the lounge with snacks and coffee is great. Service was also personalized, excellent, and attentive (one quibble: it seems that in the rule-abiding Japanese culture, concierges aren't very good at getting last-minute reservations at hot restaurants -- so if you want to dine at top places, book well in advance). The Toranamon Hills complex is upscale and appealing; it doesn't have a huge amount going on, but at least it's an easy walk to the subway. I would certainly stay at the Andaz again if visiting Japan.
user_name:
David L
New York, New York

review_body: This was the most luxurious hotel I have ever stayed in. Everything was perfect from top to bottom. The decor of the public spaces and rooms is top notch, modern, comfortable, and well thought out. The staff were all friendly and very good with English, eager to please. The pool/spa is not to be missed, seriously. The views are out of this world, with several pools with differing temperatures, jets, etc. Great sauna and chill pool and a room with massage chairs and calming music. I seriously did not want to leave!! It is located a short 10 minute walk from the subway station.

New hotel with great rooms and nice views (get a bay view room). conveniently located, especially to and from Haneda. Nice restaurants and izakaya in the area. Subway only a short walk away. One of my favorites in Tokyo.

This room was much larger than the average room in Tokyo. we stayed in 4737 for a night before moving to somewhere else. I loved this hotel & there is nothing much I can find fault with it. Landed in Tokyo around 7am and reached the hotel around 7.30am, Mizu (sorry if I had her name wrong) was one of the best hostess we have met in our crazy travelling history. She was extremely helpful, courteous and managed to help us upgrade our room (i think she could clearly see we are really tired + husband was gold member of hyatt hotels)service was great, location was great, hotel amenities were great. definitely will come back here again =)hotel is a pokemon stop as well (>.<) - PERFECT!!

This is a great hotel and really sets the standard. We had an excellent stay here and enjoyed it in all respects. The building is really attractive and has a number of great areas for sitting or reading. The rooms are well-designed, large for the location, and are simply enjoyable to be in. The showers are particularly great. The staff is very attentive and were happy to assist with any questions or needs that we had, while also balancing not overwhelming us with attention whenever we walked past the front desk.I can only think of two drawbacks -- the breakfast is a little expensive (although it's a great breakfast) and the location isn't directly in the center of things. However, it is pretty easy to use the metro to get around the city, so this wasn't too much of an issue.

I would strongly recommend this hotel, make sure to choose the Tokyo Tower view - great view to wake up to, sophisticated interior design ! complimentary snacks, soft drinks and other non-alcoholic beverages from the minibar, a great choice for travellers interested in clean streets, friendly people and japanese culture

This is the way all premium hotels should be. From the attentive staff and short wait at (an unannounced) early check-in to the clean, well-designed, quiet room via the wonderful amenities (the spa, the restaurant, the gym). I cannot think of any downside to Andaz Toranomon Hills and I always find things to complain about. I long to return and recommend this hotel to anyone who has very high standards about what a premium hotel stay should be.

I stay at hotels at least 100 nights per year for work and leisure, divided over multiple hotel chains and this hotel is by far the best hotel I have ever stayed at. Impeccable service and hospitality, the staff goes above an beyond to make you feel at home. Food and breakfast is excellent, if there is something you like but dont see just ask the chef and will make it for you (we love guacamole for breakfast).The city view is amazing, both towards tokyo tower as tokyo sky tree and imperial palace. Close to subway station and connection to narita and haneda!
user_name:
thomasv60
New York City, New York

review_body: I really enjoyed my stay here at this hotel. The staff were great. They were super friendly and helpful. We had a tokyo tower room. The bath tub was huge to my delight and the room was simple and mordern. The staff at the main entrence were extremely helpful and one staff even kindly printed off a map with directions for us and looked up local ramen shops that we might like to go to.The spa is very modern, with a nice layout. There is a relaxed atmosphere to it and i really enjoyed my daily trips to therel. There is a hairdressers Mods hair which is located on the same floor as the lobyy and the hairdresser was fantastic!. It was the best haircut and head massage i have ever recieved! I will most certainly be visiting mods hair when i am back in Tokyo. My only concern was the breakfast as it was very limited and there wasnt as much of a japanese flair as i was hoping. It had more of a western style with a bit of Japenese mixed with it.

The hotel is contemporary and very beautiful. The staff was very friendly and we had a wonderful stay. No negatives to point out. The check in process is relaxed in a seat and not at counter. When I asked someone for directions to the Tokyo tower, he mapped other temples on the way which made our morning walk lot more enjoyable and squeezed in few more places in our sightseeing.The view from my room had Skytree. Walkable distance to Tokyo tower and few beautiful temples. They had a happy hour in the lobby with drinks and light snacks. Lobby also has free soda, juice, coffee and water 24 hours. The breakfast has a nice spread both continental and oriental. Chef can make eggs to order.The pool is large lap pool and three different hot tub areas. A decent Gym.Room has nice amenities and the huge round tub is elegant. As a norm with most Japanese hotels, this room has Toto toilet with all bells and whistles.

When in Tokyo, the very best hotel to consider and MUST stay is Andaz Tokyo. Service is impeccable throughout the hotel, the very best breakfast, F&B quality, great view and most well managed hotel in Tokyo. View, location and comforts... the very best!
user_name:
trvlsoftend
New York City, New York

review_body: Although located in a business area that quietens down (a blessing in disguise actually in busy Tokyo) the Andaz personifies luxury without the pretence. If you like: incredible service sophisticated elegance simple luxury that's effortless... then stay here.

Re-visited the Andaz again for 3 nights following a great experience earlier this year. I want to reiterate how much I like this beautifully adorned establishment that is new and modern (and super clean) but containing many elements of the local culture. The layout of the lobby and rooms draws visitors to explore the many facets it has to offer. I took the opportunity to partake in their fitness facility and spa this time around - which were well managed and provided excellent services. That I actually enjoyed my daily workouts says a lot of how much I liked the ambience. The staff were professional, polite and friendly and their overtures to accommodate our visit was clearly evident. Food at the Tavern (breakfast and dinner) was good but not excellent - a little too eclectic perhaps. There are other restaurants on the lower floors that are designed primarily to serve the office workers and conference attendees in the building (simple fare). I would definitely re-visit if I need to be in the Minato area again.

My colleague recommended this hotel. The tasteful wood decor in the room blew me away. Amazing place. The panoramic views of Tokyo were stunning. The bar managed to be simultaneously grand yet cozy...not an easy combination.

Fantastic hotel, great rooms and service, the lounge has a great view but service is little slow and bad style of music not suited for this kind of hotel with poor level of musicians playing retro music. Something more modern would be nicer I think.

The hotel excels in every aspects that one would aspire of in a modern hotel. Love the tower view and the happy hour. Breakfast is also good.The check-in process could be improved. It took longer time than most other hotels. It would be more efficient to have guests check-in the same process as the hotel offers for check-out. Seating in the lounge and waiting for hosts to walk back and forth just makes check-in time longer.Overall, cannot beat this one in Tokyo.

You would expect all the goodies in the room of this new hotel (from 2014), plus the excellent huge overflowing bathtub even in the standard rooms. A huge wooden work-bench facing the big windows just inspires your mind both in the day-time and night-time.On the 51st floor reception area, there are sharing benches for free wine and snacks throughout the day can have the guests mingle, creating a young and active scene. It is just a purely great hotel.Of the Hyatt Group, they already have Park Hyatt, Grand Hyatt and Hyatt Regency in Tokyo. Andaz is just another exciting addition.Only shortfall is that the subway/train stations are around 10 minutes away, instead of just downstairs in most hotels.... well, its worth the little exercise, I think.

Exelent place to rest your tour-day in the town! Also have to say the brekfast is the BEST what ever get in Hotel! The view from any window incredible if you would spend time to see things from the air!

Amazing hotel. Gorgeous rooms. Killer views. Luxurious bathrooms. Fantastic pool in the sky. Great service. Location is in a business district, so it is very quiet at night with not many restaurants or sights nearby. Love the Hyatt list of additional amenities like nail polish remover or hairspray that housekeeping will bring you, it really comes in handy!

Impressive Lobby on the top floor and the rooms are actually lower but still on floor 45+. Nice and very stylish rooms. As Diamond Member we did not get an upgrade but a great room with direct view towards Tokyo tower. Breakfast is really nices as well

The hard product is tough to beat... everything is shiny and new. As an Andaz, the design is sleek, simple and modern, but Andaz Tokyo also feels more sophisticated and upscale than other Andazs. Free non alcoholic minibar like all other Andazs - stocked with a good selection of japanese snacks & beverages. Overall good service, especially at breakfast. Gym is very well equipped with brand new Technogym equipment and has a fantastic view extending out to Shinjuku.

Only one sheet on the bed. Not a big deal, but I usually like to have a top sheet as well - it is a Western thing and with the type of hotel the Andaz is and the reputation it has I'm very surprised this kept getting messed up time after time.Didn't replenish water when requested for turn down is another gripe we had.Asked again for top sheet on bed and did something strange - the front desk sent the photo of the comforter on top of mattress bare. Explained again what it is to have a top sheet and they came to fix it only to take away the top sheet. Asked again for them to just GIVE us the top sheet. It was literally impossible to tell them how to do this or when to keep the top sheet we had put on the beds in the same place.Also in the morning the room smelled of fish and then again in the afternoon. The vents must be connected to the kitchen. Returned and it smelled like they sprayed a whole bottle of fragrance and also warmed the room to 26 degrees CAlso to kick things off, the front desk had messed up my reservation to start with and when got off the plane feared that all my reservations had been cancelled. Asked for birthday suggestions by email and never got a response. Overall a messy front desk and also inattentive house cleaning, hopefully our next visit will be different. Some parts of the room also showed more wear and tear than I would have liked to see in a property of that type with its age.

Located in Beautiful Toranomon Hills, Andaz Tokyo is is a beautiful property throughout. The comfortability and service provided at Andaz is always more than expected. Everything about the hotel from the first floor entrance to the rooms, restaurants and bars, Spa and Fitness,Sunday Yoga, and incredible services are excellent. The afternoon happy hour, views from the 52d floor rooftop bar, and morning breakfasts are second to none. My wife had an allergic reaction to food we had while out on the town and the hotel staff was quick to arrange a medical clinic visit and followed up on her health during the course of our stay. Always a comfortable and pleasant stay at Andaz regardless of the city but especially in Tokyo and London.

I must admit that most of my biggest problems of my stay at the Andaz Tokyo are a problem of the Andaz chain and not this hotel in particular. This is the 3rd and definitely last time I tried any of their hotels, because they are definitely not for everyone. From a very rocky start at the reception where they always give you a lot of attitude and because every 'host' part of the staff are meant to be concierge, greeters, bell boys,... None of them are actually specialized in their job. So when you need some help you don't always get the best advice or efficiency. The fact that there is no concierge means you need to always call the reception and they are always busy at the reception and they are not particularly good in terms of recommendations or searching for information. Service depends on the 'host' that you get on the other side of the line. Some of them are outstanding some of the have big attitude problems. A big shout out to Owen, Ayari Kure, Arisa Takeda, Rie Moroi, who were part of the really really helpful personal. The rooms are super weirdly arrange. The rooms even feel smaller and less high than other Tokyo rooms. There are desks and coffe tables almost as big as the bed and beg are placed in front of a sofa that blocks the window, which is a big shame given that the views from the rooms are magnificent. The doors and furniture are rather IKEA quality. Even their towels are not great quality.

Wonderful stay at this chic hotel with probably the best rooftop bar in Tokyo! Nice interior design, absolutely love the bathroom, each room comes with great views of the city. I personally prefer the interior layout of the twin bedroom rather than the King-sized room. The only downside is the lack of a metro station nearby and the hotel is situated in a rather uninteresting part of Tokyo with no shopping and no good restaurants nearby.

I went there a couple of time on business, as it's more of a business hotel, but my wife and I stayed there in June for 4 nights with our 2 kids (6&8). It's quite different from the New York or Shanghai Andaz. It's a five star hotel here, no question about it. On par with the best asian Park Hyatt. Very well designed, the pool facities are worth the stay by themselves. We had the junior suite, they provided the kids with bathrobes and goodies. I loved the kimonos and the bathroom. We had a direct view on Mt. Fuji - we were lucky, we had no clouds. As for service, from the concierge desk to the lobby attendance or the restaurants crew, everything was sublime. We asked for restaurant recommandation and it was always good - altought sometime a bit on the pricey side. I stayed at other top hotel in Tokyo ( like the Tokyu or the Conrad) and the staff are cooler and more friendly here. They're is some front-desk attendee that are non-japanese, and it's nice too. They also responded well to my emails. As many stated, breakfast is king here. They also have a sushi restaurant, but you have to reserve as places are limited. We tryed the burgers on the ground floor Tavern - it's ok, but the food court in the office tower offers better alternative for lunch.Great stay really, amenities and staff are top. As for location, I actually found it well located for somebody who wants to explore the city as you are really central. Might be far from Shinjuku, but Roppongi is a very short taxi ride away, and we had no problem visiting the zoo or the cool districts using public transport. Highly recommended.Martin

The Andaz was pretty much everything I could ask for in a hotel.The rooms are very large (especially for Japanese standards), including a large bathroom/dressing area/shower and tub room. Soft drinks in the mini-fridge, coffee, tea and snacks are all free (you have to pay for the alcohol in the mini-fridge) and are restocked daily. The front desk/concierge will help you with almost anything...including calling stores to see if they have an item you're looking for.The location is walking distance from Tokyo Tower, but isn't really in a "touristy" location. However, with Tokyo's public transit, a short walk to a subway or JR station means you can get pretty much anywhere in Tokyo quickly.

1st experience in an Andaz! As expected, "cool" decor in every sense! Lobby and especially the Guest Lounge was a nice touch! Room was well appointed - contemporary lux warm materials and colours, electrical controls with bronze old school buttons a nice touch. Bathroom size=Room size! Amenities not as extensive as a japanese hotel like Palace Hotel.Host and Guest Services needs further concierge training-info not at finger tip!Food at Tavern below expectation-eg. lobster bisque way too salty!Location isn't the most convenient for shoppers though Ginza and Marounichi is a short taxi ride away.

Stayed 2 nights in a King Tower view room. Located on the 48th floor, the rooms are large and comfortable . Long lounge along the window to enjoy the views. Great bed and linen. Oversize bath was nice to soak in. Complimentary mini bar (non alcoholic)Service was exceptional . Had drinks on the roof top bar with fabulous views. Soaked in the mineral baths on the 37th floor and swam. Room service was good.Would not hesitate to stay here again. Highly recommend. 5 star modern luxury

By far the best hotel our family stayed in Tokyo. The check in was smooth and courteous ( thanks KIKI-San) and the rooms were very big large for Tokyo standards. The breakfast is well worth the price tag , although if you are Diamond, it's free and the evening wine reception is satisfactory.The best part of our experience were the views that you are able to see from your room and the public areas.Recommend stay away from the rooftop bar (way too expensive) and take advantage of the pool. You will not regret it! There are separate jacuzzi and mineral bath pools too!!! Service was TOP notch, as it would expect from an Andaz, but the location was a little far from what you would think, although, there were some great soba/udon joint about 4 blocks north of the hotel that are open 24 hours and are Greeeaaatttt!

This is one of the best luxury hotels I've been to. The rooms are just amazing - it seems that they've though of every small detail. All the features you think about would be there. The bathroom is superb as of course the fully-automatic Japanese toilet. They also have complimentary wines and cheeses in the evening, which is an awesome touch. the view is amazing. Wow, simply wow. The only downside is that the location is somewhat sterile and boring - there is nothing to do around and you'd need to hop on metro or cab to get to busy night life areas.

It's our very first time to stay at Andaz Tokyo. We were pleasantly surprised by the nice facilities. The hotel rooms are sufficiently big given that we were in Japan. We are a family of five and had two rooms next to each other. The staff offered to open the connecting door which is very convenient. The staffs were very friendly and helpful. Pool/spa is super nice, considering many other hotels in Japan would charge you for using it. The complimentary mini-bar is definitely a plus. The airport shuttle dropped us off right in front of the hotel from Narita, which made things so much easier for us. The shuttle service to Haneda airport is very limited though. One has to walk quite few minutes to the nearest subway station. I highly recommend this hotel.

This was a 3rd trip to Tokyo and we really wanted to try this new Hyatt location. It was hard choosing to stick to the tried and tested true Park Hyatt Tokyo or this newer location. In the end we decided to split it between 3 hotels to compare our experiences.The Andaz is a completely different hotel from the Park Hyatt Tokyo. If you try and compare the 2 hotels, it's pretty much comparing apples and oranges. They are in different locations and have completely different clientele that it attracts. Having put that out there...the hotel is very nice. You cannot fault the view, decor, or service. Rooms were spacious in comparison to a typical Tokyo hotel. The beds were very comfortable, even a roll away. The restaurant has an amazing breakfast spread and we ate there every morning. We loved the specialized made toiletries they had in the bathroom. The snacks and drinks available in the lobby was a lovely break. We also made use of the umbrellas in the rooms several times. They provided kids toiletries, pj's, robe, and cup for our 6 year old son.The only con I experienced was that it was a holiday week when we were there and the hotel was booked solid. The reception area would be crowded with not enough seats for those who wanted to have a drink and snacks. There were several wedding parties staying there so it was crowded in the reception area. The informal check in area was a little hectic since there is no separate counters, instead there is one large table with several employees checking in/out. Not a dealbreaker at all and it was the only time we really had to wait for anything during our stay.We did walk around the hotel to check out the area and were able to find a few places open to have a ramen meal at, even late at night. So, it is quiet in the area, with businesses closing by 9-10. If you however are willing to walk a little, you will find my open businesses and places to shop if interested.When we come back to Tokyo, I wouldn't mind staying here again for a few days.

We stayed for 1 night at Andaz Tokyo. In terms of location, it is not the most convenient given that the walk to Toranomon station (Ginza line) / Shimbashi station (Yamamote line, for JR pass holders) is not sheltered. Nevertheless, I highly recommend this hotel if you are looking for a beautiful room and exceptional service. Our three-person room had sleek wooden furnishing and a beautiful view of the city (the hotel has ground floor lobby but the main reception is at the 51st floor; our room was on the 49th floor). The minibar was stocked with snacking essentials like juice, nespresso coffee capsules, chocolate and rice crackers - all complimentary (save for alcohol). Of note is also the bathroom, which had both a shower (with overhead and the normal showerheads), and a bathtub. Quite apart from our lovely room, I was very impressed by the service. I was a total klutz and dropped my wifi device in a taxi. Because we took the taxi from the hotel lobby, the staff took the initiative to inspect the security cameras for the licence plate number, and managed to contact the taxi company and the driver. To give you a sense of how efficient they were: I lost my wifi device at around 5.30pm, and it was tracked and retrieved by the next morning, in time for my flight in the afternoon! My thanks goes to Kenta-san and Michi-san (I hope I got your names right), the taxi company, the taxi driver and everyone else who helped me with this situation. Suffice to say, I was very happy with my stay at Andaz.

We stayed here from Tuesday to Saturday in June and staff were always helpful and courteous. For example, we found the pillows to be too soft and mentioned it to the reception staff. They immediately arranged for foam and buckwheat pillows to be sent to the room, and followed up the next morning to see if we had a better night's rest.It was slightly unusual that the reception was on the topmost floor with the bedrooms located below. I guess it makes sense in terms of security as all foot traffic has to go through the reception area. The room (4841) was large, especially for Tokyo, and the views were excellent. Finishings were well appointed and we enjoyed the sunken bath after a hard day of walking. The only strange thing was that each morning after 5 am, there seemed to be a few minutes's knocking on the external windows. At first we thought it was the window cleaning crew but hotel staff said they did not work that early.We had room service breakfast each morning and the offerings were varied enough that we did not have to repeat dishes during our stay. We liked the bursher muesli, as well as eggs florentine and nutella filled brioche bread. Non alcoholic drinks in the room fridge are free and they also provide local snacks like biscuits. In the evenings, wine is available for free at the reception area for hotel guests.The gym was well equipped and underused, and Imhad the entire floor to myself in the afternoons. There is also a pool with winderful views and a rather upscale and expensive spa on the same floor.The location itself is within Toranomon Hills, which has several restaurants, coffee cafes and convenience stalls in the lower levels. The nearest Metro - Toranomon - is five minutes's walk away and is on the Ginza line, which runs from Shibuya to Asakusa. The nearest JR station is at Shimbashi, about 10 minutes away, where you can also find more restarants and shopping options.

Andaz Tokyo is an excellent choice for family travel. Located in a business district, Andaz Tokyo is actually a great for vacationing family. The Toranomon station is within walking distance, one can take Ginza line, then connect with one more line to major hubs for sight-seeing, food, shopping; and to places like Tsukiji market and Odabi. The hotel provides great amenities. In evenings one can enjoy complementary appetizers and drinks. The fitness and pool facilities are superb with great view from 37th floor. Finally the hotel offers limousine bus service to Narita airport, more convenient for family with luggage than taking subway then Narita Express, well worth slightly higher cost.

Well appointed and comfortable, the hotel tries for a boutique feel. It mostly works, though having to take a lift up to the lobby, and then another down to the rooms is a bit tedious. The views from the rooms are impressive, overlooking the city. The surrounding area is the business district, so the hotel is useful for business travellers but not advisable for tourists. Subway is about eight minutes away on foot.

The hotel is towards the top of a skyscraper so comes with amazing views from rooms and the restaurant/bar.The rooms are large for Tokyo standards and beautifully decorated and furnished. The Bose Bluetooth streaming device is a great touch for listening to music.The usual Andaz style and standards are all in full display in the public areas plus the lovely complementary snacks, sake and wine are a lovely treat before heading out for dinner.It was suggested to us that the hotel is not in a great location - it suited us very well and public transport is very, very close by so don't worry. There are plenty of restaurants in the area as well.We also hired a mobile wi-if device that we had delivered to our hotel and then dropped off into a postbox and was very good value for money.

My family loved our stay at the Andaz Tokyo--it is an amazing hotel. Beautifully designed and impeccable service. We loved everything about the hotel--rooms are spacious and beautifully furnished. Views from the rooms are incredible! The closet and bathroom area is very spacious and has a flexible arrangement with several doors that can be opened up/closed to make the space more accessible or private, depending on what you desire. Long sofa against the floor to ceiling windows is a nice touch and makes the room very cozy and comfortable. Unlike many other hotel rooms, you actually have a place to lounge besides the bed! Pool/spa is gorgeous with views of Tokyo---my husband and son rented swimsuits for an evening swim, they were the only ones in the entire pool area! Service was also excellent--hotel staff was very helpful and everyone spoke English beautifully. The location of the hotel has been commented on by various people--I really liked the area. It is very close to the Toranomon Station (approx 5 min walk) and there are a number of restaurants/convenience stores in the area. The Toranomon Hills buildling itself also has a number of restaurants/cafes. Easy access to Ginza district and commute to other areas of interest for tourists like Asakusa, Odaiba, etc. is also fine. It's not as busy of neighborhood compared to Shibuya but I actually liked that. I highly recommend this hotel to anyone! (PS we used the Hyatt Credit Card promotion--2 free nights if you spend $1000 for our stay--what a bargain!)

My husband and I stayed at the Andaz Tokyo and really enjoyed our stay. It was in a nice location with delicious restaurants nearby and a 15 minute walk from Shimbashi station. The room was really comfortable and had a beautiful view. Nice extra touches included were the beautiful pool and spa, and wine and small bites provided from the hotel early evening. The Andaz Tokyo is a beautiful hotel, we would definitely return if in Tokyo.

If there was a way to rank this hotel above five stars, we would have given it a perfect 10. From the personalized check in process to the unique decorative and architectural touches , this property exudes modern charm with an attention to detailed service. The staff remembered our names and did everything they could to make our stay comfortable. The Andaz Tokyo is one of the most beautifully designed and furnished properties that we have ever stayed in. The staff compliments the setting by providing its guests with impeccable service.

This is an amazing hotel. My wife and I had a wonderful time staying here. It is located close enough to most of the major subway lines that it feels very centrally located. It is running distance to the imperial palace, and you can actually see it from a number of the rooms. This also puts it within walking range of many major museums. While you are there check out the spa, it was worth the money. The concierge service is used to dealing with a very rich clientele, they seemed a bit surprised when my wife and I declined eating at an 800 dollar a steak restaurant LOL.

This is a beautiful hotel with top level service. Rooms were great, the staff was very attentive, the view from the lobby was gorgeous, breakfast was excellent, close to the subway. We had stayed at the grand Hyatt before and prefer the Andaz, it's new and fresh, although it's a Hyatt it tries to incorporate Japanese design and gives you more of a sense of place. We'll be back.
user_name:
Z Z
New York City, New York

review_body: Perfect one night in Tokyo. Business facilities were great. Little breakfast snacks in the morning in the lobby and afternoon tea. Film event look very cool and I wish I'd been available to join. My second time for a short visit and it didn't disappoint. Will become my regular stop-over in Tokyo.

The view of the room in this hotel is perfect because we can see Tokyo tower. And My favorite point is breakfast. The breakfast is the best of all hotels in Tokyo in aspect of service,staff attitude,and taste.

We had been really looking forward to staying at this hotel for 2 nights - it was out last stop on our first trip to Japan. Our only point of comparison in Tokyo was the Park Hyatt - which we had stayed at for the commencement of our trip.THE ROOMAs expected, the room was fantastic and spacious. I loved clever joinery / storage + bathroom design. The way everything had a place and fit together really well.The complimentary in room Andaz refreshments were a little limited - but it was quite easy to head downstairs and grab whatever you need from the lounge area.THE HOTEL The service was defiantly more 'relaxed' than the PH, though still always very professional. We did have a bit of an issue at check in where the room rate didn't match the rate on my booking - though this was resolved fairly quickly - to be honest, this was perhaps the only service 'fault' I can recall from our entire trip to Japan (we were blown away). While the rooms / design might have it over the Park Hyatt, I'm not sure that I particularly enjoyed the layout of shared areas. All on level 51 is the main reception, the guest lounge, a number of function spaces and the Andaz Tavern + lounge.I always found the floor to be quite busy and loud (weekend, there seemed to be a number of functions) - which I find is the opposite to what I want after a full on day in the city. THE FOODWe had breakfast one morning at the tavern - it was quite relaxing and we were given a really nice private table by the window.Most of the hot food was on the warm side which was disappointing, but the pastries and fresh fruit + juice were fantastic. Given Tokyo is a 'late to open' city (main shops and attractions open after 10:30am) it is a great way to start + plan your day.Dinner at the Tavern was also good - food was great - be prepared to wait 40+mins for one of the 'clay pots'.The only disappointment I found was that I spoke to staff 2hrs before we wished to dine and asked if it was possible to be seated by the window (it was our last night in Tokyo, and we hadn't managed to get a window seat at a bar or restaurant at night in Tokyo for the entirety of our trip). I was told that all window seats were unavailable - which wasn't that big of a problem - the view from our room was good. The annoying part was that a window table sat empty for the majority of our dinner. BeBu - burgers on the ground floor.We made a dinner of it one night and it was fantastic - the 'Pub Buddy' burger was amazing and the service was super friendly. HYATTThe hotel staff made a real effort to acknowledge my Platinum status - which was quite nice. We ended up in a room with a fantastic view and were offered 2pm checkout without even asking.

I lived in Japan for two years ( a LONG time ago) and I have traveled to Japan many more times in the last 50 years. I traveled to Japan this most recent time with my son as a graduation present. Our stay at the Andaz was a special treat I saved for our last three days of our two week trip. The hotel was a fabulous mix of the Japanese and Western styles. (I am a former architect.) The staff was wonderful without being deferential OR snooty.

I have a weakness for all things Japanese, for all things Tokyo, and for modern hotels. This place hits the nail on the head for all three of these. The location is a bit out of the way, but an easy walk to the metro. The rooms are extremely comfortable, spacious, and well-decorated. The bathtub is very large and accommodating, and the Toto is state of the art. I even had to update my Toto at home after being inspired by the new models. Perhaps even more amazing than the room is the pool area. I did not bother packing a swimsuit for my trip, but after getting a glimpse at the pool, I rented some swimwear from the spa and went for a dip. Between the amazing views from the pool deck, the adorable mini-pools around the corner, and the wonderfully decadent changing rooms, I can say this was the best pool experience I have ever had. The rates are, of course, a bit on the absurd side for anyone who is not a 'job creator' or living on a trust fund. But you can definitely see where your money is going. I just hope the dollar stays strong on the yen, because I definitely wish to return soon.

I really loved everything about this hotel. I was in Tokyo for 3 days on business. I am a frequent traveler and spend more than 75 nights a year in hotel rooms. I have stayed in a number of hotels in Tokyo over the past few years, but going forward the Andaz is the only place I'll go. The staff greet you warmly and make sure you have everything to your satisfaction. The lobby is on level 51 and the rooms are on the 4 floors below the lobby. Every room has gorgeous sweeping view over Tokyo. The colors are earthy and muted and are a welcome return to a classic palate that hoteliers have largely forgotten about. Lighting is perfectly muted, not too bright, not too dim, just right. Again, too many hotels, especially in Asia, use harsh white fluorescent lighting and the muted warmth provided a relaxing tone the minute you enter your room. The room has plenty of outlets and they are well placed. My biggest pet hate these days is walking into a hotel and spending 10 minutes trying to figure out the electricity. The panel operating the lights and drapes is conveniently placed next to the bed. No need to get up to make adjustments. Bed is super comfy, and the towels and linens rival the Four Seasons.I love that there is no charge for the minibar, Its shocking that more hotels haven't figured out that this keeps customers happy and doesn't cost much. Good free wifi with the room. Bath and shower very nice with decent rainshower. Could do with a touch more water power, but on the 50th floor, it's still pretty amazing. Free wine gathering every evening in the lobby is nice. The rooftop bar on 52nd floor is pretty cool, but I wish it were more open. Location overall is fantastic as its in a quiet part of business district but train is close and even roppongi is walkable in about 30 minutes. I walked it to see. I can't wait to come back.

Full disclosure: I have not spent a night at the PH, but did explore the public areas and had a drink at the New York Bar. I'm glad I chose the Andaz.I really appreciate the overall design of this hotel. It's modern and interesting while still being warm and luxurious. The lobby and lounge/restaurant area at the top is a really cool space. (Don't miss the wine/snack hour from 6-8.) The pool and spa are great too (though Japanese pool culture can be a bit intimidating to the uninitiated--if you're a Westerner, do yourself a favor and read up (swim caps required, rinse off before you jump in).I loved my room (a king). The entry/bathroom/changing area is almost as big as the room itself, which I found really luxurious. Views are stunning--plan on spending at least an hour or two in your room after the sun goes down to soak it all in. Loved the huge soaking tub, as well as the most spacious shower I've ever used in a hotel. Soaps/shampoos are unbranded--some people might not care, but would it be too hard to tempt us kleptomaniacs/hoarders with some Aesop? The bath salts are a nice touch, though.I had fun playing with all the lights in the room--the options are almost infinite. The rooftop bar was fun. Prime Instagram opportunities. It was a little windy, but there are more sheltered interior areas, too.Visit the stuffy/aging Park Hyatt for a drink if you must, but if I were splurging in Tokyo, I'd probably stay here again.

We have been staying at Andaz hotel for the last 7 days while we have the following comments :The overall room product is kind of disappointed especially being the latest Hyatt property within such a booming hotel market in Tokyo now.The lighting within the room is very poorly planned, far too bright, lack of any dimmer control whatsoever, light switches are not user friendly plus made the room without any ambiance.Since most lightbulbs being used are LED light bulbs on the ceiling which are only ideal for public area for energy saving but honestly is not suitable for guest rooms, major shortfall is it cannot even connect to any dimmer light switch together at all. Classic example is that 4 LED ceiling lights shining above my head while working on the working desk now, a table lamp should have been in place as it is seriously affecting my wife's sleeping when I need to work late.That 4 very bright LED ceiling lights above the bathtub has completely destroy the ambiance within the bath / shower room, I need to stick 4 papers by myself to covering it in order to reduce its brightness.Then that very dazzling long light beam above the bed has constantly made the bedroom area extremely bright while nothing can be done to adjust it at all. Have to ask your engineering to come in at night to unplug that however the ceiling lighting along the room foyer area cannot be switch off independently.Water pressure for both the hand / rainforest shower are kind of weak especially the rainforest shower is only like drizzle, had asked engineering to adjust it but apparently nothing can be done at all. It has taken 15 minutes to fill up the water for your bathtub plus apparently no ventilation system is available within the bath room area.The bathroom's amenities (shower, shampoo, conditioner, lotion) are non branded local stuffs unlike your other Hyatt properties at least using Aesop and fortunately I have brought my own. For your information even the good old Palace Hotel Tokyo is using French bathroom's amenities product now which has lower ADR than your property.The hair blow dryer's power is so weak that I really miss that from your Park Hyatt Tokyo.The humidity of the room is the driest that I have ever stayed in top class hotels in Tokyo, not to mention the Peninsula Hotel which has very nice air-con which is filtering into the room with individual controlled humidity. This is the first time in Tokyo that I need to request for a humidifier in my hotel room but its water tank size is so small that cannot even last for overnight function.Those bath towels being used are the worst quality that I have came across globally, one side is flat and rough and is like a rug. It is so rough and hurting the skin plus not functional when drying your body / hair at all.Your two towel hooks are installed wrongly within the shower room behind the glass door which is not serving its purpose to drying the towel after being used. Plenty of space facing the big mirror to installing that instead.Unfortunately your published room size at 50 sq.m is a false information as it has only 41 sq.m instead unless you are accounting for the public corridor space in front of our room. My wife is an architectural designer as profession so is very hands on plus with our actual measuring of the room. For your information the standard room at the Peninsula Tokyo is having 51 sq.m which is pretty genuine and unlike here.Due to the smaller size of your bedroom portion versus the bathroom, you have no choice but to put the bed facing the window however that long sofa is blocking half its window view already which is pointless despite you have large window. Then the height of the sofa level is too low to matching the working desk level nor is comfortable whatsoever.There is only one small drawer within the whole room to put clothing which is not acceptable.Your so call working desk has no drawer nor any basic stationary being provided especially supposed to be a business travellers' hotel.Almost all your pillows are so soft and not well supporting the neck despite we have more than enough pillows within our room now.While there are actually sufficient space at the bedside but the two bedside panels are too small and lack of sufficient space.Very disappointed hotel ....

My stay was perfect. The hotel was spectacular. Clean and very well presented. The rooms were very comfortable and nicely decorated. I loved the morning coffee bar, that included croissants and danishes every day. The service staff was very helpful and accommodating. The food was excellent and the rooftop bar magical!
user_name:
Stephanie M
new york, United States

review_body: Location: Toronomon Hills is a great location between Roppongi and Ginza. The subway station is a short walk away. Also plenty of taxi and uber nearby given office building below. Hotel lobby is on the top floor (51st) and hotel rooms are just below. Office tower on the lower floors and lots of food options in the complex. The pastry shop in the building is also excellent.Lobby: I would call it modern Japanese with warm wood accents. It has a very open and hip vibe. Check in staff aren't behind a counter, they work around a central island. The waiting area has several long communal tables that facilitate interactions.Room: we're Hyatt Diamond members and got upgraded to a studio suite. It was a huge room with a totally awesome view of Tokyo Tower. There's a row of bench seating (for 6) along the window. Wow!!!As with all Andaz, all non-alcoholic drinks and snacks in the mini-bar is free. A great benefit. Room has coffee pot and tea kettle.Bathroom: Lovely wood vanity sink and a huge modern "furo" tub with enclosed shower adjacent. This is the one luxury we enjoyed every night. There were lots of complaints on tripadvisor about the round tub, it's big and deep.Bath amenities are house brand, but scent changes based on the season. For Spring, the scent is Cherry blossom. A gentle scent.Service: Overall, excellent service with the staff and very polite. Only thing to be aware is the concierge is good, but some don't speak great English. Easier to process request in person or via email.Loved it here and will stay here again.

With their "Senior Rate" discount, two-night stay (Thur. & Fri.) cost a little bit more than US$1,000 not including meals but with free soft drink and snack in the room frige. The hotel is new (in their second year here), and so the room is clean and tidy. Electrically operated curtain and sun-shade has the "Black-out" mode that completely shuts down the outside lights and gives you a deep 'coma'. The hotel section is located in the upper part of the 52-story building ("Tora-no-mon Hills") which commands very good view of the heart of the Japan's beaurocracy; you can even feel as if you own all you see from that height. Unlike the neighbouring Akasaka or Ginza area, there are not much famaous restaurants or pubs in the vicinity; but this Tora-no-mon (Tiger's Gate, literally translated) Hills forms virtually a vertical town where you don't have to go out for your daily needs. You can enjoy $200 a person steak dinner quite casually in the office section. Try extra-charged express laundry service; they do a perfect job for $50 for just a long-sleeve shirt and a pair of pants. Parking lot is provided in the basement 1 to 3 levels and is charged $30 a day. City life in the mid-town Tokyo is, in the eyes of a countryman like me, an exorbitant extravagancy, a kind of surreal experience even. Is it a value for the money? No, it's the other way around. Money is the only value here. And as long as you have it, there is nothing you cannot get including the very best service, security, and smiling faces from the young attractive staff, at the Andaz Tokyo.

Being in this hotel is like being in a resort, you may not want to leave and enjoy the rest of Tokyo, so be warned. The spa is complimentary with the rooms and is wonderful with an amazing pool and massage chairs!

This is one of the most talked about new hotel in Tokyo. And it did not disappoint: very well thought out rooms, magnificent views of Tokyo Tower and further beyond you can see Haneda Airport and the Bay. Clearly much thought was given as to the kind of staff they want to have working there - young, energetic with the usual high standard of service. The gym is very huge and underused with impressive cadio and other equipment. The spa with jacuzzi comes complimentary to guests. Andaz definitely offers another top choice among 5 star hotels in Tokyo if Ginza is not a big factor in the equation.

Coolest hotel I've ever stayed at. It was like staying at a modern art museum. The pool and hot tub / spa were amazing. I wish we used it more while we were there. Free wine reception every night was a nice touch. The rooms were quite impressive and tranquil with a modern feel.The location is not the most ideal. Felt like a business district. About a 30 minute walk to Tokyo Station or 15 minutes by train. Close to lots of neighborhoods, but not really "in" one. The building itself is gorgeous and almost a city unto itself, with multiple bars and restaurants. Surrounding neighborhood was dead at night on the weekends. Walk a few blocks north and there's nothing going on. Walk a few blocks east and there's a bit more action. All in all, amazing hotel, but you're probably taking a cab or subway anywhere for nightlife / activities.

If you are looking for a different hotel stay, try Andaz !No waiting at lobby reception desks to checkin, they seat you near the lobby , take care of your bags, offer a vast array of refreshments and then have you sign in. A welcome change to lining up with millions! Rooms are innovative , fresh and appealing. Large couches that span the whole front of the room. Better than a tiny couch and no room to stretch out. Stunning bathrooms with all the amenities you can think of! Oh and if you left anything at home, no problem, they have it all even hair straighteners !!

Our first stay at this gem and what strikes you first are the amazing views from all angles 50 stories above Tokyo. The staff were professional and friendly and really add to the value of your experience. The room was neat modern with spectacular views of the skyline. Circular bathtub was quite large and shower had excellent pressure. We ate at the most excellent Lobby Tavern restaurant (it is definitely misnamed) and would highly recommend for at least one night of fine dining and excellent service. They also have a Skybar which is a "don't miss", again, affording outstanding views of the city in a ultra cool space.

This was my second time at the Andaz and once again very pleased. Rooms are very comfortable with plenty of space and great views. They do service well from check in to the little evening snacks and drinks for guests. Was very pleased with the night I did dinner in the hotel. Interesting menu and very well executed. This is not a place to go on a budget but worth the price.

This is the first time I try Andaz brand and I must say that this Tokyo branch encouraged me to try other Andaz properties. The interior design was fabulous and the service was great. The staffs were very helpful and service-minded. The breakfast line was also very good. Next time I visit Tokyo, this hotel will be the top list of mine.

We were treated as VIPs from the minute we arrived to check in. The hotel lobby is stunning and check in takes place around a huge communal wood table where tea is offered whilst they check you in. Very dignified and personalised. The staff even remembered our names.The room was beautiful with a stunning view over Tokyo from the floor to ceiling windows. The bathrooms are beautifully appointed and the coffee machine was a nice touch. It was far superior to what we had expected and would definitely stay here again.

The hotel have some of the most spacious rooms I have seen in Japan. The location is quite convenient within close proximity to several subway/train stations. It is also within walking distance to Ginza. Also the bathtub was awesome. :)

The Andaz is a special place. It's expensive, but boy is it worth it if you want to treat yourself. From the wonderful rooms to the great breakfast buffet, to the amazing pool and spa. Almost didn't make us not wanting to go out and explore the city, because the hotel is so fantastic.

Hotel lobby starts on the 51st Floor and the staff takes good care of you. It has an amazing view from the top. My room overlooks the Tokyo Tower. The breakfast is great right and there is a restaurant right next to the check in counter is great. It also serves a wide variety of food. It also overlooks the tokyo tower if you ask for a window seat. Sincere staff and very detailed explanation if you ever need directions. You should also ask them for restaurant recommendations if you are new to the area!

Facilities wise, this hotel maybe one of the best in Tokyo. Great design in the space of the room, great views and great spa. Unfortunately, very min. content/service to fill the beautiful shell. c/i agent has very little knowledge about hyatt gold passport, didn't communicate with bell staff so after I got my key I need to chase down b.staff myself to ask them bring my luggage to my room. drinks/treats in the lobby lounge you see at other Andaz almost non-exist here. they put out some cheap/salty crackers all day long. that's it.I tried very hard to squeeze my memories to say more nice things about this hotel bc it's so beautifully built. But, I just can't. there's really nothing memorable ab my stay. Location is not helping either, like other reviews mentioned it's far from everything else.

I stayed here for 5 nights and it was wonderful experience all around. I picked it as I had heard that this newer hotel is better than the famous Park Hyatt in Shinjuku in terms of service as well as the room itself. Also the location is fantastic because its central to pretty much all of Tokyo. While Toranomon itself doesn't offer much to do, you can take the train and get to pretty much anywhere in Tokyo in about 20-30 minutes. The Ginza line can take you pretty much wherever you want. I arrived early in the morning and they got me checked in quickly. I noticed that this isn't always the case for other guests as their front desk staff doubles as concierges. So during peak checkin times there maybe a bit of wait. The room itself was fantastic and had great views over Tokyo. I had a friend who works in Osaka join me for a couple of days out of my stay and the Andaz hosts were kind to provide a rollaway bed and amenities so that he can stay with me. Their concierges were able to get me some reservations at decent restaurants but they were not my first choice. These restaurants were good sushi but a bit touristy and the chefs were not of the same caliber as I got to try later during my visit. The breakfast is great. Both the western and japanese options offered in their buffet are of good quality and variety. I normally don't think highly of hotel breakfasts and only have it when I'm in a hurry but I ate here everyday. The staff were extremely kind and helpful with everything. Once I left my room a little late at night to grab a light snack outside of the hotel. While I was walking on the road a hotel employee who had just gotten of her shift asked me whether I needed help and went out of her way to direct me. All in all, a great experience and I would stay here in the future for the great service and location.
user_name:
trippynappy
New York City, New York

review_body: I spent one night here with my son and it was spectacular! we had a room with a view of tokyo bay and the city. The hospitality was amazing, every amenity you could ask for! the room size was great for tokyo. the breakfast was amazing! you felt you were in a luxurious hotel in the city. They also had a sweet good bye gift, and i loved there umbrellas! I would surely recommend this hotel, can't go wrong. nothing negative to say at all. it was pricey as i was there during the sakura, but worth every penny!

This is our second visit to Andaz Toranomon Hills, Tokyo, simply put, one of my favorite hotels in the world. This time we had an unusual, not up to Hyatt standard interaction with a Young male -not Japanese- during check in process and later during our stay. I am afraid he did not seem sincere, had poor choices of wording and poor timing in offering information. More in detail: We -spouse Jonathan and myself, Ricardo- booked two rooms, one of them through Founders Club destined for the use of mother in law. At check in time he welcomed us by saying something along the lines of "Welcome, Mr Solines we appreciate your loyalty, you can check out by two pm... you will have to check out at noon, he said to Jonathan" (?) No one had inquired about check out then so that was unnecessary and made anyone that was not me unimportant and less than. Silly, really. We requested of him the two rooms be on the same floor -any floor - to be closer to mother in law but he said that was impossible at the moment... In another example, the same guy, when asked about the location of a pharmacy where to buy medicine for a small cold sore Jonathan had developed on his upper lip (I asked him about Abreva- he tried to help, but after a few phone calls he informed us that a Doctors prescription was needed and that being the weekend no doctor was available. "I am sorry we could not help with... your sickness" He said while looking at it like Jonathan was growing a second head!! Kind of funny the whole experience with this person, but not really funny. A couple days in Kyoto we were easily able to get the medicine at a pharmacy with the help of our wonderful personal guide. I must say that while our general impression of this member of your team was poor everything else was as expected: We had drinks at the rooftop bar with out Tokyo friends, ate lunch an the Andaz Tavern and had buyers at BeBu a couple times and everything from lobby to room was Andaz perfect.

Very impressed with this hotel. The staff is very friendly and absolutely the professional. The best service I ever received in a hotel. Anywhere. You will not have a single complaint about this hotel.

I was slightly nervous about traveling with an infant from the US to Japan and booked the Andaz because of the excellent quality and service I have experienced at their other properties. The Tokyo hotel was wonderfully ZEN, accommodating, and caring. Service was top-notch, as was the food, babysitting services, house cleaning, and concierge. It was a lovely place to just hang out and the spa, pool, and baths were an incredible escape.

Okay, I stayed here on as a result of having excessive amount of points, and a need for avoiding the chaos that is Tokyo. So perhaps this review will be bias (then again most are).Locationwise, the hotel is a good walking distance away from Shimbashi station, but the taxi service downstairs is well supplied for those who are willing to pay for it.Front desk service is very discreet, as there is no actual desk for one to walk up to. Rather, the staff invite you to wait at a waiting area while they complete your check-in. Room-permitting, they'll ask if you would like to upgrade your room to a better one, usually for a discounted price (I already had one with a view of Tokyo Tower, so the next upgrade would've been a suite at 75% the price, I passed).The room itself had a very clean, minimalistic, with a fusion of Japanese and Western culture in it, with green tea and coffee amenities.Service was quick and always professional with every staff that greets you to seemingly know your name (or perhaps my name was too easy to remember).The bathrooms were one of their most outstanding points, the bathtub was a medium sized, round, jacuzzi-style, bath tub, with seasonal bath salts (autumn for me) provided. Connected to the tub was a rainforest style shower with amazing water pressure (big plus for me).Facilities - This was a staycation for me so I got the opportunity to use their spa and athletics facilities. The gym is shared with tenants living in the apartment complex (same building, ridiculous rent), but rarely used by anyone. New high tech treadmills, weight machines, and free weights. The pool was extremely well lit, and great for tanning or relaxing.At night, ending with a spa service which was revitalizing and soothing.The restaurant served a delicious lobster risotto with a seasonal soup.

A very good hotel ,outstanding service. The rooms were spacious and well planned Breakfast menu was good Overall very good ambience .The staff were always smiling and very helpfulA home away from home

Andaz was wonderful! The service, friendliness and professionalism of the staff is superb. It is quiet and the rooms are very nice. The location is good. I will make a point of staying there again when in Tokyo

We where so excited to stay at the Andaz in the beautiful sky scraper. Every morning we would wake up to clouds clearing and the city appearing around us. The room and bathroom where stunning, like being in a bento box, hand made wood pieces with machine precision. Great breakfast, cute little sky bar, good gym. Love it and can't wait to go back.

I recently used points to stay at this hotel for just one night and I wish it was longer! Everything was great, from the room, to the pool, to the rooftop bar. Amazing views of Tokyo and amazing service all-around. Personally, I even prefer this hotel to the Park Hyatt in Tokyo and it is less points/$ per night.Only drawback is the location, but although it isn't great, it isn't terrible, as it is close to the subway and is in the Toranomon complex that has many restaurants. Also is walking distance to Shimbashi, Roppongi and Ginza.
user_name:
croberts82
New York City, New York

review_body: Top-notch in every aspect. I was so spoiled during my hotel stay I didn't want to leave. By the hotel staff as well as the food served in the restaurant, and most of all, by the rainfall shower and auto-flush toilet that lifts its lid as you near it.

Having stayed in Hyatt most of the time and Andaz as my first, I have to get used to this new style. The toughest is a proper concierge , knowledgeable and able to recommend me places and also can arranging everything for me including restaurants reservation and others. The team here is still lacking.Out of 6 correspondence with the Andraz Host, I have 2 misses. No on replied me. Those 4 replies were very polite and helpful.Overall still a very good hotel...it will be a very tough choice for me next trip between Andaz, Park Hyatt or Grand Hyatt next trip.

Our son insisted we stay here over my birthday. We were a complete family. It was a great experience. The GM had sent a welcome note, champagne came and sweets. But that would may have been offered at most luxury hotels. Andaz is unique in many ways. The ambiance, the hosts and attendants are extremely caring and stand by you to serve and make you feel special at all times. More than our expectations - Excellence!

Very bad fixture in the room very bad services expesinve but not up to 5 star standard should stay at AMAN or Peninsula in that price they charged the room USD 700, but the room is relatively bad design and bad fixture . And the staff there is not attentive at all even I asked their help for the delivery of my lost Iphone they also charged 10 % on top of Fedex Fee . its 5 stars hotel not a ordinary one I wish they r better than this
user_name:
Po Chi L
HK, Hong Kong

review_body: I had ready many reviews of the Andaz Tokyo, but still was blown away by how wonderful the hotel was. The more time we spent in the room, the more amazed I was by all the design touches at the hotel. I especially enjoyed the bathrooms--it definitely feels like having your own spa integrated into your room. We enjoyed the large bath and connected shower. Japanese toilets are also amazing--loved the heated seat, automatic flush, and all kinds of options.The views are also amazing--so nice to lay in bed and open the blackout shades to amazing views of Tokyo. We spent a lot of time just sitting at the couch taking in the view.I loved breakfast--it was not the largest breakfast spread I have ever had, but it was the highest quality. The Japanese fruit was amazing, especially the strawberries. The hotel does an amazing job with both savory and sweet options at breakfast.The hotel also hosted a few amazing events while we were there--looks like it is becoming a favorite location for events and weddings in Tokyo.The service was also amazing--so friendly and willing to help. There were not any language barriers, even though neither of us spoke any Japanese. I already miss the Andaz and hope to return soon.

Yes, the Andaz may turn out to cost you an arm and leg, but after staying here, I have decided that limbs are highly over-rated. This is possibly the best way to splurge on a couple of days in Tokyo and let the rest of the budget balance out with Air B&B's. The entire property is nothing short of stunning, particularly given the fact that the hotel rooms START on the 46th floor with the lobby on the 51st. This should give you some idea of the views to be had of Tokyo. Nothing at this place is short of first class and even though expensive, unlike some other large chains, you never get the feeling of being gouged. To the contrary, all in-room snacks and non-alchoholic beverages are free and there is a complementary wine and sake reception every night. The service and staff are beyond compare without making you feel as though you are being fawned over. Add this to the fact that, in Japan, tipping is rare, and one gets the feeling that the level of hospitality is genuine and not geared toward financial gratuity. We didn't eat at the Andaz Tavern, but its quality is well-reviewed elsewhere on TripAdvisor. Hats off to this boutique hotel for achieving near-perfection. I get the feeling that it is probably giving its sister property ( the famed Tokyo Park Hyatt ) a run for its money.

The service, the rooms, the food. But for me is was the design features. Art strategically placed so that each corner you turn, each room you enter you're just blown away. If your budget stretches this far a definite perfect case from which to see Tokyo.

There are hotels... and then there are.... sensory experiences. This hotel is the latter. The Andaz is one of the first hotels I have seen without a front desk. The easiest way to explain the check in process is like walking into an Apple store for technical support.... except with much better staff in a beautiful setting. You are seated in the lobby's lounge area and go through the check in process right there. After that, you are given your hotel key where you head DOWN to your room (that's right haha, down!) Our room was on the 47th floor, making it the highest hotel (and nearly highest building) in all of Tokyo.Before I go into detail about the room, I have to attempt to explain the view. Understand, people pay good money (Willis Tower, Chicago) to see views like this. The windows in the room are floor to ceiling and you are literally looking down at the skyline of Tokyo. Because of the buildings height, the hotel has a 360 degree view of the city - there are no bad rooms here.The room itself was separated in two main areas. The bath area and the bedding area. The bath area was exceptionally large and offered a beautiful rainfall shower head, oversized tub, enclosed toilet area, safe, minibar, and dresser area. From there you walk into the room itself which is bright and fun. The bedding area reminds you of your friends house... just warm and inviting (but with a much better view).Although we didn't get to use the spa, it seemed extremely high end. Wish we had more time to experience the spa! They have a bar of herbs, salts, and other items that they will blend according to your personal feelings, colors, and relaxation goals.The fitness center was large, uncrowded, and one of the most professional centers I have seen in a hotel. The machines were brand new and very high end. I'm not much one for working out, but even I had to try out the treadmill!I'm not huge into art, and I am not much one for design; however, the Tavern (hotel's restaurant) was a master piece in every aspect. The lighting, the art, the ambiance, the view, the staff - just everything was perfect. It was emotional sitting down, and something I will never forget.If you are staying in Tokyo, the Andaz should not be a consideration - it should be a promise.

On my first-ever visit to Tokyo with my teenage daughter, I had the good fortune to stay in two different suites at the Andaz. And, unlike the Bill Murray movie, absolutely nothing was lost in translation! This hotel has captured the best of Eastern and Western cultures in sweet harmony. From the moment you enter the lobby in the 50-story tower called Toranomon Hills, you realize you are in a very special place, with outstanding architectural and design elements. The sweeping views from our suites were stunning, and the decor had a modern Asian vibe while also being very comfortable. (I personally enjoyed the high-tech hands-free toilets!) The staff was friendly and highly professional, with flawless service throughout our stay. The breakfast buffet and drinks at the rooftop bar were terrific, though the room service menu was a bit limited. All in all, it's easy to see why this hotel has rocketed to the top of lists of favorite hotels in Tokyo; it's one of the best places I've stayed anywhere around the world.

The Andaz is an extraordinary hotel. It is located in a chic part of Tokyo and is on top of a new building. The fast elevators raise you quickly to the entrance foyer with spectacular views over Tokyo. The swimming pool is stunning. Beats the park hyatt by a factor of ten

The Toranomon Hills Andaz is understated luxury. Even for Japanese standards the workmanship of build and finish is extraordinary, staff unusually capable and friendly. It doesn't suffer the hipster orientation at other modern hotel concepts, but it does feel fresh.

This hotel was probably the most wonderful hotel I've ever stayed at. The hotel is within walking distance to the imperial palace and about a half hours was from the Tsukiji Fish market which was perfect for us.We showed up hours before check in and they greeted us, gave us free coffee and tea, and allowed us to go up to our room. The service couldn't have been better here.Our room was fabulous with a beautiful view, amazing tub and overall just a very luxurious feel. We also stayed at the Park Hyatt while we were in town and found this hotel to be superior in every way. Although the room itself was incredible, we found the service to be what really set this hotel apart from any other place we stayed. Everyone we met was so helpful and kind and treated us like royalty. We were also appreciative that they had free coffee, bottled water, and soft drinks available at all times for their guests. They also provide free wine and snacks at happy hour and a free light breakfast in the morning. We wish we could have stayed there longer!

My family stayed in this hotel for 5 nights with 3 rooms for 5 adults and 1 child. Hotel is very new and is at the top of a high rise office building. Every corner of the hotel - room, coffee shop, check in area give you a panoramic view of Tokyo down town with Tokyo Tower in the horizon. As this is a business hotel, luckily no noisy tour groups in the hotel. Following high Japanese service standard, hotel staff is friendly and helpful. It is a luxury to enjoy the panoramic downtown view in breakfast and night drink. Children amenities are available for my baby. (Surprisingly not in Four Seasons Singapore!) My baby even refused to check out for Disney Resort Hotel! Definitely will come back next time!

The check-in area is at the 51st floor. There are only 4 floors for guest rooms, from floors 47-50, so no matter what room you book, you are guaranteed a VIEW of Tokyo. South wing gives you the Skytree and Imperial Palace grounds; North wing gives you the Tokyo tower and Imperial Palace grounds. Checking in: far different from other hotels I've stayed at, you are welcomed in a lounge where you are offered a choice of coffee, tea, juices, or wine, while they check you in. After which, you are shown to your room.Rooms: Room has a walk-in closet, separate toilet and baths. Decor is mix traditional and modern Japanese design. There is a yukata which you can use. A traditional Japanese tea set is adjacent to a Nespresso machine (mix of traditional and modern, right?). Drinks in the minibar are complimentary, except alcohol, and they are restocked every day. Smallest room size is 50 square meters, which is A LOT in a city known for its space limitations. The view at sunrise, sunset, and in the evening is spectacular. Makes you want to stay holed up in the room. There are a lot of power outlets, including beside the bed, so it's very convenient. Toilet has a motion sensor, so when you go near it, it automatically opens itself. It flushes itself also, just in case you forgot to flush. There is some sort of jacuzzi bath besides the rain shower, so you can have a warm bath with some bath sea salts (one of their amenities).In short, this room spoils you.Service: It is impeccable. Staff are all warm and helpful. Airport limousine bus takes you directly to and from the airport. We asked the concierge for the bus pickup schedule and they gave us not only that, but also purchased the bus tickets for us. It was effortless. They answered all our questions regarding getting around Tokyo, gave us maps of nearby areas, train maps, and all kinds of maps and references. The lounge offers small bites in the morning with coffee, tea, juices, or wine (wine may be available only in the afternoon to evening, i'm not sure.) So you can wait there forever and not mind at all.Breakfast: It is limited. There are not much choices. Mostly Western food of pastries, fruits, sausage, bacon, eggs. For me it is enough. The view from the breakfast area is enough to fill me. Service during breakfast is excellent. Staff were all very attentive. Rarely did I call them to have my coffee refilled. They approached my table when my cup is empty and ask me if I want a refill.Gym and pool are on the 37th floor, along with the Spa. All areas offer you views of Tokyo.There's a rooftop bar on the 52nd floor, a chapel, and a small sushi restaurant. The rooftop bar offers open-air spectacular views of Tokyo.Bottomline, this hotel spoils you with views, doesn't scrimp on space, and does its best in making you feel at home in Tokyo. It's a hotel that's hard to leave and say goodbye to.Nearest station is Toranomon station of Ginza line (10-minute walk). Shimbashi station is the next nearest (15-minute walk).

Excellent new hotel with superb views, many dining options, excellent staff, fantastic pool. The design of the room is very well done - sober, efficient and tasteful. The spa and pool area are excellent - and given the limited number of rooms - this area is not crowded at all. We stayed in one room as a family of 4 and arrangements were made to make this work very well.

Yes, I am a heavy points traveler, meaning that I use all my credit cards and rewards programs to my advantage. How lucky was I to be able to use my rewards at the Andaz Tokyo. Not sure how much you can book a night here for during the low season, but man this place is amazing.View: The lobby is already up somewhere in the 40th/50th floors. This means you get a high-rise view of Tokyo. Our room had Tokyo Tower at night. Amazzzzzing.Pool: As an American, Japanese pool and spa culture is so nice to see. They give everyone fuzzy slippers to walk around in, the entire locker room and pool area is luxurious and spotless. There is a sauna, two jacuzzis, and indoor pool with a high-rise view as well.Room: Awesome room that is spacious. Minibar loaded with complimentary goodies. Great beds, and everything just looks new and very nice. Service here is amazing. Give them a call for anything you need. Last note on LOCATION: This is in a business district, not a super touristy place. I travel luxuriously on a smart budget. This place is a 5 min walk to the nearest subway station, Toranomon. Late night you will most likely take a cab, but that was no issue for us either. For foreigners, ask the front desk for their business cards that you can show your cab driver!

Spent over a week at the property on business. Fantastic location in a newly built, beautiful building.
