Less than a five minute walk to the Ginza line, and the Chiyoda, Mareunouchi and Hibiya lines were not much further away. The hotel staff was absolutely phenomenal, and the cleaning staff would even ask what time you would prefer them to come back during the day. The rooms and the view were absolutely incredible - I had a view facing East toward Tokyo Bay and it was breathtaking gorgeous watching the sunrise (although next time I would love to try the side with a view of Tokyo Tower). The free (non-alcoholic) drinks in the refrigerator were a lovely touch when you are too tired to go to the convenience store downstairs.After staying here I definitely have a new favorite hotel in Tokyo; Andaz Tokyo sets the bar very high for other hotels in the area.

The most beautiful hotel with the most attentive staff! Love everything about this hotel. We took taxi's most everywhere and it was always no more than a 15 min ride to all of the shopping areas in Tokyo. The food and breakfast are amazing as well!

Amazing views of downtown Tokyo, and great hotel for visit to Tokyo. Enjoy the snacks and night cocktail. High floors. Did not visit roof top garden, but was told that it gives you great view of \Tokyo,

Spent 2 nights at Andaz Tokyo. Best hotel I have stayed ever. Great service and luxury room in Tokyo. Good view of Tokyo tower, sky tree and imperial palace. Complementary mini bar and non alcoholic drinks. Also close to convince stores. About 6 minutes walk to Toronomon hills station.

The service was exceptional. The breakfast spread classic. The roof top bar really relaxed. The room large spacious with amazing books. The bathroom amenities for top class. The burger at the cafe on the ground floor was outstanding. We were travelling with our 1 year old and the hotel made the stay just perfect and took amazing care.

From the moment you walk into Andaz you will feel truly appreciated. From the comfortable check in process, to the friendly concierge at the lobby, to every waiter or staff member at Andaz, they will all greet you, provide you with a warm smile, and always be ready to provide you with the best customer service.We were a party of 8, came for a family vacation with 4 rooms booked. The night manager kindly greeted us during check in, and made us feel very comfortable after a late night arrival. We had a wonderful dinner at the restaurant behind the lobby with a gorgeous view and the service was fantastic. The next morning the general manager sought us out and was extremely friendly and polite, while we planned out our day with the concierge. The concierge was SO PATIENT to deal with a large party that unfortunately sometimes has too many different opinions. The concierge was very detail oriented and able to help us really plan out our 3 days in Tokyo to make it a very memorable stay.I've been to Tokyo a few times, and this was by far the best hotel experience I've ever had, my wife agreed it even exceeded Four Seasons Tokyo! Wonderful hotel, wonderful staff, amazing service oriented hotel, very comfortable and spacious rooms we were on the 47th floor and had excellent views of the city. Also had the opportunity to enjoy the gym and it was very well equipped. Plenty of treadmills, free weights, and other full size equipment, all the latest technology. You can have a full workout, it has almost everything you have in a gym membership.Upon our return everyone kept saying how much they missed Andaz, what a wonderful experience, a true vacation.

A place of quiet restfulness in the heart of Tokyo, the Andaz Tokyo is a wonderful hotel and experience. Upon arrival you are greater by the excellent hotel staff ready to make your stay a great one. tThe rooms are lovely and very quiet and comfortable with great views. The bathroom has a great soaking to alleviate stress after a long journey.

Luxury treatment all the way with amazing Tokyo views! Staff was very friendly and helpful. Really loved the modern yet earthy styling. The standard King room was great, good amount of space and really loved the shower/bathtub and remote shades! Utilized the gym, which was fully equipped. Enjoyed a wonderful sushi meal at the rooftop restaurant. Was also able to access a nice walk to tonkasu ramen nearby and the Imperial palace.

Tokyo has many great hotels (my favourite had been Okura, which is undergoing rennovation), but Andaz takes it to a new level. The reception on 51st floor sets the stage. While you sit in a comfortable lounge, sipping sake or green tea, receptionists take care of checking in. The rooms are spacious, filled with amenities and a great rainfall shower. The pool/spa were great. The restaurant breakfast service is impeccable. After day one, the staff even remembered that I like my espresso to end my breakfast. My only reservation is that the bell staff seem a bit unwelcoming (we had to lug our luggage ourselves, which has NEVER happened to me in 30+ year stay at Okura)

I love my stat in Andaz Tokyo. The room is great, big and nice compared to thost hotels in the same category. The staff helped me friendly and offered anything I need. I was not that lucky to get a tokyo tower viewer room but I still enjoyed my stay in Andaz. Hopefully be back one day.

I stayed for two weeks at the Andaz on a recent business trip, and can say this is one of the nicest hotels I've ever been in. I loved the decor of the hotel and the rooms - everything was new and well taken-care of. The rooms were incredibly spacious for Tokyo standards, particularly the large walk-in closet and separate round soaker tub. I also loved that housekeeping set out treats after room service - I came home from work to delicious mini eclairs one evening!

staying for two night it was my last trip in Japan- the suite room and the bathroom were fantastic. The view from hotel room was incredible awesome. the train station is only 10 minutes walking distance from the hotel- Toranomon hills station - Definitely we will stay there again one days

This hotel was a delight from the minute we arrived. The staff were charming and friendly. The room was just beautiful. A giant circular bath as part of a wet room with rainfall shower and a hand held shower too. Good space for clothes. Nespresso coffee maker. Breakfast was excellent too. Couldn't fault it.The only minor disappointment was on our last day when we arrived back at the hotel after a long day of site seeing, we just wanted to sit and have a drink in the bar, but we were told (politely of course) the bar was very busy and there was no room.I would still not hesitate to recommend it highly.

After carefully reading reviews for choices in Tokyo, I was so happy to choose Andaz and was completely wowed by it! On any future trips to Tokyo, Andaz will always be my go-to choice!The superior Japanese service during our entire stay was spectacular! The concierge was very helpful in recommending and reserving restaurants for us--not just famous ones, but also delicious local spots where the natives eat. The property felt very new. The hotel lobby was located high above the city on the 51st floor, offering a spectacular view of the skyline, and I assumed all the rooms have a view from high up. We were upgraded to a bigger room, which was spacious with a chic modern design that seamlessly infused Japanese traditional elements. Breakfast is offered at the lobby, a high-end buffet style with a wide array of choices, from Japanese to Western. The manager there was very kind to let us dine in one of the private rooms next to the floor-to-ceiling windows during our stay. One of the best things is the hot tub and swimming pool, which offer great views and total relaxation. We also enjoyed a delicious omakase dinner and enjoyed the spa, both of which were great experiences. Can't wait to go back!

New York City, New York

review_body: My husband and I spent our last three nights at Andaz Tokyo during our three weeks journey in Japan and we weren't disappointed at all! In fact, after staying at super amazing Aman for five nights and the boring Peninsula for another three, we were happy to end our trip here at the Andaz because it gave us a sense of energy and happiness the moment we stepped in. We were first very impressed with its contemporary design of every aspect of the hotel. The view was breathtaking from our room overlooking the city, the bridge and the river. Although it's not as luxurious as the other two hotels we stayed in Tokyo, it still made us relax and we liked the comfy and light-weighted kimono in the room very much. Location might not be ideal if you are a tourist, there is nothing really exciting around the hotel. You have to take a cab or subway if you want to find more restaurants and shoppings.

I knew this would be a nice hotel but I was impressed with just how nice. The hotel staff are helpful without being overbearing and the rooms and beautifully done with an amazing view that only gets better at night.
user_name:
travelingponytail
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We've stayed at the Park Hyatt and Ritz Carlton in Tokyo and were very happy with them both, though preferred the Park Hyatt. This last trip we stayed at Andaz Tokyo and loved it. The location is terrific - on the Ginza line, easy walk to the Imperial Palace and gardens - and the property is stunning. It's newer than the other two and warmer, beautifully designed and it makes wonderful use of warm woods and excellent views. Staff are uniformly pleasant and professional. The hotel restaurant offers a lovely Japanese breakfast along with options for multiple palates and has lovely bar with perfect views for a nightcap.

We loved staying at this hotel; the location is fabulous, very central. The breakfast was excellent with a huge variety of food on offer, the gym and pool excellent. The service was almost impeccable except for the slow service of coffee in the morning. The view from the restaurants and the rooms is amazing, not much point going up the sky tree tower if you come here. The beds are very comfortable, but small. The wifi is excellent and free for as many devices you need.The only thing that wasn’t up to standard was the roof top bar on the 52nd floor, it kind of looks like they ran out of budget to finish the decor, as it has no ambience.I would highly recommend this hotel. We stayed with two young children and the staff were very accommodating of the children too.

How can I put it simply? I now have a new home in Tokyo.I really loved this hotel. From the design, the area and the staff.I was here to celebrate my birthday last December and it really blew my mind. I have been to Tokyo several times, staying at hotels like Peninsula, Ritz, etc. But this one really blew me out of my mind. I might even venture to say that this was one of my favorite hotels in all of 2015.The hotel is set in Toranomon Hills, on the top floors. I had room 5040, amazing views all the way. I could see Tokyo Sky Tree!People really doubt the neighborhood but I really enjoyed it. It is very close to everything, of course you need the subway to get to most attractions nearby but that's okay because Tokyo has the best subway system in the world.The Andaz is priced at the same range as it's sister hotel the Park Hyatt, which is more iconic but is really tired and old. I would stay here over Park Hyatt always.The spa was truly amazing as well, breathtaking views, several different pools, etc. As it happens in the Andaz chains, the minibar non alcoholic beverages are included, which comes in handy. There are several convenience stores nearby, Mini Stop, Natural Lawson, etc. Andaz Toranomon Hills is an oasis in the hustle and bustle that is the city of Tokyo, I would recommend this hotel over any other hotel in this vast city.Finally it is really worth mentioning the staff. Check in took a little too long for my taste (my flight was delayed and I was really tired, I just wanted to go to my room). But other than that the staff was outstanding. During my stay I spoke to a different staff member every morning about where I was going, they really showed interest and even researched things for me. One day I returned to the room after having spoken one morning to a staff member and they left a hand written letter saying they hoped I enjoyed the day and it had been a pleasure speaking with me. This kind of detail really stayed with me. Finally upon check out, which was seamless and took literally 3 minutes I spoke with the Front Office Manager Andrea Lobo. She was kind and showed true interest in my opinion about my experience.I am returning to Tokyo, with my mom this time, and I know where we are staying: Andaz Tokyo Toranomon Hills, here we come!!!
user_name:
Sebastian P
New York City, New York

review_body: I have a mixed feeling about this hotel. So I would just lay it down.- the lighting design is good. Room design looks nice but some what unpractical (I.e. Free standing mini bar looks nice but very inconvenient. Their bath tub reminds me of Egymptian tomb - no window, no tv, just a red marble wall and yourself)- this hotel has of those "hidden" entry design. The problem is, if you are going to hide it, you need an educated staff to guide you. When I was checking in, no one was there, found my way up to lobby, also not a clear check-in table, so I had to grab a staff myself. - food is good. Their room service was tasty, the down stair cafe is superb. They also provide free drink and snack at the lobby whole day.- staffs are kind. They try their best to help us. But my feeling was they are not trained / experienced yet. We asked for restaurant at Aoyama, it took them more than 30 minutes to find it. But again, they try their best if I ask. I think I will visit again if I can't book peninsula.

We were excited to try out in this new hotel by Hyatt as we have stayed in other Hyatt hotels in Tokyo already (Park, Grand, regency). We love the design of this new hotel and the service was excellent. The room layout is interesting. They intentionally put the bed facing the window so that you can enjoy the stunning view on bed. The living area is a bit small because of the enlarged bathroom/closet area. Personally (as a girl), I enjoy very much the bathroom and am happy to spend hours in the huge bathtub.

We spent our last night in Tokyo here using points after three nights at the grand hyatt (which is also great). I hesitated to book here at first because of the location, but the hotel more than makes up for any location shortcomings and the location isn't particularly bad at all.From check in to check out, we were blown away by the service, the amenities and the entire look and feel of the place.As a diamond Hyatt member we were given free buffet breakfast at the tavern. This was a delicious buffet with many different items, both Japanese and Western. The fruit selection was excellent!We also had access to the spa. The pool is gorgeous with sprawling views and there are two hot tubs, including a carbonated one!There were also Japanese massage chairs in the spa lounge which we loved!The room we had was beautiful. Japan meets mad men style is how I'd describe it. We had an incredible view of Tokyo bay.There were tons of in room amenities as well.Every person we dealt with at the hotel was helpful, friendly and caring. Im spoiled now. I can't imagine a better hotel.

I stayed here for the first time and had a good stay. The hotel is only two years old and has the feel of an undiscovered boutique hotel. The room and common areas are coolly decorated in a modernist style -- think Mad Men. The Tavern restaurant is excellent for both breakfast and dinner. There are unusual perks like free wine and snacks in the evening and free soft drinks from the mini bar. The gym is nice. Service is kind. Hotel is on the top of Toranomon Hill, so the views are superb. I would have given five stars except for a few things -- 1) strange un-functional bathtubs. Round wells but not jetted and feature a bizarre step, which makes it hard to fully immerse yourself comfortably. 2) gorgeous spa and pool area but the pool effectively has only three lanes, one of which is reserved for sports club members. If you like to swim, i suggest the Ritz Carlton or the Grand Hyatt, 3) the location is an offbeat business area with no super markets or good restaurants in the immediate vicinity, though Mori Bldg group has a dream to turn the adjacent MacArthur Road into a Japanese Champs Elysee in 10 years.

Great views and lovely rooms. The staff was very friendly and multilingual. When we arrived (take the elevator up to the hotel lobby) we were greeted with a smile, they sat us down, offered us a drink and snack while we waited to check in. Wake up to amazing views of the city and the bathroom space is luxurious. The hotel breakfast was tasty and even the dinning room had wonderful views. The beds are traditional Japanese style, so expect it to be a very firm compared to American beds.
user_name:
drollrover
New York City, New York

review_body: My children call this the upside down hotel as the reception is on a higher floor than the rooms. Views of Tokyo one side and Mount Fuji (if you're lucky) on the other. Nice rooms, but only one roll away bed allowed so difficult if you have two young children. Great location.

It was my first time staying in Andaz in Tokyo. Once I came into the room, the first thing caught my eyes is Tokyo tower thru the big wide window. It was amazing! Room was great and people worked there were very friendly and very quick to response any of my request. Worth to try!

We stayed here three times over the past few weeks and I have to say this is one of my favourite hotels ever. I am a huge fan of the Andaz brand and this is by far the jewel in their crown. The hotel itself is beautiful. There's a generosity in size and design that you don't often see in hotels, especially in Tokyo. Rooms are well appointed, incredibly comfortable and have the most glorious views. Staff are incredibly hospitable and friendly although if I was looking for an area of improvement, I think they could improve slightly on restaurant recommendations. Whilst the area around the hotel isn't a typical tourist base, it's just a short stroll to some very vibrant bars and restaurants and it makes for an easy base for business, sightseeing or shopping. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend the Andaz and can't wait to go back.

One of the best hotels I've stayed in. Great service, spotless rooms, loads of space, huge bathtub, complimentary soft drinks and snacks, great breakfast buffet, amazing views, great location, friendly staff. I really can't recommend it highly enough and can't wait to return.

A - Awesome Tokyo Hotel! N - Nothing Like You Can Imagine! D - Don't Miss Your Chance! A - Always The Same - Don't Change Anything! Z - Zipping With Sincere Staff and Views of Tokyo Thanks for reading this review and I hope that you have the chance to stay at the Andaz Tokyo. It will truly make memories and keep you returning for many years - Trust Me.

This hotel is 6-star warmth, chic, foodie-full, and without all the noise of say a W hotel. The service is really great: staff will do almost anything to accommodate. The Pool, spa, and gym are excellent.I've stayed here probably ten times and just keep coming back.

This hotel is in a great location with easy access to most places either on foot or via public transport / taxi. It is perched on the top floors of an office building and is modern but still retains its Japanese feel. Reception is on the 51st floor with rooms on the 47 - 50th floors. The staff are extremely friendly and helpful, nothing is too much trouble. The rooms are well appointed and have the addition of a free mini bar for snacks and non alcoholic beverages as well as little treats in your room on various days throughout your stay. The views of Tokyo from the rooms are amazing, I watched the sun rise over Tokyo bay each morning. Rooms are quiet and tranquil with very little noise from other rooms which makes a great change.The Spa on the 37th floor has a lovely pool and hot baths / steam room. The gym looked well equipped (but not my thing). There are plenty of options for dinner within the hotel you have the Andaz tavern and Bar with live music. On the ground floor there is BeBu restaurant for a light meal or the pastry shop. Failing that there are a number of restaurants within the office building itself as well as coffee shops and endless options within a short walk from the hotel. I highly recommend the bar on the 52nd floor for a drink, the mood is relaxed and the views are amazing with an outdoor and indoor seating area.I will definitely stay at the Andaz next time I am in Tokyo a very impressive hotel.

Hotel is located in 51st floor, and shared the best Tokyo views from different angles including Tokyo Towers, Tokyo skytree and Fuji Mountain. I just felt to come back home once you arrived at lobby. I have been greeted by a friendly receptionist, and served at lounge with selective drinks. Everything was perfect to end up my second trip in Japan.

This place gets so many great reviews so not sure how much more I can add. This is a special hotel and one of my favorite places to stay in Tokyo. The views are spectacular and I recommend you ask for a room with a Tokyo Tower view. The lit up tower at night makes for a beautiful backdrop for the room. The circular bath tub is awesome!! It my favorite feature in the rooms. In the late afternoon they have free wine in the lobby. Which a good place to relax and hang out until dinner. There is a awesome shabu shabu place 5 minutes away called Chiriri which was the best meal I had in Japan last time I was there.
user_name:
JuNesko
New York City, New York

review_body: Having stayed in a number of 5-star hotels in Tokyo, I would say overall Andaz is excellent and it would be my first choice on my next trip to Tokyo! The rooms are well appointed and the complimentary Nikka whisky and soft drinks and chocolates are a welcome!

The service in this hotel is the best I have ever experienced. The staff is so polite, welcoming, helpful, and accommodating. The rooms are phenomenal, I could live there. It is spacious and has a wonderful view and work space. Highly recommend staying here.
user_name:
Jillian D
Los Angeles, United States

review_body: We stay for 4 nights in the ANDAZ HotelCheck in was a little bit difficult because our room was not ready. We decided to have lunch in the Tavern while waiting. The view from the Restaurant is amazing. Service and Food are ok.Our room was with the view to the Tokyo Tower at the 49th floor. Just one Point was a Little bit strange for us: carpet in an 5 star Hotel!Gym and swimming pool just great.

Good location, amazing features, great view and awesome bar (top floor with view on Tokyo)Was , as usual very pleased with my andaz experience. Pool is very enjoyable.As an added service my shoes were shined every evening. :)The sushi restaurant on top floor with its master sushi chef was really impressive

Andaz Tokyo is undoubtedly service par excellence. Impeccable service by the staff. Fantastic views of Tokyo. The rooms are handsome, zen-like and modern. In-room amenities are great. Our kids loved the snacks and drinks in-room without extra charge. Rooftop Bar had a stunning view of Tokyo. The cafés within Toranomon Hills served the best coffee. The hotel was just a little out of the way, and there isn't much shopping to do around the vicinity. But we didn't mind that.

What a wonderful hotel - excellent staff and service as well as excellent food (I am a coeliac and the staff went above and beyond to ensure I ate correctly). Magnificent views of Tokyo. Accommodation was spacious and tastefully decorated with a subtle hint of Japanese style. Cannot wait to return in June for another stay. This has changed our minds as far as hotel brands go - Hyatt you are on a winner here! We need an Andaz in Australia!

My husband and I stayed at the Andaz on a recent stay and I cannot say enough great things about the hotel. The location was within walking distance of several of the places we had planned to see, but the room and spa were what really made the experience. The room was outfitted with beautiful yukatas in place of bathrobes and any ammenities that we had neglected to bring were readily provided by the hotel. Our room had phenomenal views of the city which we loved watching as the sun went down and all the city's lights came on. The spa was a little piece of heaven. The pool had the same view of the city as our room did, but also had a carbonated pool and a floating jet pool. The locker rooms had fresh citrus water and healthy snacks with luxurious massage chairs that I could have stayed in all day. All the amenities you would require to get ready were furnished in the locker room including a face lotion that left my face feeling so soft, I tried to find where I could buy it. My husband and I are already trying to find a time to go back.

This hotel is super reachable by metro from Haneda airport. The hotel was clean, modern and well designed. The staff were super friendly and helpful from the second I got there to the moment left. The location is also great, especially compared to the Park Hyatt, which is farther from the metro station.

I have the privilege of staying at the Andaz Tokyo for a couple of nights on a stopover from Manila. This is a world class hotel; I'd recommend it to anyone.WHY YOU'D LIKE THE ANDAZ TOKYO1. Fantastic rooms. Aesthetically beautiful and interesting. Comfortable beds. Spacious bathroom. Nice views of Tokyo Tower if you are lucky. Rooms are practically soundproof.2. Impeccable service. Staff is super friendly and warm. I forgot my iPhone on the bus from Narita - no problem. The front desk called Tokyo Limousine bus, they found the phone, I received a note letting me know when to expect it from the bell desk. I only remember the name of one staff member - Sakai-san from the morning - but everyone had the same level of warmth and positive energy.3. Food and beverage is amazing. I was able to have breakfast included due to my Diamond status. Everything was delicious, especially the pastries and the Japanese items. I had already eaten breakfast at Tsukiji market but I ate anyway. There's lots of elbow room in the restaurant, which is really nice in Tokyo.4. Adjacent restaurants in Toranomon Hills complex. These restaurants are extremely high quality and are used to dealing with foreigners. As a result, the restaurants are more accessible than most in Tokyo for non-Japanese speakers.5. Gym. Really luxurious. I had not seen such modern treadmills in my life (and I have been to many hotel gyms). The pool looked really nice too but I did not use it.6. Goodies in room. There were four bottles of water for me, some rice crackers and a few other snacks, a couple of cans of Coke and juice. All of this is included in the rate.7. Internet is amazingly fast. Fastest I have ever experienced in any hotel.WHY YOU MIGHT NOT LIKE THE ANDAZ TOKYOI preface this by saying these are not deal-breakers or complaints. I always try to point these out because these points may concern people.A. Location for limousine bus to Narita is not great. (I assume it's good if you are arriving from Narita). You need to add another 30 minutes driving around to other hotels prior to heading to the airport. I recommend getting on the bus at Royal Park Shiodome instead (take a cab there). If you are going to the hotel from Narita a backup option is the bus to Tokyo Station (get out on the Marunouchi side and take a cab).B. Subways are pretty far away. It's a good 10 minute walk to any of the subway stations.C. Not much shopping in the immediate area.D. Suites are expensive and not available for upgrade. If you are traveling with two kids you will need two rooms.If you don't mind the above points, by all means stay here!!! It's a good deal, especially if you are using Gold Passport points.
user_name:
gocats89
New York City, New York

review_body: Very well appointed, very new and tasteful fit-out of rooms and bar/restaurant/spa areas. Outstanding service and facilities. Not for the budget traveller, but a great premium experience. Great location for business travellers in the heart of the business district, easy walk to trains/metro.

My husband and I spent four nights at this Andaz with another couple of friends and had a wonderful time. We're big fans of the Andaz hotels across the world -- this Andaz is on par with all the other ones in the chain -- stylish, comfortable, luxurious.We had a fabulous room with a view of the Tokyo Tower. The room was sized well for Tokyo standards and the shower/tub combo was fantastic. And while it is the norm all over Japan to have the automated toilets, the one at the Andaz was notch higher than a lot of other hotel toilets I've seen. As a Hyatt Diamond, I was able to take advantage of the breakfast every morning. Breakfast was superb -- probably my favorite breakfast buffet to date at a hotel. The selection not incredibly extensive, but the offerings were all top quality, carefully prepared, and delicious. Service across the board -- from the front desk, pool area, housekeeping to the restaurants and bars is friendly, warm, and professional. The pool and spa area was gorgeous and had plenty of little touches that made it a wonderful oasis to relax and destress at any time of day. I would stay at the Andaz Tokyo in a heartbeat the next time I'm in town. I know there was a debate that said this hotel was a little out of the way versus a few other more centrally located hotels, but I preferred that the Andaz was in a more quiet part of Tokyo. That being said, any part of the city is a quick cab or subway ride away.

I stayed at the Andaz for 2 nights for a conference. When you arrive on the airport limousine, you are immediately greeted by attentive doormen who escort you to the hotel's stylized private entrance and instruct you that check-in is located on the 51st floor. Check-in was informal, efficient and managed by well-trained and welcoming staff. Admittedly, the layout of the floor requires some effort to orient (e.g., the elevators for the rooms are separate from those that transported you from the hotel's entrance). There are also a number of small sitting areas that are cordoned off by large decorative cabinets that makes visualizing the lay of the floor plan a little challenging. But once you are oriented, you appreciate that the hotel is beautifully and thoughtfully decorated. The corridors to the room are decorated with Japanese motifs. The room, like the rest of the hotel, is also exquisitely decorated and the floor plan is unique and functional - it feels very much like a home than a hotel. Finding and discovering the variety of drawers, cupboards and safe was an adventure - as they are built into the decor - I love it. Amenities were great - there was a rain shower in the bathroom that provided ample water pressure as well as a large soaking bath and the toilet had the expected array of controls that one could partake as needed. Lighting and curtain control was accessible and easy to operate - the view from the window was impressive (because of the height). Wifi was fast and free. The gym had a very nice locker room and was well equipped with a variety of equipment - it also offered a sauna and whirlpool. Breakfast (buffet) at the Andaz Tavern was very good - although it was slightly expensive. Staff throughout was excellent - they were high attentive, polite, helpful, friendly and professional. I thought this was a super establishment - and would return if the opportunity presents.

The design of the hotel is world-class. The décor is JUST RIGHT and has a very homely and relaxed feeling. You don't feel like you are in a hotel environment. The service is excellent! Location is very central. Highly recommended.

Stayed for 2 nights here. In my opinion, this hotel is in a much better location than the Park Hyatt (basically more central). The service is impeccable, the pool and spa are wonderful and very similar in grandeur to the Ritz-Carlton in Hong Kong. The room is well furnished in a trendy style with expansive views of Tokyo and a generous bathroom. The small, intimate sushi bar at the top of the building is a nice touch, as is the free cocktail hour in the lobby area.

Had a morning flight in and took the limousine bus to Andaz. Arrived just after nine and was provided a regular room first until the large king became available later in the day.I am not huge fan of hotels that make you switch elevators at the highest floor that is the lobby just to go few floors down. This is waste of time and becomes annoying after a while.Didn't check the complimentary evening wine hours or the breakfast in the morning.The room were done in a tasteful manner and plenty of wood being used.Whether the location works or doesn't, depends where you need to be in Tokyo.

The Andaz is a great hotel situated high above Tokyo, we had a room with a magnificent view. It is a funky hotel compared to some of the other very good hotels in Tokyo with a popular rooftop bar that is great, good cocktails and extensive choice of drinks. The pool, spa and gym are very good. The front desk and concierge service could be a bit better, check-in was a bit chaotic and we received very general recommendations when we asked for a restaurant, but we probably were a bit spoiled by the incredibly outstanding service at the Ritz-Carlton the week before. The room was nice, bath was great and a nice touch: the Bose wireless speaker performed like a high end system. All in all a great stay.

As a Hyatt Diamond member, we stayed at the Andaz Tokyo for 5 nights during X-Mas break per the recommendations of the people on Flyer Talk and frankly I wished we picked another hotel. There were several things that bothered me and my wife, chief among them is we felt preferential treatment was given to white guests. I don’t want to get into racism claims, but white guests received more proactive attention and better service than I did as a Hyatt Diamond. It was evident to me, and I’ve voiced my opinion on Flyertalk that there was obvious differences between how Asian (Chinese in particular) guests are treated versus white guests. Had it happened once or twice I may have overlooked it, as it could been my own personal sensitivity BUT sadly this was not the case as it happened repeatedly throughout my stay. I plan on drafting a letter to Hyatt to address my concerns in hope Hyatt will investigate. I also urge Hyatt to contact me directly so I can address my specific concerns about this property.I also want to point out another unsatisfying FACT about this hotel. The room we stayed at had a condensation (or was it a water leak?) problem that would cause a puddle of water to collect near the windows. This problem never went away during our stay and while apologies were offered and housekeeping wiped and cleaned, there was never an offer to move us to a room that did not have this "condensation problem." Whether this is related to what I said earlier cannot be proven but for me this is not something any guest should have to deal with.

We chose this hotel because we loved the Andaz approach to service - funky, laid back but still adopting all the principles of a five-star hotel. If you ask me, this is harder to achieve than the common subservient, rigid, almost robotic service you get at many Asian hotels.On arrival, we checked in to the lounge and were offered a soft drink before we headed to our room. The lounge is a lobby in disguise, with a more relaxed feel and long benches where guests are encouraged to stop for a drink on their comings/goings from the hotel, with alcoholic drinks and snacks from 6pm-8pm nightly an added incentive. If you need more privacy or cocktails, simply head to the main bar (but you must pay, of course).Our room was the entry-level king, but it still had all the features and great views of northern Tokyo, just not Tokyo Tower. Not sure that's worth the extra cost but would be a nice upgrade treat, for example. The TT views are available to all guests from the bar and the pool, which is among the best I have used at hotels of this class/style around the world. And best of all, guests don't have to pay to use it, which sadly is the case at many Japanese hotels.The fact rooms are on the floors below the lobby takes a little getting used to at first .. rooms are on levels 47-50 and all have a large entrance hall, massive bathroom, separate toilet, shower room and a large walk--in wardrobe.All the amenities, especially the towels, were top class. I want to buy those towels!Nothing was too much trouble for housekeeping - they shined my shoes and delivered them back to the room. They also serviced the rooms extensively twice a day - much more effort than I have seen in other hotels.Yes, it's expensive, yes, it's not in the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku/Ginza .. but is that what you want when all that can be a walk or subway ride away? We loved the quietness of the district at night and in the mornings, having Toranomon Koffee just downstairs was the perfect way to get moving each morning.We made extensive use of the pool and change facilities which were all excellent.We did not eat at the hotel so cannot comment.We are already planning a return trip to Japan next year and will definitely consider staying here again - the only reason we wouldn't is to experience a different location, nothing to do with the hotel itself. we loved it.

I've stayed here a couple of times...Love it. Rooms are beautifully appointed. Staff are great. Food is great. Design is magnificent.Only downer for me is the Gent's changing rooms and the spa - no steam room and all feels a little 'squashed'. Gym also could do with better lighting as it's got fancy spot lights. apart from that, it's cool

Stay here for one night in mid December 2015. I should preface/ qualify this review with the fact that I had stayed at the Park Hyatt the week before and was therefore quite spoilt by the time I got to the Andaz. It is also clearly a business hotel while my review is written from a leisure traveler's perspective.Service: The level of service is I suppose normal for a 4-5 star business hotel. As mentioned, perhaps I was spoiled by the Park Hyatt but I was surprised that there was no one to accompany us up to the lobby and we had to find the check in area ourselves. Since the design was very modern, it wasn't immediately obvious to us (after a 10 hour flight) as to where the check in desk was. The restaurant recommendations from the "Andaz Host" (they do not have a concierge department) were also disappointing. Room: The rooms were smaller than the Park Hyatt but still spacious for Japan. They were chic and I liked that they had a long desk facing the window. However, the room design was problematic. Not disastrously so, but enough to be annoying (especially given their pretty expensive room rate):-1. The bathroom is connected to the wardrobe/ luggage area. There is no door between the two. After even a quick shower, the wardrobe area became a bit humid from the steam. This was ok for one night but probably not ideal for a longer stay.2. The problem with not having a door between the bathroom and the wardrobe is that if you were staying with a friend you can't access the wardrobe/ luggage area while the other person is using the bathroom. Therefore we had to put our suitcases in the entrance corridor of the room (it was the only area in the room where one could fit big suitcases). Which led to the problem in para. 3 below.3. The door to the wardrobe area and the bathroom were along they same entrance corridor. These doors open into the entrance corridor. When opened, they take up 70%-80% of the width of the corridor. This means that in order to access our suitcases (see para 2 above), we cannot have the bathroom/ wardrobe door open at the same time. It also means that one needs to be careful when coming out of the bathroom/ wardrobe. This gets very annoying when there are two people packing in the room the night before/ morning of the day of departure. 4. For ladies, the vanity kit/ mirror is on a strangely high shelf in the bathroom. The design of the bathroom is such that the mirror at the sink is a bit too far away for doing makeup (you have to stand and lean quite a bit over the sink to see properly and the lighting in any event not conducive to doing makeup) so one has to use the vanity mirror. However, I am 5'3'' (normal for Asia) but was only at the right height for the mirror in 3.5 inch platform heels. The mirror is moveable but the only place that you can conceivably move it to is the long table next to the bed/ in front of the windows (no space in the bathroom). Again, not disastrous, but quite annoying. Pool: The pool was surprisingly small but given that this is a business hotel I suppose it is normal. The facilities were new, though, and the changing room was relatively big with steam, sauna and ofuro facilities. Accessibility: Toranomon underground station was 3-5 minutes' walk away. It is on the Ginza line and so very convenient. The hotel is also near various business districts so probably convenient for business travelers.Overall, I do not think the hotel's room rates are justified (it was more expensive than the Park Hyatt). As a leisure traveler, I would stay elsewhere. However, this hotel is probably quite good for lone business travelers.

11 days of pure bliss in this excellent hotel over the Christmas/New Year period. Modern and cool hotel ambiance - very classy but warm feeling with small touches of personal attention. Best room design with a stupendous views over Tokyo from the 47th floor. Excellent staff, very friendly and more than helpful. Excellent public spaces and restaurants.very centrally situated between Ginza and Roppongi.

Very very over -imaging and luxurious decoration in the hotel room. The view of room is really incredible and can see the Tokyo tower. The survice is really nice and make us feel be welcome. Good position Very suggested to visit.

I could not recommend Andaz with any higher regard – the stay was perfect from start to finish (so much so that we cancelled our other plans for travel within the region). The staff, rooms, food and amenities are all incredible.

From the minute we arrived to the minute we left this hotel is faultless.Excellent service, very friendly staff, extremely clean rooms, beautiful view of Tokyo from any side of hotel, free snacks and non-alcoholic drink (between 18:00 and 20:00 alcoholic drinks free too).We couldn't recommend it enough.

We stayed here for 8 nights over Christmas and we felt at home right away. This was a hotel and a room we that I would love to call home. Except for the fact that we wouldn't be able to afford living like this for more than a few weeks though.. The design and lay-out of our Tony Chi-designed room was super and so was the killer view from the 49th floor. The walls are designed to look like shoji screens which is really cool and the large oval bathtub which is designed so that you could sit and read in it (if you feel like it). Small smart cool details everywhere. Beats the rooms at Park Hyatt Tokyo. Free Wifi, free soft drinks in the mini-bar and firm beds are 3 extra points as well.Service is good and they are not all over you all the time which I think is good: Friendly and efficient. We never used concierge services so I don't know if they deliver or not. We've been to Tokyo a number of times and manage our own stuff.Location - there are some comments here and there about the location of the hotel - that it is far away from tourist sights. For me Tokyo is not about tourist sights so I'm not sure that I understand those comments. If you want sights - go to Kyoto or Beijing. Tokyo is about state of mind, hole-in-the-wall places in hidden back streets that you find in any part of the city and so on. Yes, Toranomon is a bit of an office-area and not on the great Yamanote-line, but it took us 15 minutes to walk to the Imperial Palace, a few minutes to Toranomon subway station that serve Ginza, Aoyama, Shibuya and Asakusa. For me location was no problem.Any minuses? The variety at the breakfast buffet was too limited but otherwise I can't think of anything right now

This is an amazing hotel, great views of Tokyo. Rooms are very spacious with modern interiors. Fitness center and pool are also beautifully designed with amazing views. Haneda airport is 30 minutes by taxi and there is a subway station 5 minutes walk from the hotel.

The rooms have beautiful design and tranquil views over Tokyo. Location is a bit out of the way for the International Leisure Tourist,. Major flaw is that the hotel restaurant connected with the hotel lobby is periodically packed with non hotel guests , which makes the lobby experience quite hectic and the opposite experience of the tranquility of the rooms, and the serene hotel pool.

The Andaz Tokyo has an excellent location: just 5 ~ 10 mins' walk from Toranomon Station of the Ginza Metro line: this means that you can get to almost everywhere from Ginza to Omote-sando to Asakusa within 40 mins from Andaz, which is nice for such a huge city like Tokyo. Try to get a Tokyo Tower view room, as the view from the room is incredible. The breakfast buffet is solid: I think the quality of the buffet food is comparable to some set menus for breakfast in other top luxury hotels in Tokyo, which is really impressive. Overall this is really an great experience, and I can't wait to return to Andaz Tokyo for my next adventure in the city.

One of the best experiences we've ever had. Staff are very friendly. Miki at the Andaz Tavern was very friendly and accommodating. She remembered us from the last time we dined (which was in May 2015). Food was fantastic most especially the clay pot chicken.. We had a great view of the city and Tokyo Tower. Housekeeping staff were very accommodating and provided us with what we needed. Thank you for making our holiday and anniversary a wonderful experience.

Our first experience of an Andaz hotel. One of us had an extended stay of a couple of weeks and it was all good. Both the room and bathroom are very well appointed and laid out. So important for a longer stay. We especially liked cushioned bench next to the window that ran across the length of the room - it allowed you to enjoy the great views of Tokyo. And we liked the generous and practical desks too. Good in house toiletries and walk in wardrobe.The lobby area is very buzzy though a little compact in size. In the evenings, you can enjoy complementary cocktails in the cosy area next to the lobby. A nicer spot is the Tavern bar area with its expansive views of Tokyo - it has larger tables for a big group and private little spaces next to the fireplace for a more intimate experience. The gym, pool and spa are fantastic places to unwind after a long day or flight.The only downside to picking this hotel is the location - it's great if you have meetings in the vicinity or even better, within the Toranomon Hills complex. Not so great if you are a tourist looking to shop though it's no great hardship to take a 7-10 minute walk to the nearest metro station and from there it's a very short ride to Ginza. Within the Toranomon Hills complex we have to recommend the coffee at Toranomon Koffee. Seriously the best coffee we've had anywhere.

Great views over Tokyo bay in a well appointed room. Concierge was extremely helpful with requests. And the breakfast was sumptuous though the variety of dishes can be improved especially if you're staying for more than a week. All in all, a great hotel in a quieter area of town but still accessible with the subway nearby and a 15 minute walk to ginza

Stay one night in Andaz Hotel Tokyo when I attending a Expo/Seminar in Tokyo.It was a very nice experience:1. The reception is very professional and did not take too much time (if you are a member of GoldPass, they can just get your data from system)2. The room is big compare to other business hotels in Japan and I am lucky to have good night view in the room3. The bath room design is also nice, the only drawback is that I can not see the night view when taking bath (ever had such experience in St. Regis Osaka)4. The hotel offer free minibar - everything in the minibar you ca eat and drink except alcohol drinks5. Special thanks to the Concierge - My friends ordered something via Amazon JP and the hotel helped me to keep it until my check-in.6, Breakfast is typical buffet style7. Free WiFi in Lobby and guest roomsOverall is a very nice experience

It was amazing time! Great dinner at "the SUSHI", nice swimming pool & gym. Room is so nice. In lounge, free drink & snack. Nice viewing with Tokyo tower, buildings, Mt.Fuji. Shops in toranomon hills were so nice.

I was extremely impressed with the size of my room, the quality of the furnishings, the room features and the housekeeping staff. The room, while not inexpensive by Tokyo standards, was much larger than I had expected in such a large city and the entire staff was polite and attentive. Very stealth housekeeping staff....I never saw them anywhere in the hotel but I could tell they had attended to my room while I was out (even straightening some personal items I had left in a slight mess). Both the walk-in shower and the walk-in closet area are spacious. I was surprised to find only one drawer in the closet area; however, there are a few shelves for folded clothing. The entire room is well-lit with ample sitting and work areas. The complimentary (non-alcoholic items only) mini-bar was well-stocked and consumed items were replenished daily. The main lobby is on the 51st floor of the building (no view from the main lobby area) but the views of Tokyo from the rooms (floors 47-50) are fantastic. The hotel is located several blocks from the Shimbashi train station (served by multiple lines) but the walk is quite pleasant and only takes 15-20 minutes. The Toranoman train station is closer but only 1 line stops there so a transfer might be necessary. I would recommend the hotel for business travelers and perhaps couples but I'm not sure it is suitable for families with children (I don't recall seeing any children during my stay).

Andaz Tokyo is the place to go if you are looking for a stylish hotel with gorgeous views and a quiet location. The rooms are quite spacious for Japan with unobstructed views over Tokyo. The hotel is making extensive use of beautiful materials, wood and leather in particular, to create comfortable and luxurious atmosphere. Great buffet breakfast and restaurant with the same gorgeous views. Not the perfect location for tourists but quite good nonetheless. Irreproachable service. Highly recommended.

What more you can ask for in life when you step into a room welcomed by a remarkable Tokyo Tower right in front of you? or you fell asleep with a breath-taking panoramic Tokyo city view with blinking red lights? or wake up by fresh beams of sunlight to brighten up your day? Heartfelt thanks to Andaz team for this priceless experience, my husband and I have a great memory for our first anniversary in Tokyo. Thanks Andaz Tokyo, see you next time :)
user_name:
Joyce M
Hong Kong, Hong Kong

review_body: Amazing views from the rooms. Its a place where VIPs like to stay. There are many unique touches with modern Japanese art work. The lobby is quite interesting - instead of a lounge, there is a large open common area on rustic wooden tables where there is a happy hour with free flow wine and some snacks - the wine is not that good however. Great place to meet people in an informal setting.

Andaz is Hyatt’s entry into the boutique hotel brand wars. The Tokyo edition sits on the 47-52d floors of a skyscraper in Toranomom. The views are spectacular, although if you are in town for a lengthy stay, the vertical commute tires and I wouldn’t want to be in this hotel in an earthquake. The Good: the rooms are small but well laid out with lots of wood and stone; a zen take on a cruise ship, with more spacious bathroom designs than most Hyatts in Asia and the most functional lighting switches I’ve seen in a hotel room—a series of heavy metal toggles with no reostats and no sconces or nightlights that can’t be tunred off from bedside. The beds are good and given the height above street level, the rooms are totally quiet. F&B is OK—the sole restaurant--all day dining -- has spectacular views. The downside is that the edgy architectural vibe has been allowed to trump practicality in a number of cases—the room numbers are set just above floor level so the weary traveler looking for their room may take some time to find it and the layout of the lobby — more wood panels and low lighting-- is mazelike. If Bill Murray and Scarlett Johansson do a ‘Lost in Translation Two,” this would be a good location for it. It's also a good place to have lunch or a drink and take in the views. If however, you are a business traveler to Tokyo, (sans ScarJo…) you may find it not as well suited for your needs.

Very nice hotel. Conveniently located, albeit many comments about it being far away from the hustle and bustle. It's a 5-10 min walk to the Toranomon subway, which is a few stops away from Ginza and a few more from Omotesando. The airport limousine (buy tix at the aiport, available at both narita and haneda; for return trip, can buy tix at Andaz front desk) also stops right outside the hotel entrance, which is extremely convenient. Stayed at a standard room on the 49th floor. View was spectacular even though we weren't facing the Tokyo Tower (had frds who did). I would recommend people to spend a little extra to stay at the tower view rooms (can see both the Tokyo tower and also the Mt Fuji afar). Had dinner at the Tavern on the 51st floor. Ordered the seasonal set menu (seafood mostly, scallops, crab, lobster, fish, etc). Nice ambience. Staff were attentive yet not instrusive. There's room for improvement on food quality though. Food's ok, but can be better compared to the superb quality of the room and service overall. The crab and lobster didn't have the freshness odour and taste which they should supposedly have. Fish was overcooked. Staff recommended a Japanese white wine (Toriivilla 2012), which was interesting since it's not commonly available in other restaurants or outside Japan. Sweeter than the chardonnay, but still a good pair with seafood in general. Ordered a birthday cake last minute after closing of pastry shop. Really appreciated the staff for their help and effort in delivering the cake and making the celebration of my partner's birthday a memorable moment. Overall very good experience staying at the Andaz.
user_name:
Jensen T
Hong Kong, Hong Kong

review_body: Not many hotels have given me that WOW factor but I must say, the Andaz Tokyo certainly did! The moment I walked up to the hotel and gazed up at the 52 floor hotel, I had to rub my eyes to make sure I wasn't dreaming. The hotel looks absolutely stunning from the outside in the day or night and I could only marvel at what a beautiful building it was. It was an experience in itself checking into the hotel, with the reception lobby located on the 51st floor! Once you're in the elevator, there are only buttons for the first floor and 51st floor! There isn't a conventional reception desk but more of a casual lounge where you are greeted by the warm, friendly staff who explain everything you need to know about the hotel and offer you a welcome drink. I was also signed up to the Hyatt Gold Passport as an added incentive. I stayed here for two nights in the Andaz King room on the 50th floor. Upon exiting the lift, walking the long winding corridors to my room I felt a sense of excitement. The moment I opened the door to my room, I was amazed and in absolute awe of the hotel and the room. The room was ridiculous (in a good way)! The size of the room was huge! Walking in and seeing an enormous king sized bed, with 4 soft lovely pillows was exactly what I needed on my last 2 nights in Japan! There was a couch that extended the length of the room and the view from the 50th floor truly felt like you were on top of the world! There was a large 42 inch TV, nespresso coffee machine, complimentary water and soft drinks/juices in the minibar and other drinks such as green tea. You were also provided with a tea pot and two tea cups.They had the large shower head in the shower and there was also a deep soaking bathtub. Bath salts were provided. There was also a walk in wardrobe area, where an ironing board and iron were provided. I also believe there was a complimentary shoe shine service which I didn't utilise.The hotel also provides a gym and indoor pool and these are world class! The view you have from the 37th floor would make anyone want to exercise or go for a swim! The health club was also on level 37 but I ran out of time to experience this but I'm sure it would have been amazing too! On my last night, I dined at the Andaz Tavern and it was fantastic, nothing short of what I expected. I checked out the rooftop bar but didn't stay long enough for a drink but the view is to die for! Also, you have an amazing view of the Tokyo Tower at night when it is lit up, it truly is a beautiful sight.I needed to checkout early on Saturday morning to catch a flight and the hotel staff were very accomodating to my request and made my checkout seamless and got me a coffee for my travels.Overall, this hotel is a must for anyone wanting to experience a world class hotel. I honestly can't speak more highly of this place and if I ever get the chance to come back, would stay here in a heartbeat. I thought I would feel out of place, being a solo traveller and not exactly being the trendiest guest but the hotel staff were all so lovely and made me feel welcome, I didn't feel out of place. Andaz Tokyo, thank you for the giving me the WOW factor and capping off my Japan trip in true style!

My first stay and the Andaz Tokyo was memorable because of the excellent rooms, staff and facilities. I have stayed at numerous 5 star hotels in Tokyo and throughout Asia and must say that this hotel is one of the best. It was modern, professional, friendly, clean, vibrant yet tranquil, the rooms perfectly furnished and quiet. I truly look forward to my next stay at the Andaz Tokyo.

Simply the best hotel that my wife and I have ever stayed. Premium spa facilities, outstanding customer service, panoramic views, gorgeous design. Extra thanks to the wonderful staff who answered many questions before our stay in truly made our Tokyo experience one to remember.

I love their bar, their restaurant and their breakfast. Everything is fantastic. They have nice fancy decoration. The tube is big. Stuffs r always kind and helpful. When I arrived there before my bf for a few hours. they took me to have a seat with free tea at the restaurant room.

The Andaz chain did not fail to impress in Tokyo. Stylish and trendy, yet comfortable and accessible. Four night stay in October. The restaurants offer a solid yet interesting menu with lots of options. The room was comfortable and well appointed; again, trendy, but it had everything you needed. The bathroom and adjacent closet were well designed and functional for two people in a room. (My one observation about hotels in Tokyo... the beds are always much too firm for my taste, no matter what hotel/chain I stay at.)The hotel offered a casual "happy hour" for guests with wine and a few nibbles; that was a nice way to unwind after a long day of walking around Tokyo.Overall, a great hotel. It was worth the value.

Enjoyed delicious cocktails and spectacular city views at the Andaz. We watched planes landing at Haneda in the distance, two ferris wheels and the lights changing on Rainbow Bridge. Less formal than the famous bar at the Park Hyatt, the bar is quasi-open air and comes complete with throw rugs to take the chill off if needed. We all enjoyed hand crafted cocktails which were beautifully presented.

Maybe the best get away place from life in the fast lane that Tokyo can offer! A view from the hotel (room and pool) is very special. Sky Tree and all! Especially, in night. You can bring your special person and spend time with them the in lounge 24 hours. Yes, some drinks are complimentary to the hotel guest so.

The room was a little more spacious than most other hotels i have stayed in while in Tokyo, with amazing views of the city as the rooms start around the 50th floor. Excellent service as is to be expected in Tokyo, really friendly staff, and the design of the rooms was just so comfortable and stunning, very close to the underground if you are getting trains around and lots of restaurants within the building, in a mall type part of the building.

This is a beautiful facility and the service was outstanding. Consider this a botique hotel experience delivered by Hyatt - the best of both worlds. I will make it my preferred location on return trips to Tokyo.
user_name:
Michael T
Red Bank, United States

review_body: As a frequent traveller (business and leisure), I would say that I have stayed at a fair number of hotels across the globe. The Andaz Toranomon Hills is one of those unique properties that sticks with you, even well after you have departed and returned home.The hotel is located on the top floors of the current tallest building in Tokyo (SkyTree and Tokyo Tower are not buildings officially) which affords all rooms excellent views of the city. I would argue that these are the best views of Tokyo as you can see Tokyo Tower, Skinjuku, Ginza, the Imperial Palace, Tokyo Bay, the Rainbow Bridge and even Tokyo SkyTree in the distance! Waking up to stunning views and returning to the city all lit up at night is nothing short of breathtaking.This particular trip was a treat for a big milestone birthday for my Mother. The hotel treated her like a special valued guest including a special cake-treat on arrival to the room and a lovely set of flowers. On arrival to reception, she was greeted with a very warm Happy Birthday and well wishes. I requested a room with a view of Tokyo Tower and was provided with one which was lovely as I appreciate that there are not many twin rooms with a view of the tower and the hotel was at full occupancy. The staff also made sure that we did not have to wait too long on check-in as we arrived early. We arrived at the hotel at 1000 with the room available by 1100 (3pm standard check-in).The hotel itself has a very contemporary and boutique-style feel and is well suited for both business and leisure travellers. It is accessible by a myriad of subway stations within 5-10 minutes walking distance and is also only a 15 minute walk from Shimbashi station which is also very handy.The facilities are second to none with a state-of-the-art gym affording excellent views of Chiyoda (with SkyTree in the distance) all the way to Shinjuku. The Pool is absolutely gorgeous and is big enough to do laps and has floor-to-ceiling views of Chiyoda (with SkyTree in the distance) and the Imperial Palace area. The changing room facilities (I can only comment on the male facilities) has a lovely hot onsen, large sauna, showers, massage chairs, newspapers/magazines and some healthy snacks (e.g. nuts, fruits and cereal bars). The hotel has a part-open rooftop bar and a lovely lounge bar/restaurant in the lobby on the 57th floor. I can't rate this hotel high enough and will certainly be returning to this hotel on a future visit to Tokyo.

Ever smiling people devoted to make you happy. In a very beautifully designed architecture. Pure luxury by all means. The place to be.Extraordinary pool and spa. Refinement of the rooms. What to ask when you have all this?

Excellent hotel experience in Tokyo. The building itself is magnificent, the hotel is brand new and is neatly decorated (with wood dominance). The room is spacious for Tokyo standards, quality linen and bath towels are provided, and the bed was highly comfortable. I was upgraded to a special view room and the view was astonishing, just in front of Tokyo Tower ! The staff is very nice and the facilities are top of the class (pool and fitness). Only (limited) drawbacks : Overpriced Breakfast (4500 jpy) No quick access to metro station (closest are Shimbashi and Toranomon, both are 10-15 mn by foot) It is of equivalent quality to the Grand Hyatt Tokyo.

Andaz Tokyo was much nicer than I expected. It has the typical high level of service seen throughout Japan. I checked in late and as I walked into my hotel room, I remembered how great the Tokyo night view is. Even tho my room was a basic rectangle, the layout of the closet openings and furnishings didn't make it feel like a typical hotel room. The control panels for the room are physical switches, not buttons--finally light controls that don't have buttons that distract and glow all night (except the privacy switch). There is one sink in the bathroom vanity. The room wasn't as soundproof as I would have expected. The person above me was tromping around a bit and I could hear voices from next door.I originally was a little weary of the location but was happy to explore a new setting. It's in kind of a "middle of no where" quiet area with a lot of restaurant alleys. Amazingly, somehow it is not connected underground to a subway station and underground shopping (like many other hotels). All the subways are a bit of a walk away but once you get your bearings down it's easier to know which way to exit the hotel. Pedestrians are banned from the hotel car/taxi circle so you have to go all the around or up to enter the hotel from certain directions.There is a 20m pool and 3 different co-ed baths, plus a hot bath in each locker room. The gym is standard hotel gym that also has a rower. It seems the gym/spa has a membership base but it was never that crowded in the pool.The hotel always seemed very busy. At check-in, you hang out in this small area that is packed with people doing who knows what (why aren't they hanging out in their hotel room?). The public areas aren't that wide open so it always feels like there's people everywhere. The hotel complex has a few floors of restaurants/business downstairs, and I was pleased to come across a small no-frills massage place Sula on the 3rd floor that offers head and face massage (things hard to find in NY and not done that well). It's not a fancy place but it's clean and the masseuses are great.

This hotel is amazing and is the complete package: great service, amazing rooms, awesome amenities, and fantastic view. The only possible issue someone might have with this hotel is that the location isn't close to shopping or touristy stuff. The hotel is located in a commercial district. The hotel is in an office complex that can be confusing to navigate if you approach the hotel on foot. Train access is about a 5-10 minute walk and I don't recommend it if you have a lot of luggage. The lobby is on the 50 (51?) floor and has an amazing layout with high ceilings and dark wood paneling. The checkout area is a huge seating area where the Andaz staff invite you to sit while they finalize the check in paperwork. They offer free non-alcoholic drinks and snacks while you wait for the check in to finish. The staff all spoke very good English and were friendly and inviting. They showed us to our room which had a beautiful layout with an fantastic view of Tokyo with peakaboo views of Tokyo Tower. Simply beautiful. The room was super clean and had amazing looking furniture. No expense was spared in this hotel room from automatic window shades to a wood paneled dressing vestibule. To put it simply, I wouldn't mind living full time in a room like this. The hotel restaurants all were great though pricey. The hotel also had an indoor swimming pool with great views, a well stocked gym, and a spa treatment area. I didn't partake of these amenities because I was on a business trip, but my friend who traveled with me got to swim and said it was divine. The hotel also had free continental breakfast in the lobby and free wine tastings in the evening. And the food and drinks were good not just because they were free. Seriously, no detail was overlooked in this hotel.This hotel was fantastic and while pricey was definitely worth it for special occasions or just to splurge. Would highly recommend this hotel.

If you want a bit of luxury (actually quite a bit) and you're not on a tight budget then the Andaz in Tokyo is a great choice. We had a lovely 3 nights in Tokyo and everything was perfect. The high level of service and attention from the staff and the well appoint d and generously sized rooms were a delight... And the view .... oh the view - we had a view of the Imperial Palace Gardens and the Sky Tree. It was breathtaking by day and mesmerising at night... Will have to go back as soon as I can...

There is a hotel of several many in Tokyo, but ANDAZU is best. Whichever I get, interior design, a view from a window and service are wonderful. Check-in sits down on a table, and can do a drink gracefully while giving the service. The equipment is latest, but consideration feels hospitality in a luxury Japanese-style hotel. It's a word that the big window and the view from a high-rise floor are wonderful from a floor to the ceiling in a room. A clean towel and a good bathrobe with the design. The design of the slippers of slippers and the yukata is also nice. A soft drink from refrigerator and a snack from room can be enjoyed for free of charge. A guest is a glance, but much, Japanese and a person of the European and American system also recommend the one which is quiet and is the quiet atmosphere. A good impression is also popular with the one by which the staff are a smiling face and the brisk service posture. If I waver in a hotel in Tokyo, I'll recommend you ANDAZU by all means.

The hotel is great. Facilities are wonderful and the staff is very professional. But there is not a lot of things to do in the surrounding area because the hotel is in a business district. If you need to do any shopping, you will have to go to Ginza or Roppongi.

Beautifully designed hotel on the 51st floor with the stunning views to match. Impeccable service and quality of rooms. Truly a luxury stay. The only downside is it is in a business area of Tokyo so a little bit isolated - but not enough to stop me from highly recommending this wonderful hotel.

This hotel has e-v-e-r-y-t-h-i-n-g! Impeccable service, gorgeous accommodations, the friendliest staff, premium location... what more can one ask for a stay in Tokyo?? Any. last but not least, the price is very "affordable" for such a property...

What a stylish and beautiful hotel. The service was amazing, the rooms were exceptional and spacious, and we would certainly return! Check in was simple and relaxed, the breakfasts were great, and the concierge was incredibly helpful and accommodating!

We deliberated long and hard over a hotel in Tokyo as this was a special 40th bday trip for my partner and we planned to spend a week in the city.We had a fantastic time at the Andaz from start to finish. We managed to secure an early check in- 9am as our flight landed. As our cab pulled up we were greeted by name and whisked up to the 51st floor for a very efficient but relaxed check in before being taken to our room.We booked the tower view room which didn't disappoint at all- stunning views over the city. The bathroom and room were exceptional and the room and in fact the entire hotel felt light, bright and spacious.Our favourite thing about the entire hotel was breakfast. The food was stunning but even better was the service. I've stayed in many high grade hotels and breakfast service is usually of a much lower standard than dinner- not here! The breakfast team were continually striving to deliver excellence and went out of their way to ensure our every need was taken care of- one of the Managers even took the liberty of booking us a table with a stunning view across 2 of the days without us even having to ask. There was lots to choose from and lots to eat- so much so we skipped lunch most days in spite of walking up to 8 miles a day seeing the Tokyo sights! The concierge team worked really hard to help accommodate us too. I'm a vegetarian which has proved challenging across the entire trip but the Andaz team worked super hard to help and find us great locations for dinner. We spoke with many of the team and they were all equally as helpful and gave us a lot of their time to ensure we had the help we needed. Location wise for us the hotel was perfect- I couldn't have dealt with the craziness of Shibuya every day/ night on holiday. 2 tube stations sit very close to the hotel (around an 8 min walk) and easily get you everywhere you would want to go in Tokyo. Do not let the location of this hotel put you off- the tube is very easy to use and very cheap! To put this statement into context, we had dinner one night at the Park Hyatt and from what Google maps told us the closest tube station was a good 20 mins walk away which was really inconvenient (and painful as I had to walk it in heels!)I cannot recommend this hotel highly enough and just hope we get the chance to visit again.Just to finally mention, we did have a slight query with our room during our stay as we decided to stay one extra night as we loved Tokyo and the Andaz so much. We contacted Arnaud the GM directly via email and everything was efficiently sorted the same day.Thank you Arnaud and your wonderful team for a fantastic first experience in Japan. It was truly second to none and has made our trip super memorable- we have used our Andaz experience as the bench mark for the rest of our stay in Japan and nowhere has lived up to the experience you and your team provided. We hope to visit again very soon.

This was our first stay at an Andaz property, and we certainly hope it is not our last! Beautiful local touches in the Decor can be seen throughout. Walnut tables and vanities in the bathroom. Staying true to tradition, the rain shower head is located next to the bathtub so you can rinse off before soaking.Every morning you can come downstairs to complimentary fresh juice and pastries and in the evening free cocktails for a couple of hours. The room includes complimentary water, tea, snacks and even a Nespresso Single cup espresso maker. We were provided a room on the "low" 47th floor...needless to say the views are spectacular. Even though we were on the opposite side of the Tokyo Tower the view definitely did not disappoint. The rooms are decorated in very good taste and everything is controlled with switches located right next to the bed. Big rooms compared to others we have stayed at in Japan. I found myself enjoying time working just so I can stare at the view while looking up from my laptop. The service you are given, along with the attention to detail at the Andaz Tokyo is impeccable. Some do complain about the location, but if for some reason you can't enjoy the 5 minute walk to a metro station there is always a taxi waiting at the lobby. We rather enjoyed being away from the hustle and bustle at night but close enough to be there within 15-20 minutes. There are many nice little Cafes just outside the building if you prefer a quick or more local breakfast outside the hotel. If you have the opportunity or are indecisive, the Andaz will not disappoint.

The first thing one has to say is that this hotel really adheres to the Andaz concept in that it has a very homely feel. That's not easy when you are 50 floors up in a new skyscraper!The check in which is carried out in the open living area is informal and a welcome drink is offered. What I personally dislike which happened here is that without my asking I was offered an upgrade to my room for 2 different prices depending on size of room. I politely declined, and then when I queried whether my room faced Tokyo Tower, I was quoted another additional cost for such a room. Maybe it's just me, but if you are prepared to upgrade then just do it on a complimentary basis or don't offer at all! If I had wanted a higher grade of room, I would have booked such at time of booking!Anyway, we were then escorted to our room which really was beautifully appointed with stylish decor. Great view towards Tokyo Skytree (having declined to pay a surcharge for the Tokyo Tower view), extremely comfortable bed and lovely bathroom. No real negatives about the room at all.The hotel also has an indoor swimming pool with excellent adjoining jacuzzi area which was great for relaxing aching limbs after all the walking you need to do in Tokyo. Also offered were complimentary drinks and canapes for an hour in the evening in the living area. This was miserable for such a high class hotel. A bottle each of white and red wine plus sake. And just one kind of canapé plus 2 kinds of Japanese snack. It looked pathetic sitting there on the table. We were the only guests there and didn't bother to return the next day.But that is really just a minor negative which the hotel could easily improve on if they wished to. The main disadvantage of the hotel is its location. Firstly, we only realised later that our taxi had dropped us off at a small side entrance on the main road. We had to find our own way and bring our luggage by ourselves to the reception floor. The main entrance is in a side road which it seems taxi drivers are not so familiar with. The nearest subway station is about 10 mins walk away and is not a major station therefore requiring changing lines at other station hubs. So be prepared to take taxis if you don't want a lot of walking exercise. This is not a cheap option in Tokyo! As the hotel is in a commercial building and a comparatively new business area, the area is pretty much dead in the evenings. Trying to find somewhere to eat in the mall below at about 8pm, everywhere was closed, about to close, or no customers.So don't get me wrong, I really did love this hotel in many different aspects. But its location has to be seriously considered before staying there.

We stayed here for 2 nights in september and we had an amazing time! The rooms are on the top floors of a building - i think floors 48 - 51 so there are crazy views from everywhere! The pool and gym is super nice and everyone is very accommodating! Bathrooms are insanely gorgeous with wood everywhere. In the lobby in the mornings there are fresh pastries, juices, and coffee/latte available, and the rest of the day they have little cookies and snack - the best part is ALL FREE! The location is pretty central too. Its like 5 blocks to walk to the Metro station and from there you can go anywhere in the city. Loved Tokyo and this hotel is definitely worth the price!

We choose the hotel for our stay in Tokyo as it was our honeymoon and we wanted to treat ourselves by staying somewhere special. We are so pleased we did as this hotel exceeded our expectation in every way. Due to bad weather we had to postpone the second part of our trip which was to the Maldives and so we ended up extending our stay at the hotel for an extra three nights when we returned from Kyoto since we loved it so much. It is hard to put into words a feeling that you get when the hotel you visit leaves you with that warm luxurious feeling but that is exactly what Andes did for us. Our room’s design was impeccable with a perfectly designed space for everything and yet the design hides everything away leaving a smooth clutter free beautiful space to enjoy.
