The floor to ceiling glass windows giving us a spectacular views of the Toyko city skyline reminded us of the movie "Lost in Translaction". The location is perfect as it is in central south Tokyo so we could get around the city relatively easily either via the Tube or taxi. My husband likes to run whenever we travel so he enjoyed running around the Imperial Park every morning which was only a 10 minute jog from the hotel. Given the fact that my husband and I do not speak Japanese, we relied heavily on the concierge to give us recommendations of where to eat. I can honestly say that every place they recommend for dinner was spot on. All the restaurants were small, intimate and away from the touristy crowd with absolutely delicious food. They also helped us to find a wonderful Ryokan in Kyoto because everything we tried to book was not available.The spa was my favourite part of the hotel. Sitting in a carbonated hot tube overlooking Tokyo’s skyline felt very indulgent and the design of the spa and facilities left us feeling so relaxed we both fell asleep the first day we used it because we were able to comply switch off and forget the rest of the world. The staff of the hotel were very welcoming and friendly and we felt that the staff genuinely wanted to ensure that we had an amazing stay. None of our requests seemed to much and they went out of there way to accommodate us and make us feel special. Being world travellers and having stayed in many top hotels in the world, we have to say that hotel overall, this is one of the best we have visited. We have already started recommending this place to our family and friends and when we visit Tokyo again this will be our go to hotel.

All I can say is WOW! We had taken a cab over from the Hyatt Regency Tokyo (about 3000 yen) after a two night stay for our final nights stay in Tokyo and it was about 12:30 pm. The Motor Entrance collected our luggage and all we had was our hand baggage. When we made it to the 51st floor, Check-In person Mommi (SP.?) had escorted us to the Guest Lounge area and offered our party of 4 beverages while taking care of our check-in. We were informed that our rooms, which were adjacent, were NOT ready, so we would need to come back at 3. We were offered the ability to use the Spa prior to our rooms being ready. We were ready for lunch so asked for a recommendation for a casual, noodle place. We were referred to a local noodle place 2 blocks away that was good & inexpensive. We also asked for a restaurant recommendation for dinner. We told her we wanted a mid-priced Japanese Restaurant, and we narrowed it down to a Tempura Restaurant in Ginza that was about 10,000yen pp. Mommi would make a reservation and email the confirmation to us. At lunch we had decided that we didn't want to travel to Ginza for dinner, and wanted to stay very local, so I started to do some research on my phone (T-Mobile worked GREAT, BTW) We still had some time to kill before check-in, and with my parents in their 70's and 80's we decided to walk to a nearby park several blocks away and relax a bit. While there doing my mobile research that I noticed the Toranomon Hills complex contained several other restaurants. After a short, relaxing rest in the park we walked back to the hotel to check out the other restaurants in the complex. As I walked into Pirouette, I knew immediately that's where I wanted to have dinner. We made a 7:30 reservation. I highly,highly recommend this Farm-to-table Creative French Restaurant! Although there is no English menu, we assigned a Server that had a good command of English and was able to translate the menu for us. The 5,000 Yen Prix-Fixe 4-Course Menu was beautiful, creative and delicious! We got back to the hotel at 2:45 and our rooms were ready. In interest of shortening this review, I'll give you some info now via bullet points. * Assigned a standard room on 47 facing the Imperial Gardens.* Used the Fitness Center & Spa. Beautiful space, great equipment in the Fitness Center with actual weight training machines and free weights (Unlike the HRT). Locker room facilities excellent (Missing Steam Room) VERY HOT Sauna.* All day access of beverages in Lounge Area a great benefit! EXCELLENT coffee from the automated machine -your choice of coffee type.* Cocktail hour very nice benefit, enjoyed a couple glasses of Sake!* Received a Financial Times newspaper in the morning.* Requested and received a 2pm late checkout. (Hyatt Gold Passport Platinum Member)* Morning Breakfast buffet very tasty but EXPENSIVE(10% Gratuity added) the Nutella Brioche French Toast is yummy (You have to ask for it and ask for 2 pieces - they are small and the size of a slice of French Baguette!)* Checked out the bar on 52 and it's an interesting space; there was a DJ spinning tunes and pretty crowded at 9:45pm.* Airport Limousine Bus is an easy way to Narita from the hotel; purchased the tickets from the hotel. As an architecture and design buff, this hotel probably was the nicest place I have stayed design-wise.

What an amazing experience! From the elegant check in to the beautiful rooftop bar, it has been a real pleasure. you even have a bluetooth speaker resting beside your bed! (bose soundlink mini).one of the main attractions is the bar at the roof, which is to my opinion one of the best in tokyo, with it's view and style.the breakfasts were great and served a large variety of food, eating dinner in the restaurant was nice but there are better. the rooms were spacious, beautifully decorated in east meets west style and the staff was very nice and accommodating.we all really enjoyed this hotel, and we have been to many good hotels.

Andaz Tokyo ia luxury at it's finest, from the guest rooms to the lobby and staff. From the moment we entered the property, we felt welcome and taken care of. The rooms had every detail in order..coffee maker, snacks, scrumptious bedding, and deluxe bathroom with Japanese warm toilet. The room came with Japanese AND American bathrobes and slippers. We were in Heaven.

We had a wonderful time at the Andaz. Our room was beautiful, our view was out of this world, the linen and bathroom were perfect. The staff friendly, service brilliant! Great location, great coffee and chocolate downstairs in Patisserie and Foyer. Nori Uchiyama was very knowledgeable and gave us a private tour of the chapel on the 52nd floor. It was truly beautiful and we very much enjoyed the tour and appreciated his time and courtesy. Just great! Loved it.

Wow...you need to stay at this hotel. My wife and I stayed here for 4 days, 3 nights after a week of business in Tokyo. The rooms are elegant and spacious, even by American standards. Floor to ceiling window in ever room offer amazing views of the city regardless of direction you are facing. (We were facing the Tokyo Skytree and City Center) Also - the rooms have a light filtering shade option as well as a blackout shade option. With the blackout shade closed you will think it is midnight when it is really 10am...amazing for vacation sleeping in!The lobby for this hotel is on the 51st floor of the Toranomon Hills bulding and the rooms are floors 47-50. Spa, Fitness and Pool are on floor 37. There is a restaurant and bar/lounge on the 51st floor as well as a rooftop bar on 52. The Rooftop Bar is a little more upbeat than the 51st floor lounge - we enjoyed the very well made cocktails on the 51st floor lounge with a live piano player in the background. The service was impeccable throughout our stay - want 4 ice cubes for your Japanese Whiskey nightcap in your room? Not a problem - they'll bring it right to you. Every request we had was met with a definitive yes and was acted upon within 5 minutes. This is just not the standard in hotels around the world any longer. One nice surprise which we don't often find in high-end hotels is the WiFi was complimentary and the non-alcoholic drinks in the mini-bar were free as well. In addition, each room has a Nespresso Machine with pods for you to make espresso/coffee each morning. They even keep the water receptacle filled for you! :)The ONLY cons to this hotel would be the price and a bit of a walk to the Metro system (10-15 minutes depending on your pace). If you are looking for a budget or mid-priced option, this is not your hotel. That said, if you are a person/couple like we are who values service and comforts - this is the place for you. I will definitely be staying here again and be looking for Andaz hotels around the world as we travel!

Wonderful experience each single day. Ever best gym, swimming pool, room, vallet parking, restaurants and bar come with lovely and kind hotel stuff service. Gym facility is awesome. I feel bad that I didnt try the gym and swimming pool for first 10days. I will visit there again with my family and also recommend my collegues to stay there if any rooms are available,

I've been going to Tokyo on business for over a decade and this time stayed at the Andaz and in over 30+ hotels I've stayed in over the years this was by far the best experience overall I've had in Tokyo. Excellent facility and the staff could not do enough to make the stay even better. The only caveat to my ratings is that I had a special corporate rate due to the company in Japan I was working with and that skewed the "value" rating; the standard rack rate can be a big number.

I heard good reviews about this hotel and decided to try. The hotel is quite new, having opened for less than a year. Andaz is under the Hyatt group. It’s a more hippy, layback in style and position somewhere between Grand Hyatt and the more luxurious Park Hyatt. ArrivalI arrived by taxi after checking out from Shangri-la which I had a great stay once again. The vibe and style of the Andaz is distinctively different. First thing one notice entering the hotel is the very modern architecture style adorning the public areas. Most of the staff are made of up young good looking people who seems friendly and eager to help. Check-in was swift and I was escorted to the room and explained about the features. No upgrade was given despite my Virtuoso status but irregardless, the room is quite nice so I did not complain. The room has a size of 65m2 with an enlarged bathroom and a large foyer / corridor which kind of waste the space. There is a large table with a long sofa that makes up most of the room. The bed is king size and positioned quite low but otherwise it’s comfortable enough with quality bed sheets. The bathroom has an extensive shower room with great water pressure and a gigantic deep soaking tub that can easily accommodate two or more adults. In particular, I love that long table and sofa where I can layout my laptop on one side and have food and drinks at the other or just relax in the long sofa seat. The furniture and fittings are of good but not luxurious quality but the room is well equipped with modern electronics like electronic curtain coffee machine. Most of the electronics and lighting are very intuitive and easy to use, which is not to be taken for granted. A simple bedside control with analog switches can turn on or off the lighting, on or off the curtains and other controls. There was no need to deal with hard to press control panel buttons or worst, a wireless iPad or similar tablet device that takes a geek with an Einstein brain to operate and still doesn’t work most of them. A lot of hotels nowadays are keen to implement these features but made them so complicated that it takes an Einstein’s brain to figure it out. Other amenities include free non-alcoholic minibar and even the tibits and chocolates were free for staying guest and are replenish daily. Internet is free and super-fast. At the 50th floor, the room has a distant view of the skytree and theTokyo bay. Other than that, it’s not a particular nice view at night as the hotel is in an office area and nothing of interest nearby. So it's not the "sea of lights" view that we expect from skyscraper hotels facing the busy Marunochi district or the bustling Shinjuku area. It’s a comfortable room but sound proofing is not good as I can hear noise from the street when there was a outdoor concert nearby. Fortunately it only lasted only 8AM. Common Areas and LocationThe hotel has one main restaurant called the Tavern which serves breakfast, weekend brunch and all the day dinning. There is also an adjacent bar. One floor up and there is a sushi restaurant which I did not try or visit. I had breakfast and Sunday brunch at the Tavern and find the food rather mediocre and I will say the hotel’s F&B standard needs improvement. For better value for money and also better food, there are some interesting restaurants nearby ( 10 to 15 mins away by taxi ), just ask the hotel staff to recommend. The hotel recommends and helps me booked a nearby Teppanyaki restaurant which turns out to be excellent. The hotel also have a common hall with large tables and communal seating, which serves free drinks and alcohols and tibits during happy hour. It kind of resembles a club lounge but for all hotel guests. I am not a fan of communal seating and prefer my own table for privacy. Others may not mind. This place was very crowded during the evening. I end up taking the food during happy hour to my room and the staff happily obliged. The hotel has a large gym and spa with swimming pool located at the 37th floor. The décor was very “Zen” and relaxing. The gym has nice exercising equipment and modern amenities. The hotel is located at Toranomon Hills, a mixed used complex housing the Andaz hotel, some restaurants and shops and an office complex. There isn’t anything very interesting within the building or the surrounding area are all office building. A subway station is conveniently located nearby and it’s about 2 stops away from Ginza. I will not say the location is ideal. It’s rather quiet and lack of atmosphere at night. ServiceNothing much to complain as all service request were attended to quickly. Not very pleased with my view, the hotel graciously offered me an upgrade to the more premium Tokyo Tower room but I find the view there to be equally unexciting so I decided to stay at the same room. On my second night of stay, there were some noise from an outdoor concert in the street and again I complained and they offer a room switch immediately but since it ends at 8AM, I decided also not do. Overall, nothing particular outstanding but I find the staff very quick to respond to service request and quite obliging as well. For a short stay, this is fine. ConclusionBasically, this is the “W” version of Hyatt and there are many similarities between the two. I quite like this hotel but the location is not ideal and their F&B needs improvement. The rate is on the high side also and may not be value for money for some. It’s all down to individual preferences. I would not mind staying at this hotel but it is not my first choice which is the Shangr-la.

I had the pleasure of returning here for the second time at the end of July and everything was even better than I remember it! Even though it had been many months since my first (and only stay) there were a few staff members that remembered me, which is always a nice touch. The breakfast buffet was more delicious than I remember it being and even though my favorite nutella brioche wasn't on the spread one morning, the chefs were kind enough to prepare it for me.I also had some random odd requests about my Japanese cell phone that the staff did some research for me, which was above and beyond their duty (thank you again if you read this)!The room was still comfortable, clean, well thought out and has one of the biggest hotel closest I've enjoyed! Made sure to visit their hamburger place on the first floor again, Bebu, and like everything else it was better than I remembered. Love the food there though in the summer for lunch that room does tend to heat up (though all of Tokyo was scorching when I was there)!This time I had a great view of Tokyo Tower from my room (see photos) and even though weather didn't fully cooperate, I still was able to get some good shots!Even though location isn't my first choice in Tokyo, it's close enough to 3 stations to not be too inconvenient and in part of Tokyo that is a little quieter than most. All in all, probably my favorite hotel to stay in when visiting Tokyo and can't wait to return again.

What an incredible blend of Japanese style and culture with American convenience. Staff was so service oriented and the hotel and rooms are beautiful. Location was convenient and food was delicious and varied.

Truly perfect stay in Tokyo - everyone we met was so courteous and helpful. Appreciated the happy hour as well as all the amenities in the room. Room was surprisingly spacious for a hotel in Tokyo - we had 3 beds and still had room to move around. Beds were very comfortable. The bathroom had a good amount of space for multiple people people to be moving around although will say that it was awkward that the shower door was clear meaning that if you were taking a shower, you could be seen by other members of your party using the bathroom. The automatic massage chairs in the locker rooms were a great perk! Train station was only a few minutes walk away which made it easy to get around Tokyo.

Stayed for 3 nights with husband and toddler in a standard king room on the 50th floor. Although located in a large skyscraper, the plentiful signage made the hotel easy to find within the building. Check in was quick and easy. Toddlers and parents will all love the bathroom. The round tub is large enough to function as your own private onsen - my son thought it was like a mini swimming pool, and he was able to splash around as much as he liked since the tub was in enclosed along with the shower in it's own "room." I liked that the shower included a standard shower head (as to avoid getting my hair wet), but also a rain-type shower head, which my son loved. The child-size bathroom set (robe, yukata, towel, slippers, toothbrush, & toothpaste) was a thoughtful touch. We kept the window shades open the entire stay, and thoroughly enjoyed waking up to the beautiful views each morning. Having the complimentary drinks nesspresso and snacks was an added bonus.Free wifi and large desk would also make it a good selection for business travelers.The only downside for us was that the breakfast buffet was quite pricey, and that the hotel is not the most conveniently located in terms of train access. It's at least a 5 min walk to the nearest metro stop (Toranomon), and a 10 min walk to the JR line. So keep this in mind if lugging around difficult-to-maneuver suitcases.

We stayed here for four nights in September 2015. The service ahead of check in was excellent, with swift and helpful responses to queries about a late check in and a transfer from Haneda Airport. The hotel arranged a private car transfer, but also offered advice on a number of other (cheaper) options. For the return journey, to Narita Airport, hotel staff arranged tickets for the Airport Limousine Bus, which picks up from the hotel.The hotel is on the 47th - 52nd floors of Toranomon Hills, one of Tokyo's tallest buildings. Views from windows in all directions are very impressive. Check in was smooth, and carried out over a drink in the lounge. The layout of the hotel is potentially confusing at first, but easy to get used to. The ground floor of the building has the hotel's taxi rank and car entrance, as well as a pastry shop and restaurant operated by the hotel. The building is large, so there are a number of other entrances, although the the hotel does have its own well-marked entrance from the street. The lobby is on the 51st floor, accessed from the ground by a dedicated lift, which we never had to wait long for. Also on the 51st floor are the main restaurant, the Andaz Tavern, and the residents' lounge, as well as function rooms used for weddings etc. Rooms are on floors 47-50, (ours was on the 48th), accessed from the lobby by another set of lifts. As these three lifts only serve those floors, again, we never had to wait more than a few seconds to get one.The hotel's design is contemporary but not wacky, with lots of natural materials and a definite Japanese minimal influence. Our standard King bedroom was a great size, with a large bathroom featuring a big circular bath and separate rainfall shower. Oh, and of course, a very Japanese toilet ;) Privacy in the bathroom is excellent; it is possible to have two fully closed doors between the toilet and the bed.The hotel's location is in a quieter, more business-y part of the city, with little nightlife nearby. Public transport links, however, are excellent, with at least three metro stations within walking distance. The nearest, Toranomon, is a 5-10 minute walk away. This suited us very well, and we were able to get around a lot of the city very easily.Finally, I cannot overstate how good the service at the hotel is. Staff were friendly and eager to help, even when we came back to the hotel on the first day having failed to obtain any money (short version: you have to use an ATM in a 7-11 or a post office). Many staff speak excellent English, and those who didn't were very patient with my lack of Japanese.Overall, whilst this is clearly not a budget option, the Andaz delivers an excellent experience, and I'd leap at the chance to stay there again.

Yes everything is perfect. Yes location is amazing, yes service is perfect ..... But you have the same in Grand Hyatt roppongi for 30% cheaper !!!The most surprising is maybe Bebu restaurant. Very affordable and deliciousThe roof top bar is nice also with a very good choice of whisky

For those who don't know, Andaz is to Hyatt what W is to Starwood. Excellent hotel. Incredible attention to detail:i. Hotel umbrella has 16 spokes not 8 so you won't get blown away even in a Tokyo typhoon (well unless you weigh under 80lbs in which case you may fly away with the umbrella...);ii. Shower has ledge to sit (appreciated by older folks);iii. Wash basin and tables are solid teak with superb finishes;iv. Blackout blinds for sleeping in;v. Deep safe for laptop/tablet;vi. Two tables - a higher work table and a lower coffee table;vii. A long sofa the length of the wall which one can stretch out on - and amazingly the height of the sofa is right for both the lower coffee table and the higher work table (!); viii. Free non-alcoholic drinks and snacks from room minibar, refilled daily; andix. The list goes on.This is a seriously well thought out hotel and it is in many respects better than the W 's I've stayed at (W's are hipper but have less attention to detail).Only drawback - the price. I guess some things you have to pay for...

This was our first trip to Tokyo, and we had an amazing experience at the Andaz. The location is great, near subway lines and a number of shops and restaurants are in the same building. Certainly the best part about the hotel is the view. From our room (we had a view of the Tokyo tower on the 50th floor - can't be beat!), to the view from the gym/pool, to the rooftop bar, we were ever disappointed. We took advantage of happy hour each night with snacks and drinks served from 6-8pm. The facilities in the hotel are absolutely breathtaking. There were 3 wedding one day, and I can imagine why. The entire place, down to the elevators is gorgeous. I also have to mention that the staff at this hotel is perhaps the most helpful and welcoming that I have seen in awhile. They cater to your every need and treat you with respect no matter what. We will certainly be back to the Andaz!

Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Stayed here a few times now and it's one of the best hotels I have stayed in. Close to Haneda airport, great views from he rooms, walking distance to local places to eat and drink, good transport links and the service and standard of the rooms and restaurants are excellent.

This was my first time staying at an Andaz hotel and this experience was truly exceptional and probably counts as my favorite hotel to date. The team is exceptionally helpful and friendly, the views of Tokyo are exceptional and worth the visit on its own, the bed is incredibly comfortable and the Rooftop Patio is worth the visit.

It may not be in the most popular area to stay but the hotel is gorgeous. From the lobby with its ridiculously high ceilings and beautiful bar/lounge, to the fitness center and pool, to the rooms everything is near perfect. We went almost a year after they had opened and you could tell they had worked out most of their issues but some of the staff was still green. Our check in process was not smooth and only one of our three rooms was available. We had confirmed 3 rooms on the same floor but by the time we came back to check into our other 2 rooms they had given one away so our family was now split onto 2 floors. Not a deal breaker but still a hassle. One positive of this hotel is that because all the rooms are so high everyone has a view and the views are breathtaking because of the floor to ceiling windows. The rooftop bar was breathtaking and the bartenders were friendly and knowledgeable. Be prepared to take lots of elevators if you stay here, there is one elevator that takes you to the lobby and then a different set of elevators that take you too your room.

Average: for this high level "boutique hotel": the staff(reception) is not sufficiently professional. I mean: no explanation about the different possibilities of the hotel and in summary too approximative. We didn t hear about the "sky" bar, the swimming pool ( gorgeous), the presentation of the room ( not at all, but really nice and high tec, difficult to manage alone )the happy hour ( basic and more for the big family who don t want pay a drink than the happy hour in other branch, lack of brillant attitude for happy hour , lack of privacy and luxe - W and R basic wines, some ( few) snacks, ok a good sake). I am not sure that there s a real concierge function in the hotel ( i mean real one concierge to help you to go out of the common pathways )It s ok when you are in a basic hotel not with this pretention and this price...where is the perfection of the japonese art? Maybe...the GM is french...he have to learn the culture of the perfectionAnyway....the hotel have a perfect modern design. The location is perfect, the room is beautiful.I hope that my remarks are only kindness sickness...go higher and be adult to be one of the best

I just completed a Japan trip with a one night stay at Andaz. While the hotel indrastructure is beautiful, its location central (yet far from public transport) , there is a clear issue with staff training and service attitude.As you would expect, the hotel is new, Andaz style and very nicely decorated. Any rephrasing of the other contributors' positive comments would be using up readers' bandwidth. if you are looking for a great looking hotel in Central Tokyo with fittings of this decade, go here.If you are looking for Asian hospitality and Japanese style welcome, don't!Front office is a weird mix of checkin and welcome desk and concierge, of counter and sit down somewhere else, with plenty of trips back to the counter for passport scanning, credit card swiping and what not. The staff is overwhelmed with all but the basic tasks or anything that isn't in the textbook. My checkin experience was horrible. the staff member's only concern was to verify my rate credentials. My business card was in the luggage - which kindly enough was taking care of on the ground floor - and didn't show up in my room until I had to head out, about 30 minutes after my arrival. I was summoned orally, through an escort to my room and in writing to show my business card and bring it to them straight away ... or face a higher rate. Appealing to some reasonable sense of customer service triggered more incomprehension.... Anyway, after my luggage had shown up and I was back in yhe evening, the matter was solved. I had warmer welcomes at Novotels in Russia, though.Not to mention that I wasn't told about the spa facilities (which are gorgeous), the happy hour in the lobby for all guests (which was OK only, given the patronage of families holding court in a rowdy fashion) or the rooftop bar (where you should reserve a window seat before showing up).Concierge services aren't existing. Even the simplest of questions (like a good yakitori restaurant nearby... really?) leads to good looking youngsters scrambling in their computer for hours, not to much avail indeed.... it's what you get when you privilege procedures over substance in staff recruiting and training.Some time to go until the 2020 Olympics.I probably won't be back. You should always take your first chance to make a good impression.

My family and I just spent (August 19-August 23)the last five days of our trip to Tokyo at Andaz. Anodize is the best hotel we have been to. The facility itself is amazing and the service was beyond our expectations. Every single person working there was helpful at all times. What we did really appreciate was that the employees were fluent in English, which could be hard to find in Japan. They were also helpful in every aspect of our trip from questions about the hotel all the way to shopping ideas. There was not one thing we did not appreciate about the Andaz. Though the location is not as convenient, everything else about the Andaz makes up for it. We are already planning our next trip at the Andaz. I told my husband from now on if he takes me on vacation anywhere, I expect to be staying at somewhere comparable to the Andaz or don't take me at all......

Pleasant experience checking in - check-in on 51st floor, guest were invited to sit at the open tables to wait for check in. I liked wooden furniture and fittings. The hotel room, the check in area had wooden furnishings, made me feel very warm and homely.

Visited 4 countries changing hotels 8 times. Our stay at the Toranomon Andaz was by far the best all the way around. I have had breakfast buffets with many more choices but none with Better quality food or better preparation. Try the omelette. Distance to train or subway was the only undesirable aspect Of our stay.

The Andaz Tokyo Toranomon Hills is a refreshing Andaz expereince in the heart of Tokyo. While the Toranomon area is more of a quiet business area compared to other Hyatt locations in Tokyo, the onsite facilities make the Andaz a good social destination. Service, decor and facilities are at the highest level one wold expect from an Andaz property - and the whole hotel still has that nice 'brand new' feel to it. The multiple elevators others have commented on were manageable - and not unusual in such a high rise building. All of the staff were excellent to interact with and very prompt and courteous with their service. The pool/gym and spa area were flawless with wonderful views of the city.I was there on business but will return with my family.

The lobby of the hotel is located on the 51st floor, and rooms located on the 5 floors below, with the pool and spa on the 37th floor. So all rooms have an amazing view, the best being from the breakfast area/bar on the 51st floor. Service is simply outstanding - exceptionally friendly and polite and very helpful. I lost my wallet near the end of our second stay at this hotel and was amazed and very grateful by the help and assistance received from the manager and staff in resolving this issue. Food and drink choice is very good and of very high quality. Housekeeping is outstanding - so clean and efficient! Rooms and bathrooms have high quality furnishings and amenities and are very modern in outlook. Only negative point I would put across is that the concierge service could have been more helpful (less rushed) in explaining destinations to taxi drivers. This is a minor point and did not distract from our stay at all.

What a hotel! Everything is so well thought of. Excellent service amazing and very helpful staff. Spacious and well designed rooms fantastic views of Tokyo. We had a room on the49th floor overlooking Tokyo tower. You gonna love the bathroom. Absolutely fantastic. Highly recommend it.

I had a wonderful stay at this hotel. The property is very elegant and chic, but at the same time very contemporary and cool. The rooms are amazing, and truly invite you to relax in the middle of a bustling city while enjoying amazing views on all the activity going down 50 floors below you. The staff couldn't be any friendlier or attentive. You truly feel a guest in this hotel, and they try to make your stay as comfortable as possible. The breakfast is truly delicious. I don't think I've ever had a better breakfast. I was in love with the breadpudding and still miss it every day since I left. The hotel is very centrally located, and there's public transport close by. Therefore, it's a great starting point for discovering the vast city of Toyo. Overall, this may be the best hotel experience I've ever had, so I highly recommend a stay at Andaz if you're in Tokyo.

We stayed at the Andaz Tokyo (owned by Hyatt) in July 2015. What an experience. The service was wonderful...Andrea was so helpful and kind to us...Kudos to the hotel for having on hand such wonderful staff.We had a room on the 49th floor which faced Tokyo Harbor and the Rainbow Bridge and it was an incredible view...especially at night with all the lights. The hotel room was lovely...lots of deep dark walnut. Just so pretty.I fell in love with the bathroom/dressing area...lots of room and oh so pretty and the toilet was fully automatic...the seat would raise and lower on its own...and it had water for cleansing...toilet was heated. Made you feel like royalty! ;) The breakfast was very nice and complete (ours was complimentary) but we didn't try any other of the restaurants in the hotel as there were so many places around the hotel to try. We were so surprised by how great the Andaz was we are looking for others to stay in.

Impressive hotel with very nice decoration and great staff that makes you feel at home. Amazing views of this city with a relaxing SPA with nice pool and well equipped gym. Don't miss it if you can afford it, if not, go for a drink at rooftop.

Location: As many commented it is a 8 mins to Toronomon Subway Station which is 2 stops away from Ginza. If you don't mind the walk or else you have to rely on taxi.No interesting activities or restos in the vicinity. Not even in Toronomon Hill, the F&B outlets are very average.ROOM: Spacious, may be bigger than Conrad. Most rooms with a long couch along the floor to ceiling windows , but watch out some are just with chairs only. I like the work table separates from the lower long coffee table. spacious bath and dressing area. Many shelf space, sufficient hangers and a/c outlets for 21st century business travelers. Since it is a new hotel, the waffle-knit bathrobe is soft unlike the other Hyatt facilities rough worn towel bathrobe. Higher grade room with better toiletries! Complimentary non-alcoholic mini bar is a plus.Faciities: at the lounge on Lobby Floor 51Fl, you can lounge there with hot and cold drink from the fridge throughout. Overall design is sleek modern with a hint of Japanese zen.F&B: In-room dining quality and service is average only.  Laundry service is swift and wrapped like a gift. impressive.The Décor is sleek, first timer may have difficulty in finding the elevators, or the exit. I noted many got off the elevators then start to daze... Service is quite friendly overall. If the rate is right, it is a better choice than Grand Hyatt.

This is my first visit to Andaz Tokyo after staying at Park Hyatt Tokyo and Hyatt Regency Tokyo a few times (4 times each to be exact). One of the reasons is that our destinations this time are closer to this side of Tokyo, whereas Park Hyatt Tokyo and Hyatt Regency Tokyo are closer to the Shinjuku end.The walking from the Toranomon subway station is not too far. The check-in area is just like Park Hyatt Tokyo that it's on a higher floor. It does take us a while to figure out the way to the elevator (guess we didn't enter via the car area so no one was escorting us like Park Hyatt Tokyo). But after once or twice you will know the way.Unlike Park Hyatt Tokyo which performs check-in inside your room, Andaz Tokyo has an area with a few tables for you to sit down, enjoy a drink and check in. They accommodated our early check-in request (around 11am) as well as late check-out (around 3pm) without additional charge as I am a Diamond member, and the room has been upgraded to a Tower view room. The lady even brought it up proactively if I had sent packages to the hotel - because I've asked about this over email a week ago (and eventually I didn't send any packages).The tower view room has nice big windows facing the Tokyo Tower and easy buttons to manipulate the curtains. The couch is so big that it's from one end of the wall to the other end, and two people can probably lie on it at the 2 ends of the couch!!! There are so many more visible power outlets (than Park Hyatt Tokyo) that it's more work/business friendly.Bathroom consists of a few areas. The part that trumps Park Hyatt Tokyo (in a standard room) is the bathtub which is round and spacious. My wife also told me that the handle allowed her to get out of the bathtub more easily without worrying about slipping (than the one in Park Hyatt Tokyo).Shoe shine service is just like Park Hyatt Tokyo. I called them for pickup, and they gave the shoes back to me shortly.The minibar in the room has free non-alcoholic drinks and snacks! Yes, FREE!!! Coke, green tea, water, sparkling water and different types of crackers and chocolates!There's no chance for me to enjoy the spa, but the gym has a nice city view though. One new thing to me is the separate gym areas for male and female. If you and your spouse (of opposite gender) would like to work out together, sorry, no luck here.Breakfast has a pretty healthy buffet selection. I asked if there's menu (just like Park Hyatt Tokyo) but the waitress said it's all buffet. I ordered omelet from the counter and he brought the omelet to my table quickly.There's no English communication problem with any staff members in the hotel. The staff members are more courteous and of a different style from Park Hyatt Tokyo - Andaz Tokyo has a more friendly and casual style of courtesy, whereas Park Hyatt Tokyo has a more serious style (but both with lots of smile of course).I have yet to try another Grand Hyatt Tokyo which is not too far away, but given the nice experience here at Andaz, I will simply pick Park Hyatt Tokyo or Andaz Tokyo depending on my Tokyo activities. If I visit the Shinjuku/Shibuya area more often, then Park Hyatt Tokyo, else Andaz Tokyo for the Tokyo Tower/Odaiba side (and Hyatt Regency Tokyo if it's a business travel with limited budget).

KY L
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is quite new. Heard it's been open for about a year. The staff members are very courteous and speak good English. Hotel floors are on the upper part of the building so the rooms have great views of the city. The entire hotel has very thoughtfully designed with a great contemporary feel, yet warm and comfortable. Rooms are well appointed and spacious. Highly recommended for both business and leisure.

The hotel is absolutely incredible and the views are unreal. Rooms are large, staff were attentive, and my expectations were exceeded. Andaz Tokyo is one of the nicest hotels I have ever stayed at in my life. 5-10 min walk from the subway and the ground floor of the building had great restaurant options as well.

I spent THREE days in Tokyo for business and wish to find a place close to financial and Ginaz area. Andaz Tokyo is the one of my choice. I never stay in Andaz hotel before and the environment is pretty modern. There's no check-in counter but a check-in round table. People can speak very good English and friendly.

I travel to Tokyo a lot for work and this new Hyatt Andaz property is outstanding. The rooms are beautiful, the staff are warm and welcoming without being overbearing. They treat everyone like a VIP. The location is great for getting out to walk with the Imperial Gardens and other parks very nearby. Loved the rooftop bar too. Also easy for commuting given proximity of the subway.

Probably unsurprisingly for a new hotel in Tokyo, the Andaz is an outstanding property. Excellent Japanese service as you would expect, very good room service and terrific breakfast. I would rate it as the best of the four Hyatt properties in Tokyo. If you have stayed at other Andaz hotels and found them wanting - perhaps in the quality of finishing, for example - I absolutely would not hesitate to stay at this Andaz. In fact, the difference between the Toranomon Hills Andaz and those on Wall Street, in Shanghai, West Hollywood and to a lesser extent London, is quite marked. The only minor downside of the hotel is that the Toranomon Hills location is perhaps not as convenient as Marunouchi, Shinjuku, Tokyo Midtown or Roppongi Hills but for us this was a minor consideration.

Don't eat at the Andaz Tavern. Stopped by at 3PM ish when nobody else was there with a friend for two bowls of lobster bisque, one glass of Norman cider, a cocktail, a single salad, and we split sorbet. The salad was boring, the lobster bisque was overpowered by the uni which was not fresh. They didn't screw up the cocktails or the sorbet aside from taking 30 minutes to serve them. ..... $133 US/ 647.59 YEN .... Nice view, worst meal I had in Japan. Stuffy joint.

Everything is so perfect. The hotel is amazingly beautiful, and the staffs are very kind and well trained. I even want to come to Tokyo just for staying at this hotel. This hotel is literally flawless.

房間內超大片玻璃，無論何時回到房間，白天夜晚都令人感動 Check in時，不同的方式以令人印象深刻。原木設計。處處都讓人直接感受到非常高級的質感。 24小時貼心的小餐點飲料，sweet. 51chech in view 就值得我們流連忘返了 大浴室。smart interior decoration. All wood material in bath room nice trimming accessories, free soft drink mini bar... 適合任何人來住。 Good for enjoy.
user_name:
Pei Ying S
臺北, Taiwan

review_body: I stayed in Andaz Toranomon mainly to check out its interior design (by the legendary Tony Chi) and I was not disappointed! All design elements are beautifully carried out in a modern interpretation of Japanese style. The room was huge for Japanese standard, with a panoramic view of Tokyo city. I must admit the hotel is located in a blah neighborhood, with little choice of restaurants. However, it is not too far from the subway station.My only real interaction with the hotel staff was during the check-in, where I found the staff courteous, but not very warm, and a bit confused. I wonder if it was because the hotel has just opened not long ago (I stayed in Oct 2014).

My employer moved offices into a new tower which luckily has the Andaz in the building. If the location suits and you want cool and stylish this is your hotel.The guest rooms are really nicely appointed, it has a nice spacious feel, the bar at the top of the building is terrific and the two meals I had were very nice. Highly recommended.

We felt a little like we had arrived at 007's hotel. The hotel is not known by taxi drivers but the building it is located IN -Toranomon Hills, Is known. If you are using trains, take the Ginza line to Toranomon station and take Exit 4. Coming up from the exit, go to the very first block (there is a Pronto sign on the side of the building) and turn right. Walk about 3 blocks and the small street will dead end at the Toranomon Hills building. Once you enter the building the actual Andaz entrance elevators are discreetly located. You have to take the special Andaz elevators up to the 51st floor for check-in. The rooms are located on floors Below the lobby and to get to the rooms, you need to use a different set of elevators than the one you came to the lobby in from the 1st floor (that 007 feeling, lol). The lobby is beautiful (see pic) and a place you just want to relax in which the hotel staff welcomes you to do by offering free drinks, cookies and anything else you might need as soon as you sit down. Small lobby acloves are nice when you want more privacy. The staff here are top-notch!! The view from both of the rooms we had here were amazing (see pic)!! Save a little money and don't get the offered upgrade Tokyo Tower view room as all the views from the Andaz are great! Spend the money you just saved on the room upgrade to book a Spa visit at Ao. My daughter and I got the 90 minute oriental massages and were very impressed! Only two complaints - there are many different lights in the Andaz rooms but several could only be turned off by the master switch which then turned off all the lights. Second, the breakfast is extremely overpriced for the selections offered (about $50 USD per person). There is a small cafe across the street, if you need a breakfast fix, I suggest this instead. The 52nd floor bar is a "Must Do" at night - while you are staying here! Breathtaking views with a cool vibe. Overall, the Andaz has very beautiful rooms with amazing views and a five-star staff!! Hotel is more for couples, business men and women or families with older teens. Location is ok, if you are willing to use the trains / subways during your stay - then you can easily get to popular areas such as Roppongi, Harajuku or even Shinjuku without switching trains too many times from the Andaz.

I recently stayed for one night at the Andaz Tokyo. Due to a delayed flight I arrived very late in the evening, but I was impressed with the smooth check-in process. The Andaz Tokyo is somewhat unusual in that there is no actual front desk. Instead, I was escorted to a large desk to the side of the spacious lobby, where staff stood around facing Macbooks. This gave a cool and stylish impression, although some might prefer a more traditional front desk. As a side note, most of the front staff seemed to be non-Japanese, which felt strange for a Tokyo hotel, although it did add to the cosmopolitan ambiance of the hotel.Since I arrived late in the evening, the lobby area was deserted. The lighting in the lobby was very low key, making it impractical to do anything such as read or work. (To give a sense of how dark it was, staff could be seen inspecting the area with flashlights!) The massive wooden table in the lobby was nice, but clearly not meant to be used for any practical purpose, since I could not find any power ports to plug in my laptop. Since there is no business center in this hotel, I found this inconvenient. Clearly this hotel is not meant for the business traveler.Although the staff member who checked me in specifically mentioned that free drinks and snacks were available in the lobby, I later found that there was nothing available at this late hour, which left me hungry and wondering why he mentioned it. I did find some the next morning, although I was somewhat disappointed that only two types of pastries and juice were available (I was able to order an iced coffee.)Also the next morning, I had the opportunity to use the pool and gym. As with the rest of the hotel, the design was ultra-modern and stylish. However (unlike the Park Hyatt Tokyo) there were no staff stationed in the pool area. This might be preferable to guests who might simply want to take a quick solitary swim, but perhaps not to others, such as families or those who might need to call upon the staff for assistance.Later on, I needed to print out several documents. As mentioned above, the Andaz Tokyo does not have a business center, so I was asked to either provide the documents on a USB stick or email them to the staff at the front desk. Since I did not have a USB stick I had to email the documents and wait for them to receive it in their inbox. After an awkward several minutes, the email still had not arrived so I was asked to send them again, to another email address (which thankfully worked). There was also a charge of 100 yen per A4 page, which they only explained to me after they brought me the printouts (For comparison, you can do the same thing at a Kinko's or Seven-Eleven for around 20 yen/page). The whole process of printing out four A4 pages took about 20 minutes. Overall I found this system impractical and somewhat old-fashioned for a brand-new hotel. Some sort of wifi or cloud printing capability would have been nice.Overall the Andaz Tokyo is a nice, modern hotel, but definitely not one that is geared towards business travelers, or those who might need to use certain practical amenities.
user_name:
hgny76
New York City, New York

review_body: I had high expectations of the Andaz, having appreciated other properties in the chain, and I was not disappointed. Just about a perfect stay. Always helpful staff. Nice lobby with working tables and they bring you drinks. Beautiful rooms, just huge by Japan standards, with a raft of amenities. Nice walk-in rain shower. QUIET - maybe the quietest city hotel I've ever stayed in? Never heard a neighbor, only the infrequent siren from 47 stories below. The buffet breakfast is great and will keep you from going hungry till dinner time (assuming you can afford the cost of the bed + breakfast packages). Wifi was blazing fast and as with other Andaz hotels, free (also free are the non-alcoholic contents of the mini-bar).Nice firm beds, light-tight blackout curtains, quiet... what an awesome place to sleep. Loved every minute of my stay.

Gorgeous large rooms and facilities, great views and super friendly staff! The only downfall to this hotel is the location which is very corporate and in a pretty boring part of town... Its still central though so getting around is fairly easy.

It was a great time for our family to stay. My son was so excited to see Tokyotower from the room where we spent. When we choose to stay in Tokyo, we would like to choose Andaz again. Their hospotarity should be mentioned that they did a great gob to welcome us.

This is easily one the best city hotels in the world. Located on the uppermost floors of the Mori building in Toranomon, the tallest actual building in Tokyo (2nd only to Skytree), this hotel has it all. Some people have mentioned that the Andaz concept is harder to implement in a city and culture like Tokyo, but I felt they've executed it very well. While it's not exactly "mi casa su casa", the staff really tries to make you feel comfortable the moment you step in. No overly formal greetings or language, but the classy Japanese touch such as walking you to elevators and bowing slightly really blends the cultures well. The living room area is nice as well with private nooks and crannies available for relaxing or quick meetings. There's always juice or coffee or small snacks/pastries available as well.The lobby is located on the 2nd highest floor so you have to take the elevator up then down for the rooms. The large indoor pool and spas, as well as separated men and woman onsens is one of the largest in Tokyo, where square footage are worth gold. One complaint that families may have is that this is not really a kids space, as the ambiance goes more for upscale and could be a little less inviting that families would like. However this is a plus for me, and really is one of the more unique pools I've been to.The rooms are well appointed, with larger than average size for Tokyo. Rooms are either facing Tokyo tower, or the Imperial Palace, and being one of the tallest buildings you get a great view of all directions on clear days. The rooms while not that big, is nicely organized. I especially liked the long couch area where you can just sit and stare out the window and admire Tokyo from above. I didn't choose to eat at the hotel but the restaurant looked pretty popular among local business people as well. Instead I would recommend the dry aged Kobe beef restaurant located in the same building on the 4th floor. Very good prices for lunch and the beef is exquisite, and will ruin your taste for beef anywhere else in the future. The concierge here can help hook you up. This is my top choice for staying in Tokyo, probably even over their sister hotel the Park Hyatt. The location I feel is just much better since Shinjuku is not exactly central to the rest of Tokyo. The hotel is located about 8-15 minutes walk from 4 different metro stations, and hence 4 different metro lines. The only thing might be that the immediate area is a business office area so may not be the most happening at night, but there are some night spots around the area, especially Shimbashi where you can check out the local nightlife. Another slight improvement I would suggest is to feature a little more prominently their rooftop bar, maybe with a happy hour or something. It can be a little dead at night and that's a shame given the space's obvious potential.

We stayed at Andaz Toranomon 4 nights for leisure.Since hotel rooms in Japan are usually so small, so we searched for bigger names to make sure the rooms are nice, big and comfortable and we found Andaz by Hyatt!We were impressed by Andaz! The hotel is not located in the most busy location (in a commercial district), however close enough to most attractions by metro within 10-20 minutes.This is a new hotel opened in year 2014, it is stylish, clean, staff are polite and helpful and most important, the even we only stayed in a standard King bedroom, the room is big (50sqm) decorated with wooden floor, ceiling, toilet and a nice big bath. Andaz only occupy the top floors of an office tower. There are some nice restaurants and cafe inside the building, which I recommend you may try / take a look.I highly recommend this hotel for either business or leisure trip to Tokyo and will definitely return ourselves.

We really enjoyed our room in this hotel. Very large room, modern but traditional design, a lot of wood used, bathroom and vestibule very large but homey. Very pleasant and polite staff. Would stay here forever if not the price
