Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This hotel was awesome. It is very clean and modern. Staff are all very attentive and customer service oriented. Rooms are large and comfortable. The pool and fitness center are top notch (aside from the fact that the men's locker room does not contain a steam room while apparently the women's does). The breakfast buffet is very good, particularly the little nutella brioches. The rooftop bar has great views. There's a convenient mini market in the office building in which the hotel is located. The bell hops were very helpful. I would definitely stay here again.

I'm a big fan of the Andaz line and have stayed at both NYC Andaz properties before. I love the design and concept of Andaz and so was excited to try out the Andaz Tokyo. At first I was worried about the location and that it was geared towards business folks, but my stay turned out really well for our vacation.Check in was pretty quick and done over a communal table while we were served cappuccinos. I politely asked if there was a chance to get a room facing the Tokyo Tower, but the associate said it would be an upgrade with a fee. I declined.Our city view room still had nice views and I don't think it was a big deal because the next morning, it was a very cloudy/foggy day and you couldn't even see the tower so it worked out in the end. What I love about Andaz is their HUGE and beautifully designed bathrooms. The Bathroom space practically was the same size as the living/sleeping space which was already quite spacious. There was a great round tub in addition to a shower room. I love Japanese toilets in all their high-tech glory and wish the rest of the world would embrace the same! Another great feature of Andaz are the complimentary snacks and soft drinks in the mini bar which get refreshed daily. The snacks are local and are true treats and the soft drinks are abundant. We had an early morning check out so we unfortunately could not experience more of the facilities than we had hoped. We did a walk through of the pool and fitness center and it looked top notch. The Andaz vision is really great for those aesthetes that like to combine beautiful art and design with warm and inviting luxury without the highbrow haughtiness. I chose to stay at the Andaz instead of the Park Hyatt (which I'm also a fan of) because I thought the Andaz was more fresh and in line with my personality/vibe whereas I thought I would enjoy the PH more later in my life (hah!). Overall service was efficient and nice enough. Everyone was willing to help. The most helpful was the associate down near the entrance/taxi stand who helped us situate ourselves when we wanted to take the metro to Shibuya and Shinjuku, also making sure we had umbrellas in tow to weather the rain. The Toranomon station (Ginza line) was an easy peasy 5minute walk straight up out the door so very accessible to the rest of the city. My initial concerns of the location were totally unfounded and found it to be a nice respite to return to after a busy hectic run through the buzz of Shinjuku or Shibuya. I'd certainly stay here again in the future.

My wife, 16 year old son and I spent two weeks in Japan in late June, 2015. This was our fourth trip to Japan as a family and our first time staying at the Andaz Tokyo. We stayed at the Andaz for the last three nights of our trip (and we stayed at the Park Hyatt Tokyo for the first two nights of our trip - I'll post a separate review for the Park Hyatt).Upon arrival we wheeled our luggage from Shimbashi Station into the ground floor of the Toranomon Hills building and found the elevator to the Andaz (which occupies floors 47 - 52). We later discovered the covered arrival area where taxis pull in and out. I suspect if we had arrived at the property in that area, someone would have assisted us with our luggage. We're pretty much do it yourself travelers so we didn't mind at all. We checked in on the 51st floor, which acts as the Andaz lobby (although it's referred to as the Andaz Lounge). We were seated at a large table and offered refreshments while we checked in, which was a different approach for us - I really liked it!Our standard twin room was on the 48th floor and even with an extra rollaway bed there was enough room for luggage. The windows stretched from the floor to the ceiling, which made the view even more dramatic. The nightstand was equipped with a control panel that allowed you to turn all lights on and off and open and close the window shades. A Bose mini bluetooth speaker was provided which paired easily to our phones for music. The minibar was stocked with complimentary non-alcoholic beverages and a few complimentary snacks which we really appreciated. Items containing alcohol were also available, but not free.I really liked that free coffee and danish is available in the morning between 5am and 10am and free wine, sake and snacks are available between 6 - 8pm in the Andaz Lounge.It's a less than 15 minute walk to Shimbashi Station, which is on the JR Yamanote line, so it worked well as a launching point to almost anywhere in Tokyo. Toranomon Station (on the Ginza Line) is also an option and it's a little more than a 5 minute walk from the hotel. There are some decent, low cost dining options and convienence stores (conbini) on the way to Shimbashi Station.The gym facilities are great and it's equipped with the latest equipment. The infinity pool is somewhat small (more like a lap pool with two lanes) but it's really beautiful. Adjacent to the pool is a small carbonated pool, jacuzzi and a separate pool that contains different "stations" that offer a jacuzzi type massage for different areas of your body. During our first visit to the pool area, we ventured into the "outer" lane of the pool, which is closest to the window. The pool attendant quickly informed us that the outer lane was reserved for spa members and that hotel guests are to use the "inner" portion of the pool. My wife, son and I felt pretty self- conscious at this point and wondered out loud why there were no signs posted with this policy. Right about that time, we noticed the sign clearly stating the policy... oops. My son and I then ventured into the "onsen" section of the spa. The same pool attendant reminded us that no swimsuits were allowed (this time, no signs posted). There were a couple of other minor incidents that I'm not going to mention, but I guess what I'm saying is that on that first night, we felt a little uncomfortable and we weren't sure of what rules we were going to break next. Now for the good news: Early next morning (6 or 6:30am), I was in the Andaz Lounge when a gentleman asked how my stay was going. It turns out he was the General Manager of the hotel (Arnaud) and I related my experience of the previous evening to him. He patiently spoke with me for a few minutes, which I really appreciated. At around 8:30am (I was still in the lounge drinking coffee waiting for my family to wake up), Arnaud introduced me to the director of the Pool and Spa, Rachael. He had relayed my experience to Rachael and she sat with me to discuss them. I'm not sure that any changes will be made, but I really appreciated the fact that they both were willing to spend time out of their busy day to listen. I think one thing that could help - when they "check you in" at the spa entrance, they could ask you if this was your first time visiting the spa. If it is your first time (and it's not too busy), a quick tour of the facilities and a review of its policies might help visitors like us avoid the experience we had on our first night. I should add that once we got the policies down, we enjoyed the facilities immensely.I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel when visiting Tokyo. It will be our first choice when we return to Japan.Since the Park Hyatt and Andaz are at similar price points, I thought I'd list some observations:Location: About the same distance to walk to the JR Line (Park Hyatt to Shinjuku; Andaz to Shimbashi). The Toranomon subway (on the Ginza Line) is located a little more than a 5 minute walk from the Andaz as well. I found the neighborhood next to the Andaz to be more interesting, with several decent places to eat. Edge to the Andaz here.Rooms: The views from both rooms were similar, but the Andaz had windows from floor toceiling which we really liked. I thought the Park Hyatt room was more functional and the Aesop toiletries were great, but the Andaz had very modern, dramatic decor (although less space for luggage). The complimentary snacks and non-alcoholic beverages were great. Again, edge to the Andaz here.Hotel: Both hotels occupy the upper floors of a skyscraper so the concepts are similar. The free goodies in the Andaz Lounge throughout the day, were a big hit with my family. Big edge to the Andaz here.Service: I found the style of service to be quite different between these two hotels. The Park Hyatt service was always delivered efficiently, politely, and with a smile. The service at the Andaz is warmer, friendlier, and (although I'm too old to use the term) "hipper", which has its plusses and minuses. At times it helped put me at ease, other times it felt a little "forced". The staff appears to be younger and less experienced, but I never felt like there was a lack of effort. Both staffs are extremely attentive and we experienced the best service of any vacation we have ever taken. This category is highly subjective, but I preferred the "style" of service at the Park Hyatt.

The rooms are big, very modern and classy and have magificiant views of Tokyo from every room. The layout can be a bit confusing the first day as you would have to get back to the 52th floor where ever you want to go within the hotel. But you get used to it very quickly.The service is excellent. I stayed in the Andaz Amsterdam last year and I found Andaz Tokyo is more formal. It is probably because it is Tokyo.Food is good too. The buffet breakfast is probably one of the best breakfasts I have ever had.If you want a hotel where everything is there for you when you walk out of the lobby, then Andaz Tokyo is not for you. It is 10 minutes walk to the nearest station and there is really nothing intersting around the hotel. Then on the other hand you are compensarted by the quiet and serenity once you get into the hotel and your room.All Andaz have a common area where the guests can have free tea and coffee.It can get a bit cramp and noisy especially at Happy Hours.To summarise in a few words, Great experience, Enjoyable and highly recommended.I'll certainly be back.

Such an amazing hotel - location is wonderful. The rooms are amazing and thoughtful touches everywhere. The bathing complex is like nothing I have seen before. Really a wonderful place to stay. The staff are very helpful.

Truly stellar. Probably the nicest place I've ever stayed. Large gym, beautiful views. All the amenities you could hope for and certainly the most lovely of toilets. The location isn't ideal to walk to the interesting parts of the city but is a close taxi or subway ride.
user_name:
Emily B
San Francisco, United States

review_body: The service is extremely helpful, probably the second best service of any hotel that I have been to. From the bell boy to the from desk, all of the hotel staff are there to help you and for the most part exceeded my exceptions. The hotel itself is very nice and modern. The rooms are large and well organized and the room has huge windows that overlook the city from 50 floors up. There is a lot of room to work and to lounge around the room.The sushi bar was very good and the staff there is very welcoming. In addition, the hotel is pretty convenient if you are taking taxi. If you are taking the train, it is not as convenient. The closest stations is the Toranomon station which is about 10 minutes from the hotel and the only line at that station is the Ginza line. However, the taxi, though expensive, was very easy to catch and quite fast.I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone.

The Tokyo location of this new Hyatt top of the market brand hotel is an island of serenity in the middle of older central Tokyo. The hotel occupies six floors in the now tallest building in Tokyo in the Toranomon neighborhood. The interiors are very Zen like as a result of a spare decor using extensive amounts of wood contrasted with while walls and limited artwork. The guest rooms are located on floors below the lobby, which can be confusing. To enter or exit the hotel you must first go to the 51st lobby floor and then transfer to other elevators that access the guest room floors on the four floors below. The rooms are spacious and the bathroom is compartmentalized with special sections for the vanity and sink, toilet, shower and bath, and dressing area and closet. Amenities and furnishings are top of the line. We ate breakfast each day in the Tavern restaurant. The buffet was excellent with a wide variety of interesting selections of Japanese and western items. Portions are small, but that is good because you want to try everything. The mini-custom made omelets were quite good, as were the small bottles of Birchler muesli. Staff throughout the hotel was very helpful, friendly and courteous, but perhaps a little too formal. But their excellent training was obvious in the way they handled everything. My wife loved the simple elegance of the decor, while I found it a bit sterile. Yet, we definitely highly recommend this hotel for a small facility in the heart of the city for those who enjoy luxury accommodations.

The hotel's layout is a little confusing, but everything else was very nice. The staff is extremely helpful and they work very hard to make sure you are happy. Rooms are beautiful and windows give you a great view of different parts of Tokyo. You are about 3/4 of a mile from the Imperial Palace, which is a great place to walk or run. It is also very convenient to most parts of the city.

As other reviewers have noted, Andaz is a bit different from other hotels. Set high atop an office building in Toranomon Hills, the hotel is not immediately close to most attractions, or even directly adjacent to rail or subway - but the feel of the hotel is amazing. Luxurious rooms with floor-to-ceiling views of Tokyo! A terrific restaurant upstairs, as well as BeBu downstairs.The service is incomparable, on par with the finest hotels in the world. Oh, and the beds were luxurious, which seems rare in Japan.

The room is somewhat overly-done but some of the art pieces are nice. I absolutely love the Japanese paper crafts in the lift! The reception staff are attentive and nice but the boys at the entrance has no smile.. Great for leisure, not for business.

For those that don't know, Andaz has a different feel than Hyatt's other luxury brands. It's not for everyone, but I love it. As for the Andaz Tokyo, I love it. Location isn't super convenient, but within walking distance to a few different stations so it's not the worst. Room was very clean, efficient, comfortable, spacious and luxurious. Staff was great, friendly and beyond helpful. Pool and workout room is fantastic and offers great views. The food at breakfast was delicious and one of my favorite in Tokyo hotels. Also, the burger place on the ground floor was probably one of the best burgers I've ever had (and I've had quite a few "gourmet" burgers. Very happy with the hotel and hope to stay here again soon!

This hotel has got it all. The room decor is fantastic with the highest quality contemporary fixtures. The service is fantastic. The food quality is great. They have a lap pool 37 stories above Tokyo. The views are spectacular. The location is great. This hotel is absolutely flawless. If you like a modern contemporary place with all the latest technology in a zen type setting, with the highest level of service, this place has got it all. After staying at the Andaz Tokyo, this is now my favorite hotel in all of Tokyo.
user_name:
Jeremy G
Miami Beach, United States

review_body: Excellent hotel with superb facilities and service. Staff were outstanding. Room service limited though. The location is very good in a posh though business and government area. Property less than 1 year old.

Very stylish and classy boutique hotel. The room was beautiful mixing classic and modern design. Incredible view from the room (50th floor), the restaurant, swimming pool and the rooftop bar. We stayed there for 6 days and had the opportunity to try all the amenities: great gym, amazing pool (where you can actually do lines), smaller hot and warm baths also available to relax. I had a fantastical massage at the spa and the exclusive 8 seat sushi bar is not to be missed. Breakfast buffet was opulent offering a great mix of European and Japanese options. The location was perfect to do sight seeing. The hotel was a short metro ride from everywhere which was extremely convenient.

Warm welcome, a stylish and functional room - often a hard combination to achieve. Good food choices in the Tavern and great breakfast. Well equipped gym and great location for getting about. The Nespresso machine in the room a great touch.

Taken a while to get round to this. We stayed here late May and were very impressed. It's cool chic design, friendly and accommodating staff and impressive views. You're staying in the tallest skyscraper in Tokyo first of all, so access to reception is by elevator, all the way to the 51st floor. The accommodation is then accessed by another elevator, which takes you down to the rooms. We were staying on the 49th floor. On entering the room you're met with a full size panoramic window looking out over Tokyo. In our room, a sofa ran right across the window, so you sit and watch the world go by. Amazing!! The room is large by Japanese standards, with a well appointed bath/shower room. Don't miss the roof top bar, it's a must visit. Would we stay here again? Yes without hesitation

If you plan to spend a lot of time in your room, this hotel is perfect. The long bench sofa along the window, the two tables, the open closet - it all works (though the sofa is a bit low for the high work table). However, with the lobby on the top floor, it's always a challenge to remember to hit up when you want to go to the lobby. Also, while there are some restaurants and cafes in the complex, there isn't a whole lot around the hotel, unless you walk to Shiodome (about 10 minutes away). The gym is not bad, but not much room for stretching/other exercises.

The hotel is has many little Japanese style design and decoration all around the room and the common area, which makes all the stay pretty much like an indulgent of art. The room is definitely clean, bed is comfy, and we enjoy the tranquil atmosphere in side the room. The view in the room is also a plus! Breakfast is excellent with basic choices but delicate flavours and fresh fruits which includes some high-price fruits that I have never seen in other hotels. Staff are all professional and helpful. We asked a front desk staff to help us to book a seat in a Japanese restaurant because we couldn't speak Japanese. He was nice to do so. The location may not be a up-side because walking is needed (at least 10 mins) before we can reach to major train stations, so taxi will be a good choice. Its near Tokyo tower. And its not quite near shopping area but it will give a superb relaxing stay from the hustle and bustle city life.

Andaz Toranomon Hills has found a perfect balance between clean contemporary design and a casual approach in hospitality while maintaining five star standards. Everything is top notch, every single detail.One thing I was reflecting on after my star is the value of the stay. The place is pricey, but it offers so many complimentary amenities that it is somehow a great deal. Free local phone calls, wine, sake and bites in the afternoon are a great touch and soft drinks in the minibar are all included. There is also an espresso machine that makes surprisingly good espresso -also complimentary- and robes -japanese style sandals and all- and other luxurious amenities... delightful. I absolutely loved the Andaz I cannot wait to come back, which as a Platinum Hyatt member might happen soon as I noticed award night are available more often that at the Grand Hyatt. ps. Don't miss the rooftop bar!

Excellent staff and the rooms are super. Good location for business and connecting to train stations. Easy walk to several sights. Cannot get much better views than from the rooftop bar or the restaurant.

Because I arrived just after an earthquake, it is not said that I let you check in immediately. The instruction of the employee was the only worst. At first is an emergency elevator after around one hour was kept waiting in the first-floor cafe; to the 51st floor. Because there was not the instruction by the voice, people who did not know it lined up in a stream. The employee should derive it aloud. In addition, I moved to the room by a service elevator. You should tell a staying floor the place of the normal elevator upon arrival (you lost your way at the time of check-out). In addition, however, there was not the explanation of the emergency exit and became uneasy just after an earthquake.

I stay at the Andaz quite often on my monthly trips to Tokyo. Staff is amazing. The views are breathtaking looking out to the Palace or the Tokyo Tower. Close to the subway. The restaurant has contemporary and Japanese cuisine. Staff are amazing and they are the best part of the stay. The gym and the pool - entice you to break out of the jet lag.

My wife and I was very happy to choose the Andaz hotel because the room was very pleasing and staffs were also very helpful. They provide the water and soft drink free and that make us very happy even though it was not much money. The location of the hotel was not very convenient because the subway was not very close. But view from the hotel was the best!
user_name:
Eunsung W
San Diego, United States

review_body: Stayed 6 nights there for business/leisure. Although Andaz is the boutique-styled brand under Hyatt, the qualities of service and room of this Andaz is on par with a Grand Hyatt hotel. The difference is simplicity, from the overall hotel design to reception to guest rooms, it tried to give guests more for less. The hotel is placed on the top 6 floors of a high-rise office building in Tokyo, so it obviously provides us a very good view of Tokyo (my room could see the Tokyo Bay and the Imperial Palace). The hardware is nice. Rooms are modernly decorated and spacious. Another nice novelty with this hotel is guests can have free minibar beverage and snacks. The staff are quite courteous proficient in English. Most of them came out of their ways to help guests as they helped me make lots of restaurant reservations. Location is somewhat convenient. 5-10 mins walk from Toranomon Station and another 10 mins more to Shinbasin Station. Ginza station (one of the hubs in Tokyo) is only two stations away from Toranomon St. One thing to nitpick though, getting around the hotel is quite confusing for clients who patron the first time as the directions inside the property are often not clear enough. Overall, a very good hotel.

We ended our Asia trip here. It's reasonably easy to reach from the metro system and very quick to get to Haneda by taxi. The hotel is at the top of the skyscraper and accessed by a super fast lift. Entering the lobby you realise this is the heart of the hotel, check in is at one of the hand carved tables along with a chilled drink. It is quite informal but cool and stylish. At one end of the lobby is an amazing vista of the Tokyo tower and the other end has a lounge which was always full of a mainly Japanese but international crowd enjoying cocktails. The room was one of the best I have ever stayed in, I could live there! everything is well chosen and high standard, from the super HD tv to the bose sound system, a sumptuous bed with electronic curtains and a complimentary mini-bar. The bath robes and Japanese dressing gown was so good I wanted to steal it (but I resisted). Being japan the toilet has a heated seat and electronic functions, e.g. the lid opens at night as you move towards it. The bathroom has a huge round onset style bath and there is a massive shower in a separate space. The walls can be re-configured to create openness or privacy. The amenities were nicely packaged and a dressing area joins the bathroom. You absolutely must make use of the spa it is sensational, the pool looks out onto Tokyo and is super clean and quiet, there is also a massage jet pool and after bathing massage chairs. This is a new kind of hotel experience - and I hope I get the opportunity to try other Hyatt Andaz properties - for me it was perfect.

Great two night stay at the new Andaz. Although the layout is not that practical, it is beautifully decorated and the rooms have superb views of Tokyo. Rooms are decent size for Tokyo standards and well equipped. Just missed the complimentary bottle of water. Bathrooms are large and nicely done.Nice indoor pool and gym. Roof terrace / bar is worth a visit, although unfortunately not without a roof. Excellent service.

Wow this hotel is so beautiful ... The hotel has such a beautiful view of Tokyo. Service is excellent , rooms are beautiful . We held a business conference here and the conference room also as a great view of Tokyo & Tokyo tower. We could even see Mt. Fuji.

The hotel and staff provided a memorable first time to Japan-with helpful staff for directions and also a great restaurant to dine in..The valet staff was helpful and friendly during the stay..Highly reccommend this property

Expect everything that a 5* hotel offers and Andaz will surpass your expectation! It is a beautiful hotel with outstanding service. From the moment you reach the lobby, you're treated like an old friend or a family member. Reception is warm and welcoming. You'll be offered refreshments while checking in. The room is very well designed and furnished, super clean and large with a spectacular view (rooms are located on the 47-50 floor.) I really love the round shaped deep Japanese style bathtub, Ofuro.Service is impeccable overall. The location is great though a bit of a walk from subway Toranomon and JR Shimbashi stations. There are millions of restaurants, izakayas, and bars near Shimbashi Station, which is an exciting place to roam around at night. I am super picky when it comes to hotels, but I can honestly say that the Andaz is nearly perfect.

This hotel was exactly my style. 5 star luxe, but with an indigenous, unique touch.The design incorporates unexpected, quirky details, without sacrificing any of the comforts or functions one expects of a top-tier international hotel. Clever and cool, but approachable. The room design was interesting without feeling like it was trying too hard (like a W for comparison). The common areas in the hotel were also interesting and well done, without feeling like were trying to be different for the sake of being different. A subtle differentiation, but one I appreciate.With views out to Mt Fuji (on a clear morning) one way, Tokyo Tower out the other, and the bay from the rooftop bar, you're never left wanting for something to look at.We ate breakfast in the Tavern one day, and in-room the other. Both were excellent. The buffet in the Tavern was of typically high quality and variety found in good Asian hotels. I could sit and eat breakfast there all day!The pool facilities were extremely nice. Expansive views from the lap pool, and common soaking tubs. Some fun hydrotherapy to help regenerate after a long day walking the city. The one thing I didn't love, is that locals can purchase memberships to use the pool facilities. So one day while I was attempting to do some morning laps, there were a couple guys there who must have thought they were training for the Olympics, doing the butterfly stroke, splashing about, racing each other. Not exactly conducive to guests' quiet enjoyment. Especially with only two lanes in the pool. The other several times I used the facilities, however, I was the only one, and very much enjoyed myself.The service throughout the hotel was tremendous. This is Japan we're talking about, so service tends to be pretty uniformly good, especially in a luxury hotel. But I felt the staff was not only eager and energetic, but they seemed genuinely invested in us getting the most out of our stay. Helpful and smiling, giving us good recommendations, always having answers to our endless questions. Service is the cornerstone of a good hotel, and these guys nailed it.I thought the location was great as well. Near good subway lines, and walking distance to several attractions. Nothing was ever too far away for a cheap subway ride, or a relatively inexpensive cab ride. Well, except for Narita, but that's a Tokyo-wide issue.Can't wait to visit the Andaz Tokyo again!

My husband and I love this hotel. We will definitely return when we go back to Tokyo. Spectacular views from the room, excellent staff service, extremely attentive to customers' needs. Gym and rooftop bars are great places to hang out.

The staff is really kind and helpful, breakfast is great, rooms are peaceful and very comfortable, well thought. Good situation. I travel a lot and generally do not like hotels in big towers, but this was one of my best hotel experiences in a big city .Many thanks!

Please believe every positive review that reports that Andaz Tokyo is absolutely amazing! Rather than echo their superlatives, I will share a story of the extraordinary service of a lovely young woman, Mau, who is a Team Leader in the Tavern. In addition to enjoying an excellent dinner, we were able to get to know her, talking about her upcoming vacation to Andaz New York, where we have stayed. We mentioned we were checking out the next day, and she asked if we would be there for breakfast. She found us the next morning, and presented me with an sweet origami she had made that morning. I was so touched - a special souvenir and wonderful memory.

Located in the TORANOMON HILLS BLDG. where had been born in just a year ago as a new landmark of TOKYO central area. You can be amezed to find an aproach to the hotel entrance at the first time since the bldg itself has complexed structure. Also you would face similar maze-like situations through the entrance to the door of your room. This causes by a design philosophy of ANDAZ. Once you are in your room, everything is very fine. You can see dramatic views of Tokyo metropolis, which even Tokyo residents can not see. Beautiful ! If you would like to spend some luxious time in Tokyo, I recommend to stay here.

This is definitely the best Andaz, and one of the best hotels I've ever stayed.Beautifully designed, rich in details and luxury. Maintained in pristine conditions.Excellent service with very attentive staff, but provided in quite a discreet way.Amazing, creative breakfast buffet felt like you were ordering of a menu...with enough changes daily to make it feel different.The views are breathtaking from every angle and you can't get used to them.Big spacious well equipped gym with high ceilings.Great pool. For us it totally made our trip to Tokyo.

The Hotel is situated on top of the highest skyscraper in Tokyo (being in the 6 top floors of Toranomon Hills Mori Tower). Style: The concept of this hotel is quite casual, which I personally like very much. Other ppl. who prefer old institution like luxury hotels, might have a different view on this. Pros: - Unbelievable views of Tokyo Tower and also the Imperial Garden and Shiodome - Rooms are really big with a fresh mix of Asian design with some western influences - Bathroom has a nice layout combination of shower and really big circular bath tube- The place is very quite and the area is a bit off the usual tourist centers in tokyo (this is good if you want to have a calm stay and know where to go)- staff is very friendly - The Sky Garden on the top floor is an unreal place (however you need to ask at the bar to get access) I really don't understand why they don't use this for a restaurant, which would be absolutely stunning Cons:- limited restaurant choices in the hotel (However the breakfast was superbe)- its a little walk to the subway (about 10 minutes) - due to the height of the building you may be uncomfortable thinking about earthquakes

There were so many great things about this hotel - the service, the views, the rooms - that it is difficult to know where to begin! From the moment we arrived, the staff made us feel entirely comfortable and at ease, and were enormously helpful in helping us to navigate Tokyo and giving us tips on what to do and where to go (it was our first time in the country). We came here for our honeymoon and when we informed the staff, we were given a free upgrade. The hotel itself is beautiful, and the views of the city are unparalleled. To take full advantage of the views, I would really recommend going to the rooftop restaurant, where the food was excellent. Another great feature was the fact that the minibar was complimentary and restocked everyday - it was just a small but lovely part of the overall feeling of hospitality within this hotel. I would really recommend this hotel and cannot wait to return.

This was my 6th trip to Japan, and I have stayed in a range of accommodations - from ryokans, to 5-star luxury; even my friend's living room floor! To date, the Andaz has been my greatest hotel stay in Japan. Big call? Try it, and you won't be disappointed!This is a new hotel. Opened less than a year ago, it's still gleaming. Asking some of the locals for directions was a little misleading, as they didn't know of the hotel. How could they miss it? It's the tallest building in the area, but there is very little signage, with nothing on the building itself. Even directional signs around the ground floor plaza only mentioned "Hotel". I could only find one small "Andaz" sign in front of the ground floor cafe and bar.Once you find the entrance, the bellhop will direct you to the elevators - taking you to the 51st floor lobby.As is the Andaz style, there's no check-in desk. You will be welcomed to sit at a large table, offered complimentary non-alcoholic drinks and snacks. Relax, sign in to the free WiFi, and the staff member will organise the check-in and room keys. You can return to this area, for complimentary snacks and non-alcoholic drinks, at any time during your stay.Our rooms were actually 2 levels below the lobby level, on the 49th floor. This equates to an amazing view of Tokyo city.We had two interconnecting rooms for our family of five. Our three children in one room; my wife and I in the other. Biggest rooms I have ever stayed in - in Japan. The two rooms made it comparable to a suite, but you get double the amenities! That is, 2 Nespresso machines, 2 huge bathrooms, 2 complimentary mini-bars....what?! That correct, all non-alcoholic beverages and snacks in the mini-bar are free of charge.I must mention the most technically advaanced toilet I have ever experienced. Don't have to touch the seat, as it raises/lowers automatically. Fully adjustable bidet, and heated everything. You won't want to stand up.Super comfortable bed, with block out shades on the massive windows. You will want to admire the view at night - just beautiful.Buffet breakfast was fantastic value and the best quality. With our three children, I only paid for one, and that was half price. Great selection and tastes.I could not fault this place. I remember looking around, at the hip and swanky lobby area; then seeing my 8 year old son skate past in his roller-shoes. Being with my happy family, in cool, luxurious surroundings is how I always want to travel.

Stayed here for seven nights. Super helpful staff, personalized service, great modern and sophisticated vibe but NOT cold and pretentious. Good sleep every night, spacious for standard room (and by Japan standard), nice quiet neighbourhood ... I don't think I can fault this hotel in any way!I will definitely come back and for now this would be my hotel of choice whenever I come over to Tokyo. I love, love, love this place!!

This place is amazing! Staff knows perfect English, rooms are huge and very luxurious, free mini bar and coffee at the lounge. View is amazing.Very expensive though and a bit far from public transport.

Been to the Bar a few times as a friend frequents staying at the Andaz and I can safely say that you will not be disappointed. The Barmen are all knowledgeable and the drinks list extensive. What strikes most is the friendliness of all staff- Barmen, GM's, F&B Managers, anyone and everyone. Well Done guys.

We were greeted by a very friendly receptionist and given a drink whilst we were waiting to check in. The room wasn't ready, so we left our luggage with them and went shopping and they rang when it was.We had a gorgeous corner room (5007) with very smart decor in white/dark wood with floor to ceiling windows and fantastic views over Tokyo Bay and the Imperial Palace. There was a kettle, coffee machine, three-seater sofa and large table and lots of storage space. The fridge had complimentary soft drinks. The wood-panelled bathroom came with a Toto WC, a round and deep bath and a separate rain shower plus a normal shower. WiFi was free and very fast, and there were sockets next to the bed, together with controls for the lights and electric blinds.The hotel offers free wine and canapés in lobby between 6 & 8pm every night, which is a really nice touch. We also ate breakfast in the hotel's Pastry shop, which was lovely and very reasonable, and ate in Bebu, which was also good.

This is by far an away a phenomenal hotel. The service is top notch through and through, rooms are absolutely gorgeous and tastefully designed. Many people comment on the location- true the immediate area is not bustling, but you are very short taxi ride from roppongi or shibuya. Subway stops are 5 min walk away. Location is great in my humble opinion. Great Spa and gym, pool is phenomenal too. The staff here goes out of their way to be helpful, and the concierge is spot on with their tips and recommendations. This hotel has all of the class of the Mandarin Oriental, and a touch more style. If you are looking for a 5 start experience, look no further.

Andaz is one of the newest hotel in the Tokyo luxury segment. The location is fine but a little isolated. There is not anything interesting close by to explore if you want have a stroll or just a simile walk. Hotel occupies the last floors of the toranomon Hills. View is great. My room was facing Tokyo tower but the bar and the taver offered a spectacular view of Tokyo too.The service maybe needs a little improvment. I found check out very slow and breakfast in the morning luckying of professionality.Room was very nice. A good mix of japanese tradition and modernity. Wood, calm colours, big shower, everything you expect in a great asian hotel

Fantastic Hotel! From the moment you enter the hotel on the 51st floor, the views are amazing! The rooms are spacious and well appointed with all the latest amenities.The fitness Center and pool area is the entire floor. Amazing Hotel!

Hyatt did a pretty good job executing on the Andaz Tokyo. The hotel is modern and hip without trying too hard. Rooms are quite nice but not on par with the Mandarin or the Four Seasons in Tokyo, however the facilities are exceptional. Bar upstairs (lobby level) is great, quite relaxing and amazing views of Tokyo, the gym, pool and spa level are stunning.The area is not known to be bustling but had enough going for it when we wanted to stay local. Would recommend the Andaz.

Stayed here recently for 4 nights in a standard King. Was a bit difficult to navigate to the 51st floor to check in as there isn't any staff to greed us on the G/F, so I ask the security guard instead for direction. But we were greeted by very friendly staff and the whole check in process quick and easy. The room is clean, tidy and neat. Simple modern design which I always love. I'm very happy that the bath room got a good sized tub to let me relax in at the end of the day. The bed and pillow is very comfortable. Its definitely one of the best hotel I visited, highly recommended. The location will make you think twice at first, as it is away from the major shopping district (e.g. shinjuku) but there are several train/metro stations with in 6-10 mins walk away, is within acceptable distance, I've no trouble getting around Tokyo.

The hotel is beautiful and the staff are very friendly. City view from the room is amazing. Large elegant Japanese motif room. Big tub and full feature shower. Minibar in room is free except alcohol. Complimentary snacks, tea and espresso in room. The pool, spa and gym are first rate. A few blocks walk to subway and local food/ drink establishments. One of the staff, Owen, went out of his way to help us with some trip planning. This is a great new hotel. Good home base to explore Tokyo.

I have never stayed at a "boutique hotel" before, but having stayed at a variety of Hyatt properties and the mostly positive experiences, I decided to give Andaz a try. And I am so glad that I did! From the moment we arrived at the lobby (which is not on the first floor, must take an elevator to arrive at lobby level - 51F), we were warmly greeted by the staff and they took us to a table with a comfortable sofa. This I have never experienced before and I was very pleasantly surprised by this "new" concept of checking guests in. I have gotten so accustomed to standing at the front desk, handing my passport over and wait for my room keys. The staff at Andaz politely greeted us after they sat us down, and asked if we would like something to drink while taking our passports and credit card to check us in. The entire process was smooth and very thoughtful. Our room had the view of the Tokyo Bay and can I say that the room made me want to turn my vacation to a staycation? Similar to Grand Hyatt, the housekeeping staff did a great job at making sure that all of the toiletries are replenished and that we walk into the room feeling like when we first checked in each day. Also unlike the traditional hotels, the snacks and non-alcoholic beverage in the minibar came free! This may not seem like a big deal but having stayed at many luxury hotels, it is really the small details that keep bringing guests back time after time.The pool was relatively large - 20m, and came with a great view of Tokyo. Beside the pool there was also a carbonated whirlpool and a hot tub. In the change room, there were massage chairs (just like in Grand Hyatt Tokyo!). We also visited the lounge at night and enjoyed the breathtaking view there with romantic candles and live music. The non-alcoholic beverage selection was good, and the smoothie tasted great.Location-wise, Andaz is situated near Shinbashi station. It is within walking distance to Chuo, Ginza (about 30 minutes), and takes about 10 minutes to walk to JR Shinbashin station. But unlike the Peninsula, it is not located right next to a subway station. This didn't bother us at all as we visited in March when the weather was mild and warm, and we really enjoy walking!Last but not least - the pastry shop on the first floor! It had the best shortbread cookies I have ever had in a long time. Try the buckwheat cookies and they will not disappoint you. The pastry shop also has a large selection of eclairs with flavours ranging from sakura to burnt caramel with hazelnut. Overall, I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel to anyone travelling to Tokyo, and will definitely return to this property on my next visit!

This new hotel is beautiful. The welcome was very special and the staff could not do enough to make our stay special. We received unique recommendations for what to do and the staff were particulary able to help me with cool places and areas for my 12 year old daughter. Walking distance to the metro , and imperial palace

Nice hotel and in a business location but i still could walk five minutes to all the nice places to eat and drink. The hotel is new so not to worry about any issues with that. Style is simple and woody with a hip single lounge and a nice bar cafe and main restaurant. Overall a great hotel and helpful staff too. I still prefer the Park Hyatt in Tokyo, but for a change this was perfect. Oh and a cool bar on the roof top, don't forget to check that out,.

Great hotel, great location, great staff, great amenities, great rooms, great service, on and on. This hotel is tough to beat. I would stay here again without hesitation. This hotel is similar to other Andaz hotels, consistent theme and service.

We were blown away by the beauty, service and elegance of the Tokyo Andaz. Less than a year old, ten Andaz is already competing with the Aman and Four Seasons for personalized, gracious stays for its guests. Upon arrival we were greated by the GM who gave us a drink, a tour and and thoughtful tips for our stay. It felt like he was focusd only on us, and gave insigt into the relaxed, thoughtful, friendly and first class vibe of the staff. The rooms are unusually large, fresh, comfortable and all have amazing views from the top floors of the Torronomon Hills tower. Don't miss the spa and swimming pool. A huge, infinity pool,with many hot baths in nooks. The excessive room is brand new with everything you would need We had breakfast each morning at the Andaz Tavern. Perfect! Delicisiois fresh baked pastries, made to order omeletts, fruit, smoked salmon etc,.. I could go on and on! Better than th Patk Hyatt, Aman or anything else around!
user_name:
David W
San Francisco, United States

review_body: Gorgeous hotel room with fantastic view. Business location with no shopping nearby, but close to Metro Station (about 5-10 mins walk). The Tokyo Tower view is amazing. Pricey but very worth to stay!!!

I have stayed in several Tokyo business hotels over the years. This one is by far the best, in fact I would say it ranks as among the best hotels I have stayed in anywhere. The rooms are large and come with a full Japanese bath, they are soundproof to the extreme, teh food is good at any time of day and the facilities very elegant. Highly recommended.

We stayed at this awesome hotel during the cherry blossom week. Like all the other Andaz properties, it is sleek, modern, and elegant. We had a tower view room that was spacious and comfortable, decorated with the localized flavor and a modern clean look. The front lounge staff were very helpful with suggestions, recommendations, and information. I think the Wailea Andaz is their best site, and I've been comparing the other Andaz's I've stayed at to that, and this Tokyo property is the one I think definitely comes close or matches it. Only downside to this hotel now is that the Toranomon area is pretty quiet in general, but it is convenient by 10-20 min walk or Ginza subway line to most of the major tourist areas.
user_name:
kuor2010
New York City, New York

review_body: I was lucky enough to stay here on business during the cherry blossom season this year, and could not have wished for a more luxurious and modern hotel. The staff were highly trained, the approach was modern and contemporary, yet totally Japanese in efficiency, and they remembered me immediately every time.I felt thoroughly pampered from the moment I arrived, and made the most of the incredible pool and gym area - the finish and quality of materials here and throughout the hotel was second to none, and the rooms were excellent - even the smaller spec had nespresso machine, free drinks and rice crackers/chocolates, excellent wifi throughout and stunning Bose Soundlink Mini bluetooth speakers in the rooms (loved it so much I ordered one for when I got home!). Nothing but compliments and admiration for this hotel - it is very expensive, but you really do get what you pay for!

Stayed here for a week, and I am leaving very impressed!!! The hotel itself is absolutely stunning, great views, beautiful interiors and the rooms are extremely spacious for Tokyo. I could live here!!!!The breakfast was great, but wouldn't recommend lunch or dinner here - sorry!No room tips - seems every colleagues had a terrific room. Hope to come back soon!

This hotel is an amazing addition. Even the basic room category provides for absolutely stunning views, a spacious, well designed and well thought through experience. The gym and sauna are equally brilliant - everything in this hotel has an amazing cosmopolitan yet pure vibe. I went up to the bar and can only imagine how great this must be during summer time- we could only sit inside in March.

One of the best 5 stars I have stayed at. Class, Modern, a warm atmosphère where wood suround you, and at the same time the feeling of being in a Boutique hotel. A pure image of what Jpanan is: modern, zen but at the same time very active in a subtle way. Without the contradiction of Japan! ;)A Team fully dedicated to its customers!! With the Shanghai Andez Team, the best two 'Concierge' team I ever had, eventhought no one at the Andaz bear the title of Concierge!!

We stayed at the Andaz for 6 nights. The hotel is new, clean, modern and sleek. If you don't like the contemporary minimal style then this hotel may not not impress, but for us it was spot on. The room was large by Tokyo standards, comfortable with all the amenities we needed, a spacious walk-in shower plus soaking tub, a desk area with a 9 foot sofa plus the amazing view. The hotel gym is good (access included) with a bank of aerobic and resistance machines, some free weights and a small smith cage. The immediate area is a business district but don't let that scare you off, we found local spots to eat (non-English speaking though), a laundromat and multiple subway stops within a 5-15 minute walk. We walked from the hotel to the Imperial Palace area in less than 20 minutes I believe. The highlight of our visit, though, was our interactions with the hotel staff. Most speak English and helped us throughout our stay (and prior) with recommendations, directions and reservations -- don't be afraid to utilize them for anything. Especially notable were the servers at both the bars in the restaurant and the top floor lounge. After 6 days they were our friends giving us local tips. Oh, and they know how to make American-style cocktails that seem to be difficult to come by when away from the states. Our only disappointment would be the restaurants in the shopping complex of the associated Toranomon Hills building. Overall the Andaz is highly recommended and would be our first choice on our next visit to Tokyo.

This hotel was great and is in more or less a neighborhood. It is in walking distance of many temples and shrines too. If you get a room facing Tokyo Tower you will be in for a treat at all times of the day. I suggest taking multiple pics as the sun is setting. It is great.

I live in Tokyo actually stayed here twice for my friends visiting end of last year and my birthday treat. Love the Spa, swimming pool and fitness facilities. As it wasn't busy the staff were very kind and chatted with me. The equipment is very up-to-date as I like to stream Youtube playlist when I work out. They also seem to have Personal Trainers if you want to have some guided training, did not make use of weekend yoga lesson but they have been promoting it a lot (definitely, next time!).Room design was flawless and it would not go out of trend any soon as they incorporate several Japanese elements into the interior. There are delicious sweets for guests to enjoy and lovely turndown service by three housekeeping staff so I totally felt pampered even though I did mess the room much. ^^Came to Lobby Lounge (Tavern?) for quick tea time once, but this was the 4th visit to the Rooftop Bar with my group of friends for some birthday drinks to celebrate after our dinner. Was quoted with some charge for tables which was new to me as I did not know about this in previous visits (I often bring friends who visit Tokyo for drinks here as the cocktails are awesome, they also serve quality cigars). The Bar Manager and Head Bartender Warren (a very nice, talented person whom I got to know in a different occasion) were not there so I did not bother to argue with the staff and just stood outside for other friends to smoke (it was pretty chilly and windy that night). After 20 min of negotiation by another friend, the staff finally let our party sit down in the sofa inside. I guess hiccups like this can be easily avoided by stating the charges clear on the website like Park Hyatt Tokyo does or by the receptionist (which was not manned by anyone that day).Overall I always had a relaxing time at the hotel, and probably staying there again in April with another visiting friend. We will see.

Stayed here for 3 nights, check in area located at the 51 floor. Once you come out of the elevator you will see the beautiful wood through out the walls, unique furniture, high ceilings and spectacular views of Tokyo.The rooms are spacious, modern, great amenities, spacious bathrooms, round tubs and a ceiling shower head. It's consider one of the top hotels in Tokyo, it's very new hotel, their first anniversary is coming up, still few customer service details to be fixed but overall recommended!!

read such lovely reviews about the hotel on this website. was also recommended by a friend who said he had read about this hotel in a magazine. truly, the design is indeed spectacular, from the point of arrival to the hotel rooms and even the toiletries. definitely top of the range. there was nothing not to like, except I probably should have booked a slightly larger room as the standard room was just a tad small. tried to speak to the hotel to allow me to pay in order to upgrade to a bigger room but was told that they are running at high occupancy. the major letdown about this hotel is the service. from the moment of check in till check out, the service i got was cold, brisk and impersonal. such a pity, because the design of the hotel exuded so much warmth. the check in staff couldn't even be bothered to escort me up to the room to explain the amenities and was just a tad condescending. check out was equally poor, the staff too harassed to even smile. cant say i will stay here again. location was alright, just don't expect to find lots of food nearby.

Tokyo has some of the best hotels in the world. Having previously stayed at some of the top properties in the city, I was still presently surprised at what the Andaz had to offer. Sitting on the top floors of the brand new tallest tower in the city (Toranomon hills) the Andaz offers absolutely spectacular panoramic views of all of Tokyo from every room and from the magnificent restaurant/lobby floor. The hotel is beautifully designed with perfect service throughout, and of course the signature Andaz qualities (free food in the lobby, free drinks and snacks in your room) which set it apart from other high-end Tokyo hotels. The washroom is huge, the lights have useful physical buttons (great for hitting the master switch at night), and the toiletries of high quality.The amenities are second to none. With quite possibly the most beautiful hotel pool in the world, the Tokyo Andaz's 37th floor pool, gym and spa facilities are absolutely spectacularly designed, jam packed with features and the newest work-out equipment and with a view to kill for.Considering the price was also half that of the Ritz Carleton/Shangri-La/Pennisula/Four Seasons it was definitely worth it.The only caveat is the location. It is not directly located off any transit line, but it is a close (800m) walk away from multiple train/subway stations so altogether not too bad.

This hotel is new and modern. My room has upgraded to the top suite. The room is huge with a 180 degree spectacular view. I was amazed seeing the day and night view of Tokyo tower. However I was not happy the cafe at the lobby do not serve anything at 11am because lunch hasn't started and breakfast has finished. We got nowhere to go but outside the building. The location is ok although not a walkable distance to Ginza nor Tokyo station.

My husband and I stayed at the Andaz Tokyo for 4 nights at the beginning of a trip to Japan and 2 nights at the end. We arrived very early in the morning to Tokyo and despite the early hour and a very busy hotel (it was the tail end of Chinese New Year) were able to check in to our room within an hour or so of arriving at the hotel. The hotel is beautiful. Stylish and understated and finished to a high standard. Service from beginning to end was excellent, even when the hotel was very busy. We found all the staff friendly, professional and helpful (even when things sometimes got lost in translation). Our room at the beginning of our stay was slightly smaller than the room we took at the end of our trip (a corner room with views of the sky tower), but both rooms were well thought out, design led and comfortable. The views in both rooms were also a highlight, especially at night. If you have a chance also use the hotel spa and swimming pool. The spa was one of the best I have been to. The staff there were exceptional, the treatments very professional and the design and feel of the spa made for a very special experience. Our room came with complimentary breakfast. Breakfast was a buffet style with a good mix of more western breakfast choices and traditional Japanese choices. This was my husband's second stay at the hotel (he first stayed shortly after the hotel opened) and he tells me that some of the small teething problems the hotel had at the beginning have well and truly been ironed out. Were I to find myself in Tokyo again I would definitely stay at the Andaz as for me it has it all, style, location, great service and comfort.
user_name:
Jessica S
Greater London, United Kingdom

review_body: Armani Milano was. But I think this Andaz property has surpassed it. The hotel encompasses so much more than somewhere to stay. I love the area, it is 'businessy' but has a modern class about it that suits my taste. The building has so many great restaurants and dotted with great art work. I enjoyed the sushi and Chinese restaurants on level 4 and 5 of the building and got a blow dry on level 3. The food itself at the hotel was great as Tokyo was the end of our 2 week trip and I was missing some nice fresh juices and salads. I felt they cater to both local and foreign market. The staff are professional and not pompous. There is a difference. They take pride in their delivery which no doubt comes from their training and when you take the time to speak to them you will come to note many varied backgrounds, and experiences. Despite being Chinese NY, I felt everything was handled perfectly.Views are unreal and the wood gives a modern yet very warm feeling. The lighting even conveys this ambience. The spa and spa facilities, gym and swimming pool are top notch. Only St regis Saadiyat Island rivals it! Subway very close to link with main sights. Just fantastic, can't wait to return :)

This hotel is simply stunning and a must-try when in Tokyo. Newly opened less 8 months ago. Modern looking but incorporates a lot of Japanese design concept within, e.g. Lots of wood, fish motif. Great views all round from the 47th floor up. Service was excellent. Everyone was friendly, all smiles and eager to assist. I've stayed at many 5-star business hotels in Tokyo and sometimes you get the cold / stiff polite types - not here! Warm, young and energetic is what you'll find. Rooms are above average size, not outsized, flow lines work really well. Spacious bedroom. Big round bath for 2, same for shower. Free non-alcoholic beverages from mini-bar (a cool Andaz standard). We had a small upgrade a room facing Tokyo Tower and it was stunning. Romantic both day and night. 2 bench tables for separate work area and keeping putting personal items kept the OCD in me happy. Sofa seat was comfortable enough though not for long working sessions - which you might want to do at the lounge with private booths Gym is very big by Tokyo standard and well equipped to work all major muscle group. Full set of dumb bells - sufficient for most anyways. The carbonated pool in the swimming area is da bomb!! So relaxing with little bubbles massaging your body. Workout clothes, shoes and even swim shorts provided if you forgot yours as we did. Train stations are not far away by Tokyo standards. Toranomon station (Ginza line) is 550m away, connects easily to other line at Ginza station (2 stops away) or to Shibuya (6 stops away). Walking distance is not more than other hotels, e.g. Park Hyatt, Grand Hyatt and Westin. Shout-out to Gerard who made our stay a super special one and Minori who gave a warm welcome and helped with last min dinner bookings. Well-done, Andaz Tokyo team.

From A to Z just a huge disappointment, first the check in which is poorly executed by snobish junior staff, requested a late check out at 13h30 they asked me to pay 150 usd, as a Hyatt member they should be a little more considerated.The room is small, with 2 massive wood furnitures at less than 30 cm from the bed. So better not waking up at night.Bed do not even have a surmattress! Free non alcoholic minibar, that at 600 usd is 4 cheap 7/11 drinks, fb could have been a little creative!Bathroom is also small with a single sink! Toilett is poorly painted.For the same price better stayed at Park Hyatt.

I've stayed in 3 Andaz hotels. This one truly lives up to this newly established brand under Hyatt. As a Hyatt Gold Passport Diamond member, we were treated well. But, I expect that all guests would experience similar treatment. The property itself is situated in a relatively quiet part of Tokyo - particularly on weekends, in reasonably close proximity to the subway. The rooms weren't quite as large as we were expecting (based on other reviews), but certainly large by Tokyo standards. The views were spectacular and the staff was helpful and beyond courteous. My only suggestion is that they hire a professional concierge. Again, the staff made every attempt to be helpful, but it was obvious their knowledge of restaurants around Tokyo was limited.

Contemporary urban design and an intimate boutique ambience set a chic tone at Andaz Tokyo Toranomon Hills. Andaz Tokyo occupies the top seven floors of this tower (the city’s second tallest). Despite being famed for its heritage and shrines, Toranomon is a little too business like for such an urban lifestyle hotel ... The rooms are chic and contemporary. Among the expanses of Hokkaido walnut wood and white walls, there are carpets the colour of matcha green tea, plus tomato red leather chairs and headboards. The bathrooms are fantastic with wooden enclaves, spa like showers and a majestic circular baths. And centre stage? The views.My only negative comment is that I find it hard to differentiate the Andaz and Park Hyatt brands ... Especially in Tokyo.

I travel to Tokyo a few times a year, and I'd heard good reports about this hotel, so thought I'd try it as an alternative to either the Park Hyatt or the Imperial where I normally stay. From my perspective, it's materially better. Although the hotel is medium sized, it has the atmosphere of a boutique hotel, with plenty of quiet areas to retire to, books and magazines to browse, and a welcome absence of a formal reception desk. The service is first class, and all the staff I encountered were friendly and efficient. The General Manager, Arnaud (who was responsible for opening the Andaz in London) was ever-present, checking that everything was in order, which I think is a rarity for hotels of this type/size and definitely helped. The rooms are compact - as you'd expect in a city central location - but excellently laid out and equipped. Free wifi, Nespresso machine, a logical lighting system and every plug socket you could wish for. The gym was well set out with plenty of aerobic equipment and weights. The breakfast was well presented, with plenty of variety. And, finally, because it's relatively new, the pricing is very competitive. I'll certainly return there on my next trip.

A well designed space. Contemporary feel but not pretentious. Check-in was exactly as it should be; swift.Tower View King room - unreal view, immaculate, huge bed (long enough for once), blackout curtains, completely soundproof, spacious wash area - no open bathroom nonsense that appears to be the new norm in Asia. Attention to detail evident everywhere from travel adapters built into the wall to the espresso machine and bluetooth speakers. Facilities: Everything, including pool, all new. You can hire gear should you not want to pack your own, yoga/exercise mats available to use in your room. Complimentary wine/snacks in lobby lounge from 6-8.Breakfast: all obvious western and Japanese options available, perhaps more expensive than i'd have expected ~Y 9000 net. Location: ~500m walk from the Metro if that's your means of travel, tons of cabs otherwise. . No complaints with district - it is a stop on Narita Express if you're not Haneda-bound and the hotel will fix all transfer times for you on check-in. Andaz felt less like a business hotel to me though you are a 5 min cab from the main financial area.Staff: Many different nationalities and even by Tokyo standards service was excellent. We had a few tricky requests that were dealt with quickly and without hassle. I will definitely stay again.

We stayed here when we visited Tokyo earlier this year for New Years. This hotel is probably the nicest hotel we have (and maybe ever will) stayed at! The hotel lobby is located on the 51st floor of the building, with the hotel rooms on the 51+ floors. When you arrive at the hotel, they take you up to check in. You don't have to stand in line and wait for someone to check you in, instead they seat you in a dimly lit lounge/lobby area and you get to enjoy free wine/snacks/food while they take your passports and get you checked in. After, they walk you upstairs to your room. The rooms are gorgeous with amazing decor! The bed was comfortable, the couch was comfortable, and shower/tub/bathroom area was fantastic! The walls in the bathroom were made with dark wood and all the doors opened 180 degrees and tucked away in the wall so you couldn't even tell there was a door there (which made the room very spacious). Except for alcohol, everything in the minibar was free, the TV had a lot of channels in English, and the staff was awesome and friendly. You definitely need to check out this hotel if you are going to Tokyo--it was the best/nicest hotel we've been too!

Allround good experience with very nice Hyatt-standard rooms but then the rooftop bar will let you down and spoil the whole experience - not only once, but almost every time. It was like the B-team was running the show up there. Been coming to Tokyo on a monthly basis for the past few years and thought to give this a try. I'm not sure that I'm convinced it's worth changing to this property for keeps.

once you "land" at the 51st floor, you access a lobby that does not look like a lobby. You are welcome by your hosts... Most refined decoration, whether in the restaurant, lobby or in the room. Bedroom is just outstanding, overlooking Tokyo (on my side the Imperial Palace). On the other side, you could actually see the Mount Fuji for a full day, as if it crowned the Mori Tower! On the rooftop, there is a trendy bar where you can enjoy the view on Tokyo by night/light!!! If you go there in the wintertime, as I did, you enjoy blankets to help cope with the cold weather! Just outstanding expeience, can't wait to go back there.

I have been to tokyo a couple of times last year and on this trip i stayed at the Andaz Tokyo. I would say its the best hotel in Tokyo. From the welcoming staff to the fantastic decor. Everything is top notch. The rooms are fantastic with wooden interiors, the linen is white and crisp, spa is fantastic. Your every need is taken care off. I will definitely stay there during my next visit.

I was in Tokyo for business and chose this hotel because it was one of the few that still had reservations available to me (beginning of Nov timeframe). It is a bit pricey compared to more budget hotels but it makes up for it with what you get. I've read some other reviewers' comment about having difficulty trying to find the hotel. I would have to agree with them. In general, it isn't very clear where the heck the hotel entrance is but I also think it has to do with what they are trying to do with their image; cool, modern hotel that is not trying to shock-and-awe you with bright neon lights and huge signage. When trying to find the place, look for where the cabs are pulling up. Otherwise, find the Audi dealership/showroom. An entrance will be across the street next to a cafe.The lobby is on the 51st floor which I thought was really cool. That is because the hotel rooms are below the lobby (I believe it goes down to the 45th or 46th floor). All the floors below that are residential. My room was on the 49th and, when I walked in, I expected a small box of a room. Boy, was I surprised! You walk into the foyer and to the right you find a very modern looking, open space bathroom. There is also a shower/bathtub combination. Further into the room leads you to the bedroom with one of the best views of Tokyo. It really was a stunning sight. Linens are clean and of high quality. Espresso machine and other accoutrements like water bottles, tea, soda, juices and bar snacks are gratis. Location of the hotel is great for people one business. It is a bit like the financial district in NYC; hustle and bustle during the day, somewhat quiet at night, nice and quiet on weekends. It is close to many of the main train lines so getting to other parts of Tokyo is quite simple. If you like the bars in Ginza, well, you can walk to it and be there in 15-20 minutes and not have to worry about catching the last train at midnight back home because you can walk back! If you don't feel like going out, you can head up to the 52nd rooftop bar. Great vibe, pleasant staff, good food, and nice place to kick back and have a cocktail with a cigar.Bottom line: Would I stay again? Yes, definitively.

Andaz is rather difficult to find if you're unfamiliar with Tokyo. I hired a car service to drive me from Haneda to the hotel and even with GPS, the driver had difficulty finding the valet entrance. The signage for Andaz is painfully subtle, so just look for the skyscraper labeled "Toranomon Hills" and that's the building.The location is in a business/diplomatic district so the area is dead and like ghost town on weekends. The rooms are extremely well appointed, functional and spacious. The views are dramatic and stunning. Minibar is complimentary for non-alcoholic beverages and snacks. Toiletries are well stocked. Complimentary wine and snacks in the lobby from 6pm to 8pm. The buffet breakfast was underwhelming and not recommended. Housekeeping was excellent. In room dining was excellent. Rooftop bar was excellent. Valet was excellent.The only tradeoff/caveat that comes with most modern/boutique hotels is the staff are mostly younger, usually with less hospitality experience than staff in traditional "old world" luxury hotels. It's subtle but apparent that this need improvement.I'd have given this hotel a five star review, however, I took one point away for the following: they claim to provide complimentary newspaper service, yet failed to deliver for both weekend and Monday edition of The Wall Street Journal to my doorstep. Also, checking out was absolutely dreadful. Hotels usually save credit card information at check in, then process any extras (dining, minibar, etc) automatically at checkout. Here, I had to provide my credit card again during checkout, which I found rather annoying. Also, reading previous reviews, i did not experience any sit-down lobby reception for either check in or out.Overall, I would recommended this hotel but would probably not stay here again myself.

On business in Tokio for 2 days - Andaz was a great choice. I usually stay at Hyatt but this was better, especially the room. I don't know if I have a extra luxe room (my assistant booked) but the room was just amazing.

Please allow me to establish a frame of reference - I've been traveling internationally since 1999 and typically log between 200k and 300k miles per year across 5 continents. I've stayed at everything as basic as a Premier Inn (UK) or Hampton Inn (US) or Tokyu Inn (JP) to more exclusive properties like the Westin on Langkawi Island, the Mondrian in the UK, and the Hyatt on Sydney Harbor. I've been staying at mostly boutique hotels the past few years and have fallen in love with the Andaz properties in Manhattan. I come to Tokyo on business five or six times each year. When I first started coming to Tokyo back in 1999, there was this sense of 'awe' that I had because of the 'futuristic' feel of everything. That awe turned into a patina over the years as the economy continued to struggle and things started to feel 'dated'. Lately, I've been staying at the Park Hotel in Shimbashi. It's been perfect in every way and its an excellent property. But recently, Hyatt opened an Andaz here in Toranomon Hills, near the Tokyo Tower and the fish market. Based on my stellar experiences at the Andaz properties in NYC, I thought I'd give this hotel a try. Candidly, I'm a little jaded, having spent the last 15 years moving around hotels. I'm not hard to please- but I'm difficult to impress. This hotel: simply and incredibly awe inspiring. No doubt, the 'newness' of it is a factor, but the execution at this property has raised my expectations to an entirely new level. Style that is amazingly understated. The designers have accomplished an incredible thing - using warm woods and muted colors that are both classic but amazingly futuristic. Small details abound. Toggle switches. Creative lighting. Bose Bluetooth wireless soundock. Drawer pulls and bathroom fixtures that feel like they've been machined on 3D printers. The rooms are huge. Not by Tokyo standards. By ANY standards. I could simply gush about the views, the linens, the bed, the great sound insulation, the work spaces and the state of the art Panasonic HD television. But I need to save my enthusiasm for the service. Like all Andaz properties - no front desk. You are 'greeted' in a beautifully configured lounge area where you enjoy a cold or hot beverage while the staff checks you in with what I would describe as 'a warm and painelss reception'. Service in Japan is almost always the highest caliber, but this entire team feels like a contingent of personal valets. The usual Japanese customer service is threaded into the Andaz model to create a new level of attention. I've only had the buffet breakfast so far (perfect in every way with very fresh and beautifully presented Japanese and Western dishes), but I'm anxious to try the bar and the restaurant, which both look to be on par with the rest of the property. This doesn't come at low cost, of course. But, as I sit 50 floors up looking out over Tokyo, I'm back in 'awe' of this futuristic and perfectly crafted vision of the future. Thanks Andaz for both raising the bar and bringing back a feeling of 'awe' whenever I open my hotel door.
