New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is fantastic. I stayed here for my Christmas holiday from December 22nd to December 25th and I have to say that it was one of my best hotel stays I have ever had.When I arrived to the hotel, it was amazing! The elevator went to the 50th floor where I went to check in. There was another elevator which went to the rooms and the lounge (46 - 50). I was amazedI was shown to my room which was at the 47th floor. It had a great view! I could even see mt. Fuji. It also was clean, with a enormous bathtub and a shower. There were also two beds which were very comfortable.It was 1:00 so I was pretty hungry. I went to the hotel’s restaurant on the 50th floor and saw the menu. I ate japanese noodles and varieties of raw fish. It was delicious. I was stuffed so I went back into my room!There also was a great 20m pool in the hotel too it was great! On the other side of the hotel there some shops and convenience stores. When I went back in my room there were international plugs and outlets so I could charge my electronical devices. There was television which was a flat screen which I watched time to time.The staff were very welcoming and they were very helpful when I was looking for my attractions. The location was more of a business area but there was a metro station near the hotel and cabs kept on coming.I enjoyed it but I suggest that you could have some kid - friendly activities for some families but other than it was a very great hotel!

I love, love, love this hotel! The Andaz brand is a totally new concept from Hyatt. I presume it stands for: Boutique-ish. Exclusive. High-end. At least that’s how I ended up feeling there. It is located in a brand new high-rise called Toranomon Towers very close to the Royal Palace. The lobby is on the 50th floor and the rooms are on Floors 47-50. We had our room on the 50th floor which had a stunning view of Tokyo. You could also see Mt Fuji!!There is a lot of wood in the decor which is Japanese beautiful. The reception is very low key, just a bunch of Macbook Air’s closed down on a beautiful marble table. The restaurant and bar have the same stunning views as the rooms. There are many tables for you to work at, sit down, have a chat with a friend, read a book. The space is very multifunctional and luxurious. And wifi is omnipresent, very fast and very easy to log on.The breakfast buffet was outstanding. Wow! Every morning when I woke up I was looking forward to the breakfast spread.Then there were the rooms. Very spacious, gorgeous bathroom, techie yet functional. Quasi space-age in design with earthy tones. Along the whole window there was a wonderful built-in couch so that you could sit on it and have the stunning view of Tokyo right next to you. I loved spending time in the room especially since I came to Tokyo exhausted and just wanted to unwind. It was a perfect room for that.Lastly, the gym and pool. Located on the 37th floor, not sure if it belongs to the hotel or if it’s a stand-alone club, nonetheless it was equally impressive.This is truly an excellent hotel. I haven’t been this excited in a long time!

Put up in the Andaz by my hosts - and I could not be happier. Exquisite service from check in throughout the entire stay. Food was very good, but I only had lunch and breakfast. I actually liked the lunch at the bar better than the restaurant as the latter has a kind of european-asian fusion, whereas I preferred the more traditional udon dishes at the bar. Very nice room with great black out shades (important for jet lag sleeping). The bath was quite luxurious - rather startled by the loo - 12 buttons on the electronic controls! Extremely nice fitness room and pool.

Stayed 3 nights in late December 2014. Had a deluxe room on lev 48 with incredible views stretching from Tokyo Tower, Roppongi Hills (with Mt Fuji clearly visible just to the left) and all the way to Shinjuku.Hotel was very stylish and service was impeccible. Thoroughly enjoyed the buffet breakfast and room service for dinner. Reception staff were very attentive, friendly and helpful, as well as concierge / luggage people downstairs, and the room service / cleaners as well.The swimming pool / spas are wonderful, and the pool attendants are very friendly and helpful. No smell of chlorine here and the carbonated spa was amazing.The surrounding area is quiet and I found this to be an oasis away from the hustle and bustle of other areas. the hotel is easy walking distance (20 mins) to Shinbashi / Ginza / Imperial Palace etc. 5 mins walk away is the subway station which is on the very handy Ginza line, which stretches from Shibuya to Asakusa. Once you get the hang of the subway it is very easy, and inexpensive, to get to wherever you want to go quickly. Taxi fares to popular places are also not prohibitively expensive.There are great eating options nearby the hotel if you want alternatives. this may sound strange but there's something different about this hotel. While it is quiet, comfortable, luxurious and laid-back, it doesn't smell like your regular luxury hotel - they use clean, fresh scents which are replicated in the toiletries provided. This is a nice touch which contributes to my overall perception that the hotel wants to differentiate itself from the rest of the pack.Will definitely come back.

It's several minutes walk from Toranomon station but would not miss the 50+ tall & newest additional building around the area.Several fine dining bars and restaurant can be found. There is wheelchair access at far side of the escalators. Whole area is clean & well maintained with outside seating on 2nd floor to enjoy spring or summertime breeze while sipping some tasty coffee or just a good book. Trees are still a bit thin as visited in winter so hopefully full of green leaves as the weather changes. A cute statue of 'Doraemon' a Japanese animated cartoon character is displayed, tho the coloring is quite different & named as 'Toranomon' instead.

My Wife and I spend few days in Tokyo last December, and I must say this personalized hotel beat all my experience have before.The interior are modern contemporaneous with a lot of wood log tables to warm up the ambiance on the high ceilings atrium located on the 51 floor; the rooms are very private with only few per floors, large and very comfortable with the most amazing view on the Tokyo City...i will suggested to all the new traveler on Tokyo to try!

Stunning views but exceptionally quiet and really very average amenities.Rooms are spacious but food very average -from room service to breakfast this hotel is a far cry from Typical Japanese service. The Hyatt Roppongi is a much better option -it belongs to the same chain and is far more happening.

We stayed at Andaz from Dec 28 to 31, 2014.My family loved the location, concept and the decor and design. The view is stunning all day long from our room or the lounge. The staff is helpful and we like the idea of having one person help us for all our needs. Great attention to detail, thoughtful touches like the pre and post new year snack/sake, and good F&B. The roof top bar is quite personable and again the view is stunning. Definitely, as a great hotel for couples. Well designed pool.Opportunities - there a few minor ones:We don't think some of the staff are ready to assume their role completely - a few are still unsure of basic details, although some are very good.The bell desk team/person was overwhelmed or unsure of what to do during our check in (our luggages for storage was kept at the bell desk until the next morning), check out (15 mins to come up to our room), and on Dec 29 early am when there was nobody to help us with a taxi to Tsujiki.The buffet area during peak breakfast time can be quite crowded.Overall, I would recommend Andaz Toranomon. Looking forward for a revisit.

I was staying at Andaz @ toranomon during my last trip in tokyo. Great design with large rooms and great view of tokyo, very large room and special attention to details. Upon arriving I had a problem with a suitcase lock and highlight it to the reception. As I was in hurry to go to a dinner, I have asked them to have a look and break the lock. When I was back to my room the lock was open without breaking and nice word from the reception mentioning they have found the lock code. They have been beyond expectation. Overall service has been great.

I went to Andaz Hyatt Tokyo at Toranomon Hills, a very newly built "Hills" in Japan. The experience was fascinating as it would be for Roppongi Hills and some other buildings in Tokyo. We checked in at the front of the hotel which is at 51F. However, they don't really have a reception "desk", instead, they have an area with tables where they sit down with you for check in while you are having coffee and cookies provided by the hotel. Some might think it's great this way, but some might not. The remit self is really decent and full of Japan elements. We got the Tokyo Bay view room and personally I think it "might" be a better view for Tokyo Tower side, but not sure. The most wonderful experience for me is the pool. Very nice ~20M pool with around 3 lanes spacious enough for swim. It was not crowded at all in week days. They also have a sparking spa which is also a different experience.Personally, I would definitely go again for the pool and to have a getaway from busy life in Tokyo.

This is a new property located near Shimbashi - opened in May 2014 I think they said.I stayed here for 3 nights, 2 different stays in November 2014.The hotel is on roughly the 47th through 52nd floor of a new tower called Toronomon Hills. The city views are outstanding. On the first stay, I had a view of Tokyo Tower that was centered right on the large windows of my room. It could not have been more spectacular.Even though the location is very central, the hotel is not really in walking distance to a lot that you would want to see as a tourist. The walk to the nearest JR Station - Shimbashi is about 15 minutes. Not bad in good weather, but it would seem like a long walk in the rain.The rooms are very large. I especially like the arrangement of the bathroom with a large attached walk-in closet.The service is excellent and the staff is very friendly.There are free non-alcoholic beverages in the mini-bar - water, soda, juice.I ate breakfast one morning in the restaurant on the 51st floor - it was excellent. I also had a burger is the small restaurant on the ground floor of the building called BeBu - also excellent.Since this is a new property, the taxi drivers don't seem to know about it. Even with the hotel name and address written on a piece of paper in English and Japanese, the cabbies were stumped. I was able to get there each time, but there was a fair amount of work on the driver's part with the GPS.

Lovely hotel. Wonderful views. Great staff. Lovely design for the restaurant on the 50th floor.(I didn't sleep in the hotel -- my friends did though)They liked their room and had no complaints other than: all of us thought the Sunday brunch buffet was a total rip off. Yen 40,000 (incl tax) doesn't even get you a glass of bubbly or a Bloody Mary. Small buffet area is very poorly organized with minimum of offerings. It is totally disorganized and had long line-ups of guests waiting for a simple omelet. Cold foods were warm, warm foods were greasy.We left the restaurant very dissatisfied - we actually felt cheated. The roof top bar is great at night! Excellent Martinis and Negronis. Live music adds a nice touch.

We stayed here for 5 nights, and were debating between staying here and the Grand Hyatt. I'm very glad we stayed here. The rooms are spacious and stunningly appointed. The layout is excellent - we stayed with our toddler, and it was plenty of room for all three of us. The couch along the window was our favourite feature. Quiet rooms with good amenities - loved the bath, shower, Bose system, etc.Great views from every room too. Really appreciated the complimentary mini bar, the breakfast each day was great, and loved also using the hangout space in the lobby. The staff were all super nice and very accommodating.With a toddler, eating out was difficult, which is why we really appreciated how great the room service was too. Lots of good restaurants in the complex here, as well as small restaurants nearby.Last but not least, the location is excellent. It was a 5-10 minute pleasant walk to different train stations which offered easy access to all parts of Tokyo. Toranomon Hills wasn't our first choice in location, but we really enjoyed it (we'd previously stayed in Akasaka, Ginza, Ueno and Shinjuku).One of my all time favourite hotels. Definitely coming back.

Modern hotel with excellent decor of natural wood furniture and stone. Great views. The toilet greets you and open its lid on entering the toilet room. Great Japanese and American breakfast and open roof bar. The best spa with cleanest water in edgeless pool, multiple massage spots in Roman pool and sparkling water pool! Soak in St Pellegrino at the end of busy day. Great location - 2 subway stops from Ginza. And personnel speaks English!!!!!

I stayed with family at the Andaz for over a week in September and then again in October. It is quite new with very nice furnishings. When I compare it to The Westin Tokyo where I normally stay, it has a more modern feel to it, by about 30-40 years. All the other reviews do a nice job of describing the pluses, which I appreciate, but I prefer to nitpick for this review.No bath salts. They have a nice tub but no salts. Every other amenity was available, this seems like a glaring oversight.As mentioned in previous reviews, compared to other western hotels the staff at the Andez has a limited English vocabulary, yet most were very friendly. The one person that did know English well was a pushy gal from India that we all wished we had never met. The concierge staff were nice, but half of them didn't seem to know the city well or did not know the duties of a concierge.Hard beds. If you are aware of the Westin Heavenly bed, think the opposite; "The Andez bed from hell"Lots of elevators. You need an elevator to get to the 51st floor lobby, then another elevator to get to your room. There is yet a third elevator to get to the roof bar.Roof bar is awful. You feel like you are competing with the mechanical equipment. There are a ton of staff who are very busy ignoring you - I felt like I was in Italy.Most Asian hotels, such as the Westin Tokyo, have a nice club for elites to have a complimentary drink and appetizer before going out. Here you sit in the small lobby amongst people trying to check in while you gnaw on rodent-sized niblets of cracker and drinking swill that they call wine. The free in-room munchies are likewise rather disgusting - fried cookie morsels in wax-paper bags was the best they could muster.This started out as a 5-star review, but after realizing the number of shortcomings, I had to drop it. I reserve 5-stars for spectacular stays. Perhaps once I reach my Diamond status a revisit will change my mind...

After a long trip from Melbourne via Sydney, I walked into the Andaz and was made to feel as if I were being welcomed home. I had not yet stayed at an Andaz location, and my stay has made me into a lifelong customer. I have enjoyed hearing from the different staff their 'local picks' for where I can see the latest in Tokyo dining, fashion and night life. This curatorial approach is a perfect match for my tastes and will only attract more customers seeking this mix of boutique hotel experience with a consistency across locations in major cities.The hardest part has been going outside of the hotel - I saw Mt. Fuji yesterday from the spa and was dazzled by its majesty. The different pools, gym equipment and spa treatments combine to define wellbeing and equanimity. And all this in only 4-5 months since the opening. Well done!

We stayed at the hotel during its first week open in June and it was seriously the highlight of the trip. From the moment you arrive in the lobby they greet you and make you feel welcome. The best part was the design of the room and the views! We had breakfast in the hotel and the buffet was very good. The lobby bar and rooftop bar were always busy in the evenings. The pool and spa area are an unbelievable benefit. Definitely helped to relax during a long vacation.

It's new and the service is grand. We wanted to try it because the reviews were so great, and the hotel met our expectations. The reception area is on the 51st floor, and the rooms are the four floors below, so the views are sensational and the rooms were very spacious. The bathroom is well laid out and roomy. Because this is in the business district, there are a lot of restaurants down back alleys frequented by businessmen. Most of the menus, however, are in Japanese so there was a lot of gesturing, pointing at food involved in ordering a meal. There are two subway stops close by, and I was able to walk to the Ginza shopping area (although wear good shoes and count on a 20-30 minute walk). The hotel is in an office building which I believe is the second highest building in Tokyo and there is an office mall but it's quite limited (so far).

I recently stayed at the Andaz in Tokyo on a quick business trip. I normally stay at the Grand Hyatt, but it was fully booked. The Andaz lived up to the service of the Grand Hyatt and provided a more relaxing vibe. I have stayed at the London Andaz previously so knew the style, but the Tokyo version is newer, shinier and happier... The rooftop cocktail bar was worth a visit - good cocktails and friendly manager, as was the burger and beer restaurant/bar on the first floor. The hotel is conveniently located (close enough to Tokyo station / Otemachi) and has a variety of restaurants above it in Toranomon Hills. Had an excellent massage at the spa and the gym was well equipped too. The service was very friendly and I find the idea of having on tap tea/coffee in the lounge quite refreshing. Would definitely stay again.

Excellent service, wonderful and attentive staff, and a well appointed and located hotel. I had initially booked to stay at the Grand Hyatt in Roppongi (where I had stayed earlier in the year, and which too, is an excellent property) but decided to give the Andaz a try since I'd never tried the brand before. A decision I didn't regret one bit. My only recommendation would be to ever so slightly increase the food options during the breakfast buffet - seemed a bit sparse, compared to the Grand Hyatt's I've been to. But the attention to detail, and the friendliness/efficiency of the staff at the Andaz are commendable, and will definitely be staying here the next time I'm in Tokyo.

I first visited the new Andaz hotel last week with a number of international clients. I had heard so many great things about it from clients and friends so I was excited to check it out for myself. On first impressions the hotel itself is absolutely beautiful and stylish. Upon entering the rooftop bar I was instantly put on the back foot with a very cold and abrupt greeting from the reception team. However after being seated and getting some drinks on the way we were really looked after. Our waiter who I believe was also the manager, was a friendly and helpful South African guy who made us feel totally at home and guided us through the cocktails. He really looked after us. My clients were very impressed as was I and will absolutely be back. Great bar, great cocktails and great service. Very highly recommended!

This hotel is truly perfect. While mostly one travels for the city and a hotel is the means to achieve this, with the Andaz Tokyo the hotel IS the destination.When I enter the hotel, I feel like I've entered the MoMA - everything is stunning and practical. Every detail in the room is planned and has a purpose, while also being pleasing to all senses. A subtle combination of modern, western, technologically advanced, and Japanese, all come into one seamlessly. To me, this is a combination of Park Hyatt service standards with a fresh and modern take on the decor. I believe the hotel strikes a balance between casual and trendy (Andaz) while retaining the features of the most elegant hotels in the world.I recommend this hotel wholeheartedly. Furthermore, the location is superb. There's not much in the "direct vicinity". But the Ginza line at Toranomon Station means that the most interesting areas of Tokyo are within easy reach - Ginza, Tokyo Station, Omotesando, Shibuya. Roppongi can be reached by a 30-minute walk, and in fact, so can Ginza.

We stayed 2 nights here in late October at the end of a long trip to Asia. It was easily the most luxurious hotel we visited. One of the nicest I have ever stayed in. The decor is modern with extensive use of Walnut finishes throughout the public and private spaces. Sitting between the 47th and 51st floors, the views are stunning of Tokyo especially at night. Our room looked directly over the Imperial Palace, perhaps a half mile North.The bathroom was huge, all of the materials used were of top quality and beautifully finished. The shower had that WOW effect the first time I saw it. The bed was one of the most comfortable I have ever slept on.The location is new and a few taxi drivers are unaware of the Toranomon Hills location. Take directions in Japanese with you when you arrive or return.Overall, a gorgeous concept from Hyatt. Highly recommended.

We stayed here in October 2014 and took a chance on a "new property," even though friends told us to stay elsewhere... this was one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in. The rooms are stunning, as are the lobbies/ restaurants/ hallways/ spa/ everything. The views are breathtaking from everywhere you look (we had a view of the bay). The bathrooms (bath/ shower) are unreal. Be sure to visit the rooftop bar for the sunset!
user_name:
CRS621
New York City, New York

review_body: Andaz Tokyo has raised the bar for hotels in Tokyo that want to provide a trendy but still top-service accommodation option. I stayed at Andaz for the last 10 days, and had a chance to try out most of the facilities. It's a brand new hotel, and the staff are just fantastic. After a day or two personal preferences are remembered, and greeting by name is obligatory. The hotel is not too big, but still has all facilities that A 5 star place is expected to have; best is the staff though, they just know how to deliver service that is efficient, personal and still more relaxed than at more traditional Tokyo hotels. I can highly recommend this hotel for business or private stays. The location is very central with many subway and train services near by. For those looking for a not too long workout, from the hotel the round-the-imperial-place jogging run is a 7.5k affair. Overall a great addition to the Tokyo hotel list.

This is one of the newest 5-star hotels in Tokyo, close to the Imperial Palace, Tokyo Tower, Ginza, Shinjuki and Roppongi. Great views of the city as the hotel occupies the top levels (Floor 52 down to 45, I think). Reception is on Floor 51 and then there are separate elevators down to the bedrooms, pool and so on. There is a nice lounge, dining/breakfast room on Floor 51 and an excellent and very trendy rooftop bar on Floor 52. Decor and furnishings are what I have come to expect of Hyatt hotels around the world and the rooms are spacious, well laid-out and afford great views of the city with full length and full width windows. Only downside is that I thought the room rates were more expensive than I would have expected and compared with other Hyatt hotels of similar standards in Asia. The value for money aspect will definitely make me look at alternative options for future visits to Tokyo (maybe it just reflects Tokyo prices!)

Andaz took me with suprise, it is a trendy boutique hotel in the Hyatt Group and realtivly newly built at the time of my stay. It is in a new area that is under development for the 2020 Olympic Games and located at the new "Champs-Élysées" of Tokyo.The rooms are cleverly designed with a lot of white mixed with warm earth colors. The interior of the room as well as gadgets are carefully designed and added to feel really unique.My view from the top residential floor of the Tokyo Tower was magical and during night time the tower will also light up. The hotel also has a very trendy bar with a nice view over Tokyo.

Just back from great Tokyo visit. The hotel is great, good location, nice design, really liked the room, the spa and the guest lounge. Staff nice but many spoke surprisingly bad english for this kind of place. Had big disappointment last night - went back to hotel to enjoy the nice roofbar instead of going to Roppongi. Were not allowed to enter the bar because it was full, only offered to be put on waiting list with 10 other groups ahead of us. To me that is unheard of - 1. Not being admitted as staying guest at a hotel like this, 2. Staff not communicating so we were allowed up but not to enter bar 3. No other options available at the hotel. So all in all - the ambition is good but they are not there yet.

It is clear that the Andaz is positioning itself as something special in the market. Beautiful natural timbers and a calming ambience. The gym and pool were first class and the breakfast one of the best that I have had anywhere in the world. The Andaz transformed a business visit into an experience, which is always a welcome surprise. It is expensive, by any standards, but I for one would be happy to pay the cost for the experience that it provides.

Very clean hotel and very friendly staff.Nice gym and swimming pool, but I got injured inside swimming pool (cracked my toe) by accident.Otherwise, beautiful hotel room, though it was a bit small- buffet was so delicious.It seemed a bit inconvenient to access to subway, but the view was amazing...
user_name:
nyay
New York City, New York

review_body: Stayed here twice in September. The hotel has only been open since mid June and are trying to raise their profile by offering some well priced introductory rates. The hotel accommodation is centred around the 50th floor and has great views of the area including the Skytree. The room was a very good size with great comfortable beds. The rooms have a full length couch along the window where u can work in comfort using laptop etc, although if u want the view whilst working and work from the other side of the desk the small chair isn't that comfortable. The bathroom and wardrobe areas are very generous. The windows have two sets of blinds should you require blackout and a good sleep. The breakfast fare is very good with lots of variety. Although one morning one of the staff tried to push me out of the dining room without explanation. Had a lunch in the dining where there is a limited menu which was fine. Also hosted a dinner which was very very good and the Japanese in the party found the gooey chocolate and avocado an interesting combination. Was a very very good stay. Would return.

I am confused by the negative reviews of this hotel. Our stay was excellent. My only criticism is that status recognition for Hyatt Diamonds is below average at this property.The hotel itself is in a brand new building that is in an up and coming area of Tokyo. The views from everywhere in the hotel are excellent. The room was very clean and beautifully designed.As a Hyatt Diamond, we enjoyed free breakfast at the Andaz Tavern. The buffet breakfast was excellent and the service in the restaurant was very friendly and efficient. It was a real treat to enjoy my morning coffee with sweeping views of Tokyo!The hotel setup is typical Andaz (which we love), but it is a bit unusual and not suited for every traveler. There is not a traditional front desk/concierge division of labor, but instead there is a front table that handles everything. I think this concept works very well and the front table handled both roles with ease. The service overall was fantastic even though some of the staff struggled with English.I used the gym several times during our stay and it is above average. Like everywhere in the hotel it has amazing views of Tokyo. The spa and pool looked amazing as well, but we did not have time to use them. The spa seems lovely, but I must say that the prices seem outrageous. I have never seen a spa where the average treatment is $200+. I would strongly suggest to the hotel that they consider getting the spa prices more into the $150 area. $200+ is simply prohibitive to most visitors in my opinion.We chose this property over the Park Hyatt Tokyo and we were not disappointed. I would strongly recommend this property to anyone visiting Tokyo. Although some have said that the location is not great, we did not find that to be true. The property is very close to multiple subway stops and it is easy walking distance to Ginza, Roppongi, Akasaka, and other areas.

Stayed for 3 nights and used it as a base for exploring Tokyo.I don't understand why not every review posted here is stellar!This was one of the best hotels we ever stayed at. The decor was elegant, work of art really; the view from the room was spectacular; the room was large and comfortable, the bathroom - perfectly designed.Also, the little touches, such as having a coffeemaker in the room, complementary non-alcoholic drinks and snacks, as well as complimentary happy hour drinks and snacks in the beautiful lobby completed the picture. I didn't want to leave and would love to stay there again!
Best facility hotel in Tokyo I have ever experiencedNice staffs, very new but good qualityI want to stay there again.

Stayed here for business for 4 nights last week (Sept 2014). It is a brand new hotel opened just a 2-3 months ago and managed by Hyatt group. Rooms are all on high floors in a office building which is about 500 metres to Toranomon subway station. There's not much surrounding as most are office buildings but near to some temples and shrines. It's a short taxi drive to Shinjuku or Ginza.The hotel design is chic and understated with dark wood furnitures and color scheme. The lobby on the 51st floor looks like a lounge with a long table and chairs where guests are seated for check-in. Front Desk agents stand around an empty table with only some Macbooks which look like an Apple store. There's snacks available for guests throughout the day here as well as champagne/wine and a few finger foods available from 6pm to 8pm. We missed this as were out everyday but that's a good amentity, feels like all Club concept (though the range of champagn and finger foods were not much as they are free).Complimentary Internet throughout the hotel including guestrooms was fast enough. Rooms are super spacious for Tokyo or any other big cities. Our rooms were at least 50sqm with a huge bath-tub that can easily fits 2 persons. (Just that there was no bath salt or bath gel, only shower gel available). The shower including the rain shower head were strong and great. The view to the city from our rooms, 49th & 50th floors was amazing. The remote control for all lights and blind curtain on the bedside was convenient. There's walk-in closet on the left of the room door. There's also complimentary non-alcoholic beverages incl. bottled water, soft drinks, fruit juice, chocolate bar and snacks in the minibar which is refurnished daily. This was not advised upon check-in but we found out by reading the Directory book in the rooms. Alcoholic drinks are avaialble but of course chargeable. There's also Nespesso machine/capsules as well as tea making facility.Buffet breakfast at Andaz Tavern on 51st floor, same floor with the lobby, was good and pricey (around SGD50 per person/day). Breakfast selection didn't change during our stay of 4 nights. Perhaps they should change for more variety.Overall, it is recommendable to business guests.

Every item and design feature was simple yet incomparable to your standard hotel. The food is superb. The breakfast assortment was carefully chosen and I say without hesitation the best in the world. The best hotel pool I have ever swum in. The true test of service is handling a problem. On this the Andaz went above and beyond to leave us feeling truly looked after.

My wife and I take one and two day vacations in all of Tokyo's luxury hotels, over the past 20 years. We have been surprised, again and again, at the inability of brand name fame to correlate with the fun-ness of our stay experience. ANDAZ good points:1) better than two Baldrige Awards for Quality Ritz Carlton service---Andaz is the only hotel other than Ritz where you can order food from any restaurant IN any restaurant--the waitress told me sake was not available in the Tavern BUT she would run upstairs to the rooftop bar and get it for me "wait a minute please--she was back on 104 seconds by my watch!). 2) every room, seat, public space is a work of art---blows away EVERY other hotel in Japan and perhaps only matched by the new Ritz Carlton Hong Kong3) the background jazz was so good I kept getting little pieces of paper from the staff with the name and song and album of the current song---for my collection via iTunes--also GREAT SPEAKERS everywhere and PERFECT VOLUME so conversation is easy everywhere, even in the crowded bars at night4) handling air conditioning in summer in Japan HURTS WOMEN -----BUT my wife instantly got a shawl and hot tea, complimentary, in every lounge, bar, restaurant when too cool5) my milk allergy was somehow communicated to all places instantly so everyone arranged for it without being asked, reminding me when milk-less or milk-substitute items appeared6) ALL THE LITTLE THINGS ARE DESIGN SUPERBLY---no other Tokyo Hotel does anything small well--the Andaz toilet door in rooms slides soundlessly closed at night not disturbing sleep by your partner, the default razor has five blades not cheap two, the entryway is citrus perfumed, free drinks were offered both of us as we checked in--taking a total of 22 seconds and GETTING A ROOM FREE TO USE 3 hours before out assigned check in time without comment complaint or fee 7) great rooms--huge, superbly designed 8) giant tables in all rooms restaurants lounges inviting laptop use, paper spreads, drinks and foods without having to shift things around or catch things falling off edges 9) TERRIFIC BENTO for 3,300 yen--absolutely every bite superb (been in Japan 20+ years so I KNOW what Japanese superb is), TERRIFIC in room DINNER for two--for under 15,000 yen---every bite was great and bigger servings than I imagined better seasoned---not dull but healthy. 8) THE BEST SPA, GYM, POOL, 3 HUGE HOT SPRING TYPE JACUZZIS in Tokyo---no comparison with others----MUCH MUCH BETTER equipment, views, conditions, beauty, heat, options, service---after ONE visit we are seriously considering becoming members (member fees are NOT high) 9) Hotel general manager greeted us morning of second day inviting comments on "how we can serve you better next time"---the right approach indeed My only complaint---coffee quality---NO LUXURY HOTEL in Chicago, Tokyo, Boston, Manhattan---has managed in the last 20 years to serve decent non-over-roasted coffee. The Cafe Nire since 1953 in Shinjuku could teach them all but no one learns---we tried to teach the Ritz Carlton for years but failed. With non-over-roasted coffees the Andaz would be flawless.The air quality in rooms was flawless (the only hotel I can say that about in Tokyo) and the sheets and matress firmness was perfect for me (the only hotel I can say anything near that about in Tokyo). You may be different but I slept WONDERFULLY at the Andaz--combination of perfect air, no fiddling with thermostats and humidifiers, and perfect bedding. As it is---this hotel is, for right now---THE ONLY GREAT HOTEL IN TOKYO. It made me enjoy being alive more--made my wife smile and laugh more, made us talk too long and too often to hotel staff, made us enjoy Tokyo living more, eating more, swimming more, hot spas more. It MADE LIFE QUITE GENERALLY BETTER both while we were there and now afterwards. THERE are no competitor hotels to this one inTokyo--we have stayed at them all save the Shangri La and this one is TOPS at present.

The hotel was only less than a month old when I stayed at Andaz in Toranomon Hills for two nights, so the room was in perfect condition. I particularly like the modern aesthetic of the entire hotel—minimal decor with mostly wood paneling and furniture—but what stands out is the careful attention of the staff. They are not overbearing with their care but are quick to respond when you seem in need of assistance. The lounge/reception of Andaz Tokyo offers drinks (wine at 6pm!) and snacks (the macha and chocolate cookies are good!) The room has a great view of Tokyo and a wonderful bath, too—two things I am keen about. When it comes to location, we didn't leave the premises much (it was a business trip) except when we had to go to Ginza, which was a few minutes away. The building has restaurants and cafés on the first few floors so dining options are varied; there is also a restaurant/bar right by the hotel lounge, which has good fried chicken (only thing I ordered, unfortunately). The chef of the hotel created the menu for our business event, and it was above average. Dessert was stellar. If that's a glimpse of what he serves at the restaurant, then it wouldn't be disappointing. Overall, it was a great stay.

I visited the new Andaz in Toranomon in the beginning of august. First of all it is quite a nice building and easily recognized. In my opinion it is nice located an within walking distance from the Toranomon station on the Ginza line (Exit1 probably the nearest to the hotel). The hotel itself is excellent, the rooms are big enough and very nice designed. I especially liked the big wooden desk and the rainfall shower. We were 3 people in a room, so we got an extra bed. The extra bed was quite comfortable (like the normal beds) but used up quite some space. So I would say the room is quite spacious for 2people, 3 feels a bit cramped (but still OK). The lounge has a nice sitting area with free wine from 6-8pm! The view from the room was spectacular (we had the west view). I "guess" in clearer month you might see Fuji-san, but we were not lucky enough. Though I wished I would have gotten a Tokyo Tower View room. The service is very good, but still needs some time to get to the Park Hyatt standard. Dont get me wrong, it was very good service but there is still some things to make better. All in all I can only recommend the hotel. It is in my opinion almost on the level of the famous Park Hyatt Tokyo, but it feels a little less "stiff". I would like to come again!

I was surprised that the last shuttle bus from Haneda airport to Andaz was two thirty in the afternoon. However Haneda is not far from Toranomon Hill, there are other nearby hotels where shuttle buses stop more regularly. I took a taxi from one of these hotels to reach Andaz. Going back, it took just over forty minutes and 7000 yen to reach Haneda.The Bell person led to a side entrance, walked across elongated hall with mirrored columns, colourful artworks on front side and series of empty sitting areas on another side. The tall first lift lobby was reached through a narrow 'light' corridor. Celebrating school of fish paper artwork welcomes the guests in the lift car. This was my first experience at Andaz. I do like the idea that guests are checked in within a comfortable living room, it is a simple welcoming gesture yet personalised. There are three private recesses with sofas and a spacious space with two large wooden tables + soft table lamps of 'washi' paper, in early evenings guests are served wine here. My mind noted a gentle scent of perfume at second lift lobby, the charming receptionists from different countries, a sculptural chair at centre, the intricate cut wooden pattern on upper wall over and behind the island reception counter, beyond was Andaz Tavern with aerial wooden sculpture by Charlie Winney. The guest room lift lobby is box like of walnut veneer leading two directions by white panellised corridors with floor level lighting following Japanese architecture of being discreet. The focal point ones sees is a light gold bronze panel of room signage. The guest room foyer feels like a 'genkan' in Japanese homes with two sliding doors to closet and bathroom + a folding brown leather stool so one can take off the shoes. Across there is a blue + white bar unit, a safe drawer unit, and a wooden shelf with its solitary bowl + small black white print. The living sleeping area is flooded by afternoon light, in my case, I could see the Tokyo Tower. In front of these windows, there is a large wooden table with two orange red leather arm chairs to dine and work. The low bed with matching orange red leather bed head + interesting bed side tables, the panellised walls + the same 'washi' paper wall lamp and olive plain carpet make the interpretation of a Japanese (living) room. The blue colour surprises. The use of mirror and granite stone tiles, walnut laminate panels and an oval clay artwork complete o-furo style bath shower room. One almost wishes for a real wooden tub.I enjoyed the Japanese breakfast of miso grilled cod with pickled white spring onion, the Rooftop Bar made a delicious campari orange juice while outside Tokyo was pouring rain. Sitting at high table on blue and white woven cane chair eating Nippon Burger at Bebu and a morning coffee of fruit tartlet at Pastry Shop with its black and mirror graphic sliding doors made the experience. One evening I went to the Tavern for dinner, it was full and I was offered a table at the Lounge instead. The band was playing, the same 'washi' paper wall lamps glowing in this tall space, it would have been great to be seated along the window banquets which were empty instead of facing a glass fire place. Toranomon station is ten minutes walk, down the block one can climb up the steeped steps of Atago Jinja Buddhist Shrine. On one street corner there is a period furniture shop selling interesting pieces. On the other direction, there is also a kimono shop as well two or three restaurants in its original wooden buildings with quaint entrances. On the podium level to office tower, there are more restaurants to choose from as well a grass hill to people watch.The experience of spontaneous hospitality within a sophisticated interior on a local setting, Andaz makes a great stay in Tokyo.

I had a wonderful time staying at the Andaz. After a busy day out and about in Tokyo coming back to this hotel was a calming and soothing experience. The staff were delightful, helpful without being obtrusive.Small touches such as the complimentary glass of wine after 6pm in the lobby was lovely. The rooms were absolutely brilliant , spacious and luxurious with an incredible view. The spa was beautiful - we went every evening. Overall I highly recommend this hotel.

My initial arrival experience wasn't great. Finding the hotel entrance was not an easy task for first timers, arriving on a crowded reception area filled with people waiting to be seated at the restaurant was not a welcoming experience. BUT.... all seems to go away when I was whisked into the room after a 10 minute wait (which seemed like a looong time). The room is gorgeous! The design is impeccable, the lighting design is perfect and the details beautiful. The photos do not do the room justice, as the space is a lot more handsome.Food in Tavern is not bad, but not amazing. Drink prices are hard to swallow, even for Tokyo standard.Service is not perfect yet, but give it time. I'd go back in a heartbeat when back in Tokyo. I heart Andaz Tokyo.

Am a diamond member of Hyatt. This hotel should not be even in operation. While rooms / interior / pool is nice, the service is terrible. Try ordering tea at breakfast and if it arrives within 10 minutes consider yourself lucky! Staff has poor English understanding. We made several restaurant reservations on advance up find on arrival no information packet ready or maps on location! Unlike Park Hyatt Tokyo or Grand Hyayt Ropponggi, where they give you a package of full restaurant details, Andaz Tokyo forgot what places they even booked for us! After requesting these the first day, they were still not done. When questioned why, the Andaz Host said they didn't have the time! Ridiculous! Then on the second day, we came back at 3pm to find room not even cleaned! I asked to speak to the General Manager, unavailable! Director of rooms was completely useless and said sorry we could not live up to your standards! Is having my room done by 3pm difficult? Do the management even have experience in running a 5 star hotel or do they even care? On checkout day, took over 30 mins to settle my bill as complete chaos! General Manager and director of rooms both in Andaz Lounge / lobby area, did absolutely nothing in looking after guests, these two management people complete useless as just wander around "looking busy." All in all will never return and a huge disappointment!

A charming diner one month after the grand opening. The setting is great, scenic view, elegant local tableware. The cuisine is delicious, refined, creative, opening new taste association. The waiter has stories to say, explaining for instance where this specific balsamic vinegar is produced following an original and unique natural process.And the ambiance is relaxed and elegant. One of the place to be in Tokyo.

Service was nice, food tasted good, but then the diarrhea.. My date and I both had horrible food poisoning from this place. Ughh..Rooftop bar was also a disappointment, they could have done so much more with the space and the service was slow.

Summary:There are a lot of positives to take away from the Andaz Toranomon Hills - The rooms and Spa are amazing, and the views are breathtaking. The interior of the hotel is like a museum, with art works throughout the establishment. The Staff are extremely attentive, and are generally eager and keen to please and make your experience as personal as possible. However, it became apparent that staff did have issues with English, particularly at check-in, and the Rooftop Bar. Also staff did not have much local knowledge of the surrounding area, and there is no limousine bus that takes you directly to either Narita or Haneda airports. I have stayed in a number of Andaz hotels globally, so was heartened to discover the newest Andaz hotel would open in Tokyo, coinciding with my trip there. As a Platinum GP member, I chose the hotel stay rate for platinum members, which did not include their free breakfast promotion. The hotel is difficult to get to from the Ginza line at Toranomon station. Take Exit 1 or 7 if you are travelling by the Ginza line, and then look up - it is a short stroll to Toranomon Hills. The entrance to the hotel is around the block, past the taxi drop-off point. I would suggest getting a taxi to the hotel from Shimbashi or Toranomon stations if you have heavy luggage, or are worried about language difficulties. I was left standing around to check-in, asking a number of staff how to check-in when I arrived. Check-in was done standing at the reception desk, and no welcome drink was offered when I checked-in. When I asked where the in-house drinks were in the evenings (5-7pm) I was told they were upstairs in the rooftop bar, which opened at 5pm. This is not true, and free wine is served in the lounge. Visited the Rooftop Bar anyway - the view is very good, but the staff appeared hesitant to serve you due to language inability. It is also extremely expensive, with 2 draft beers and 2 glasses of white wine costing almost Yen10,000 (US$100).The key attraction for the Andaz I believe is the room and the view. The room was stunning - on the 50th floor (1 floor below the reception area), very well furnished, and amazingly quiet. The wall to ceiling windows offer breathtaking views, and the full-length sofa next to the window allows you to sit back and enjoy the view with the complementary non-alcoholic drinks from the mini-bar. The shower has a raindrop as well as a hand-held showerhead, and the round bath is deep and perfect for 2 people. The window also has black-out shades which render the room completely dark - perfect if ambient light is annoying. The Spa and fitness centres are also worth visiting. With extremely attentive staff willing to help you with Spa appointments and how to use fitness equipment, there were a number of plunge baths available to help relieve any stress evident. I had breakfast at the Andaz Tavern restaurant - I admit I was taken back by the lack of selection offered, and the limited choices available. I have stayed at Hyatt Places with more breakfast selections than the Andaz Toranomon Hills. I believe this might be due to the hotel's promotion of offering free breakfast. However, I was paying, and to pay almost Yen10,000 for two people for a small bircher museli and a juice, with a side of passionfruit each, seemed a bit excessive. At check-out, trying to get back to the airport, I was informed that the limousine bus does not stop at the Andaz. I was told to go to the Okura Hotel nearby, but informed that the last bus left at 3pm (I needed a 4pm bus). I instead traveled to the nearby Grand Hyatt Roppongi Hills to get the Limousine bus. You can probably imagine my surprise when I discovered the bus pulling into the Hotel Okura.... I think the staff need to improve their transportation and local area knowledge, but this will probably come in time.In all, I would probably recommend the Andaz Toranomon Hills as a perfect place for businessmen to stay, given the limited shopping and entertainment areas nearby. It is also perfect for a romantic getaway - however be prepared to pay for the view, particularly in the restaurant and rooftop Bar.

Checked in for my first visit thus evening. To the train to narita and a taxi to the hotel. Hotel is in a quite location. Views are fantastic and the room are pretty nine. I have not tried the food or the pool yet. My room is on the 48th with a view of the palace. Only surprising part. They sat free non-alcoholic beverages on your mini room but you are only allowed to ask for one replacement per day. Mine had coke, diet and water. So If I drank them, I could ask for one on each day for the next three days. Very strange!

We stayed in the first week of this hotel's opening. Whilst it was a little hard to find the place on foot, it was worth it. The casual check in where you sit in lounges and are served a beverage whilst a "host" comes to you would have to be the best check in process yet. The rooms start on the 47th - 50th floor of this building. Great views.The rooms themselves are amazing. The bathroom is the size of a small apartment, where you can lock off parts for the bathroom, the dressing room, etc. The bath is a small pool!The timber desks were a beautiful touch and the floor to ceiling glass opens up the entire room to a gorgeous view no matter where you are. And block out electric blinds for sleeping!At best it is a 5 min walk from the closest metro, but there seems to be a lot of stuff opening up around. It was good to look out at the heart of Tokyo without having to be in the centre of the craziness that is the heart of Tokyo.
